HEADLINE: Is Downsizing a Myth? Ask the Downsized

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Downsizing Myth" (Op-Ed, March 25): 
 H. Erich Heinemann says the American economy is "upsizing" because the number of civilian workers has risen by eight million since March 1991 and half the new jobs can be classified as managerial or professional.
Sounds great, but it's not true.
Growth in employment since March 1991 is only 7.1 million jobs, well below the 10 million to 12 million gain that occurred after the previous two recessions. Manufacturing employment is still 172,000 below the March 1991 level.
In fact, 40 percent of the jobs created since 1991 are in low-wage industries, largely in the service sector, paying an average of $7.47 an hour -- just about the poverty level for a family of four.
A manager at McDonald's may earn only $20,000 a year. But under Mr. Heinemann's analysis, the job is still managerial, and that's supposed to be good news.
Tell that to a middle-aged, downsized AT&T manager whose two kids were hoping to go to college.
Commerce Department statistics show that while wages may have risen 18 percent since 1989, prices have risen 22 percent and business profits 64 percent.
Real earnings for workers have declined 12 percent since 1979.
During the same period, productivity increased 24 percent. And so has executive compensation, by 360 percent since 1980.
Mr. Heinemann acknowledges that deep anxiety exists and that the economy's transitions are painful. But he calls only for more investment and productivity to spur growth.
What about greater fairness? What about shared sacrifices and shared rewards? What about economic and social justice?
That's what the 1996 elections also should be about.
 
JACK SHEINKMAN
President
Americans for Democratic Action
Washington, March 25, 1996

HEADLINE: Don't Finagle a Way To Build Yankee Park

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Creating a sports authority to finance a new ball park for the New York Yankees (news article, March 28) would only be a smokescreen to insulate Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki from the politically unjustifiable decision to ask taxpayers to pay for an $800 million stadium for George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner. 
 The credit of the city and state would still be needed to raise the money for the stadium.
It would be fiscally irresponsible to commit nearly $1 billion on a single ball park when the city and state face huge budget shortfalls. Even under the best circumstances, it would be risky to finance a new stadium. Stadiums do not cover their fixed and operating costs and do not add significant new revenues to the city's economy, and sports teams usually have fewer than 100 full-time employees. And most New Yorkers could not afford the increased ticket prices.
New York would remain a "major league" city with or without the Yankees. The city would be better off fixing deteriorating schools or restoring quality service to the subways.
 
FRANZ S. LEICHTER
Senator, 30th District
Albany, March 28, 1996

HEADLINE: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a nine-day cash management bill. On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction a 52-week bill.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5 percent and the six-month issue was at 4.98 percent. In when-issued trading, the 52-week bill was offered at a price to yield 5.10 percent.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: DOLE'S COURSE;
Senator Lets Experience Guide Policy on Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Although Senator Bob Dole avoids the kind of detailed economic policy debates that President Clinton is known to relish, the all-but-official Republican Presidential nominee nonetheless has a loose grouping of economic advisers who are helping to shape his views and sharpen his message.
And they seem likely to play an increasingly important role as Mr. Dole's Presidential campaign develops its economic strategy and formulates more specific positions on issues like how to promote greater growth and end the long stagnation in average wages. 
 Reflecting the Kansas Senator's background and political instincts, the team is generally composed of Washington insiders, including Republican Senators and a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, and it hews to mainstream conservative economic thought. But it is also sprinkled with real-world experience, which Mr. Dole values far more than graduate degrees, aides said.
The team's job, several members said, will be to take the legislative agenda that will provide the framework for Mr. Dole's campaign -- balancing the budget, cutting taxes and reducing regulations -- and insure that its details will have the desired effect in the real world while also selling its merits to voters.
Mr. Dole frequently relies for economic advice on Senate colleagues like Robert F. Bennett of Utah, a wealthy entrepreneur serving his first term; Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, and Connie Mack of Florida, a former banker who as chairman of the Joint Economic Committee in Congress has taken a lead role in attacking the Administration's economic record.
The only professional economist to have Mr. Dole's ear is Wayne D. Angell, a fellow Kansan who was appointed to a seat on the Federal Reserve in 1985 by President Ronald Reagan with strong backing from Mr. Dole. Mr. Angell, who was a farmer, a small-town banker and a state legislator before serving on the board, is now chief economist at Bear Stearns, the Wall Street brokerage firm.
Mr. Dole also relies on a small cadre of current and former aides. Most notable is his chief of staff in the Senate, Sheila P. Burke, a former nurse who received a master's degree in public administration from Harvard. Another is Robert E. Lighthizer, who was an aide to Mr. Dole on the Senate Finance Committee, served as a deputy to the United States trade representative and now, as a Washington trade lawyer, is treasurer of the Dole campaign.
"I see Dole putting together a team that will agree with him in his overall vision, which is to unleash the inherent powers in the economy by cutting regulations, simplifying the tax structure and putting more trust and opportunity in the hands of ordinary Americans, and then letting that team work out the details and come back to him with proposals," Senator Bennett said. "Then the decision will be made on instinct, and that's what has always attracted me to Dole -- his instincts.'
Many of the advisers have their own areas of expertise and their own agendas.
Mr. Dole, by all accounts, relies heavily on Mr. Bennett to provide him with perspective on how legislation would affect business people, especially entrepreneurs. Before being elected to the Senate, Mr. Bennett built a company in Utah called Franklin Quest, which produces day planners and organizers and now employs 2,700 people. He sold his stake in the company before his election in 1992.
"The net growth in jobs is going to come out of the entrepreneurial side of the economy," Mr. Bennett said.
Mr. Dole often speaks to Mr. Angell about tax issues and the economy's performance. And Senator Mack not only compiles critiques of Mr. Clinton's economic record but also has a strong interest in monetary policy and in keeping the Federal Reserve focused on fighting inflation.
Senator Dole will frequently ask one or more of his advisers to look at a particular issue and provide him with a brief rundown on the economic and political implications of it. He has been happy to contrast his style of economic decision-making and the kinds of people he relies on with those of Mr. Clinton.
"Many top Clinton Administration officials, including the President himself, claim degrees from the world's most prestigious universities," Senator Dole, who graduated from Washburn Municipal University in Topeka, said in a speech last fall. "But in their graduate programs and policy schools, they seem to have learned everything about our economy except what really makes it go -- the hard work, creativity and idealism of a free people."
To his political opponents in the New Hampshire primary last month, Mr. Dole clearly displayed a lack of interest in economic policy when he told workers at an electronics factory, "I didn't realize that jobs and trade and what makes America work would become a big issue in the last days of this campaign."
Even some of his supporters acknowledge that the Senator has had difficulty finding his voice in talking to voters regarding their concerns about job security and the economy's long-term health.
But they said it would be a mistake to conclude that Mr. Dole does not have a grasp of or interest in economic policy. Indeed, they said, as a former chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and as the Senate majority leader at a time when balancing the budget has topped the political agenda, he is well versed in the details of tax and economic policy and has a good grounding in how legislation works in the real world.
"The view of Dole that he's not interested or too political is not justified," Mr. Angell said. "If he is not interested in economic ideas, how is it that he has always been a reliable supporter of opening the world to freer trade when there is always pressure from special interest groups that want to close off imports."
Instead of deliberating on the subtleties of policy, advisers said, Mr. Dole wants to get straight to deciding how enactment of a policy will harm or benefit those who would be affected.
"You have to learn to come to the point very quickly, because if you don't, his attention will wander to other topics," Senator Bennett said. "Dole will not sit down and have a discussion about the intricacies of movements in the discount rate by the Fed, but he is much more interested in the impact of Federal economic decisions in the real world of commerce, Main Street as well as Wall Street."

HEADLINE: Tenants' Choice: Their Dog or Their Home;
Pet Owners Face Eviction in New Rule by Connecticut Housing Project

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., March 25

 BODY:
In a housing project where gangs deal drugs and the playgrounds are sprinkled with shattered glass, the risk posed by Teddie, a 3-year-old Pomeranian the size of a football, might not seem to be grounds for eviction.
"He's scared of a knock on the door," Nick Nation, his 15-year-old owner, said. 
 But to the New London Housing Authority, there is no difference between a Pomeranian and a pit bull. Last week, all dogs were ordered out of the Briarcliff and Bates Woods projects by May 31 or their owners would be evicted. According to the housing authority, tenants are being terrorized by packs of vicious dogs that roam the streets and occasionally attack children.
"I don't think of this as banning dogs," Frederick L. Wallace, the authority's executive director, said. "I see it as liberating people."
The issue has emerged here as housing authorities around the nation are cracking down on pets. In Allegheny County, Pa., last October, after a court battle that went to the State Supreme Court, the local housing authority demanded that tenants part with not only dogs and cats, but also chameleons, goldfish and gerbils. Since July, the San Francisco Housing Authority, plagued by what some consider the worst pit bull problem of any public housing in the nation, has evicted about 50 residents for keeping dogs.
And in New York City, Ruben Franco, the housing authority's chairman, provoked an uproar last year when he sent letters to 600,000 tenants saying: "Do not jeopardize the roof over your head. If you have a dog, get rid of it." Only after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who owns a yellow Labrador retriever, weighed in was the policy narrowed to animals that residents complained about as threats to health or safety.
Animals are not allowed in Federally financed housing projects, unless the owner is elderly or disabled, but the law is often disregarded. Still, the issue has become more pressing in recent years with the growing popularity of pit bulls and a host of well-publicized incidents in which these dogs have mauled small children.
The two New London projects, which comprise 300 brick two-story townhouse apartments, receive no Federal money and are financed by state and local governments. They are intended for the working poor, charging $260 monthly to families for a two-bedroom apartment.
For years, these projects have allowed dogs, as long as they were insured and licensed by the city and had the proper shots. Recently the animals have met growing opposition from tenants, and in June, the projects banned any new dogs and prohibited pit bulls, Rottweilers and Doberman pinschers.
"The policy was impossible to enforce," Mr. Wallace, the housing director, said. "You'd see a dog wandering in the street and you didn't know whether it was legal or illegal." He recalled questioning one owner about a dog that looked to Mr. Wallace to be a Rottweiler and being told that it was part German shepherd.
Over the last five months, dogs have bitten at least three people, including a 5-year-old girl on roller skates, and Mr. Wallace said that when he took the job in December, one of the first things that tenant groups urged him to do was get rid of the dogs. Although no exact count has been made of dogs in the projects, Mr. Wallace said that it was easily more than 30.
"One night I came home from bingo and had to sit in my car for a half-hour because of these big dogs in front of my house," Iris Gilbert, a tenant, said.
On Friday afternoon, as Mr. Wallace toured the grounds, another tenant, Eleanor Tate, 53, an advocate in a Head Start program, gave him a thumbs-up sign as she drove by. "I step in dog feces all the time," she said. "Why say little Fluffy can stay, but a Doberman can't? A dog is a dog."
But the dog owners, who are raising money to hire a lawyer, contend that all dogs are not alike and that a dog is only as good as its owner.
Pedro Morocho, a 28-year-old unemployed laborer, walked his yellow Labrador retriever, Nestor, through some paces for visitors the other day. "Dame la mano," he told the dog in Spanish, and Nestor wagged his tail, gave Mr. Morocho a paw and then licked his face. A few minutes later, Nestor was distracted by his tail and began enthusiastically spinning in circles as he tried to catch it.
When encouraged to pose for a picture, the dog kept trying to kiss the photographer.
"What are we supposed to do, kill him?" Mr. Morocho said glumly, noting that he and his wife were looking for another apartment but were not sure where they could find one for so little money.
"Why don't they just take the bad dogs?" he asked.
The problem is that "bad" may be in the eye of the beholder. At first glance, another dog in the projects, a lean German shepherd named Blitz with a bark as loud as a howitzer, might be considered bad. He lives behind a door with the sign "Warning, Property Protected by Guard Dog."
Blitz, a graduate of a $600 guard-dog training program, answers only to commands in German. When introduced to visitors recently, he strained at his leash and bared his teeth. "Platz," his owner, Tina Chappell, said, and the dog sat.
But Ms. Chappell, 29, considers Blitz, who has never bitten anyone and never goes out without her, a hero. The run-down Briarcliff project, which is strewn with litter and pocked with broken windows and abandoned apartments, is troubled by crime. A murder took place there a year or so ago, and burglaries are not uncommon.
One night, Ms. Chappell said, someone tried to force his way into her apartment, and Blitz barked and "hit the door so hard" that no sane person would have dreamed of entering. When she leaves late at night to work the graveyard shift at a Dunkin' Donuts, she feels that her two children are safe because of the dog, she said, echoing a sentiment voiced by other dog owners.
"I cleared it with the authority five years ago before I got him," Ms. Chappell said. "Now it's like a landlord saying you can't have your kids. My son and daughter are in tears."
Others say the ban is outright discrimination. "What about the cats?" a longtime tenant said.
Mr. Wallace, the housing director, who has owned some big dogs in his life, said that he is not anti-dog, but a pragmatist. It is "a privilege to live in public housing," he said, and sometimes people have to "sacrifice some freedom for the greater good."
The best protection is not dogs, but getting to know your neighbors and establishing block watches, Mr. Wallace added. He has started a dog adoption program to try to avoid having any of the pets put to sleep and to find good homes for them.
Are cats next?
"They don't bother me," Mr. Wallace said. "They're nice. They eat mice. They don't bite kids."

HEADLINE: Wood Pulp Prices Off 40% Since Autumn

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 31

 BODY:
The prices of North American wood pulp have fallen 40 percent since last fall, one of the sharpest price reversals in the history of the industry, and consumers of many paper products, from tissues and paper towels to stationery and envelopes, are expected to find lower prices.
Surging inventories and slower growth in paper consumption worldwide are behind the price cuts, which have dropped the price of northern bleached softwood kraft pulp, a bellwether grade, from $985 a metric ton in November to $575 in mid-March, the lowest level since 1991. The decline, however, followed big increases over the last several years. 
 "I would think there would be even more slippage as producers compete on price," said Harold Cody, director of a forecasting service for Pulp and Paper magazine, a trade journal. Pulp is made from wood chips and other residue at lumber mills.
Mr. Cody estimated that prices of some grades of printing papers at the wholesale level were down 20 to 30 percent. Linerboard, which is used for boxes and cartons, has been under similar pressure.
The Procter & Gamble Company said last week that it was cutting list prices for its facial tissues, bath tissues and paper towels by 4.8 to 8.6 percent, citing the lower pulp prices.
Competitors are expected to make comparable cuts.
Though many newsprint producers have their own integrated pulp mills and do not buy pulp on the open market, the weakness in pulp prices has been a factor in their recent decisions to cancel price increases for newsprint.
Canada is the world's largest supplier of pulp. In the first two months of this year, shipments fell 18 percent, according to the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association.
As producers increased prices in 1995, pulp on hand at mills in Canada, the United States and the Nordic countries, the principal supply points, shot up to 2 million tons from 1.1 million, the fastest rise in inventory levels since the mid-1970's.
Struggling to get inventories down to more manageable levels, North American mills have announced extensive shutdowns. MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., a giant producer in British Columbia, is closing its lumber and sawmill operations until May 4, affecting 1,250 workers.
Crestbrook Forest Industries, Slocan Forest Products and Repap Enterprises are among other Canadian companies that have announced temporary shutdowns. Georgia-Pacific idled 14 lumber mills from Maine to Arkansas in the last two weeks of December.
After price weakness and the severe winter, which has also affected bottom lines, analysts expect that first-quarter earnings of many paper companies will take a dive.
"In the first quarter we'll see virtually every company with far lower earnings and further deterioration in the second quarter based on the sharp drop that's already occurred in pricing," said Mark Rogers, paper industry analyst for Prudential Securities in New York.
Yet some analysts expect a turnaround later this year. Patricia Mohr, a vice president of economics at the Toronto headquarters of the Bank of Nova Scotia, pointed to the "relatively favorable" underlying demand for most paper products. "This is a big inventory correction but it will come to an end over the next few months," she predicted.
And Sam Magid, an analyst with Salman Partners of Vancouver, British Columbia, said that as mills go through temporary shutdowns to reduce pulp, they also reduce supplies of lumber, a commodity that has recently had rising prices. Since the fourth quarter, the producer price of a bellwether grade of two-by-fours has risen to $295 for 1,000 board feet from $244. "The death of the pulp market," Mr. Magid said, "brings with it breaths of life to the lumber market."

HEADLINE: Reviews/Fashion;
Making an Elegant U-Turn Toward Indulgence

BYLINE: By By AMY M. SPINDLER 

 BODY:
Robert Hughes, in his book of essays on art, "Nothing if Not Critical," takes this swipe at those who would measure the art market in decades: "The inflation of the market, the victory of promotion over connoisseurship, the manufacture of art-related glamour, the poverty of art training, the embattled state of museums -- these will not vanish, as at the touch of a wand, now that 1990 is here."
Substitute fashion for art and stores for museums and that pretty much sums up fashion's sluggishness in recovering from 1980's excess. There has been no wand for fashion, either. But this is the first season in a while in which -- in New York, the most commercial of fashion's capitals -- some designers have begun to embrace connoisseurship again. 
 The conservative chic that the boring past year produced offered expensive clothes for women who really didn't like fashion at all. How could anyone who loves fashion take pleasure in the joyless suits and dull sheaths? In Paris, the best example of fashion returning to its creative mission was at Comme des Garcons. In New York, it was certainly at Marc Jacobs, where hints of Bloomsbury, the 20's and the English eccentric were secondary messages; the first love here was the love of getting dressed up, a ritual that for some women will never be part of a dull routine.
Victor Alfaro and Mr. Jacobs both offered caviar clothes this season -- Mr. Alfaro, pure chic richness, and Mr. Jacobs, an elegant, ornate collection full of charm and more than a hint of decadence in the gilded, shiny fabrics and precise cuts.
Though Ghost's clothes were more minimal, its designer, Tanya Sarne, picked up the mood of the weekend, showing in the former American Savings Bank on Union Square, with film crews tucked around the teller's cage and with caviar, toast points and Absolut vodka on every table.
It was another kind of indulgence that drove Betsey Johnson's show, an upbeat tribute to Patti Smith's styles through the years. Nicole Miller, who seemed to have lost confidence in her quirky style last season, was back to off colors, alarming prints and personal take on hip.
Indeed, it was a weekend in which confidence was the key to success. Nowhere was it more winning than at Mr. Jacobs's show, where the designer seemed to have dipped everything in molten gold or silver for a collection that glowed from within. It was an optimistic, heartening vision, from trench coats glazed lightly and worn with a golden leather skirt to velours that glittered to tweeds that sparkled to the shimmering panne velvet dresses that closed the show. There were sweet indulgences: a hand-embroidered candy-colored camisole beneath a double-faced cashmere coat with feather trim and a platinum leather coat over a red-and-brown damask 1920's-style dress.
Mr. Jacobs is one of fashion's most prescient designers. This collection was the best news the industry could possibly receive, a sign of heady hedonism to come.
It would have been possible over the last few years to have underestimated Mr. Alfaro as a guy who makes nice dresses. As Lawrence of Arabia once said, "Nothing is written."
With a combination of sheer will, smart politics and an enviable ability to figure out the needs of such coveted clients as those recently well-married Miller sisters, Mr. Alfaro has made himself into much, much more than a dress designer. There are many designers as talented as Mr. Alfaro. But without his other qualities, they couldn't possibly expect to be where he was on Saturday, working with some of the most sumptuous fabrics this season and with impressive front-row guests, including the fellow Latin American Oscar de la Renta.
In the deepest ink blue, olive, burgundy and camel, Mr. Alfaro's mink-trimmed camel-hair jackets, belted cashmere cardigans, thick leather jackets with mink collars, open-weave crocheted cardigans and slim belted suits offered fresh, clean luxury, a step above conservative chic.
Mr. Alfaro seems to have determined that he will dress the young ladies who lunch. And what is clear is that, if Mr. Alfaro determines something, he gets it.
There is perhaps no designer more underestimated than Ms. Johnson, who has more life, youth and energy in her shows than there are in the average mosh pit. This season, she gave tribute to Patti Smith's fashion, with each segment tailored to landmarks in the rocker's life: the Chelsea Hotel, Max's Kansas City, the Kitchen, CBGB, the Factory, the Village Gate and Lady Astor's. With all the models in black Patti Smith wigs, Ms. Johnson showed baby doll and earth mother, monastic and metal and what she called "lava-lamp blue minithong dress" and "chlorine blue Buddha jeans and fur kimono."
It was all to the tunes of "People Have the Power," "Dancing Barefoot" and "So You Want to Be a Rock 'n' Roll Star," ending with Ultra, a new all-black collection in jersey that will be more expensive than the main Betsey Johnson line. It seems time for Ms. Johnson to seize her own star status.
While plying the audience with caviar and salmon, Ms. Sarne showed the least decadent-looking clothes of the group, many in blinding white. There were minimalist tunics slashed up the front, hooded dresses, lean mandarin collar suits with tiny hooks up the front and pretty long bias-cut dresses. She also played with tweeds for the first time, in salt-and-pepper stretch fabrics.
And Ms. Miller, who took her minimalism a bit too far last season, bounced back with computer-generated prints, hexagonal pieced color-blocked sheath dresses and cool new Sergeant Pepper jackets that snapped up the front. Ghost and Ms. Miller both offer fashion for a fair price, and it is the spirit of their shows that make them work on the runway in a pricey world that excludes far too many women.

Salt-and-pepper tweed stretch top and trousers at Ghost; Nicole Miller's brown wool sweater, brown-and-aqua skirt and brown faux leather jacket. (Photographs by Corina Lecca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Don't Capsize the U.N.

 BODY:
The United Nations is in financial straits that are deep, dangerous and only partly deserved. As of the beginning of this year, half its members had not paid last year's dues in full, with the United States leading the pack. The deadbeat total has swelled to $3.1 billion. According to Joseph Connor, the Under Secretary General for Administration, the U.N. faces a cash crisis that could curtail or even shut down its operations by November.
The U.N. is out of fashion these days, and alarms about its financial problems have been raised before. But this time the crisis is acute. While the organization still needs much reform, it should not be allowed to wither for lack of money. 
 In past years, the U.N. kept afloat by borrowing from separate peacekeeping accounts to cover shortfalls in its $1.3 billion operating budget. But a reduction in peacekeeping has eliminated this option. America's debt, which represents a default on a treaty obligation, is an inexcusable embarrassment. Washington owes $699 million for this year's regular budget and $909 million for peacekeeping operations. No country has a worse record.
Americans rightly ask whether the U.N. has done its share to cut costs. Mr. Connor, who has applied rigorous American accounting standards to U.N. bookkeeping, maintains that financial management demands by Congress have been met. The U.N. budget has not been increased since 1994. A new inspector general, Germany's Karl Paschke, is aggressively investigating waste and fraud.
Some abuses persist. Senior echelons of the U.N. are clogged with patronage appointees. Trade, trusteeship and development agencies overlap with other U.N. offices. The American share of the budget needs to be cut to 20 percent from 25 percent.
Over the decades the U.N. has unquestionably helped end wars and preserve the peace in many regions, mediating and monitoring cease-fires. It has helped put human rights, including women's rights, on the diplomatic agenda. Its specialized agencies track epidemics, provide shelter for millions of refugees displaced by war and disasters and perform other indispensable tasks to which little attention is paid or credit accorded.
Congress has agreed to a foreign affairs budget that meets the Administration more than halfway with a five-year plan for paying back dues. It provides $823 million instead of the requested $934 million for dues, and the full $445 million for peacekeeping sought by the White House.
Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina insists in return that Mr. Clinton agree to fold any one of three now-independent Federal agencies dealing with arms control, information and foreign aid into the State Department. It is not a pleasant choice, but Mr. Clinton should settle on one, preferably the Agency for International Development, and end the deadlock with Mr. Helms.
If Washington fails to come up with money solemnly promised by three successive Presidents, not only downsizing but capsizing the U.N., it would be a moral and financial default by the organization's principal founder.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: After 12 Years of Delay, New Snag Clouds Coliseum's Future

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
After 12 years of debate and delay in deciding the fate of the New York Coliseum, a new snag has left the project's future as murky as ever as the city and state continue to haggle over whether to set aside part of any new building for trade shows.
The standoff, between John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, and Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, has pushed the next step in the project past a deadline. That is because both officials had promised to solicit proposals from prospective developers by the end of March. 
 Mr. Dyson insists that the project include convention space. His staff analyzed the benefits of a new convention center on the Columbus Circle site last year, finding that it would generate $30 million a year in taxes for the city and create thousands of jobs.
But Mr. Gargano has rejected the city's plan, saying that "setting aside any part of that property for exhibition space would simply lower its value."
After years of public protest and court challenges since the Coliseum site first went on sale in 1984, one more missed deadline is hardly provoking an outcry from neighborhood groups, who have vowed to fight any proposal they consider too large, or developers, who are eagerly waiting to bid on one of New York City's most valuable real estate parcels.
But the dispute between City Hall and Albany hinges on conflicting agendas for the city's economy, and has thrown the shape and timing of the Coliseum project into greater doubt.
And delaying the project further, critics say, will only add to the huge financial losses that the city, the state and the coliseum's owner, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, have already sustained by keeping the building mothballed or in partial use.
In the background of the dispute is the M.T.A., which proposed last year that the sale of the Coliseum be postponed for a decade or more until Manhattan's weak real estate market recovers. The agency has since reopened the building for trade shows.
In recent months, with both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki hoping that the Coliseum project will be a showpiece of their campaigns to privatize government operations, the M.T.A.'s chairman, E. Virgil Conway, a Pataki appointee, has accepted a back seat in the negotiations while quietly siding with Mr. Gargano.
"Our real estate people feel that some combination of retail and residential development would give us the best return," said John Cunningham, an M.T.A. spokesman. "But the bottom line is we want the highest possible use and, if somebody can come up with something that includes exhibition space, we won't necessarily object."
The disagreement between city and state officials has as much to do with New York City's shifting economic landscape as it does with politics.
If the Coliseum site is offered for sale any time soon, it will be at a time when the economics of real estate development are vastly different than in 1984, when the M.T.A. put the building on the market. Manhattan was beginning a development boom then, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher and builder, won preliminary approval to erect apartment towers on the site that would have filled almost every inch of height and density allowed by the city.
That deal, presided over by Mayor Edward I. Koch, came as the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center was nearing completion, when the Coliseum's exhibition space was considered redundant. But the scale of Mr. Zuckerman's project provoked a storm of protest and lawsuits that ultimately forced him to walk away in 1994.
Although the blocks on the Upper West Side surrounding the Coliseum have since attracted several new projects -- including Donald J. Trump's redevelopment of the Gulf and Western Building into a hotel and apartment building -- most of Manhattan's real estate market is considered too weak to support new construction. That makes it difficult for anyone to predict how much the Coliseum site would fetch.
And executives in the tourism and convention industry, lending some strength to Mr. Dyson's argument for new convention space at the Coliseum site, say that New York has lost ground to cities like Chicago, San Francisco and New Orleans because the Javits Center cannot accommodate enough trade shows and conventions.
Indeed, while the Javits Center has been close to fully booked in recent years, the city's share of the most profitable convention business -- the kind of gatherings that attract out-of-town visitors who stay in hotels -- has dwindled.
According to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, the city attracted 346 out-of-town conventions and trade shows last year, down from 478 in 1994 and 568 in 1993. "It is safe to say we have lost a lot of business opportunities over the decade that the Coliseum has been out of operation," said Steven Morello, executive director of the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
But if that seems to support Mr. Dyson's case, he said, the equation is actually even more complex.
"By itself, the Coliseum would not be the solution," Mr. Morello said, adding that the site was too small for a convention center that could compete with those in other cities. He said a better approach was to expand the Javits Center or find another large site.
Amid the uncertainty about when anything will be built, the M.T.A. has been trying since January to fill the Coliseum with conventions and exhibitions. To enable a development plan to proceed, it says it will take reservations no more than a year in advance but has nonetheless filled much of its calendar this year. The biggest event will be in June, when the Smithsonian Institution's 150th Anniversary Show will fill all four floors.
But even with such business, the M.T.A. said it was collecting far less in fees from exhibitors than the Coliseum did before it was closed in the 1980's. Mr. Cunningham said the agency expected to collect $1.4 million this year, compared with $3 million in 1984, the last year the Coliseum was in full operation.
To make matters worse, he said, the M.T.A. will have to spend $5 million this year to fix the building's leaky roof and complete other long-delayed repairs, making the Coliseum a "money-losing situation."
For now, no one promises any immediate insight into the Coliseum site's long-term future. Mr. Dyson said he hoped, but could not be certain, that the city, the state and the M.T.A. could agree to a joint request for proposals within three months. Mr. Gargano declined to speculate. "I couldn't set a date," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chronology: "CHRONOLOGY: The Coliseum Saga"
 
December 1984 -- The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city reach a deal to sell the New York Coliseum and to use the proceeds -- an estimated $200 million -- to improve the city's transit system.
 
July 1985 -- The M.T.A. chooses Boston Properties, headed by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, to redevelop the Coliseum site. The project is immense: 2.9 million square feet for stores, offices and apartments. So is the sale price: $455.1 million.
 
September 1986 -- Three community boards in Manhattan object to the Zuckerman plan as neighborhood opposition grows. Critics say the project is too big.
 
December 1987 -- Salomon Brothers, a co-owner and principal tenant of the project, withdraws amid widespread layoffs in the securities business. The developer vows to press ahead.
 
January 1988 -- The city and the M.T.A. agree to a new price of $357 million.
 
June 1988 -- Mr. Zuckerman scales down his plan by 500,000 square feet, making the towers shorter and thinner.
 
April 1989 -- To resolve legal and administrative challenges, the project is redesigned again and the price is cut to $338 million. It now calls for 2.1 million square feet. Community boards voice support, but the Manhattan real estate market descends into a deep slump.
 
May 1989 -- The Board of Estimate approves the 59-story project.
 
November 1993 -- Boston Properties submits its final proposal, cutting the space to about 1 million square feet and preserving the existing office building. Officials say construction will begin in late 1994.
 
June 1994 -- Mr. Zuckerman and the M.T.A. agree on a new deal in which he would pay $80 milion for half the original site. Mr. Zuckerman agrees to put up a nonrefundable $17 million deposit.
 
July 1994 -- After nine years of challenges and court battles, Mr. Zuckerman's deal collapses when he misses a deadline to sign a contract with the M.T.A.
 
January 1995 -- The M.T.A. begins seeking short-term tenants for the vacant Coliseum.
 
September 1995 -- After minimal renovation, the Coliseum reopens as what it was designed to be in 1954, a home for commercial trade shows.
 
November 1995 -- The state and city agree to look for a new buyer for the Coliseum. Officials promise that requests for new development proposals will be issued before the end of the year.
 
March 1996 -- The requests for proposals still haven't gone out, despite a March 31 deadline, because state and city officials cannot agree on whether the redeveloped Coliseum site should include convention space.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN CONGRESS;
The Speaker's Gruff No. 2 Takes Charge in the House

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
When he arrived on Capitol Hill in 1985, the Almanac of American Politics promptly summed up the politically crude, rough-edged and brooding Texan as someone "hardly likely to be a power in the House."
Representative Dick Armey is still politically crude, rough-edged and brooding. But 12 years after quitting a college classroom to run for Congress, he has become one of the most powerful politicians in Washington. 
 Several predecessors could be cited to rival Newt Gingrich for the title of most powerful Speaker of the House in the nation's history. But it is almost universally accepted in Washington these days that never has a majority leader, the No. 2 job in the House that Mr. Armey holds, commanded so much authority.
Unabashedly partisan, fiercely conservative and with a tongue as sharp as barbed wire, the 55-year-old Mr. Armey has emerged as the leading Republican voice in the House as well as the majority's biggest political stick.
"Nobody enjoys confrontation, I certainly don't," Mr. Armey said in an interview last Wednesday. "But it is a tool and sometimes you use it."
Since the start of the second session of the 104th Congress in January, Mr. Gingrich's low poll ratings have become a drag on the Republican majority and its agenda, which has been suffering. In the face of that and, more important, to free himself to travel around the country raising money for Republican candidates, the Speaker has ceded more and more of the day-to-day power to his deputy. As a result, Mr. Armey has a decisive voice in determining which bill will be brought to the floor, in what form and when.
It is rare for any leader to trust his No. 2 with such power. But Mr. Armey describes himself as "a man totally without guile," and Mr. Gingrich, and even some of Mr. Armey's most ardent critics, agree.
"He hasn't tried to trim his sails as majority leader and he has not been one who looks for compromise," said Representative Martin Frost of Texas, whose district abuts Mr. Armey's and who heads the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. "He does not have a hidden agenda. What you see is what you get with Armey."
Mr. Armey, who is 6 feet 3 inches tall, gravelly voiced and usually scowling, has cultivated a reputation as a political brawler.
In the 103d Congress, which overlapped the first two years of the Clinton Administration, it was Mr. Armey who frequently led the jousts with the White House over the budget and taxes. In the debate over health care he once denounced Hillary Rodham Clinton, who led the Administration's fight on the issue, as a Marxist.
"I was just being my naturally charming self," Mr. Armey said later. Mrs. Clinton called him "the Dr. Kevorkian of health-care reform."
Leadership has not dulled Mr. Armey's tongue or his style.
Barely three weeks into the 104th Congress, he was engulfed in controversy when, in a radio interview, he referred to Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a Democrat who is a homosexual, as "Barney Fag."
Mr. Armey called it an "unintentional mispronounciation" of Mr. Frank's name and he apologized immediately. But six months later the majority leader was again under attack when, in a television interview, he referred to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as "a misguided special-interest organization."
Politically safe in an affluent district that is anchored by Dallas suburbs, nearly 90 percent white and staunchly conservative, Mr. Armey has been known for wry jokes and quick-fire oratory that has kept him and the Republicans on the defensive as much as it was intended to keep the Democrats on their heels.
"Dick Armey is becoming more and more aware that he cannot shoot from the hip," said one of his advisers. "It took him awhile to realize that he does not only speak for Dick Armey any longer, but for the Republican majority in the House of Representatives."
Mr. Armey readily concedes as much: "When we first came into power, both Newt and I were besieged by the media and we frankly were too generous, and both of us had a couple of stumbles early on. I have learned to be much more sparing. And another thing I have learned is not to respond to hypothetical questions."
Richard Keith Armey was born on July 7, 1940, in Cando (pronounced CAN-do), a small farming town in North Dakota. He worked at a grain elevator and as a lineman for a rural electric company.
Along the way he developed a passion for running, even running marathons, and fishing, especially at a favored spot on the upper Potomac River, where he wades into chest-deep waters in search of bass. He often goes fishing with Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, whose wife, Virginia, is a senior aide in Mr. Armey's office.
Mr. Armey's other passion is keeping Big Government at arm's length. "I've always been taught that if you make a deal with the Government then you are the junior partner," he said.
Except for being a favorite speaker on the conservative circuit, political power has not placed Mr. Armey on the Washington social register. He is a devoted homebody -- "just like an old nag," he said, "once they take the bridle off on Capitol Hill, I just head to the barn."
Mr. Armey, who received a bachelor's degree from Jamestown College in North Dakota in 1963 and a master's from the University of North Dakota a year later, left his home state for the University of Oklahoma, where he received a Ph.D. in economics in 1969.
A job offer from North Texas State University brought him to Texas, and a C-Span broadcast of proceedings in the House helped lure him to Washington. As Mr. Armey likes to tell it, he and his wife, Susan, were watching the broadcast when he remarked, "Honey, those people sound like a bunch of darn fools."
"Yeah," his wife replied. "You could do that."
Despite his lack of political experience, Mr. Armey defeated a freshman Democrat, Representative Tom Vandergriff, in 1984, and arrived in Washington as a self-described "budget commando."
"Jack Kemp told me when I was a freshman, 'You're scary, you're a very scary guy,' " Mr. Armey said. "I think there's something about my physical appearance. I'm a big guy and I have this stormy look."
"But I'm funny," he added. "I'm really one of the funniest guys I know."
When he arrived on Capitol Hill, the off-beat college professor and father of five soon provided some amusement with his much-publicized decision to sleep in the House gymnasium, and later in his office, as a way to save money. Ten years later, as part of the Republican leadership, he declined to ride herd on several freshmen who took up residency in their offices.
Mr. Armey first came to national prominence in 1987, when he proposed an independent commission operating outside politics to shut down hundreds of obsolete military bases; Congress approved the legislation a year later. In 1990, he led a bipartisan coalition in a winning assault on agricultural subsidies.
And Mr. Armey was one of the earliest and most vocal proponents of the flat tax.
His rise as a political power in Washington began slightly less than three years ago, when he won the chairmanship of the Republican Conference Committee in the 103d Congress. That made him No. 3 in a party hierarchy that had Mr. Gingrich as second-in-command as the minority whip and Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois as the minority leader.
Mr. Armey and Mr. Gingrich were the major architects of the Contract With America, the political manifesto that helped the Republicans take control of the House in the 1994 elections for the first time in 40 years.
And it was Mr. Armey who supervised the effort to turn the political promises into draft legislation and then held together the Republican majority, including the unruly freshmen, to force House passage of all but one of the 10 parts of the contract.
Behind the scenes, Mr. Armey has acted as a restraint to the sometimes impulsive Mr. Gingrich. "Newt is a history professor and has this very broad sweep of the world," Mr. Armey said. "I'm a micro-economist and I look at the details."
"I'm fascinated by policy," he continued. "I'll do politics when I have to, and I think I do it well, but it's not my favorite pastime."
More times than not, he has played the role of "bad cop," manipulating the rules of debate to shut out Democrats and his own party's moderates. Although Democrats did the same thing to their opponents when they were in power, Mr. Armey's actions have brought him some criticism. But they have also won him a fiercely loyal following among conservative groups -- and adoration from a freshman class that sees the majority leader as a political soul mate.
"Dick Armey has the same bent not to waver even if there are problems in public perception about what we are doing," said Representative John Hostettler, a Republican freshman from Indiana. "He is not going to go along just to get along."
Republican conservatives insisted that Mr. Armey be brought into the White House discussions on balancing the budget, along with President Clinton, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, and Mr. Gingrich.
Some who were involved in those budget talks have said that Mr. Armey acted as a political counterweight to the hard-line stance taken by two top officials in the Clinton Administration, Vice President Al Gore and the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta.
"I don't have much fear that the Speaker will compromise all our goals away," Mr. Hostettler said. "But I can tell you that, in a supporting role, there was absolutely no fear of that when Dick Armey is in the room."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ECONOMY;
Can the President Capitalize On the Economy's Strength?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The conventional wisdom in American politics is that a strong economy greatly helps incumbents, especially incumbent Presidents, and that a weak economy hurts them badly.
Some academics have gone so far as to quantify the point. Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a politicial scientist at the University of Iowa, has shown that almost every time since World War II that the unemployment rate was falling in the second quarter of an election year, the incumbent's party won the Presidency in November. Ray C. Fair, an economist at Yale, has found that the percentage of the popular vote a Presidential candidate receives can be explained by a formula that measures the rate of inflation, the overall rate of economic growth and the number of calendar quarters in a Presidency in which the economy has been particularly strong. 
 But many believe that the old rules about voters and the economy may not apply. One reason is that the economy today is so mixed.
On the one hand, unemployment and inflation are extraordinarily low. Fears of recession have faded. Business investment and exports are strong. And the stock market seems to break new ceilings weekly.
On the other hand, the pace of economic growth is excruciatingly slow, wages and family income are flat and the degree of public anxiety about layoffs is unusually high.
But there is another, perhaps more important reason that the economy may not be the central force this year that it has been in past Presidential elections, and it is an anomaly that political analysts are just beginning to discuss. The public seems to be giving President Clinton little credit for his economic accomplishments and little blame for the economy's shortcomings.
When the economy was strong under Ronald Reagan and George Bush, The New York Times/CBS News polls show, the public gave the Presidents credit. When the economy was weak, their poll ratings plunged.
But in the last two years, while the polls have consistently shown that most people believe the economy is relatively strong, not once has a majority approved of the way Mr. Clinton is handling the economy.
Why that should be the case is a matter of some dispute.
Lloyd Bentsen, who was Treasury Secretary in the first two years of the Clinton Administration and who now practices law in Houston, said the fault lay with Mr. Clinton's staff and Cabinet. "They don't talk about it enough," Mr. Bentsen said. "They have to be out there selling the jobs that have been created and the other accomplishments, and they're not doing that."
Prof. Charles O. Jones, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin who specializes in Presidents, said that to the contrary, the fault was Mr. Clinton's for not taking personal responsibility for the economy, or, for that matter, much else.
"You never have a feeling that this is the guy who's in charge," Professor Jones said. "If he is not projecting an image of being in control, then why should people give him any credit or any blame?"
Professor Lewis-Beck at the Univeristy of Iowa agreed with this assessment and said his models for forecasting the outcome of elections based on economic factors might no longer be valid if the public no longer sees the President as the central figure in the Government.
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster, said the biggest difference in this respect between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Clinton was that Mr. Reagan articulated a direct relationship between his actions and how the economy responded, while Mr. Clinton had never managed to do this.
"Reagan would talk about how he disciplined Government, how he cut taxes, so there was a story in people's head about why he deserved the credit," Mr. Garin said. "This Administration says they reduced the deficit, which led to lower interest rates, and they opened up foreign markets, but they never establish a cause and effect between this and the state of the economy."
On the White House staff and among Mr. Clinton's political advisers, the question of how he should deal with the economy is a matter of the highest order and one that has not been fully resolved.
Before the days of overarching budget deficits, Presidents could prime the economic pump in election years, distributing new programs here and new projects there, and people could see the connection between Government action and the economy. But this is not a luxury President Clinton can afford.
Gene Sperling, an economic adviser in the White House, put the situation this way: "In the economy we inherited -- high deficits, slow job growth and a stop-and-go economy -- the improvements we could make in the economy are fairly substantial but fairly subtle."
Mr. Sperling said the economy would "definitely be a plus" for Mr. Clinton in the fall campaign, but that too presents a problem.
This time four years ago, when the economy was struggling out of a recession, Mr. Bush maintained that the economy was strong, and Mr. Clinton told strapped voters that he felt their pain.
So what does the President say this year? If he stresses the strength of the economy, he risks seeming insensitive, a trap that may have cost Mr. Bush the election. But if he paints the economy as weak, then voters have every right to ask why he has not fixed the problem.
In his recent speeches, he has emphasized how the two biggest promises on the economy he made in his campaign four years ago have been fulfilled: eight million jobs have been created, and the budget deficit has been cut in half, to an estimated $140 billion this year from $290 billion in 1992.
But then he quickly says that much more needs to be done. For example, in a speech to the Ohio Democratic Party in Columbus last weekend, the President said: "This is a record to build on, not to stand on. We have to meet the challenges of all those Americans out there who do not feel strong and certain about the future."
It is a delicate dance, because so many Americans do not feel strong about the future. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that twice as many (29 percent) felt the economy was getting worse as felt it was getting better (14 percent), while 55 percent believed the economy was staying about the same.
"At least he has avoided one hit," Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, said of Mr. Clinton, referring to the favorable unemployment and inflation numbers.
"Whether he can turn that to his advantage," the Senator added, "is quite a different matter."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Placing Blame for a Scandal
Paul Rodriguez is head of a social services agency in East Harlem that was a more highly rated bidder for two city contracts to monitor welfare recipients, but lost out to a politically connected agency in Queens. After Mayor Giuliani canceled the contracts following questions of propriety, he placed the bulk of the blame for what happened outside his administration -- squarely on Mr. Rodriguez's agency. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]

H.I.P. Failing to Pay Bills
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, the state's largest and oldest health maintenance organization, routinely fails to pay millions of dollars of its members' medical bills each year, leaving subscribers to either cover the bills themselves or fight collection agencies and lawsuits from doctors demanding overdue payments. Complaints against H.I.P. to the State Insurance Department outnumber those against any other health maintenance organization in the state -- even accounting for size -- and they are overwhelmingly about bills that H.I.P. ignored, often for years. [Page A1.]
 
Snag Mires Coliseum Project
After 12 years of debate and delay in deciding the fate of the New York Coliseum, a new conflict has left the project's future as murky as ever. John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, insists that the project include convention space, saying that it would generate $30 million a year in taxes for the city and create thousands of jobs. Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, says that "setting aside any part of that property for exhibition space would simply lower its value." [B1.]
 
Plattsburgh's Future on a Train
When a military base closed in Plattsburgh, N.Y., the victim of Federal cuts, the city of 22,000 began courting manufacturers and other businesses that might resuscitate its economy. By offering a package of state and local tax breaks and other incentives, Plattsburgh wooed Bombardier Inc., a Quebec-based aerospace and manufacturing giant. Now, Bombardier and a partner have won a $611 million contract to build high-speed trains for Amtrak, and Plattsburgh is expecting a small economic boom. [B1.]
 
Arson Suspected in Blaze
A two-alarm fire that burned a six-story building in Washington Heights and injured eight tenants -- including five children -- was deliberately set, city firefighters said. A flammable liquid was poured on the third-floor landing as well as on the stairs up to the sixth floor before the building at 214 Audubon Avenue was set ablaze, fire officials said. [B3.]
 
A Summit on the Wet Stuff
Water, the liquid link between rural Catskill communities and New York City residents, was the focus of a weekend "Watershed Youth Summit" in Denning, N.Y., a meeting for 90 students from schools as varied as Brooklyn's Midwood High, enrollment 3,500, and Ulster County's Rondout Valley High, enrollment 300. The meeting was the latest attempt to break the three generations of hostility between the city and the communities whose terrain acts as the catch basin and filter for the city's drinking water. [B3.]
 
Painting the Town Orange
Students and citizens around Syracuse are awash in the team colors of the Syracuse University basketball team -- orange and blue -- and are united in one wish: that the Syracuse Orangemen not be left blue by a defeat in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship final. It is a wish with undercurrents of apprehension; in 1987, the last time the Orangemen made it to the final game and lost, a drunken melee on campus led to smashed beer bottles, shattered windows and damaged cars. [B5.]
 
Officer Arrested in Shooting
An off-duty police officer on the force for less than two weeks was arrested for shooting a woman four times with his service weapon, leaving her critically injured and on a respirator, the police said. [B7.]
 
Message Screens for Subways
The New York City Transit Authority plans to improve communication with riders by placing electronic message screens in 54 stations, to inform riders of the general frequency of trains at a given time and of any delays or complications. [B2.]
 
REGION
 
In Projects, Dogs Beware
Housing authorities around the nation -- in New York City, San Francisco and New London, Conn. -- are beginning to crack down on pets. Animals are not allowed in Federally financed housing projects, unless the owner is elderly or disabled, but the law is often disregarded. Still, the issue has become more pressing in recent years with the growing popularity of pit bulls and a host of well-publicized incidents in which these dogs have mauled small children. In many cases, residents must get rid of pets or face eviction. [B1.]

HEADLINE: After Losing Air Base, Plattsburgh Glimpses Brighter Future

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.

 BODY:
For more than 180 years, life in Plattsburgh was tied to the military.
Three forts were built here in the War of 1812 to fight the British fleet on Lake Champlain. A few decades later, Army barracks were added. The barracks became a staging area for troops in World War II. In 1952, Plattsburgh Air Force Base opened. At its peak in 1987-88, 5,000 military personnel were stationed at the base, and 900 civilians worked there. 
 When Federal cuts closed the base last year, Plattsburgh lost its sense of self.
Shaken badly, the city of 22,000 began courting manufacturers and other businesses that might resuscitate its economy. By offering a package of state and local tax breaks and other incentives, Plattsburgh wooed Bombardier Inc., a Quebec-based aerospace and manufacturing giant, which opened a plant in the southern part of the city last August. Last month, Bombardier and its partner, GEC Alsthom, a French-British venture, won a $611 million contract to build high-speed trains for Amtrak.
Now Plattsburgh is expecting a small economic boom. Bombardier expects to hire 75 to 150 additional people at its plant here once production of the high-technology trains begins. And that is just part of it.
Amtrak estimates the project will create 6,000 jobs worldwide, many at subcontractors. Before the contract was announced on March 15, Plattsburgh was negotiating with three Bombardier subcontractors to relocate to the city. The Monday after the announcement, there were calls from six more.
For Plattsburgh, the contract means more than jobs and money. It means this city has a future.
"Right through, from the country's birth up to last September, there was a military presence in Plattsburgh," said Mayor Clyde M. Ribideau Jr., a Democrat in his fourth term. "But it's time to move on. Had we not lost Plattsburgh Air Force Base, maybe our community wouldn't have been as aggressive or accommodating to new industry. Maybe our city wouldn't have been ready for Bombardier. It changed our attitude; it made us more aggressive."
"It may be our saving grace for years to come," the Mayor said. "I know it will be."
Battered by layoffs, communities across the country have developed more aggressive strategies, particularly in former military towns like Plattsburgh where the realization has set in that the era of cold war has become the era of cold economics.
David M. Cuttler, Bombardier's vice president for United States operations and general manager of the Plattsburgh plant, credits the Mayor for the deal. "I had a drop-dead day when I would cut my losses and go to an alternate site," Mr. Cuttler said. "He made it."
With so many skilled workers, especially former Air Force employees and farm laborers, looking for jobs, Clinton County turned out to be a perfect place to build trains, Mr. Cuttler said. The plant opened last August and now employs 120 people. They have been working since August on a contract with Metro-North to build 34 train cars.
"It was a psychological victory," the Mayor said. "Not that it was going to be the biggest industry; it would not. Not that it would bring the most jobs; it would not. But we snagged it. We grabbed it. We came home with it and it's ours. We won something on our own merit and it felt good."
The Amtrak deal, the Mayor said, "is really a validation. Our investment is paying off."
The Amtrak project is expected to start early in 1998. Bombardier expects to use the Plattsburgh plant to assemble the power cars, which will whisk the new American Flyer trains through the Northeast Corridor at 150 miles an hour.
But in today's economy of uncertainty, what appear to be clear victories are often ambiguous. Hector Perales loves his job assembling Metro-North railroad cars for Bombardier. But he is not totally jubilant about the Amtrak deal. In the summer, he will probably be laid off.
Before the Bombardier plant here hires more workers to construct high-speed trains for Amtrak, it plans to reduce its work force for the smaller and more immediate task of building monorail cars for the city of Jacksonville, Fla.
Such is the nature of contract work. "We can't offer them work if we don't have work," Mr. Cuttler, the plant's general manager, said.
No one is complaining. The jobs at Bombardier are among the best in Clinton County. They pay well, starting at $10 to $12 an hour, and can lead to good benefits for full-time employees. Full-time workers are not protected from layoffs if there is a lull between contracts. They are hired back based on seniority.
Such circumstances make for confusing economic data. Clinton County's unemployment is now 6.1 percent, lower than when the air base was in full operation. But hardly anyone feels secure. The other big institutions in Plattsburgh are the State University and the Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital. Both have had cutbacks. The state prison system, another major employer, has also been scaling back.
To get a job with Bombardier, workers had to volunteer for 40 hours of unpaid training, learning how to read blueprints and use special tools. Then they were tested and interviewed before they were hired.
People like Sue Gough, who had been selling automotive parts for Sears, was undeterred by the risks of working for a contractor.
"There is no such thing as job security these days," said Ms. Gough, who is 31 and single. "I didn't have anything to lose. If anything else, it would be good experience."
Considering Bombardier's stellar reputation in the transportation industry, workers and company officials say the risks are more than worthwhile. Bombardier is part of a consortium designing the Florida Overland Express, a high-speed rail link between Miami and Tampa through Orlando. Bombardier will soon be competing to build 740 New York City subway cars.
"We are going to be in production here from early 1998 into the year 2000," said Paul J. Harris, the Plattsburgh plant's production manager. "That's a pretty big horizon for people to look at these days. It's nice for employees here to look at a company that just moved in and see a future that is now four years down the road."

HEADLINE: Pension-Fund Group Faces Its Own Governance Battle

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
The Council of Institutional Investors, a collection of large pension funds that has pushed numerous companies to make changes in how they are governed, faces a showdown today over how it governs itself. Corporate members are seeking representation among the group's officers, but union members are vehemently opposed.
The stakes are high: some corporate members have suggested that they may quit the council if they are denied representation in its leadership. If they do, the council will be weaker in number and in its financial resources, and more disagreements between shareholders and managers could be confrontational. 
 Since the mid-1980's, the council and its members -- 100 pension funds with combined assets of more than $900 billion -- have led what is known as the shareholder rights movement. They have provoked changes in policy and leadership at General Motors, Westinghouse Electric, American Express and I.B.M., among other large companies.
Numerous studies have shown that such campaigns have led to more management accountability and improved economic performance, which increases shareholder value for individual investors and for pension funds that invest on behalf of millions of workers.
For more than a year, though, corporate members have fought behind the scenes for a voice in how the council is run. The battle is expected to become public -- and to come to a vote -- today at a meeting in Washington, when Martin A. Coyle, executive vice president and general counsel of TRW Inc., is nominated from the floor for one of the council's three co-chairmen slots.
The outcome will depend to a large extent on the feelings of public pension funds, the council's third and largest contingent. They appear to be split on the subject.
"This is a defining moment for the council," said Richard H. Koppes, deputy executive officer of the California Public Employees Retirement System, whose $97 billion in assets make it the country's largest public pension fund. Calpers, as the fund is known, favors allowing corporate members as officers.
The unions, which say that corporate pension funds should not share in the leadership, contend that corporations are members primarily to keep tabs on shareholder-rights advocates and to remain familiar with participants in case of confrontations, several people close to the thinking of the unions said.
"The concern is which hat the corporate members are wearing, a fiduciary hat or not," said one union official, who insisted on anonymity. He said many corporate representatives came from the investor relations department, not from the pension fund office. "Most of them are the people you sit across the table from when you are negotiating," he said. "Corporate members by and large get what they want, and that's access to active shareholders."
Corporate members, who work at such companies as Coca-Cola, ITT and Consolidated Freightways, take a different view. Though not present at the creation of the council, they have been members since the early 1990's, and they pay the same dues.
"I think all the corporations feel strongly about this -- we think it's time," Mr. Coyle said. "We all have the same aims. We believe that good corporate governance leads to good economic performance."
Last year, corporate representatives campaigned quietly for one of the council's six officer slots. They were told to wait.
This year, they proposed Mr. Coyle to the committee making the nominations for co-chairmen. But that panel, headed by Jon Lukomnik, a deputy comptroller of New York City, selected Michael McGrath, the Minnesota State Treasurer.
A member of the nominating committee, who insisted on anonymity, said the deliberations centered on "what the corporate members are there for."
"If we have an issue with Philip Morris, and a corporate member is in the room when the officers are deciding what to do, the discussion is different," the member said. "The counter-argument is equity."
In the end, Mr. Lukomnik said, "it was unanimous" for Mr. McGrath.
Alan G. Hevesi, New York City's Comptroller, and Bill Patterson, director of corporate affairs for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, were renominated as co-chairmen for a second year. The third co-chairman, William Crist, chairman of Calpers, has served two terms and is ineligible for re-election.
The other officers, also from public or union funds, are running uncontested: Ash Williams Jr., executive director of the Florida State Board of Administration, for executive committee head; Carol Casey, chief investment officer of the Maryland State Retirement Agency, for treasurer, and Bill Lucy, of the Association of Federal, State and Municipal Employees, for secretary.
The election outcome will turn on who attends, since votes -- one fund, one vote -- must be cast in person.
If he loses, Mr. Coyle will neither quit the council nor give up. "We will bring it up again next year," he said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 3, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about a contested election at the Council of Institutional Investors, a group of large union and company pension funds, referred incorrectly to the union of which Bill Lucy, an uncontested candidate for secretary, is secretary-treasurer. It is the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, not the Association of Federal, State and Municipal Employees.

HEADLINE: Where the City Meets Country

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN

DATELINE: DENNING, N.Y., March 30

 BODY:
A cluster of teen-agers stood giggling and squirming in the moonlight on a forested hillside 100 miles northwest of Manhattan, trying their best to be silent. "Just for one minute," implored a naturalist leading them on a nocturnal hike. "Then tell me what you hear."
After a few seconds, the high school students -- some from New York City and some from the villages and towns dotting the Catskills -- stopped whispering and simply listened to the landscape. In every direction, the only sound was the gurgle, drip and rush of water. 
 In two months, the students were told, some of the water flowing down the thawing slopes would be coursing through pipes in New York City apartments. This liquid link between rural Catskill communities and city dwellers was the focus of a weekend "Watershed Youth Summit" here for 90 students -- from schools as varied as Brooklyn's Midwood High, enrollment 3,500, and Ulster County's Rondout Valley High, enrollment 300.
The meeting was the latest attempt to break the three-generation sense of hostility between the city and the dozens of communities whose terrain acts as the catch basin and filter for the city's drinking water. To many who live in the Catskills, New York City represents a foreign force that over a century has displaced thousands of people and imposed limits on development to build and protect its water supply.
"The goal is to get people to stop thinking upstate versus downstate, and start thinking we're all New Yorkers with a shared responsibility," said Arlene de Strulle, education director for the Catskill Center for Conservation and Development. The group organized the conference along with regional agricultural officials and New York City's Department of Environmental Protection.
DeAndrea Gumbs, a senior at Manhattan's High School for Environmental Studies, on West 56th Street, had spent weeks on research projects she and 11 classmates were presenting at the meeting.
"We learned all about the watershed," DeAndrea said. "But to see that water coming out of a spring from nowhere, and to know it's going to be in my faucet, that makes me want to conserve."
Students from New York City mingled with their counterparts from towns ranging from Somers to Woodstock as they hiked forest trails and examined streams around the grounds of the Frost Valley Y.M.C.A., an environmental education center in this community in the heart of the Catskill Park.
Agricultural agents in the Catskills and New York City first proposed bringing students from the city and its watershed together in 1993. But the idea lay dormant until last year, when negotiated a deal in which the city would spend some $1 billion to protect its water supply in ways that do not impede development in the economically depressed watershed communities.
As she toured the Rondout Reservoir with the students, Marilyn Gelber, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said the watershed accord -- many details of which are still being hashed out -- is a milestone, but bringing children from city and countryside together is equally important.
"The adults can sign documents and argue over dollars and terms," Ms. Gelber said. "But ultimately, this agreement has to have a human face. The relationships between these young people are an important part of that."
The students were quick to point out that their projects, all related to water supply were more than just classroom exercises. A study by Rondout students of road salt storage in the town of Rosendale concluded that a cheap enclosure could prevent harmful runoff into streams. When the students presented their findings to the Town Board two weeks ago, a resolution was passed to build a shed, said Stephen Ashton, an Ulster County agricultural agent.
Bonds formed quickly, but some were already well forged before the conference got under way. Inseparable were Adam Toschler, from Kingston, Ulster County, and Rishi Maharaj, from Manhattan's High School for Environmental Studies. The two computer enthusiasts had been communicating over the Internet for weeks, but met face to face for the first time on Friday night, Adam said. "I practically know him better than some of the people in my own group," he added.
Clayton Brooks, the Town Supervisor for Denning, population 524, guided the students on a bus tour along the shores of the Rondout Reservoir, now a shining eight-mile-long expanse of water, but 50 years ago a thriving valley of dairy farms, sawmills, homes, schools and churches. He reminded the visitors that the building of the reservoirs came at an enormous cost. As the bus passed a submerged spot that was once a town, he pointed to the water and said, "That was Bittersweet."
Clarine St. Ange, a senior at Midwood High intent on becoming a doctor, said she first appreciated the importance of clean water when she visited relatives in Haiti. On several visits there, she became ill, she said. Today, she doggedly pursued each water official or local resident she could find and asked probing questions.
After a tour of the beef cattle farm of Richard Coombe, she pointed to the deep pools of manure on a hillside and told Mr. Coombe there could be risks from runoff into the reservoirs. "When decaying organic matter mixes with chlorine, it can cause cancer in laboratory animals," Clarine said.
Caught speechless for a moment, Mr. Coombe, a former state legislator now working with other farmers to cut watershed pollution, quickly reassured her that grass and other vegetation downstream acts as a filter, absorbing most of the nutrients before they can taint the water.
Ms. Gelber jokingly whispered to a colleague that she would hire Clarine as a public affairs aide in an instant.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 15, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 1 about a meeting of students from New York City and communities around the city's upstate reservoirs misstated the stance of the Rosendale Town Board on a recommendation by students that the town build a storage shed for road salt. The board took the proposal under advisement; it did not vote approval.
