HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Against the Yen, And Strength Aids Rise vs. Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by concerns about the Japanese banking system and by expectations that Japanese investors would move more money abroad as their fiscal year began.
The dollar reached a 25-month high against the yen in Tokyo trading, before paring its gains in New York. Still, "there wasn't a lot of heart in the move up" against the yen, said Jerry Egan, managing director at the MTB Bank. 
 The dollar also rose against the German mark, largely in sympathy with its strength against the yen, traders said. It also drew support from persistent expectations that the Bundesbank would cut interest rates in coming months.
The dollar rose as high as 107.65 yen, its highest level since Feb. 11, 1994, when it hit 108.45 yen. In New York trading, it settled at 107.56 yen, up from 107.22 yen on Friday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4835 German marks, up from 1.4765 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5243 from $1.5262.
Many Japanese companies and investors returned their funds to yen before the weekend, the end of their fiscal year. Currency traders now expect that much of that yen will be converted back into the currencies of foreign markets -- including those of the United States -- where investment yields are higher.
The view that the Japanese are likely to look overseas to invest was bolstered by more signs of trouble in Japanese banking. Yesterday, the Long-Term Credit Bank said that American banking authorities were investigating its New York-based subsidiary for misreporting bond trades.
"I suspect that this isn't the end of the world, but every time one of these things happens you worry about the next one," said Varick Martin, manager of foreign exchange at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company. "I don't want to hold yen for the moment."
The dollar held its gains against the mark because investors still expected Germany to lower rates to stimulate economic growth. Lower interest rates often hurt the mark by diminishing the appeal of some German investments.
The Bundesbank last week decided not to trim interest rates, but it might yet do so this quarter, traders said. That helped the dollar today, said Bruce English, head of institutional currency sales at the ABN Amro Bank in Chicago.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Mixed, But Long End Shows a Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the long end of the market moderately higher and shorter maturities weaker.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 13/32, to 91 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.64 percent, from 6.67 percent on Friday. Shorter maturities were held to a narrow range in lethargic trading for most of the day as supply pressures weighed that end of the market. 
 The gains in bonds came after a report that showed continued weakness in manufacturing, although some analysts said the report suggested that weakness in manufacturing might be coming to an end. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday that its March index of manufacturing activity rose to 46.9 from 45.2 in February. While a reading below 50 indicates weakness, accompanying data showed signs that the contraction was slowing.
Traders said a firmer dollar in curency trading helped bonds, making them more attractive to foreign investors. The dollar touched a two-year high against the Japanese yen yesterday in Tokyo trading, before paring some of the gain in New York.
The market's ability to hold prices steady after the purchasing managers' data helped raise investor confidence, drawing in more buyers.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the market's initial negative reaction to the purchasing managers' report reflected in part signs that the recent weakness in the industrial sector was bottoming out. "While the overall index level of 46.9 still indicates considerable slack in manufacturing, both new orders and production seem to have turned the corner," he said. "And with inventories at a very low level, further improvement should be expected. Price pressures remain very subdued, but here too a plateau may have been reached given the relative flatness of the price index over the past four months."
There are a number of other important economic reports scheduled this week including revisions to fourth-quarter gross domestic product and the index of leading indicators, both to be released today. But the market's focus is set firmly on one report: the April employment data, to be issued on Friday.
"After all," Mr. Fine said, "any revision to G.D.P. is not likely to alter the concept of a rather soft economic performance during the fourth quarter, and given that the second quarter has just begun tends to place these revision in the realm of economic history."
The April employment report, however, will be released on a day when the Treasury cash market has a shortened session and the stock market is closed in observance of Good Friday. "Should the payroll number be outside the range of forecasts, it could subject the market to even greater volatility because of the shortened trading session on Good Friday," Mr. Fine said.
The Treasury's regular weekly sales of new three- and six-month bills went well in light of the day's poor performance by the bill market, traders said. The average rate for a three-month issue was 5.07 percent, up from 4.99 percent last week, while the six-month was 5.06 percent, up from 4.97 percent for the same week.
The Treasury also sold $30.01 billion in nine-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.31 percent, a higher rate than the regular weekly auction. Cash management bills are sold to meet the Treasury's short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regularly scheduled auctions.

HEADLINE: Republicans Oppose Retroactive Tax Laws

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The Republican chairmen of two Congressional committees moved to reassure Wall Street that several tax proposals made by President Clinton would not be applied retroactively should they become law.
The statement by the legislators is likely to stimulate the resumption of certain transactions, such as the corporate sale of 100-year bonds, and such stock market strategies as "selling short against the box," which investors employ to defer or eliminate capital gains. 
 Such transactions were frozen last year after the Clinton Administration proposed ending related tax advantages, and making the tax law changes take effect the date of their first proposal.
Investment bankers said the statement, which was made on Friday by Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, meant companies could begin selling the 100-year bonds and other securities with confidence again.
"From the standpoint of corporations, there's a green light for issuing 100-year bonds and all other hybrid-type securities," said Arthur Hyde, head of corporate bond syndication at Salomon Brothers Inc.
Salomon underwrote the Korea Electric Power Corporation's sale last week of $365 million of 100-year bonds. It also underwrote a sale of roughly $875 million of so-called century bonds last year by the BellSouth Corporation.
"U.S. companies have been in suspense for three or four months while overseas corporations have been coming to the U.S. market with 100-year paper," Mr. Hyde said.
But for some companies, such as the Monsanto Company, the strategy no longer makes as much sense.
In December, the St. Louis-based chemical producer canceled a planned sale of $200 million in 100-year bonds after the Administration proposed prohibiting companies from taking tax deductions on interest paid on bonds that mature in more than 40 years.
Juanita Hinshaw, Monsanto's treasurer, said the company would not be interested in selling century bonds now because interest rates have risen nearly three-quarters of a percentage point since Dec. 8, when Monsanto canceled its issue.
Other companies also changed their plans, even though the proposals are given little chance of passing a Republican Congress.
The Administration also proposed prohibiting investors from "shorting against the box," in which an investor first borrows, then sells, a quantity of shares equal to the number of shares in a company he or she owns. That effectively hedges against losses in case the stock's value declines, and lets investors pocket the proceeds from the short sale.
But more importantly, from the Administration's perspective, the loophole lets investors avoid paying capital gains taxes on their profits until they buy back the stock to close their short positions. Indeed, capital gains taxes can be avoided entirely if the short position is kept open until the owner of the stock dies.
On Friday, Senator Roth and Representative Archer issued a joint statement saying that any legislation incorporating the proposals would not be retroactive.
"These new revenue proposals will receive careful attention and consideration" by the committees, Mr. Roth and Mr. Archer said in the statement. But they added that so as not to disrupt normal market activities and business transactions, they intended that the effective date of any of the proposals "will be no earlier than the date of appropriate Congressional action."

LENGTH: 467 words

HEADLINE: Law Comes to Public Housing

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has offered a new plan to bring a higher level of decency and safety to the nation's public housing projects. It includes the eviction of drug dealers and tougher screening of tenants to keep out criminals. It also threatens the eviction of entire households even if only one member sells drugs. The plan poses civil-liberties risks. But the risks can be averted with due-process protections like those in force in New York City.
In much of the country, what began as decent housing for the working poor has degenerated into dumping grounds for the troubled and the terminally unemployed. New York's public housing is regarded as the best in the nation, but it too has suffered. Tenants in more violent projects elsewhere live in terror and feel that the authorities have left them to fend for themselves. 
 Such tenants can take heart from President Clinton's plan to remove criminals from public housing. Mr. Clinton said Federal law had authorized so-called "one-strike" evictions since 1988, but added that in some cities, law enforcement in public housing projects had "not been a priority."
As part of the plan, HUD Secretary Henry Cisneros has ordered public housing authorities to establish tough new screening procedures to keep criminals out of their developments. Mr. Cisneros also wants leases modified so that criminal activity of any kind -- including "all drug-related criminal activity on or off the premises" -- becomes grounds for eviction. Arrest and prosecution would not be needed to trigger eviction. There would instead be an administrative hearing during which witnesses would be called and each side would make its case. Mr. Cisneros will offer incentives to local governments to adopt stricter screening and law enforcement measures. Those who apply the measures will have greater access to Federal improvement funds.
The American Civil Liberties Union worries that whole families will be unfairly evicted to get at one lone criminal in the household. But there is nothing wrong with making leaseholders responsible for those who live with them. Further, the HUD proposal makes clear that the entire household would be evicted only as a last resort.
New York City has adopted a sensible approach. The family is first placed on probation and encouraged to exclude the criminal member. The eviction process goes forward only if the criminal fails to leave. At that point the family is given an administrative hearing, a review by the housing authority board and yet another hearing before a judge in housing court. If evicted, the family is free to appeal.
The policy may sound harsh. But people in public housing deserve as much peace, quiet and safety as the rest of us. Right now, many of them are prisoners in their apartments.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Head: He Speaks, and Money Talks

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH and ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
If Boris N. Yeltsin is re-elected President of Russia in June, he will owe his victory in some part to one of Washington's least-known but most powerful people: Michel Camdessus.
The 63-year-old Frenchman is head of the International Monetary Fund, the obscure global lending organization that gave a vital lift to Mr. Yeltsin's campaign when it formally approved a $10.2 billion loan to Russia last Tuesday. 
 Although the monetary fund is not supposed to take sides in elections, the extraordinary deal -- the second-largest loan in the fund's history -- was driven by the West's desire to impede the comeback of the Communist Party in Russia.
The United States and Germany urged that the loan be approved, but Mr. Camdessus had cleared the way by rewriting fund rules in 1994 to ease credit to Russia, and Mr. Camdessus went on Russian television to announce the largesse that Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms had won.
Even Mr. Camdessus recognizes the inevitable political consequences of taking such an activist course.
"It can be seen and will be seen by many as betting on Yeltsin or a waste of money," Mr. Camdessus said in an interview in his office, three blocks from the White House. "But nothing more important could be done today for the prosperity of the entire world. So we must do it."
The case of Russia illustrates how Mr. Camdessus has played the roles of gambler, preacher and politician in his nine years as managing director of the fund. In the process, he has reinvented a staid organization whose role -- originally, the limited one of stabilizing currency markets -- has grown to the point where it can now virtually dictate broad economic policies to a major power like Russia.
But Mr. Camdessus's greatest moments of activism -- the record $17.8 billion loan to Mexico last year and the loan to Russia last week -- have brought criticism that he and the fund failed to anticipate Mexico's financial collapse and were slow in lending money to Russia. The two loans are almost half of the monetary fund's $55 billion in outstanding loans, leaving it at its greatest concentration of risk in decades.
That shift away from its original mission has led some conservative economists like Allan H. Meltzer to advocate significantly reducing its role.
"The I.M.F. has become a government-to-government welfare agency that transfers wealth at its own discretion yet fails to promote real market reform," said Mr. Meltzer, an economics professor at Carnegie-Mellon University, "like in Russia, where the fund hasn't pushed them to create institutions for capitalism, like a legal system."
At the same time that the fund has broadened its reach, it has been slow to shed its tradition of secrecy. Even Mr. Camdessus's most serious effort to be open -- a report he commissioned last year to analyze why the fund had failed to see Mexico's deteriorating financial situation -- was undercut by his decision to keep it secret.
He bent the fund's rules to accommodate the United States, the fund's largest shareholder at 18 percent, when he agreed to the loan to Mexico, which far exceeded the fund's lending guidelines, before consulting the 24-member board, the fund's governing body.
His strong opinions and ambitions have repeatedly put him at odds with the United States and the other rich countries that control an institution that lent $27 billion last year.
 
'Always Finding Things to Do'
"Damn right he can be tough," former Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said. "Sometimes you have to lean on him real hard to get things done."
Mr. Camdessus remains undaunted. Despite mounting opposition to foreign aid, he is asking his donors to double the amount of money they invest in the fund, which for the United States would mean doubling its quota to about $80 billion.
The fund pools the financial resources of richer nations to provide short-term assistance to countries that cannot pay their debts. In return for their loans, borrowers promise to take corrective actions that can cause economic pain.
Since the end of the cold war, the fund's membership has grown from 152 to 181 countries. The number of countries that need the fund's programs to rehabilitate their economies has risen more sharply: from 63 to 90.
"By temperament he's an activist," said Paul Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. "Without his active leadership, the fund might have receded into desuetude. He's always finding things to do."
Mr. Camdessus is the sort of man who sends handwritten notes of thanks, remembers the names of his colleagues' children, moves with ease from French to English to Spanish and smiles even when he brings bad news.
A graduate of the elite Ecole Nationale d'Administration and the University of Paris, he detonated mines in Algeria as a second lieutenant in the French Army before working his way to the top of the French Treasury and then became head of France's central bank.
 
Economic 'Gospel' And Sweet Talk
The Spanish he learned as a child growing up in the southern French city of Bayonne helped him solidify important ties with key Latin American countries, which along with France and Germany provided crucial support to win him his current job.
A Catholic and former Socialist who attends Mass every Sunday, he weaves his Christianity into his philosophy of management and portrays himself as an advocate for the poor even as he plays politics to fulfill what he calls his economic "gospel."
He once sweet-talked Japan into a promise to invest in a special program to make low-interest loans to poor nations. He later used that pledge to persuade 13 African countries -- all former French colonies -- to drastically devalue their currencies. That delighted his native country, France, which had helped him get his job in the first place.
Although Mr. Camdessus purposely keeps a low profile in Washington, he is seen as both Grim Reaper and economic savior in countries that borrow from the fund.
In 1987, after bread riots in Zambia followed the imposition of austerity measures to meet monetary fund guidelines, President Kenneth D. Kaunda accused the fund of waging a "smear campaign" against his country.
By contrast, on the day after Leonid Kuchma was elected President of Ukraine in July 1994, the first foreign dignitary he called to invite for a visit was not Bill Clinton or Mr. Yeltsin but Mr. Camdessus. A few days later, he was on a plane to Kiev, and only two months later Ukraine concluded its first agreement with the fund.
 
Unchastened After Failed Gamble
One of the most revealing episodes about the way Mr. Camdessus operates was his ill-fated gamble at the fund's annual meeting in Madrid in 1994 to take on the world's seven largest industrialized countries. The object of his power play: to create $50 billion in global reserves with the help of the donors.
Instead, he was roundly criticized by the United States, Germany and Britain, which accused him of empire-building. His unwillingness to compromise diminished his political capital with his main shareholders and led to speculation about whether he would be asked to serve an unprecedented third term.
Unchastened, Mr. Camdessus called a midnight news conference to justify his position, saying, "I am possibly too immodest, but I am the managing director of the I.M.F." He added: "My duty is not to look at what the industrial countries think. My duty is to give a judgment on what is in the global need."
But he bounced back a few months later with a loan package to relieve Mexico's financial crisis.
In response to an early morning plea from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Mr. Camdessus committed the fund to lend a total of $18 billion to Mexico without obtaining the necessary approval of his board. An hour later in the 12th-floor conference room next to his office, he announced his decision as a fait accompli.
The move endeared him to the Clinton Administration but incurred the wrath of Britain, Germany and other large donors, which saw it as an inter-American matter and were upset about the high-handed way he had handled it.
Mr. Camdessus makes no apologies. Instead, he gets visibly excited when he describes his central role in rescuing the Mexicans and helping the Clinton Administration in the process.
 
'I Don't Ask Your Permission'
"I told my executive board, 'Gentlemen, I don't ask your permission because you would have to speak with your ministers or governors, and you have no time for that,' " Mr. Camdessus recalled saying. "The only question I ask you is the following, 'Is that my job or not?' And they said yes."
Mr. Camdessus acknowledged that the Mexico crisis had exposed "a global problem with the culture of the fund." He himself had touted Mexico as a model of austerity just two months before the crisis erupted.
In the interview, he admitted that he was a friend with Pedro Aspe, then Mexico's Finance Minister, and acknowledged that access inevitably compromises objectivity.
"It's a problem we can never get rid of," he said. "The danger is always there, and no one can escape from that."
Mr. Camdessus is proud of his decision to ask a former fund official to re-examine the fund's failure to recognize the troubles brewing in Mexico before it was too late -- the first such critique in the fund's history. But he bristled when asked about his refusal, even at the Clinton Administration's repeated requests, to make the critique public.
"I didn't want the report to be public," he said. "You don't accuse people without giving them the chance to explain their views."
The report criticized the fund's monitoring of Mexico as inadequate and its tendency to give too much credence to the optimistic pronouncements of Mexican officials, according to a review of the Mexico crisis by the General Accounting Office, the Congressional auditing arm, which itself was denied access to the report.
 
Fund's Tradition Of Secrecy
Mr. Camdessus's reluctance to release the Mexico critique is symptomatic of a much larger tendency: the fund's longstanding tradition of keeping things secret.
Board meetings are closed. The minutes are sealed, as are the annual reviews of each member country. Even the amount of hard currency the fund has to lend at any given moment is kept confidential.
"The I.M.F. strangely enough is without any professional scrutiny in the world," said Jeffrey Sachs, director of Harvard University's Institute for International Development. "It has to be exposed to the glare of bright light."
Mr. Camdessus insists that he has tried to make the fund more open by meeting more with labor unions, non-governmental organizations, journalists and religious leaders, but that the fund still needs to maintain a high degree of confidentiality to protect its members.
Even publishing the amount of money that donors are prepared to turn over to the fund would call into question the financial health of those countries who did not take part, he said. "We would trigger a crisis," he said. "This is not the raison d'etre of the fund. We haven't been created to cry wolf."
On the other hand, he knows that the only way to maintain the primacy of the fund's mission and the adequacy of its resources is to warn of future peril. "We will have new Mexicos," he said.
And will he be around for Mexico redux? His job, which pays him $190,000 tax-free and an additional $95,000 allowance, expires in January. Before then, the fund's board will either choose a successor or give Mr. Camdessus a third five-year term.
But to hear Mr. Camdessus tell it, the decision is his: "I will decide in due time."

HEADLINE: Merger Plans Spur Stocks; Dow Rises 50.58

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
A couple of multibillion-dollar mergers helped drive stock prices upward yesterday, with all three major indicators advancing together for the first time in almost a week.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 50.58 points, to 5,637.72, ending near its high of the day. Among the broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks added 8.23 points, to 653.73, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 5.17 points, to 1,106.57. 
 In one of yesterday's merger announcements, SBC Communications offered to buy Pacific Telesis Group for $17 billion. Pacific Telesis surged 6, to 33 3/4, and other Baby Bell regional telephone companies -- now possible merger candidates themselves -- followed.
 The other big merger proposal came from Aetna Life and Casualty, which agreed to acquire U.S. Healthcare for nearly $9 billion. Shares of U.S. Healthcare, a health care organization, also soared 6, to 51 7/8, and shares of other companies in the industry were also higher.
 "The stock market likes mergers, especially among big companies," said Harry Laubscher, senior vice president of Tucker Anthony. And looking ahead, he said, the leading economic indicators report for February, due this morning, is "expected to show the sharpest gain since 1982."
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,468 to 928. Turnover on the Big Board eased to 392.1 million shares, from 413.8 million shares on Friday, and was less than the year's daily average trading of 424 million.
The bond market also climbed yesterday, after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing activity slowed in March for the eighth consecutive month and the Commerce Department reported that construction spending dropped in February. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond was up 13/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, fell to 6.64 percent, from 6.67 percent on Friday.
Among the telephone issues that surged on the Pacific Telesis deal, Nynex rose 3 1/8 a share, to 53; U S West rose 1 1/4, to 33 5/8, and Ameritech was up 2 5/8, to 57 1/8. As is usual for an acquiring company, SBC's shares fell, 2 3/4, to 49 7/8.
Fueled by the Aetna offer, shares of other health care companies also advanced strongly. Humana jumped 3/4, to 25 7/8, and United Healthcare increased 2 1/2, to 64 1/8. Again, the shares of the prospective acquirer dropped; Aetna's declined 3 1/2, to 72.
The Big Three auto companies hit new 52-week highs after the board of General Motors approved splitting off its Electronics Data Systems unit. The action renewed speculation that it might spin off part of its Hughes Electronics unit. G.M. closed at 56 1/8 a share, up 2 7/8; Ford Motor closed at 35, up 5/8, and Chrysler closed at 64, up 1 3/4.
Pollution-control stocks were lower. IMC Global fell 3 5/8, to 32 7/8, and Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan shares fell 5/8, to 61 7/8.
Some leading technology issues also closed lower. Digital Equipment closed at 54 1/4, off 3/4; I.B.M. closed at 110 3/8, off 7/8, and Microsoft was at 102 3/4, off 3/8.
Announcements of lower earnings or prospects of them led to lower stock prices. Shares of Datalogix International lost almost half their value, plummeting 6 5/8, to 6 7/8, after the company said it would have a loss in its third quarter. Pacific Scientific fell 2 1/4, to 18 7/8, after lowering its first-quarter profit estimate. And Ameridata Technologies dropped 1 7/8, to 9 1/2, after reporting lower-than-expected fourth-quarter net income.

HEADLINE: In the Queens Mosaic, A Turkish Inlay;
Community Takes Root in Sunnyside

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Knowing next to no one, Mesut Yaktubay stepped off the plane from Turkey two weeks ago and became an instant regular at Sunny Grocery, a postage-stamp-sized market on an unremarkable corner in Sunnyside, Queens.
He does not come for the fava bean paste dip, the fried liver, the shiny pistachio-dappled squares of sobiyet pastry or anything else that the little shop sells. Mr. Yaktubay is much more interested in what Sunny Grocery gives away. 
 Through the Sunny Grocery network, for example, Hatice Cetinkaya has been able to rent an apartment at a price she can afford, even though she is in the United States on a six-month tourist visa and must shuttle back to Turkey before the visa expires to get another visa to return to New York a few months later.
And Ayse Sevinc and her family, who arrived in New York with no money, found a Turkish bakery to give them bread and cakes, a Turkish greengrocer to deliver free fruits and vegetables and Turkish families to donate furniture for the one-bedroom fourth-floor walk-up she shares with her husband and three children.
Sunny Grocery, through its owner, Vedat Evren, has become the social club, real estate agent and employment office for the latest arrival at New York's perpetual ethnic festival: a growing community of Turkish immigrants that is quietly taking root in the brick and garden neighborhood of Sunnyside.
Relying as it does on an ad hoc life-support system, Sunnyside's fledgling Turkish community is a case study in how an immigrant enclave is created and nurtured, even side by side with traditional foes. It is an echo of the first city neighborhoods settled by immigrants, the constellations of Italians and Jews, Irish and Chinese.
"Little Italy must have been like this," said Nur Emirgil, who was among the first Turkish settlers of Sunnyside 14 years ago. "Chinatown was probably like this once. We are just the seeds of a community. We have a network from ear to ear.
"Somebody calls or knocks on the door and asks, 'Can this person stay on your couch for a few days?' 'Do you know any job they can get, someplace that doesn't care about green cards?' 'Can you go with them to the doctor to translate?' "
The birthing process is difficult as the Sunnyside Turks try to establish themselves in their new country without cutting ties to the old culture. They want their children to learn English but not lose touch with Turkish. They want to find good jobs and learn to function in the American system, but many need a translator just to visit the doctor, take a driving test or ask for directions.
"The community wants to be Turkish, but they also want to be New Yorkers," said Ms. Emirgil, who heads a women's group trying to raise money for a Turkish school and social center in Sunnyside. "They also want to contribute their share to the hubbub. It's past time this community moves on to where it's living now, but not to forget its culture. And the kids should not be squeezed between two cultures and wind up cultureless."
From the old country, these immigrants, who seem to come from all economic classes and regions of Turkey, have transplanted some of the tensions and conflicts from Turkey to New York.
In Sunnyside as in Turkey, for example, the majority of Turks are secular Muslims, who believe religion should be kept separate from government and education. But there is also a minority of conservative Turkish Muslims, who, like an increasingly active Islamic movement in Turkey, are much more traditional in their religious practice and are trying to gain ground in Sunnyside. The group's leader, Necdet Camli, said they are particularly interested in shaping the education of Turkish children and have set up a masjeed, or a small mosque, where children are taught academic subjects together with Islam.
The Turks are also learning to coexist with their country's traditional enemies, the Greeks, who dominate nearby Astoria, and the Armenians, many of whom also live in this northern swath of Queens. In one-on-one relationships, the Turks say, there is virtually no tension. Often, there is even warmth, as though the loud struggle of life in a new country drowns out the ethnic clashes from home, reducing them to a murmur. Armenians buy pita and grape leaves at Turkish stores, and Turks rent from Greek landlords and work at Greek gas stations.
But the Turks are aware that the leaders of the Turkish government and the other ethnic groups do not exactly exude the same harmony. Some said they have seen small groups of Greeks at the annual Turkish-American Day Parade in Manhattan chanting slogans about the divided island of Cyprus. Even the date of the parade, meant to correspond with Turkey's National Independence and Children's Day, had to be changed several years ago because it fell a day before the Armenian community's commemoration of the 1915 massacres under the Ottoman Turks.
Turkish organizations in New York read Greek and Armenian newspapers and watch Greek cable television "to know what is going on and how they are trying to influence the U.S. government," said Nihal Kustimur Green, who is president of Dost Turkish American Community Service, a Manhattan group.
"Greek television here, they have a lot of programs that put down the Turkish in Cyprus," said Ahmet Sandik, who heads a New York group called the U.S. Council for Human Rights in the Balkans and stops by Sunny Grocery every morning for coffee and Turkish newspapers. "We keep watching out of the corner of our eye."
For years, Turkish immigrants have dotted the Upper East Side of Manhattan and settled among other Muslims and Orthodox Jews in the Midwood, Brighton Beach and Sheepshead Bay sections of Brooklyn. In 1990, the Census reported about 9,500 Turks in the city; Turkish leaders say the number, swelled by illegal immigrants and those who do not respond to the census, could be three times that. In the last five years, as economic conditions in Turkey have worsened, more Turks have been immigrating to the United States.
In Sunnyside, a trim neighborhood of about 30,000 people, small family-run stores and low brick apartment buildings, a small cluster of Turks has swelled to the point where the sashaying sounds of the Turkish language can be heard on the streets, and the syrupy smell of flaky pastries drifts onto the sidewalk.
The number of Turkish children in Public School 150, the neighborhood's elementary school, has nearly quadrupled in the last three or four years, and Turks now make up nearly 20 percent of the 1,000 students, said the principal, Gloria Guzman. Ms. Guzman said that P.S. 150 now brings in a Turkish-speaking counselor for parent-teacher meetings and includes in the curriculum Turkish folk tales, music and dance.
Of the approximately 900 Turks who immigrated legally to New York City from 1990 to 1994, 75 went straight to Sunnyside, more than to any other neighborhood except the larger, more diffuse Midwood and Brighton Beach areas.
The heart of Sunnyside -- between 39th and 50th streets, and Skillman and Greenpoint avenues -- has become a magnet for Turks who had lived for several years in Brooklyn, or even in Long Island, New Jersey or Manhattan. Mr. Evren and others estimate that 400 to 500 Turkish families now live in Sunnyside.
"Every year, year by year, the Turkish community there in Sunnyside is growing," said Fuat Tanlay, the Turkish Consul General, who will pay his first official visit to Sunnyside on Saturday. "Of course, as a consul general, I want that this community be organized. That's why I would like to go there and see in place all the problems and try to help them."
Like Mr. Yaktubay, 38, who was a marketer for a large ice cream company in Turkey, most newcomers land with no job and no place to live. They stay on someone's couch for a while or find a good deal on an apartment from one of Sunnyside's Turkish apartment managers or superintendents.
They find work in other people's businesses, generally low-skilled jobs that require little English. Mustafa May, a French teacher, found himself doing construction work. A dancer who spoke on condition of anonymity because he is working here illegally got an off-the-books job with a greengrocer in Jackson Heights. Ms. Sevinc's husband, Ragip, a tax inspector for the Turkish Ministry of Finance whose family had a sumptuous house in Turkey, managed to find only a summer job selling Mr. Softee ice cream. Their son, Kubilay, began supporting the family at age 18 working 17 hours a day, seven days a week in a Turkish bakery on Queens Boulevard.
Lowery Bakery is one of only a few Turkish-run businesses that have managed to open in Sunnyside, including a meat market and a combination flower shop and greengrocer. A Turkish restaurant opened about three years ago but closed a few months later because, residents said, the food was not very good.
"We are a very closed community right now," said Ms. Emirgil, whose group recently helped 150 people apply for legal immigration status in the visa lottery. "Voters are not registered. People do not speak English. They don't know who their representatives are. Some of them do not know their rights under Social Security, medical care, immigration laws."
Ms. Cetinkaya, who shuttles back and forth on a tourist visa, is not legally allowed to open a bank account and does not know what to do with her money. Once, she said, she got mugged on the subway and was robbed of the $485 she was carrying.
In the meantime, there is Mr. Evren and Sunny Grocery.
On a recent Friday night, Mr. Yaktubay stood -- there is not even an upended milk crate to sit on -- among the plasticene sacks of paprika and tahini, the watery troughs jiggling with olives, the snug trays of filo dough and feta cheese. Turkish music slithered under the fluorescent lights, and the beneficent gaze of Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, shone from several portraits hung high on a wall.
"I buy my bread every day here and talk to Vedat, ask him if he hears something, will he let me know," said Mr. Yaktubay, who was on his way to a billiard hall a few blocks away where young Turkish men hang out. "Anyplace where Turks are gathered I go and I say, 'I am here looking for a job.' I don't think there's any other alternative."

HEADLINE: BIRTH OF A GIANT: A LEADER'S VISION;
Gambles, and Successes, at the Top

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
Edward E. Whitacre Jr. is as far from flashy as anyone gets in the communications business: laconic, unflappable and largely uninterested in spinning visions of the future.
But appearances are deceiving. As the chairman and chief executive of SBC Communications, parent of the Southwestern Bell telephone company, Mr. Whitacre has proved to be one of the shrewdest and toughest executives in the telephone industry. 
 SBC is growing faster than any of the other seven regional Bell companies, and it is one of the most profitable. But Mr. Whitacre has also attracted heaps of criticism from consumer groups and from aspiring rivals, who complain that the company has repeatedly thrown up legal barriers to choke off competition in its core local telephone business.
Mr. Whitacre is a towering 6-foot-4-inch figure who was born in Texas and came up through the old Bell System. While other communication executives boast about their vision, Mr. Whitacre prefers to pick his shots carefully -- and watch his back.
It has not been a quiet strategy. Twice before in the last 10 years, Mr. Whitacre has surprised the industry with billion-dollar bets, and both were huge successes. In 1986, when Mr. Whitacre was chief financial officer, SBC stunned many of its counterparts by paying $1.4 billion for Metromedia Inc.'s cellular systems in cities like Chicago, Washington and Baltimore.
The price seemed outlandish at the time, particularly to telephone companies steeped in the conservative culture of regulated utilities, but Mr. Whitacre adamantly argued that the deal would make sense. He was right: today, analysts estimate those systems are worth at least five times what SBC paid for them -- based on the prices that AT&T paid in 1994 for McCaw Cellular Communications.
More significant, SBC has built up its cellular business faster than any other Bell company. Subscribership in its markets is the highest of any company, as is the amount of money generated per cellular subscriber. Largely because of the cellular business, in fact, about one-third of the company's revenues come from outside its core telephone business.
Mr. Whitacre's second big gamble came in 1991, when the company paid $1 billion for a 10 percent stake in Telefonos de Mexico, the formerly state-owned telephone company in Mexico. Notwithstanding Mexico's economic convulsions last year, Telmex stock is now trading about about twice what SBC paid for it, and the company's long-term prospects appear good.
SBC had avoided much of the merger frenzy that took place in recent years. It came close to forming a joint venture with Cox Cable, a unit of Cox Enterprises of Atlanta, but then walked away from the deal after the Federal Communications Commission imposed strict rate regulation on cable companies in 1993.
SBC remained conspicuously out of the big wireless alliance of Bell Atlantic, Nynex, U S West and Airtouch Communications. Though his company continues to use the Cellular One brand name, Mr. Whitacre has shown no interest in building up a national wireless network that would compete against those being built by AT&T and Sprint.
Wall Street has been grateful. Shares of SBC, which closed yesterday at $49.875, are trading at about 17 times its earnings -- one of the the highest valuations in the industry and far higher than the valuation given to Pacific Telesis.
Even as SBC races to enter the long-distance telephone business, it has fought tenaciously to make life difficult for aspiring rivals in the local telephone business.
In Texas, the Southwestern Bell unit lobbied successfully last year for a state law deregulating telecommunications that could make it difficult for AT&T, MCI Communications or Sprint to enter the local telephone market.
Under that law, adamantly opposed by consumer groups and others, the long-distance carriers can only become certified as local telephone carriers if they provide at least 60 percent of their service over their own networks. But MCI and AT&T are planning to enter the local market largely by leasing capacity from local telephone carriers, a concept at the core of the new sweeping telecommunications law.
"Bell has worked very hard and won a lot of regulatory relief, claiming there was going to be competition in local market, when in fact they have erected so many barriers to entry that consumers are in a lose-lose position," said Janee Briesemeister, a senior policy analyst for the Consumers Union in Austin, Tex. "They're going to make everybody go to court and spend a lot of money on lawyers, instead of getting competitive phone service to consumers in Texas."
The new Federal law generally pre-empts state laws that restrict competition, but Southwestern Bell executives are intent on defending the Texas statute.
"There are some semantic differences, but this is surprisingly consistent with the Federal legislation," said David Cole, president of Southwestern Bell Telephone of Texas.The concept behind the state law, he said, was to promote investment in new telephone networks built from the ground up. "They want people to invest in Texas and create jobs, and not just to create an environment where you create rate arbitrage," Mr. Cole said today.
Regardless of how that and similar disputes are resolved, SBC Communications seems clear about its reasons for wanting to acquire Pactel.
Thanks to Pacific Telesis's slumping price, the price is relatively cheap. Beyond that, analysts said today, the two companies will be far better positioned to jump into the long-distance market because a very high percentage of long-distance calls can be handled over their own network. The two companies can also share the big back-office costs associated with billing and service in the long-distance business.
Pactel, with its huge California market, should help strengthen SBC's relationship with Telmex as cross-border communications traffic with Mexico continues to expand. And California is an important gateway for telecommunications traffic between the United States and Asia, another potentially lucrative and fast-growing market.
But this merger is driven more by nuts-and-bolts pragmatism than by sweeping strategic visions.
"They aren't working off the big themes; they work off the numbers," said Daniel P. Reingold, telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch, referring to Mr. Whitacre and SBC.

HEADLINE: G.M.'s Monthly Sales Drop While Chrysler's Increase

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 1

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced today that its March sales dropped 2.2 percent from levels a year earlier because a long strike interrupted its production. But the Chrysler Corporation reported an 8.1 percent gain for the month.
One reason G.M. car sales declined, according to Ed Lechtzin, a company spokesman, was that it delayed until April the delivery of some cars to fleet buyers in order to conserve its scarce supply of cars for retail buyers during the 17-day strike. The work stoppage involved two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, that led to a gradual closing of most of the company's North American assembly plants and some shortages of cars on dealer lots. 
 Retail buyers tend to be much more willing to look elsewhere if they cannot find what they want, Mr. Lechtzin said. He added that G.M. expected to recover during the second quarter the sales lost last month.
G.M.'s sales of passenger cars fell 3.8 percent in March while truck sales rose by an anemic one-tenth of 1 percent. Without the strike, "we would have probably been equal to last year or slightly above" in passenger cars, Mr. Lechtzin said.
There were 26 selling days in March of this year and 27 a year earlier, so percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate.
The real effect of the strike on G.M. sales, some auto analysts say, may not come until the third quarter. That is when the auto maker will be closing several assembly plants for retooling for new models and will need to depend on inventories of unsold vehicles that have already been partly drained by the strike. G.M. officials have told financial analysts that the company will be lucky to recover half of the production lost in the strike.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission today, G.M. said that the strike in Dayton, which closed 26 of its 29 North American vehicle assembly plants for a week or more, would cost the company $900 million after taxes in the first quarter. G.M.'s figure was higher than virtually any estimate by Wall Street analysts.
G.M. may also face other local labor troubles. About 2,700 workers at two suspension parts factories in a Dayton suburb are threatening to strike next week, the company said today. The workers are members of the International Union of Electronic Workers.
While G.M. struggles, Chrysler has continued to prosper. The company had its best first quarter since 1988, with record sales for the Dodge Ram pickup and Chrysler Town & Country mini-van. The mini-van is one of Chrysler's most popular vehicles, with profit margins estimated by analysts at up to $8,000 for each mini-van sold. Chrysler car sales in March were up 2 percent whiles its light-truck sales rose 12 percent.
Dealers and auto analysts said that a combination of good weather, rebate programs and rising consumer confidence in the economy all helped sales in March.
J. Chapman Morris Jr., a Chevrolet and Oldsmobile dealer in Fillmore, Calif., said that he had lost some sales of pickup trucks to the Ford Motor Company and to Chrysler dealers because the strike in Dayton had interrupted his supply. But the overall demand for new cars and trucks was so strong that the dealership had its highest sales ever in the last two weeks of March, he said.
Many of the cars being traded in have more than 100,000 miles on them. "It's not an impulse buyer -- these are calculated buyers who should have bought a car a year ago, two years ago," Mr. Morris said.
Dennis R. Sawyer, the general sales manager at Don Bulluck Chevrolet in Rocky Mount, N.C., said that sales there had also been strong in March after suffering heavily from the bad weather in January and February. The dealership ran low on popular models during the strike but never ran out, he said.
"I've got some holes on the lot, but the strike is over," Mr. Sawyer added.
Ford is not scheduled to announce its March sales figures until Wednesday. Analysts expect it to show little change from March 1995, when the company had especially strong sales of trucks.
Mitsubishi, Hyundai, Volvo, Saab and Suzuki each reported today that their March sales were down slightly from a year earlier, while Subaru announced higher sales.

HEADLINE: 2 BELL COMPANIES AGREE TO MERGER WORTH $17 BILLION

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
In the first marriage of two regional Bell telephone companies and one of the largest corporate mergers ever, SBC Communications announced yesterday that it would acquire the Pacific Telesis Group for $17 billion.
The deal would create a communications colossus, providing service to more than 30 million residential and business telephone lines in seven states west of the Mississippi, including California and Texas. 
 The combined company would also provide wireless service coast to coast, with cellular and other wireless franchises that reach a potential market of 80 million people from Boston to Los Angeles.
Coming just two months after Congress passed a sweeping telecommunications bill, the deal underscores how telephone and media companies are rushing to bulk up for the untrammeled competition of an open marketplace.
Nynex and Bell Atlantic, the regional phone companies serving New England, New York and the other mid-Atlantic states, have been mulling a merger for months, and several analysts said yesterday's deal could goad them to consummate their courtship.
Together, SBC and Pacific Telesis would be the nation's second-largest phone company with more than $21 billion in annual revenues. Only AT&T, the long-distance carrier, would be larger; both SBC (originally Southwestern Bell) and Pacific Telesis were created in the 1984 breakup of the Bell System.
Unlike AT&T, which is in the process of cutting more than 30,000 jobs, SBC and Pacific Telesis said yesterday that they planned to hire 1,000 employees to augment their combined work force of 100,000.
The new company will be named SBC Communications and will be based at SBC's headquarters in San Antonio. Telephone service to customers in California and Nevada, however, will continue to be provided by companies named Pacific Bell and Nevada Bell.
"We could have survived as an independent company," Philip J. Quigley, the chairman of Pacific Telesis, said yesterday. "But this is going to be an industry with a handful of strong global players."
By negotiating quickly and mostly in one-on-one sessions, Mr. Quigley and his counterpart, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chairman and chief executive of SBC, were able to keep the deal almost completely under wraps until yesterday. Mr. Whitacre will become the chief executive of the combined company, while Mr. Quigley will become vice chairman.
The deal is subject to approval from the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission. Despite the size and the first-of-its-kind nature of the deal, legal experts predicted yesterday that the transaction would not run aground on antitrust or regulatory issues.
"Like the Disney-ABC or Westinghouse-CBS deals, as long as there is robust competition, this should lead to economies of scale," said James H. Quello, an F.C.C. commissioner, "Success in these things is usually based on better service and more attractive prices for consumers."
Wall Street's strong reaction also indicated that investors believed the deal would go through. The merger is intended to be a tax-free exchange of stock, with SBC giving 0.733 share of its stock for each Pacific Telesis share. That gives the deal a value of $39 a share, or $17 billion -- a 40 percent premium to Friday's closing share price of Pacific Telesis.
The shares of Pacific Telesis rose $6 , to $33.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. But stock of the acquiring company, SBC, dropped $2.75, to $49.875. SBC is expected to have lower earnings per share for a couple of years, as it issues additional stock to finance the takeover.
The secrecy and haste of the negotiations between SBC and Pacific Telesis stood in sharp contrast to the long-running talks between Nynex and Bell Atlantic. Neither of those companies have yet publicly acknowledged holding merger discussions, but the talks are such an ill-kept secret that speculating on their status has become a virtual parlor game on Wall Street and in the press.
As a result, analysts and other experts were somewhat nonplused by the surprise deal, involving two companies on the other side of the country, serving geographic territories that do not even abut each other.
"There are a lot of things that make sense about this, and a couple that are tough to figure out," said William C. Bane, a communications consultant at Mercer Management Consulting in Washington.
Like other analysts, Mr. Bane had been viewing Pacific Telesis as a possible acquisition candidate. The company, which offers phone service in California and Nevada, has struggled under a double-whammy of intense external competition and restrictive state regulations in its home market.
Moreover, by spinning off its cellular properties two years ago into a separate public company, AirTouch Communications, Pacific Telesis unlocked the stock market value of that business but also gave up having a continuing stake in the fastest-growing segment of the industry.
For its part, SBC Communications has been one of the top performers among the seven so-called Baby Bells. State regulators in its region -- Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Kansas and Missouri -- have tended to be far more protective than California's utilities commissioners in shielding SBC from outside interlopers like AT&T or MCI. As a result, SBC's franchises in local and toll calls have not been eroded nearly as much as those of Pacific Telesis.
SBC has also aggressively acquired cellular properties in markets like Boston, Chicago and Washington. It has the most cellular subscribers -- 3.2 million -- of any Baby Bell.
Then, too, SBC has bet heavily on its proximity to Mexico -- acquiring a 10 percent equity stake in the Mexican national phone company, Telefonos de Mexico, for $1 billion. It is this strategy, analysts said, that best explains why SBC wants to own Pacific Telesis. More than 50 percent of all international calls to Mexico originate in states served by Pacific Telesis and SBC -- namely, California and Texas.
The fact that Pacific Telesis and SBC do not share any state borders is not seen as a major drawback. Although phone companies can cut some costs by consolidating contiguous operations, some analysts said that cost-cutting was not the prime motivation for this merger.
One potential problem in the merger, however, is the difference in the nontelephone strategies of the two companies. Pacific Telesis has committed itself to an aggressive overhaul of its telephone network to enable it to carry television programming. As an interim strategy, the company has even spent heavily to acquire wireless cable providers.
Along with Bell Atlantic and Nynex, Pacific Telesis is a partner in Tele-TV, a media company that has spent $120 million so far to develop interactive video programming.
SBC, by contrast, has been far more tentative about television, spending less to upgrade its network and eschewing wireless cable. SBC is a member of a video consortium, Americast, which has spent a fraction of what Tele-TV is spending to get into the business.
Mr. Whitacre sought to play down the importance of those differences yesterday, through a tepid endorsement of the video business. "In the scheme of things, it's not that big a deal for us," he said.
With the announcement of this deal, the industry's attention will now very likely swivel back to the East Coast and the Nynex-Bell Atlantic talks. Mark Bruneau, the president of Coba M.I.D., a consulting firm based in Boston, predicted at least one more big merger of telephone companies would occur in 1996.
"Instead of seven Bell companies, plus three long-distance carriers," Mr. Bruneau said, "you're going to see four plus two."

HEADLINE: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS;
A Big Day for Mergers in the United States

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Only one day into the second quarter and the mergers business is already on a tear.
United States companies announced about $28 billion worth of mergers yesterday, more than 10 percent of the amount announced in the entire first quarter. Bolstered by rising stock markets and low interest rates, the torrid pace indicates 1996 may exceed the record $866 billion of mergers last year. 
 "It's staggering," said M. William Benedetto, who is with the investment banking firm of Benedetto, Gartland & Greene.
The transactions announced yesterday include: SBC Communications Inc.'s plan to buy Pacific Telesis Group for $17 billion, creating the nation's second-largest telecommunications company; the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's agreement to purchase U.S. Healthcare Inc. for $8.9 billion, forming the largest United States managed-care provider; the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation's bid to buy Teledyne Inc. in a $2.04 billion stock swap, and the Masco Corporation's decision to sell its furniture business to an investment group for $1 billion.
And that does not include the sales announced that were worth less than $1 billion.

HEADLINE: For Helms, His Home State Is Source of Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., April 1

 BODY:
As the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms leaves little doubt how he feels about the Communist leaders of Vietnam.
Nine months after the Clinton Administration formally recognized the Vietnamese Government, Mr. Helms is still blocking financing for the newly opened American Embassy in Hanoi until the President certifies that there are no obstacles left in the search for possible American prisoners of war or the missing in action. In a speech last week he denounced Vietnam as one of Asia's "repressive governments," attacking its record on human rights. 
 So it might seem surprising that on Sunday night Mr. Helms had a convivial, laughter-filled dinner here at the Angus Barn, a popular local steakhouse, with Le Van Bang, Vietnam's Ambassador-designate to Washington, along with six other envoys from Southeast Asia.
"He told me we would get along very well," Mr. Bang said, surprised to find himself at Mr. Helms's dinner table. "After all, he is interested in promoting North Carolina."
In fact, Mr. Helms boasts that he intends to use his chairmanship to bring the world's most lucrative emerging markets to North Carolina's door. And the dinner on Sunday was given by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, a subsidiary of RJR-Nabisco and a longtime supporter of the Senator, which has invested $21 million in a joint-venture cigarette factory in Da Nang.
At a moment when tobacco executives are fending off Federal grand juries and corporate whistle-blowers armed with embarrassing internal documents, Mr. Helms is doing what he can to make sure that North Carolina tobacco gains opportunities in Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand.
Mr. Bang, who is acutely aware that Mr. Helms is Vietnam's chief obstacle in Washington, plays the tobacco card with skill. Opening a presentation to North Carolina business executives this morning, he looked at Mr. Helms in the front row and said, "You know, in Vietnam we have a custom now of greeting each other by offering a cigarette."
Later, Mr. Helms said he was impressed, both with Mr. Bang and the market opportunities. "I was with some Vietnamese recently, and some of them were smoking two cigarettes at the same time," he said. "That's the kind of customers we need!"
Then, pondering his own enthusiasm, he added: "Well, not exactly."
In fact, among the ambassadors here only Mr. Bang seemed truly interested in North Carolina's traditional crop, while the rest had come to strike up relationships with biotechnology and electronics companies in Research Triangle Park and to meet with regional bankers.
But the real drawing card was Mr. Helms, whose threats to cut off China's trade privileges and sharp critiques of Administration policy toward Japan, Taiwan and India have made him the biggest wild card in American policy toward Asia.
So when Mr. Helms invited the ambassadors from all seven countries in the Association for Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, to visit his home state for three days, including a excursion of more than two hours on Tuesday to the R. J. Reynolds tobacco factory in Winston-Salem that is closed to reporters, they all cleared their calendars.
"When Mr. Helms invites, everbody comes to listen," said S. R. Nathan, the Ambassador from Singapore -- where almost every vice, starting with smoking in public, is punishable by a stiff fine or worse.
Mr. Helms's interest in Asean is new, fueled by the phenomenal growth of their economies -- the gross national products of the seven countries had roughly doubled over the last five years, and totaled more than half a trillion dollars last year -- and their relative openness to American investment. "I made up my mind when I became the second North Carolinian in history to head the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that I would do all I could to promote the exports of North Carolina," he said today, "as well as other parts of the country."
His eagerness meshes nicely with the strategy for dealing with Washington that Japan pioneered and other Asian nations follow today: do your deals in the right Congressional district. Like the Japanese, other Asian countries are beginning to spread their contracts and investments around the country, to build influence in Congress.
Mr. Helms's chairmanship is therefore good news for North Carolina. But it is also the hope of the tobacco industry abroad, because the Clinton Administration has put the brakes on Washington's once aggressive efforts to pry open markets in Asia to the cigarette trade.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representive, will still negotiate market openings on behalf of American cigarette makers. But he invites officials from the Department of Health and Human Services and the Environmental Protection Agency to sit in on the talks to evaluate whether the other nation's trade restrictions are actually "legitimate efforts to address health issues," as the Administration puts it.
Recently South Korea passed the test, and the Administration revised a Reagan-era trade agreement to permit the South Koreans to impose any restrictions they want on cigarette advertising or other promotions, as long as the same rules apply to South Korean makers.
"Jesse's their last friend abroad," an Asian diplomat on the tour of North Carolina said of the American tobacco makers.
Sometimes, as in the case of Vietnam, that results in some interesting diplomatic footwork for Mr. Helms. Faced with the conflicting pressures of his disdain for its Communist regime and his interest in promoting business in his state, he has simultaneously praised Mr. Bang here and bashed his Government. "He's my friend," he said this morning, just before denouncing Vietnam today before the Asean representatives as repressive and suggesting that the country is still blocking a full accounting of missing American soldiers.
Mr. Helms makes it clear that he did not specifically invite the Vietnamese Ambassador-designate to North Carolina, but since Vietnam joined Asean last summer, he could hardly exclude one country. "I'm trying to work with the Ambassador," he said. "We have a give and take, and we're all going to profit from it."
Mr. Bang is technically not yet the Ambassador because the United States has yet to appoint its first ambassador to Vietnam. But even without the title, the slight, energetic Mr. Bang is already lobbying hard in Washington for a trade agreement with the United States and the low-tariff benefits that come with "most-favored nation" status. He knows the 74-year-old Mr. Helms is the key to obtaining any of those accords, and he expects the process will take a lot of massaging, and a lot of cigarettes.
But Vietnam, he says, is ready to rise to the challenge.
"We'll smoke for 10 more years, until we are a more developed country," he predicted. "Then we'll quit, just like you."

HEADLINE: U.N. Plans Deep Cuts In Budget For First Time

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 1

 BODY:
Caught in a financial crisis and constrained by the first no-growth budget in its history, the United Nations expects to cut $250 million from its operating expenses by the end of 1997, the organization's chief administrative officer said today. Of the total, $98 million in savings has already been identified.
The official, Joseph E. Connor, Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, said at a news conference that the United Nations hoped to eliminate 800 professional jobs. Severance and other costs are estimated at $30 million, but the layoffs should yield substantial long-term savings, he said, adding that job evaluations would identify candidates for dismissal. 
 Speaking in language almost never heard in this bastion of international bureaucracy, Mr. Connor, a former chief executive of Price Waterhouse, said there were "too many people in this organization doing the same job for 20 years."
"Mobility in a world organization is very, very important," he said, adding that there was "nothing like a little creative tension" to get the United Nations moving.
For the first time in the half-century of its existence, the United Nations will scale down not only personnel but also reports and publications, policy analyses and construction and repair costs. Upgrading telecommunications and interpreting equipment has been put on hold.
The United States mission greeted the news with elation. The Administration has said the United Nations must demonstrate that the organization can be slimmed down, or Congress will never even start to pay the $1.5 billion that Washington owes in dues and assessments.
James P. Rubin, spokesman for the American mission, said today, "Reforming the United Nations is no easy task, but this does mark a milestone in our efforts to force it to downsize and to come to grips with the problems of unnecessary construction, redundant meetings and unnecessary paperwork."
To prevent backsliding, the Administration has proposed a five-year plan to Congress during which money would be released for arrears as long as reforms continued. But many diplomats fear Congress will reject the plan, leaving others to pay.
Many diplomats see Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali as needling the United States in a report that proposes cuts in some areas of special interest to Washington. Mr. Connor's remarks were based on that report.
Americans hold more Secretariat jobs than citizens of any other nation, and American companies get about half the procurement orders -- $197 million of $396 million in 1995.
The largest cuts will come in administrative services, including conference costs, weekend and night work, publications, statistical and policy analyses and planning programs to fight poverty and enhance the status of women, the Secretary General said.
Allocations for regional economic commissions for Africa, Asia and the Pacific, Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean and Western Asia, are to be reduced sharply. The work of the commissions often duplicates that of other development bodies, but American diplomats say the proposed reductions -- totaling around $18 million -- are not enough.
Cuts will also be made in appropriations to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the Human Rights Center, both in Geneva.
In demanding a no-growth budget, the United States opened itself to some unexpected consequences that added tension to the increasingly frayed relationships between Washington and the United Nations, and between the Secretary General and Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States representative.
Most recently Mr. Boutros-Ghali, chafing under new restraints, threatened to cut off two programs the United States strongly supports: the human rights missions in Guatemala and Haiti. Both are considered successes.
He said he was trying to alert member nations to the untenable situation they create when they order new missions without allocations to pay for them.
If this was intended to get Washington's attention, it did. Mr. Rubin, the American spokesman, said the Secretary General should look for other cuts, and promised a fight to keep the Haiti and Guatemala programs, which could cost $52 million over two years.
In a letter March 12 to the President of the Assembly, Diego Freitas do Amaral of Portugal, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said there was no way to pay for human rights work in Guatemala and Haiti. Similar constraints could affect Burundi, Rwanda and El Salvador.
The Secretary General said this was not just a budgetary problem, but an issue that "goes to the heart of the purposes for which this organization was created." 
 Because of another editing error, the article referred incorrectly to a budget cut of $98 million. Out of a proposed $250 million in overall cuts, the $98 million was trimmed last year; the sum does not represent cuts that have been identified in this year's budget.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 3, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about trimming the United Nations' 1996-97 budget misstated the method proposed for reducing the staff. The plan is for buyouts, not layoffs; a new system of performance evaluations could lead to dismissals later.

HEADLINE: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE INDUSTRY;
Managed Care Empires in the Making

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Leonard Abramson decided about a year ago that U.S. Healthcare Inc., his enormously successful health maintenance organization, needed a new strategy to keep its profits up. A flock of competing H.M.O.'s, led by Oxford Health Systems, was vying for customers on his home turf, in Philadelphia and New Jersey. Even more threatening, hospitals and doctors were melding into groups big enough to resist when the H.M.O.'s try to squeeze their fees.
Mr. Abramson, the founder and chief executive of U.S. Healthcare, turned over daily operations to his lieutenants and set out to find a strategic partner. He ended up selling his managed care company to the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, he said yesterday, to get the "mass we needed, the power to negotiate with the physicians, the hospitals, the drug companies" and force down their charges. 
 The deal is the biggest in a wave of consolidation as health care companies seek to become big enough to get the upper hand in negotiating prices with their medical suppliers so they can woo employers with low-cost health plans.
In many cases, the deals have involved mergers between managed care companies and between managed care companies and traditional insurers. But in the future competition may come from a different direction. Some analysts say that the most formidable competitors might be groups of hospitals and doctors that have united to deal directly with employers and skip the managed care middleman.
Aetna's deal to buy U.S. Healthcare for $8.8 billion in cash and stock will create a combined health care business that would cover 14 million people. Of those, 4.2 million would be in health maintenance organizations, the most tightly controlled system of delivering care. In addition, Aetna has 3.8 million people in traditional insurance plans. The remainder would be in other types of managed care plans.
In a number of other recent deals, managed-care companies have acquired insurance companies that had big groups of customers in traditional lines of fee-for-service coverage. In these deals, the insurers also hope to broaden their appeal to employers by offering a variety of lines and eventually to convert their people to managed care, under which the payer's costs are lower and insurer's profits are higher.
Last year the United Healthcare Corporation, a big health maintenance organization based in Minneapolis, bought Metrahealth, a joint health insurance venture of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Travelers Life Insurance Company, in a deal valued at $1.65 billion.
And there were at least three smaller acquisitions recently of insurance companies by H.M.O.'s: Last January, California-based Wellpoint Health Networks bought the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company. Last year, Humana Inc., based in Louisville, Ky., bought Emphesys Financial Group of Green Bay, Wis. And HealthSource, based in Concord, N.H., bought the Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company of Chattanooga, Tenn.
"There are probably going to be only three to five national players in five years or so," said Larry Feinberg, a general partner in New York with Oracle Partners, a health care investment firm. "The whole health care market is overbuilt. We are still pretty early in the ball game in terms of consolidation."
Doug Sherlock, an analyst in Philadelphia with the Sherlock Company, a health care investment banking firm, recalled that Wall Street analysts used to say that health maintenance organizations were a temporary fad that would be taken over by the insurance companies. "It looks like the little fish ate the big fish," he said.
Ellie Kerns, a securities analyst in Boston with Alex. Brown & Sons, said most managed care companies needed to expand into new markets, which could be a drain on earnings while taking years for them to establish a forceful presence.
U.S. Healthcare, which already has networks with 12,000 primary-care doctors in 13 states, could form combinations with Aetna in 21 states where the Hartford-based insurer has 20,000 primary-care doctors in its networks. These doctors -- including internists, general practitioners and pediatricians -- play a central role in restraining the costs of care.
Mr. Abramson, who would be Aetna's largest shareholder under the deal, said he expected the insurers to continue growing, while hospitals will be "downsizing and closing." He was skeptical about the prospects for a hospital company entering the health insurance business, as the Columbia-HCA Hospital Corporation says it will do in Cleveland and perhaps other markets. Columbia-HCA announced last Friday that it had agreed to buy most of the business of Cleveland-based Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio for $299.5 million.
"Look what happened to Dave Jones, and he is a smart guy," Mr. Abramson said, referring to problems that arose when Mr. Jones's combination H.M.O. and hospital company, Humana, angered doctors and competing insurers, who boycotted the hospitals. Columbia eventually bought the Humana hospitals.
But Rick Scott, chief executive of Columbia-HCA, thinks things will work out differently in Cleveland, where Blue Cross is the biggest health insurer.
Indeed, Mr. Feinberg of Oracle thinks the balance of power may be shifting to hospitals and doctors at the expense of the insurers.
"The H.M.O.'s have had the greatest power over the last five years, relative to physicians and hospitals," he said. "They had the information, the demographic data about patients, and they were smart enough to understand what their costs would be."
Now, he said, "Hospitals and physicians are becoming empowered with better understanding of demographics and costs. For H.M.O.'s over the long term, this will have a negative impact on the balance of power."
J.D. Kleinke, an economist in Baltimore with HCIA, a health care information company, said the Aetna deal was "a classic consolidation play in an industry that is fragmented and ultimately will shake out." He added, "Unfortunately I think it will shake out a lot more drastically and thoroughly than Aetna realizes in the long term, say over 10 years."
Mr. Kleinke said "the Columbia-HCA purchase of an insurer was much more illustrative of where the entire industry is going in the long term." He said hospital groups in Minneapolis, Detroit, Portland, Ore., and Southern California were "already eliminating the middleman, the H.M.O.," and dealing directly with payers such as employers.
At at least one big customer, the Xerox Corporation, the amount of money involved in the Aetna purchase was worrisome. "As a purchaser I always get nervous when lots of money is shelled out by one organization that is acquiring another, say for $9 billion," said Helen Darling, manager of health care strategy at Xerox.
She added: "My worry is that the acquiring company will want to recoup their investment at a time when we are trying to control costs. I would watch them both like hawks, nervously worrying that this will fuel medical inflation, and that this might make everyone, including legislators, more cynical about managed care."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about mergers in the health care industry misstated terms of two recent acquisitions. Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. bought the group life and health division of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, while Healthsource Inc. bought the medical services business of the Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company. Neither buyer acquired an entire company.
