HEADLINE: Splendor in the Mud: Unraveling the Lives of Anacondas

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON 

DATELINE: MANTECAL, Venezuela

 BODY:
IN one of the murky, hyacinth-choked pools in these vast savannas, whorls of thick spotted coils appear and disappear at the water's surface, hinting at the mass of snake hidden below. Three researchers tensely circle their submerged quarry when suddenly, cornered, the leviathan strikes, her dripping jaws shooting out of the water. Instantly they are upon her, grabbing head and tail, and she upon them, coils tightening around arms, legs, waists. For a moment it seems an even fight as the men, knotted in serpent, struggle even to remain upright. But eventually they manage to extract all 15 feet of her from the muddy lagoon. She is taken, the anaconda, the biggest snake in the world.
Here in these savannas, as elsewhere, the giant anaconda provokes both wonder and fear. Yet almost no scientific studies have been done that might dispel the colorful folklore of monstrous man-eating horned snakes that breathe poisonous gas and have the power to hypnotize human victims. 
 Now, in what researchers say is the first field study of the species, a team of American and Venezuelan biologists is providing a long-awaited glimpse into the life of this mysterious snake and beginning to sort anaconda fact from fiction.
"It's the only project of its kind in the world," said Dr. Robert Henderson, curator of herpetology at the Milwaukee Public Museum and co-author of the forthcoming book "Tales of Giant Snakes: A Historical Natural History of Anacondas and Pythons" (Krieger Publishing). "This is a wonderfully spectacular snake that's piqued the imagination of people for literally hundreds of years."
Researchers say that though poorly understood, the anaconda is far from untouched by humans, with thousands of skins traded each year, many illegally, for use in boots, belts and wallets. Biologists say the new work will help wildlife managers and conservationists to decide how the illegal trade might be replaced with a managed harvest aimed at conserving the species.
Almost nothing is known of anacondas' life in the wild. The snakes are secretive and often lie submerged in inaccessible rivers and lagoons. Biologists seeking to study anacondas must first catch them, one by one. No capture is routine: finding and subduing a single snake can easily require the determined efforts of three or four researchers.
The species, known as Eunectes murinus, ranges throughout South America's Orinoco and Amazon River basins. But Dr. John Thorbjarnarson, a conservation biologist at the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York, and his team chose to study the snakes here in the Venezuelan savannas, known as the llanos, at a ranch called Hato El Cedral.
"I'd kept hearing about this mythical place," said Dr. Thorbjarnarson who heads the joint effort of the Wildlife Conservation Society and Profauna, Venezuela's national wildlife department. "I'd heard these tales of El Cedral, that snakes were everywhere, hanging from the trees, that you had to push them out of the road."
A working cattle ranch, El Cedral is also a preserve rich enough in wildlife to attract a healthy ecotourism trade, particularly in the dry season. Its extensive savannas, navigable only by boat in the rainy season, turn in dry weather into a patchwork of isolated pools, where more than 500 snakes have been found and marked since the project began in 1992.
In tracking these snakes, biologists have got a first peek into the love life of anacondas. When it comes to anaconda sex, they have found, the more the merrier. In the breeding season, which has now begun in the llanos, a single female can be found entwined with as many as 12 much smaller males in a heaping mass known as a mating ball. Researchers say the females appear to hang out in a pool of water, draped in and visited by as many as 17 consorts for as long as four to six weeks.
"Talk about foreplay," said Jesus Rivas, an ecologist at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville who has carried out much of the field work along with Maria Munoz, an ecologist at Simon Bolivar University in Caracas, Venezuela.
The discovery of the mating balls raises numerous questions, including just which of the males fathers the snakes and what the snakes are doing in these heaps for so long. To begin to answer these questions, Mr. Rivas is extracting blood from females, males and newborns to determine paternity using DNA tests. Researchers are also implanting radiotransmitters in young snakes to learn their fate, which for many is probably to make a snack for a caiman, the alligator-like creature that throngs the murky waters.
Biologists have found that life is dangerous for the adult anacondas too, even though they are the top predators. For while the anacondas feed on relatively docile prey like ducks, some of their other meals can be quite dangerous. After subduing their victims in squeezing coils, asphyxiating and sometimes drowning them as well, anacondas typically swallow their prey head-first. Large females can eat giant rodents called capybara, which reach the size of a small dog, and even caimans and white-tailed deer. But it is not a simple matter to swallow a five-foot-long caiman or to fight off sharp-clawed capybara struggling to free a mate. The female anacondas often bear numerous scars as the price of lunch.
Some snakes' appetites outstrip their intellect. Dr. Thorbjarnarson said he once found a dead deer with anaconda teeth marks on its heavily antlered head: the snake had presumably tried again and again to swallow the buck headfirst until the antlers forced it to accept defeat. Dr. Thorbjarnarson said he had also heard of anacondas consuming deer from the rear only to discover at the end a pair of antlers too magnificent to swallow. One snake found by the biologists had sliced itself open by gulping down a turtle with razor sharp shell edges.
Another way of studying the anacondas' menu is by examination of the feces. Even a large capybara, after its transit through an anaconda, is reduced to little more than a few claws and some tufts of fur. With turtles there may be a bit of shell and with caiman perhaps some tell-tale scaly skin.
Anacondas are rumored to partake of humans as well. In the llanos when someone is missing, fingers are often pointed at the giant snake, but biologists say there is no real evidence so far that people are part of the anaconda diet.
For females, the half-year long pregnancy is also a tough experience. While pregnant, they eat little or nothing. Yet these fasting females, said Bill Holmstrom, another researcher on the project from the Wildlife Conservation Society, can give birth to as many as 78 or more baby snakes. After a birth, a female's weight can drop by nearly half.
Two of the biologists, Mr. Rivas and Ms. Munoz, decided to make a study of the gestating females. To make sure the snakes were indeed pregnant, they found they had to establish a kind of reptilian maternity ward, where they checked the waiting mothers with ultrasound.
Seeking to establish the range required by an anaconda, the biologists tagged the snakes with radiotransmitters. They found that during the dry season, the snakes roam a regular area to which they return each year. Researchers say males, the smaller of the sexes, and nonpregnant females seem to remain in a 50-acre area. On the other hand, pregnant females, often among the biggest and bulkiest of anacondas, barely move at all, content to keep within a mere third of an acre until the job is done, sunning their ever more hulking bodies on the water's banks.
The biologists here say they still do not know enough to judge whether anacondas can be harvested safely and profitably. In particular, because of the difficulty of taking an anaconda census, researchers are concerned that it might be easy to overharvest a population without even knowing it.
Dr. Gordon M. Burghardt, an evolutionary ethologist at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville, said the anaconda researchers had developed a handful of tricks of the trade that should be of great help to others beginning work on giant snakes. The subject of the researchers' most recent publication is the sock trick.
If a sock is pulled over an anaconda's head, it calms the snake, allowing researchers to transport it to their makeshift laboratory. But measuring even such a relaxed anaconda can be difficult. Researchers, after much experimentation, found the most reliable method was to trace the snake's long, coiled spine with a string, which is then measured.
When it comes to anacondas, questions of weight and length loom large. So far at Hato El Cedral, the heaviest snake has weighed in at 214 pounds and the longest at more than 17 1/2 feet.
While clearly the heaviest snake in the world, anacondas get competition from reticulated pythons when it comes to length. Reports of anacondas that are 60, even 150 feet long, have never been verified. Dr. Thorbjarnarson said the tallest of these tales was of a snake so long it took two days' march to get from one end to the other. He said the most frequently cited, and presumably reliable, report of an outsized anaconda is of a Colombian snake that was said to have measured 37 1/2 feet with a surveyor's tape. It subsequently escaped.
Even in the hands of biologists determined to take accurate readings, a snake that can tense and relax is hard to measure. The fear and boasting that such creatures inspire may also contribute to a general inflation in reported sizes.
So while scientific study has begun to replace legend, the anaconda still has not yielded its secrets to probe and calipers.
Sometime around 1910, Theodore Roosevelt offered a $1,000 reward to anyone presenting a live snake measuring 30 feet or more. Over the years the reward has been increased and the Wildlife Conservation Society's offer now stands at $50,000, a reward that to this day remains uncollected.

HEADLINE: In A-Plant's Backyard in Connecticut, Trust Ebbs

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: WATERFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
At the very tip of this town, where Millstone Point forms the eastern shore of Niantic Bay, three nuclear power plants owned by Northeast Utilities sit idle, under intense scrutiny by Federal regulators because of a long record of safety-procedure violations.
In Waterford, where the reactors are largely out of sight, and next door in East Lyme, where they dominate the view from Main Street along the bay, people who have lived with atomic energy in their backyard for nearly three decades are re-examining their comfort level, knowing now that the state's largest utility skimped on safety to cut costs. 
 In a corner of Connecticut where nuclear-related industries have powered the economy since the U.S.S. Nautilus was built in Groton in the early 50's, confidence in the Millstone reactors remains high. Of New London County's 270,000 residents, 40,000 are active or retired personnel from the Navy base in Groton or their relatives, and tens of thousands more work at the Electric Boat shipyard, or are related to workers there, where nuclear-powered submarines are built, or work at Millstone itself.
But increasingly, the confidence expressed is personal, based on faith in the friends and neighbors who work on Millstone Point, rather than trust in Northeast Utilities or its watchdog, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
"I have a philosophy about this that I think many people share," said David Cini, the First Selectman of East Lyme. "I know people at Millstone, and I believe that the hundreds of people who work there all want to be safe. These are not people who would allow things to happen to jeopardize the safety of their families and themselves."
Laura Fitch, the 80-year-old president of the Waterford Historical Society, put her opinion more bluntly. "We live with these people who work there, and I assume they know what they're doing," she said. "I'd like to think that none of them want to die of radiation, and I don't worry about what I don't have control over."
There are people, of course, who do worry, particularly the whistle-blowing employees at Millstone who drew attention to lax safety procedures there, and members of a citizens group who helped publicize their charges.
The focus of the charges was the utility's practice of replacing all fuel rods in Millstone 1 at one time, putting a full load of hot radioactive rods in water-cooled holding tanks for spent fuel, instead of only a third at a time as required by its operating license.
As a result of their efforts, in January the Nuclear Regulatory Commission put Millstone 1, Millstone 2 and Millstone 3, once among the nation's best-managed nuclear plants, on its watch list of troubled plants. They were safe, the agency said, but it cited years of violations as the utility tried to cut maintenance costs.
Then in March, Time published a cover story charging the Nuclear Regulatory Commission with failures to rein in nuclear utilities that put savings before safety, and Millstone was its chief example.
In a town where utility booklets on what to do in case of a nuclear accident arrive in the mail once a year, where telephone books show evacuation routes, where the Millstone sirens are heard during tests the first Wednesday of the month, few people called Waterford's First Selectman, Tony Sheridan, to express alarm.
Northeast Utilities had been a good neighbor, Mr. Sheridan said. Its property taxes pay for 70 percent of the town's budget, its employees serve on town boards, and in an area where jobs building submarines are being replaced by jobs dealing cards at casinos, it is a valued employer, too.
"People here tend not to be uncomfortable with nuclear power -- we build the finest nuclear submarines in the world here -- though they may be uncomfortable with the carelessness of Northeast Utilities and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission," he said. "If you talk to people, it's not a panic, but there is a concern that wasn't here a year ago. Most people are generous with their trust, but once you lose it, it's lost, and that's what Northeast Utilities should be concerned about."
Northeast Utilities has already lost the trust of its whistle-blowers and many members of a group called the Citizens Regulatory Commission that has rallied around them. While the group's mission is to see that the Millstone plants follow Federal regulations, some members say they do not think that any nuclear power plant can be operated safely.
Having begun to accept the possibility of a nuclear accident in their community, they now question every contingency: the practicality of the evacuation plan, and the plants' protection from earthquakes, hurricanes and planes falling from the sky.
"They make it seem like you're going on vacation," Ellen Lazerow, a New London resident who belongs to the group, said of the evacuation booklet. Yet the utility, she said, advises parents to leave town without picking up children at school, trusting buses to get them.
The Citizens Regulatory Commission's founder, Susan Perry Luxton, a Waterford native, said that people had put too much trust in Northeast Utilities and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
"I think I was in a state of denial," she said. "I never really liked nuclear power, but when it came in, I was in high school. We never learned much about nuclear power. There was talk about how electricity was going to be cheap, and so people were putting electric heat in their houses."
Three years ago, she said, she bought her dream house on Great Neck Road, directly east of Millstone, to raise a second family. So last summer, when she read about the safety concerns raised by a Millstone employee, George Galatis, she took it personally.
"I'm finally settled here for life," Ms. Luxton said, "and then to realize that Northeast Utilities is screwing up a mile away, I saw red."
Mr. Sheridan credits Ms. Luxton's group for helping the whistle blowers to be heard, and for raising public awareness about what he sees as the real problem at Millstone: the holding tanks contain the reactors' spent fuel because the Federal Government has not established a disposal site. People should be concerned, he said, over the existence of a nuclear dump on Millstone Point.
But most people also express confidence that the problems will now be resolved. Some say that the people who are most alarmed don't understand how small the risks are.
"Doing nuclear power is expensive, so in some ways it's counter to someone trying to make a profit," said J. W. (Bill) Sheehan, a former submarine commander. But the people who have responded emotionally, he said, "don't understand what is an acceptable risk."
"They don't recognize when they go out their door in the morning and get in their car," he said, "that they have entered an area of risk."
That stark divide between those who are alarmed and those who feel reassured, however, is typical when people confront risks from radiation and other invisible, long-lasting threats to health, sociologists say.
In areas like New London County, or southern Nevada, where the population is long accustomed to a military nuclear presence, people's confidence may be higher to begin with, said Kai Erikson, a professor of sociology and American studies at Yale who has studied the nuclear accident at the Three Mile Island plant in Pennsylvania. But when people lose trust, they tend to lose it completely, he said.
"Having invested a great deal of faith in one institution, or technology, or company, and having come to feel that they haven't been treated fairly by it, they begin to have questions about almost everything," he said. "The whole world seems less reliable."
Northeast Utilities, at the request of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, is now going over every detail of Millstone 1 and Millstone 2 to insure that upon restarting, they will operate in exact compliance with all specifications and procedures.
"All of our employees have been asked to examine their work, past and present, and to identify and to help resolve any issues they feel need to be followed up on," said a company spokeswoman, Deborah Beauchamp.
But another challenge for the company, Professor Erikson said, is to acknowledge every public concern, no matter how small the actual risk.
Engineers, he said, calculate risks in different ways from, say, mothers of small children, and denying there is any risk because the odds are extremely low can often fuel larger, more unreasonable doubts.
"To be a mother and to have children is to be afraid of the future in ways that demand respect," he said. "It would make a very great difference if someone came along and said, "I understand your fear and I worry about that, too, but here are the actual odds.' "

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Remains Little Changed; Jobless Data on Friday Awaited

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed in quiet trading yesterday ahead of the Passover and Good Friday observances later in the week.
Currency traders were also cautious ahead of Friday's widely awaited Government report on the job market in March. The previous employment report showed the creation of 705,000 jobs in February, stunning financial markets and raising worries among investors that the economy was overheating, possibly leading to a burst of inflation. 
 Many traders said they were content to stay on the sidelines until Friday's jobs report came out.
"The fact that we have a payrolls number on Friday, which is typically unpredictable, means people aren't willing to put on big positions ahead of that," said John Rothfield, an international economist at Nationsbanc-CRT.
The dollar managed to climb as high as 107.62 Japanese yen during trading in Asia and New York.
But it retreated as some Japanese companies sold dollars to capitalize on the currency's strength, traders said. There were also rumors that a large hedge fund based in the United States sold dollars for yen.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 107.57 yen, up from 107.56 yen on Monday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4827 German marks, down from 1.4835 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5227 from $1.5243.
Trading is expected to be thin this week, with the Jewish observance of Passover beginning tonight, and then Good Friday. Most European financial markets will be closed on Friday and Monday. United States stock markets will be closed on Friday.
While the coming employment report all but paralyzed foreign exchange traders, there were factors suggesting the dollar will continue its recent rally against the yen, traders and analysts said.
There are expectations in the foreign exchange market that the dollar "is going to head higher almost regardless of what happens with payrolls," said Kevin Harris, an international economist at MCM Currency Watch.
Japanese investors are expected to shift more funds abroad now that the new Japanese fiscal year has started, which would tend to lift the dollar.
"The new year leads to anticipation that there'll be an outflow of savings from Japan into other markets," Mr. Harris said.

HEADLINE: An African Forest Harbors Vast Wealth and Peril

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: EVELA, Gabon

 BODY:
The forest grows so thick at the edge of this tiny settlement that even the N'tem River, a sizable Central African waterway, is completely obscured in the riotous greenery. Asked what lies beyond, a Fang villager shrugs and says "nothing."
From time immemorial, for the Fang -- one of the Bantu peoples who make up the bulk of Central Africa's population -- this area has been known as the edge of the world. But in fact, the land beyond this point has always been home to others: small groups of Pygmies, whose hunting-and-gathering livelihood had until recently changed little in a millennium. 
 The equatorial forest inhabited by Gabon's Pygmies, an area about the size of New York state, is at the heart of Africa's last intact belt of rain forest. It is still peopled by fewer than 40,000 inhabitants. But now it is facing changes of a pace and magnitude far greater than anyone here, Fang or Pygmy, has yet grasped.
Only a few dozen miles from this village, convoys of lumber trucks filled with stone are bringing material to French-led crews laying the paved roads that will open up this area as never before. In the capital, Libreville, and in the headquarters of European logging companies, plans are already being laid for the forest's exploitation.
At the same time, groups from the World Wildlife Fund to the World Bank are racing to mount efforts to inventory the huge catalogue of plant and animal species that live here and to identify areas for strict conservation on Gabon's last frontier for commercial forestry.
With its sparse human population and its dense canopy still intact, international environmental experts say that what happens to this jungle in Gabon will be an important bellwether for Africa's last major belt of relatively pristine rain forest, a vast area that stretches from the continent's equatorial coast across Gabon and well into the Congo River basin deep in Zaire.
"A lot of money is being spent in places like Brazil, in areas trying to rescue forests that have already been devastated," said Kathryn Simons, an American environmentalist who is studying conservation efforts in Gabon. "In Central Africa, where relatively little has been done so far, we have a unique opportunity to save a major tropical forest before it is destroyed."
It was in this forest, too, that the Ebola virus appeared in humans last year, killing some people in Gabon before it swept into Zaire and killed 244 others. Some experts warn that opening the forest, where unidentified animals are believed to harbor the disease, could unleash more epidemics.
If northern Gabon still boasts some of Central Africa's densest remaining woodlands, in particular the Minkebe forest, both experts and residents of this area can point to signs of an endangered future. Major logging companies and sawmills have not yet reached this forest, but already to the south and east of here, small operators have begun chipping away at this habitat in search of Okoume, the most readily exploitable tree species, which is used mostly for plywood.
Wildcat gold miners, too, have been reported operating deep in the forest, where they fell trees and dig deep pits, dumping mercury and other highly toxic chemicals in the ground or in streams.
An arduous two-week hike away from Evela, along ancient footpaths traversed by thick columns of army ants and spied upon by tree leopards, live Pygmies who have never set eyes on Westerners. But already, around the fringes of the Minkebe forest, more and more Pygmies are being drawn into the life of modern Africa and its cash economy.
Throughout Gabon, wild game is considered choice dining. And in towns like this and in nearby Minvoul, Pygmies wait for city folk or Bantu agriculturists to hire their services as master hunters of the prized forest elephants.
Setting out armed with old 12-gauge shotguns and a few shells each, the hunters can spend weeks in the forest, wandering a landscape teeming with wildlife. The forest's estimated 65,000 elephants, along with Zaire's elephant population the largest in Africa, are the most prized game, but the array of potential targets is mind-boggling.
Pygmy hunters say their prizes include 30-foot boa constrictors, antelopes, gorillas, porcupines, boars and monkeys of all kinds. But if the variety is rich, the Pygmies themselves say that their search for game becomes more difficult each year as the hunting parties multiply.
"When we were young men, the hunt was done with arrows," said Omer Amaya, a 58-year-old Pygmy hunter whose settlement lies in a forest clearing at the edge of Minvoul. "We could go out for eight or nine hours and come home with a big catch. Nowadays you must walk at least three days before you can count on even seeing anything interesting."
For the hunters, the reasons for this increasing scarcity seem simple: their hunting has thinned game populations. "Wherever the barrel of the gun belches, the animals will try to avoid," said Hilarion Mikou. "After a time, if all is quiet, the animals will come back."
For environmental experts, however, the picture is more complex. "These forests are still primary forests in their structure, but already they are being exploited," said Marc Languy, a forest expert with the World Wildlife Fund. "We have noted a decrease of 80 percent in chimpanzee populations. If it is true that they can rebound, this is a process that might take 15 or 20 years."
The recent outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus in the town of Mayibout, another small Bantu outpost in the forest 130 miles to the southeast of here, has reminded many of another possible consequence of the forest encroachment. The outbreak killed less than 20 people in Gabon, but swept through the Zairian town of Kikwit with devastating effects last year, quickly killing 244 people.
The origins of the virus are not known, but it is presumed to have a natural host somewhere in the forest, from which it infects primates. Those who died in Gabon had recently feasted on chimpanzee meat.
Scientists at a major international conference on Ebola held in Kinshasa, Zaire, earlier this month theorized that environmental damage to previously pristine forest areas brought about the emergence of Ebola as a major health threat.
"In Gabon, gold prospectors went deep into the forest, they cut down trees in all directions, they dug up and destroyed a part of this environment" said Jean-Jacques Muyembe, a Zairian Ebola researcher. "This gave rise to the emergence of the virus." His theory is that the virus was dormant until its environment was so severely disrupted.
Pygmy hunters, meanwhile, say that in recent months they have encountered increasing numbers of dead gorillas and chimpanzees in the forest, where they have been felled by a mysterious affliction.
"You can hardly find any live gorillas anymore," said Mr. Mikou. "We've never seen this before. A big game animal that fears nothing is just dropping dead."
If conservation groups are beginning to marshal an effort to save Gabon's northern forests from the heavy logging that has taken place almost everywhere else in this country, tropical wood interests would seem to have the early upper hand.
A Dutch concern known as Wijima has already secured rights to just over one million acres of the Minkebe forest. And Gabon's President, Omar Bongo, has roped off another 542,000 acres of virgin forest for logging, just to the south of Minkebe.
"This is the last place that good supplies of wood are left in the country," said Pierre Mezui M'Eyie, a Government forest inspector based in the provincial capital of Oyem. "Right now, no one seems to know what kind of wealth there is here, but once the first commercial permits are issued, you will see a flood of applications.
"Then is only a matter of time before the Minkebe is destroyed."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, bolstered by reports that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation.
One report, on leading economic indicators, showed a gain that was stronger than expected. But the market viewed the improvements as recoveries from sharp weather-related setbacks and not indicative of a trend that could keep the Federal Reserve from cutting short-term interest rates in the coming months. Bond prices were also supported by a weekly survey of retail sales that showed weakness and by a firm dollar. 
 Still, the rise in bond prices came on light volume, with many market participants reluctant to take positions ahead of the March employment report due to be released on Friday.
"In front of the employment report it would be unwise if not irresponsible for anyone to make big bets," said David Ader, managing fixed-income anlayst at Technical Data in Boston,
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32, to 92 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.59 percent from 6.64 percent on Monday.
The Conference Board reported yesterday that the monthly index of leading indicators rose 1.3 percent in February, exceeding the market's expectations for a gain of 1.1 percent. But traders and analysts viewed the gain as a rebound from a setback in January caused by a blizzard.
"As with much of the other weather-related spikes we've seen, the leading indicators will fail to produce a clear indication of economic activity until more data is offered from this series in the coming months," said Marilyn Schaja of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, estimated that about 60 percent of the jump in the indicators reflected a weather-related recovery in the manufacturing workweek. The report, he said, "merely confirmed the market-friendly scenario of moderate growth ahead."
The Commerce Department yesterday released its revised estimate of the gross domestic product in the fourth quarter, and that also fell short of expectations. The report said the economy grew at an annual pace of five-tenths of 1 percent in the last three months of 1995, down from an earlier estimate of nine-tenths of 1 percent. Some analysts had been expecting a revision of seven-tenths of 1 percent. The Commerce Department report suggested that the economy was weaker than many had thought last year.
Weakness was also seen in the Johnson Redbook survey, released in the afternoon, which showed a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales last week.
Bond prices received additional support yesterday from expectations that the Federal Reserve would soon conduct a coupon pass, in which the Fed enters the market to buy certain maturities to add cash to the banking system. It is used to address seasonal shortages of reserves, and is not a signal of any change in monetary policy. Traders say the coupon pass gives dealers an opportunity to sell Treasury securities piling up in inventory to a ready buyer.
At yesterday's Treasury auctions of short-term maturities, the Treasury sold $14 billion of 15-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.29 percent, and $11.1 billion of 22-day bills at 5.25 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of new one-year bills and 15-day and 22-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: Ross David Siragusa, 89; Founded a Major Maker of Appliances

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Ross David Siragusa, who founded the Admiral Corporation and led its growth from a small radio manufacturer to one of the country's leading makers of televisions, audio products, refrigerators and other home appliances, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 89.
Admiral, which was founded in 1934 as the Continental Radio and Television Corporation, was Mr. Siragusa's second electronics venture. The first, the Transformer Corporation of America, was founded in 1924, after Mr. Siragusa graduated from Loyola Academy High School in Chicago. The company grew quickly by selling battery chargers for radios, which in that era used "wet" batteries that needed frequent recharging. 
 By 1929, Mr. Siragusa's company was the largest seller of radio transformers in the country, and its founder, flush with success, turned down an offer to buy the company for more than $5 million. But five years later, the Transformer Corporation went out of business, a victim of the Depression.
Mr. Siragusa immediately turned to the more lucrative field of manufacturing radios. In 1934, after selling his automobile and most of his home furnishings, Mr. Siragusa put $3,400 of his own and borrowed money toward a new venture, the Continental Radio and Television Corporation, which later changed its name to Admiral.
Within two years, the company's annual sales exceeded $2 million, and by the time the United States entered World War II, revenues topped $9 million. Growth exploded with the arrival of contracts for military electronics during the war, after which Mr. Siragusa steered Admiral into another field with vast potential -- television.
In 1950, Admiral produced more than one million television sets; the following year, it made five million. Growth appeared unlimited until economic and technological changes nearly brought down the company.
In 1951, disputes over which regulatory framework would rule the market for color television, combined with a new 10 percent excise tax on television sets, left major manufacturers with huge inventories.
But by offering huge discounts on its television sets and increasing its promotion of refrigerators, electric ranges and other home appliances, Admiral survived the downturn in the television industry.
Still, other technological innovations continued to vex Mr. Siragusa.
"I also can't see the market potential for home video tape recorders except for the very wealthy," he told The New York Times in 1965.
In 1973, with Admiral's sales topping $600 million but with profits falling sharply, the company agreed to be acquired by the Rockwell International Corporation for $78 million. Rockwell later sold Admiral's domestic appliance business to Magic Chef Inc.
At the time of the sale to Rockwell, the 34 percent of Admiral owned by Mr. Siragusa and his family was worth $26.5 million. Some of the proceeds of the sale went to the Siragusa Foundation, a Chicago charitable corporation founded in 1950. Mr. Siragusa served as chairman of the group until his retirement in 1993.
Mr. Siragusa is survived by his wife, the former Martha Ellen Peace, of Chicago; three sons, Ross Jr., of Fort Payne, Ala., John, of Chicago, and Richard, of Lake Forest, Ill.; 12 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A daughter, Mary Irene, died in 1980. Mr. Siragusa's first wife, Irene O'Brien, died in 1969.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Small Markets Shopping For Same Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
LUIS SALCEDO waited tables for 11 years, saving tips and paychecks until he could buy a modest coffee shop in Brooklyn. A few years later, he bought a grocery store in the Bronx. Then he put together $1 million through savings and high-interest loans, renovated a dilapidated Harlem storefront and opened up a supermarket with the grand name of Bravo.
Hold the applause. 
 His ascent up the food chain may be ending. He is convinced that his business will be gobbled up by predators coming into his neighborhood with unfair advantages. A few blocks east of his Fifth Avenue store, a large Pathmark is to be built. To the west, Fairway's mammoth uptown outpost attracts a socioeconomic mix ranging from aficionados of gourmet cheese to the recipients of the Government kind.
Like many owners of independent supermarkets in the area, he is irked by the city's helping to close the Pathmark deal by providing a 1 percent mortgage on the site and offering to act as an equity partner until a Hispanic community sponsor is found.
As for Fairway, Mr. Salcedo sees nothing fair about the way the 35,000-square-foot store opened late last year, apparently in violation of zoning laws that limit retail floor space to 10,000 square feet. The store's owners said it was a wholesale operation open to anyone, thereby exempt from the laws. While Fairway's owners negotiate a solution with the city, officials are preparing this month to discuss changing zoning laws to allow stores to sprawl out over 200,000 square feet.
GOVERNMENT'S embrace of these economies of scale makes Mr. Salcedo and his contemporaries feel mighty small. They say their dealings with officialdom are often limited to maddening encounters with health inspectors and code enforcers who are quick to dash off a summons for the slightest infraction.
"We want a level playing field," he said, perched in his tiny office where video monitors provide a scan of the store. "I will not put down Fairway at all as a business. The question is how someone got away with violating the law while others can't."
His complaints are typical of the 400 or so independent supermarkets scattered throughout the city, many of them in poorer communities that were abandoned by the big supermarket chains in the 1960's. The owners of these smaller supermarkets -- many of them Hispanic immigrants who chafe at the term bodega, which their businesses are not -- moved into those empty stores, shunned by bankers but often financed by food wholesalers and others who made them pay high interest on short-term loans.
"We came in aggressively and financed it privately," Mr. Salcedo said. "Now the big supermarkets see us thriving in here and they want to come back. But they need special zoning and benefits we don't get. I don't think that's American."
Especially not when he was just hit with a $50 summons because a passer-by tossed garbage onto the sidewalk near his dumpster. The law holds him responsible, he said, even if the garbage wasn't from his store.
Before that, he faced $13,000 in fines because he had failed to put price stickers on every roll of paper towels he stacked in a display. The rolls were in sealed boxes.
"Are they technically following the laws, or do they use discretion?" he said. "Their job is to give me a summons, and then you deal with the system."
Now Mr. Salcedo is getting help. Many supermarket owners banded together to confront city agencies, working out a settlement on outstanding fines that allows them to pay only a quarter of what was owed.
MORE recently, Hispanic supermarket owners and Korean greengrocers have joined forces to make sure they don't get lost in the shuffle of new zoning maps that would clear the way for big, warehouse-style stores. This ethnic alliance would not have been likely a decade ago when the two groups considered each other as competitors. Now they've petitioned the state to study the economic impact of their small businesses, which together employ some 48,000 people.
"We're building up and sharing our common concerns and problems," said Sung Soo Kim, the vice president of the Puerto Rican-Asian-Hispanic Development Corporation. "We are a social class."
Mr. Salcedo thinks that this newly united merchant class might help them pool the resources to compete with the big guys. Together, maybe they can get government to look at them as players with economic clout and more than a few votes.
"Why not offer the opportunities to the people who went in with their own dollars and risked everything?" he said. "I don't want something for nothing. I just want the same opportunity."

HEADLINE: Dogs Make Life Better For Disabled

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 2

 BODY:
Forced by multiple sclerosis to use a wheelchair, Lane Phalen struggled for four years to open and close doors, pick up things that fell on the floor or go shopping.
Now she has become one of thousands of disabled Americans getting a physical and emotional lift from dogs trained to do some of the things their masters cannot. 
 A two-year study being published on Wednesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association found that "service dogs" improved the psychological, social and economic well-being of 48 disabled people who had asked for canine help.
With help from their dogs, people unable to walk because of multiple sclerosis, muscular dystrophy or brain or spinal cord injuries were able work more, deal more with other people and use public transportation more. In a few cases, the emotional lift the dogs provided even helped troubled marriages.
For decades, blind people have used dogs as guides. But in recent years dogs taken from shelters have helped disabled people get in and out of bathtubs or dress.
Ms. Phalen's golden retriever, named Beau, was trained by a Michigan-based organization and given to her by her husband nearly two years ago. Beau can pull her wheelchair, open and close doors with straps attached, get cans of soda out of the refrigerator and bring her a phone if there is trouble. Now Ms. Phalen believes the dog will motivate her to leave the wheelchair permanently.
"As a disabled person, I was accustomed to everybody taking care of me and the focus of activity being on me," said Ms. Phalen, a 40-year-old writer in suburban Hoffman Estates. "It's very easy to slide into, 'O.K., just take care of me.' But since I am totally responsible for his welfare, I feel needed again."
The disabled people in the study also needed far less help from family and friends once they began using service dogs, which are available free of charge from organizations supported by donations.
The study, conducted by Karen Allen of the State University of New York at Buffalo and Jim Blascovich of the University of California at Santa Barbara, found that disabled people who had a service dog for a year spent 68 percent less on hired assistants than they did before.
Dr. Allen and Dr. Blascovich said a service dog could save a disabled person more than $16,000 a year.
"That the number of unpaid assistance hours can decrease suggests that the strain on relationships between people with severe ambulatory disabilities and their loved ones will go down," Dr. Blascovich said.
Michael Sapp, chief operating officer of Paws With a Case, the organization based in Byron Center, Mich., that trained Beau, said he hoped the study would encourage insurance companies to pay for service dogs. Last year Mr. Sapp's organization trained 177 dogs and gave them to disabled people in 38 states. Most of the dogs were golden retrievers and Labradors from shelters.
Before getting Beau, Ms. Phalen felt vulnerable and alone in public and often grew tired from wheeling herself around. She credits the dog with allowing her to travel and visit bookstores.
"I want everybody who's disabled to have a dog," Ms. Phalen said. "I don't know if it's psychological, because I expected things to be better, or what, but I needed to be more active. God, he's changed my life."

HEADLINE: Republicans Are Up in Arms At Labor's Political Rebirth

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Stunned by organized labor's intention to spend more than ever in this year's national elections, Republican campaign committees and business lobbies are crying foul and turning up the heat to blunt labor's impact.
In their pronouncements, Republican organizers, who have mocked or ignored unions in campaigns since the 1970's, are calling unions "big labor" again and ridiculing "Washington union bosses" and "Beltway labor bosses." 
 They have filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission calling the unions' campaign war chest illegal, and they are forming their own teams of campaigners in Congressional districts to take on labor's workers.
Labor's rebirth as a force in these elections comes on the heels of a vote last week by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has 13.1 million members, to set up the war chest by raising $35 million, most of it from a monthly assessment on each of the labor federation's 78 unions of 15 cents per capita.
That money, to be used to pay hundreds of full-time organizers and educate voters on issues, is a new resource to pour into the campaign. It comes on top of the more than $40 million in voluntary contributions from union members to political action committees, money that will be spread mostly among Democrats running for the Congressional seats that 73 freshman Republicans won two years ago.
For all that, the unions' spending is sure to fall far short of the money that Republican campaign committees and their allies among business associations and big business are likely to raise. "There will be no parity here," said Ellen Miller, executive director of the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics. She said Republicans outspent unions 7 to 1 in voter-education programs.
Labor's redoubled campaign effort coincides with a growing public awareness of bread-and-butter issues for unions: the jobs lost to downsizing and to Mexico, the sinking wages of rank-and-file workers and the climbing salaries, into the millions, of corporate executives. For the moment, at least, those issues have surpassed others that divide workers, like gun control and abortion.
The new efforts follow the election last October of a new and more bellicose president, John J. Sweeney, to lead the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Among Republicans, the convergence of combative union leadership and the public focus on economic issues has inspired oratorical flourishes unheard since the 1930's, when unions won most of the workplace rights like the 40-hour week. Craig Veith, a spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, said that Mr. Sweeney had embarked upon "probably the biggest overt power grab in history."
Mr. Sweeney and the presidents of the federation's 78 unions have begun "an unprecedented assault against our majorities in the House and the Senate," Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, complained in a letter to the party faithful last week.
Even though unions' membership has shrunk, from a third of the workforce in the 1950's to less than a sixth today, they are still the only significant advocates for the nation's workers. In this election year, unions got an unsolicited lift from Patrick J. Buchanan, whose campaign for the Presidential nomination has bedeviled the Republican establishment, calling attention to wages and disappearing industrial jobs and to the condition of working families.
In the 1992 and 1994 election years, unions tried to make something of downsizing and the widening gap between workers' wages and those of their employers, without much visible success at the polls. Unions opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement and after it was enacted in late 1993, they promised to drive the lawmakers who supported it from office. Instead, they witnessed the landslide that won the Republicans control of both chambers of Congress.
Then along came Mr. Sweeney, president of the one-million-member Service Employees Industrial Union, one of few unions to grow significantly while others were shrinking. Last year, Mr. Sweeney led a coup against Lane Kirkland, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, and Thomas R. Donahue, the secretary-treasurer, who in their 16 years at the top of the labor federation presided over the relentless decline of union membership.
Sixty-one and balding, with sleepy eyes and a portly frame draped in Brooks Brothers suits, Mr. Sweeney is an improbable-looking firebrand. But he has packed the federation's top offices with tough-talking men and women in their 40's, and he says that when push comes to shove, he is willing to resort to civil disobedience.
Upon taking office, Mr. Sweeney made two major promises: to beef up the unions' organizing activities and to go after the new Republicans in Congress who have been voting down nearly all the important issues on labor's agenda.
Unions want to raise the $4.25 hourly minimum wage, bar employers from dismissing workers who strike, stop the $270 million reduction in Medicare spending proposed by Republicans, provide cheap health care to all workers and block business lobbyists' efforts to open closed, all-union workplaces to nonunion workers and relax workplace safety laws.
Downsizing and soaring salaries for chief executives have played into the unions' hands, the leaders say. "You've got the chief executive officer of AT&T who makes 16 gazillion dollars and lays off 40,000 workers and his stock goes up," said William W. Hamilton, political director of the teamsters union. "That sends a message that's pretty chilling."
To thwart the labor agenda, the unions' Republican and business opponents have belatedly begun gearing up to fight. The United States Chamber of Commerce is in the throes of forming a Center on the 21st Century Workplace to take on union campaigners in Congressional districts.
Two months ago, the conservative Heritage Foundation formed a Union Watch Project to arm Republicans to take on the issues that unions are exploiting. "Organized labor's renewed political activism promises to be a major factor in the 1996 elections," the foundation wrote in a document that Mr. Barbour sent Republicans last week.
The Small Business Survival Foundation, with 40,000 members, was formed here two years ago to deal mostly with tax issues but is concentrating on unions and publishes a Labor Watch newsletter. "Right now, I'd say they've gotten us on the defensive," said Karen Kerrigan, the group's president. "They've done a very good job getting outside the Beltway and delivering their message."
Strategically, the Republican groups turn their fire on "Washington union bosses" in trying to differentiate them from the rank and file. "They are two different breeds," said Cheri Jacobus, communications director for the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunity. "The bosses have high salaries, great benefits and expensive automobiles at their disposal," she said. "They are very different from the rank and file. There are Washington values and American values."
Surprised by the surge of union political activity, Republicans in Congress are looking into hearings on issues like union corruption to embarrass the labor movement. One such effort failed last month.
The House Oversight Committee called a hearing to examine the unions' campaign spending. But Mr. Sweeney and other leaders declined to appear, and the Democrats on the committee called the session an inquisition and walked out.
The federation is aglow with all the attention. "We're relevant again!" said Steve Rosenthal, its political director. "Those people have waged the worst assault on working families that we have seen in 75 years."
"They've been doing it in the dark, and we're putting a spotlight on it," Mr. Rosenthal said. "What they want to do is talk about union bosses. Well this isn't about unions. This is about working families."
What has stirred the Republicans most is that $35 million war chest. Last week, Maria Cino, executive director of the National Republican Congressional Committee, issued a statement titled, "Sweeney desperate to fund illegal campaign."
She wrote that the assessment amounted to a dues increase that many members do not support and that it represented a forced and illegal contribution to the political campaigns to unseat Republican lawmakers. She added that the Republican agenda, with its promise of a balanced budget, served working families best.
But unions insist that none of the money will be contributed to candidates, whom they can help legally only through their members' voluntary contributions to union political action committees. The money, they say, will be used to educate voters on issues important to unions. Still, in their leafleting and commercials, the unions will leave little doubt about whom they see as in their camp.
In one sense, $35 million is serious money. The Heritage Foundation estimates that it is seven times as much as the federation has poured into Congressional races in the past. Mr. Barbour said in a report last week to Republicans in Congress that spread over the 70 districts where the unions will concentrate their campaigning, "that is $500,000 per district from unions alone."
"The average candidates spent on House races in 1994," Mr. Barbour said, "was $409,000."
But Ms. Miller said Republicans were sure to far exceed union spending this year. "Labor has always been vastly outspent," she said.

HEADLINE: Researching the Enemy: An Old Political Tool Resurfaces in a New Election

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla. April 2

 BODY:
When Bob Dole campaigned his way through the Iowa Presidential caucuses in February, he was often shadowed by a young man carrying a compact, broadcast-quality, Hi-8 television camcorder.
The young man worked for the Democratic National Committee. His assignment was to gather footage of remarks by Mr. Dole and the other Republican Presidential candidates on behalf of Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign. Mr. Dole's aides soon picked him out -- the baby-faced cameraman stood out in the crowd of older TV crews weighted down with packs of professional equipment -- and for a while, dispatched Republican advance workers to stand in front of him, with instructions to block his filming. 
 At the Republican National Committee's headquarters in Washington this month, party aides have embarked on a similar, though less veiled, effort at what is known as opposition research. They are assembling an indexed catalogue of public statements made by Mr. Clinton during his career, which they will use themselves and issue to reporters as a bound book. They are also reviewing less-noticed aspects of Mr. Clinton's first term -- court rulings by his judicial appointees, Federal regulations issued by the agencies under his charge and potentially impolitic remarks by his Cabinet officers -- that might help to discredit the President in the fall campaign.
After a Presidential election in which the use of opposition research fell into some disrepute, the upcoming general-election campaign is shaping up as a confrontation between two candidates who have historically proved to be expert at turning their opponent's governmental record to their advantage.
Opposition research was critical to Mr. Dole's success in claiming his party's nomination this year, as it was in helping Mr. Clinton derail his Democratic opponents for the Presidential nomination in 1992. And aides to Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton are predicting a resurgence this year of a campaign tool that goes back at least to the time of Abraham Lincoln.
"There is a lot of information out there," said Ann Lewis, deputy campaign manager for Mr. Clinton. "You don't have to scramble."
In a revealing realignment of his campaign staff, Mr. Dole, who is vacationing in this Miami resort community this week, has retained one of the best-known experts in opposition research in American politics today, Don Todd, to help him against Mr. Clinton. Mr. Todd worked for George Bush in 1988, where he directed the memorably effective negative research effort that helped defeat Michael S. Dukakis.
This addition to Mr. Dole's staff comes after a primary campaign in which Mr. Dole dispatched his major opponents -- Lamar Alexander, Steve Forbes and Patrick J. Buchanan -- largely with the use of information turned up by his opposition research. Mr. Dole's campaign plumbed his opponents' records to find "votes and quotes," as one Republican researcher put it, to support ads portraying Mr. Alexander as liberal, Mr. Buchanan as extreme and Mr. Forbes as posing an economic threat to middle-class homeowners with his flat-tax proposal.
If Ross Perot runs as a third-party Presidential candidate, he has said he will refrain from attacking his opponents, and Democratic and Republican aides have not said what, if anything, they will do to deal with him.
Several factors suggest that the use of opposition research might be more free-wheeling this year than it was in 1992. Then, Mr. Bush was restrained in what he could do because of the legacy of a controversial advertisement in 1988 about the furloughed prisoner Willie Horton, as well as an effort to remain Presidential.
"Bush's reputation was such that almost anything he said about his opponents was discounted in the public mind as the desperate charge of a guy hanging by his fingernails," said David Tell, who headed Mr. Bush's 1992 opposition research effort and is now the opinions editor at the conservative magazine, The Weekly Standard.
For his part, Mr. Clinton, who aggressively used such information against his primary opponents, was more careful in a political atmosphere in which his aides concluded that he stood to benefit by the perception that Mr. Bush was guilty of unfair campaign practices.
By contrast this year, Mr. Dole's campaign has already shown little reservation about aggressively using information against its opponents, even in cases where the attacks are arguably exaggerated. In one case -- the criticism of Mr. Forbes's flat tax in New Hampshire -- Mr. Dole's aides now acknowledge that the attacks were wrong.
Mr. Dole's campaign asserted in one commercial that under the flat tax, a "typical New Hampshire household" would pay $2,000 in additional taxes. The Dole campaign quickly realized the assertion was based on an incorrect reading of an economic study. The campaign official in charge of opposition research then, Mary Anne Carter, was forced out of her job because of that, Republican officials said.
But Mr. Dole's campaign kept the advertisement rather than risk the political embarrassment of withdrawing it in the midst of a tight campaign. Partly because of the ad, Mr. Forbes came in a distant fourth in New Hampshire.
Opposition research has become stigmatized since the Republicans used it so aggressively against Mr. Dukakis in 1988, focusing on Mr. Horton, who terrorized a Maryland couple while on furlough from a Massachusetts prison, stabbing the man and raping his fiancee, as well as Mr. Dukakis's onetime opposition to proposed legislation that required students to recite the Pledge of Allegiance. The fallout from that campaign left negative research in such disrepute that campaign aides are publicly reluctant to discuss them.
Mr. Todd said he saw no gain in describing his record or work in Mr. Dole's campaign. "Everyone claims to have discovered Willie Horton," Mr. Todd said. "But he's going to get out of jail some day, so I don't."
In preparing for the upcoming election, Mr. Dole's research team is not planning to focus its information-gathering efforts on Mr. Clinton's personal problems. Republicans say they have steered clear of accusations that have involved Mr. Clinton in the courts and tabloids.
"You aren't going to beat Clinton on that stuff," said Charles Black, who was the senior adviser to Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign. "We didn't last time." Similarly, Mr. Dole's aides are not at this moment planning to devote much effort to investigating the Clintons' involvement in the Whitewater real estate development. That is again a pragmatic decision, dictated by the doubts they have that they could turn up anything that special prosecutors, Congressional committees and reporters have not, and that there is no need for the Dole campaign to push the issue.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says if Yanks Must Move, West Side Would Be Best

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
With the city ready to present the New York Yankees with a report on the best place to locate the team, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it would be easier to finance building a new stadium on Manhattan's West Side than at any other site.
The $600,000 consultant's report weighs the likelihood of four locations to keep the team from leaving New York. They are the rail yards west of Pennsylvania Station, a refurbished Yankee Stadium, and two other Bronx sites: Van Cortlandt and Pelham Bay Parks. One person familiar with the report said it comes down in favor of the West Side plan, which would cost at least $800 million. 
 Mr. Giuliani has said that he remains emotionally wedded to keeping the Yankees at their current location, but at a news conference yesterday, he called the West Side proposal financially viable.
"The revenue stream from a stadium in the middle of Manhattan would be off the charts," he said. "It would be an enormous amount of money because of multiple uses and because of what it would do for baseball attendance."
While the proposal has not been publicly released, the mere prospect that the city would consider building a new stadium on the West Side drew criticism yesterday, even from the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth Messinger.
"To spend hundreds of millions of dollars to move a stadium two miles to an area that will be filled with traffic problems is not a thoughtful expenditure of money," Ms. Messinger said.
According to the person familiar with the study's findings, the report found there would be more economic value in building a ballpark on the West Side than in spending about the same amount to renovate Yankee Stadium and build new highway ramps, garages and a Harlem River bridge. It rejected sites at Van Cortlandt Park and Pelham Bay Parkway.
City and state officials were supposed to meet today with the Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, but that meeting has been postponed until at least next week. Mr. Steinbrenner is known to favor the West Side site -- should he decide not to move the team to New Jersey.
While revenue from a stadium on the West Side might pay off any bonds issued to pay for the new ballpark, a host of other issues remain. A Manhattan stadium could require costly improvements to accommodate traffic and parking, as well as mass transit, since the nearest subway station would be blocks away. In addition, Mr. Steinbrenner would most likely want a substantial part of any added revenue from the West Side stadium.
Mr. Giuliani would not confirm any of the study's findings yesterday, saying: "We have a report on four sites and we'll deliver that report to the Yankees. The Yankees haven't been briefed on it."
David Sussman, the general counsel of the Yankees, said on Monday that he had seen the report and summarized its findings for Mr. Steinbrenner.
But Mr. Steinbrenner himself has been virtually silent on the issue.
That silence has been by design. He has bided his time, waiting to see what state and city officials will offer, associates say, trusting that Mayor Guiliani and Charles Gargano, New York State's economic development chief, will deliver a viable plan. Embracing one site over the other could upset the leverage he has acquired by orchestrating the trans-Hudson bidding for the last decade.
Meyer S. Frucher, a former state labor negotiator and an advocate of a West Side ballpark, said that when Mr. Steinbrenner addresses the West Side recommendation, "He'll have to say something about it has to be carefully analyzed and something about how it would be financed."
Nonetheless, city and state negotiators will have to convince Mr. Steinbrenner to share the revenues he would get in Manhattan in order to help pay what will surely be a mountain of debt. Since his talks in the mid-1980's about renovating Yankee Stadium, Mr. Steinbrenner has always sought higher percentages of revenues than his lease in the Bronx provides.
In considering a ballpark for the West Side, officials are enticed by the generous cash flow generated at such new ballparks as Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore and Jacobs Field in Cleveland, which have proven immensely popular in downtown sites.
But any negotiations would likely require Mr. Steinbrenner's agreement to have stadium revenues finance part of the debt. Mr. Ferrer, a critic of Mr. Steinbrenner, scoffed at the idea that Mr. Steinbrenner would part with such revenues.
"The debt would be repaid by the stadium?" he asked incredulously. "He's not even paying rent now!"
But the concept of having an owner share stadium financing is gaining currency as taxpayers increasingly resist 100 percent public financing for sports arenas.
To build a stadium in Milwaukee, the owners of the Brewers will have to contribute $90 million. A stadium to replace Candlestick Park in San Francisco will be financed privately by the Giants' owners.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY SHOWING SIGNS OF REBOUND FROM SLOW WINTER

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Battered recently by storms and undermined for months by weak sales, the economy has been sluggish for most of the last year. But figures released today gave some tentative signs that business could improve this spring -- and that corporations' strong profits have been relatively unaffected by 1995's weakness.
The index of leading indicators, a gauge designed to spot turning points, soared 1.3 percent in February, the biggest jump in 20 years, while business inventories appear to have been drawn down enough to encourage companies to start increasing production soon. 
 "Evidence is accumulating that the economy is in the midst of a pickup," said Rosanne Cahn, an economist at CS First Boston in New York. And Kevin Flanagan, a vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York, said that "the inventory situation should not be the drag on growth it was in 1995."
Yet analysts cautioned that it was still too early to count on growth this Presidential election year even reaching the 2 percent pace that the Commerce Department, reporting today a downward revision for the fourth quarter, finally established for 1995.
The department cut its estimate of fourth-quarter growth in the gross domestic product to a slim annual rate of five-tenths of a percent from nine-tenths of a percent. And many analysts predicted that the first quarter of 1996 might be only a little better, with estimates ranging from under 1 percent to little more than 1.5 percent.
 "An economic rebound is not yet baked in the cake," the First Union National Bank warned clients.
Analysts expressed more than the usual skepticism about the leading index and its huge advance, three-fifths of which reflected expansion of the factory workweek that dived in January because of the blizzard in the East.
But despite the doubts, many economists said that the worst might be over for now.
This combination of mild optimism and strong uncertainty have made the economy a mixed prospect as an issue in the Presidential campaign, as Clinton Administration officials search for signs of growth and Republicans deride its modest extent.
But the figures released today are likely to be reflected in another debate stirred by candidates this year -- over who is benefiting from whatever growth there is. Commerce Department figures showed that the profits of American companies grew more than twice as fast as the economy at large in 1995, jumping 11.8 percent to cap the most prosperous three-year period for corporations in about two decades.
It was the third straight year of double-digit profit gains, which reflected in part the continued layoffs at many big corporations and came despite subpar growth of the economy.
Those profits have provided the underpinning for the big surge in stock prices that were one of the factors captured by the index of leading indicators as reasons for projecting some economic quickening. The others were a slower pace of falling prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle, slower deliveries from corporate suppliers, higher unfilled orders for factory durables, a larger money supply and more building permits.
The four components acting to hold the index down were less optimistic consumer expectations, more first-time claims for unemployment benefits, lower factory orders for consumer goods and a decline in contracts and orders for plant and equipment.
The Conference Board, a business research group in New York that recently took over compilation of the index from the Commerce Department, delayed until Thursday issuing companion indexes on coincident and lagging indicators. Government shutdowns this winter have delayed publication of some elements.
The main reasons that growth at the end of 1995 was even more sluggish than originally estimated were because of downward adjustments in residential fixed investment, a smaller addition to business inventories and higher imports. These factors were partly offset by an upward revision to personal spending that some analysts took as a harbinger of possibly faster growth ahead.
Consumers account for about two-thirds of gross domestic product -- half of this at retail counters and the other half in spending on such items as rent and insurance.
The department also reported that its final estimate for its price index for gross domestic purchases was raised one-tenth of a point, to a rate of 2.1 percent.
Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is his party's presumptive Presidential nominee, took the occasion of the G.D.P. report today to sound a theme expected to be widely heard during the campaign.
"The weakest economic growth since the last recession is disappointing but hardly surprising given President Clinton's policies of more Washington spending, more regulation and more taxes," he said.
The revised fourth-quarter growth rate meant that three of the four 1995 quarters had growth rates of under 1 percent, the other one being the 3.6 percent pace during the July-September period.
The profits figures, which were the first Government tally to be reported for the fourth quarter, were better than most analysts expected.
"Corporate profits have held up remarkably well, given that the economy slowed a lot," said Paul D. Mastroddi, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust. This, he added, "well explains" current stratospheric levels of the stock markets, which is often portrayed as a largely demographic phenomenon based on baby boomers reaching middle age.
But while exceeding expectations, the profit gain was just six-tenths of 1 percent for the latest quarter compared with a 9.6 percent surge in the third quarter, the Commerce Department figures showed.
In addition to fueling debate about corporate downsizing, high profits are likely to be seized upon by Democrats to bolster their contention that too little corporate prosperity these days is finding its way to ordinary workers, whose wages have lagged behind.
"Workers are getting less than their share," contended Dean Baker, an analyst for the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal-oriented research group.
 An entry in the Business Digest referring to the article misattributed the index of leading indicators. It is compiled by the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, not by the Government.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with the continuation of an article about the state of the economy misstated the performance of one component of the index of leading indicators. That component -- the average workweek of production workers in manufacturing -- rose, contributing 0.77 of a percentage point to the index's overall increase; it did not fall by that amount.
The chart also misstated the reporting period for the index. It was January to February, not October to November.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Leading Indicators Jump, Pointing to Growth in Spring
The index of leading indicators soared in February, suggesting that business could improve this spring after months of sluggish growth. The leading indicators rose 1.3 percent, in their biggest jump in 20 years, the Government said. Inventories appear low enough to encourage companies to lift production soon, and corporate profits have remained relatively firm. [Page A1.]
 
I.B.M. Lifts Dow Average
Shares kept climbing, led by a rally in I.B.M. It surged 7 1/4 points, or 6.6 percent, to 117 5/8, partly on improved earnings forecasts. The Dow industrials rose 33.96 points, to 5,671.68, and broader measures climbed in line with the Dow. Oil, chemical and drug issues rose. [D8.]
 
Treasury bonds rose. Traders did not see signs of fast enough economic growth to increase inflation. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.59 percent from 6.64 percent. [D15.]
 
Tough Reception for Tobacco Suit
Federal judges in New Orleans asked sharp questions about the manageability of a giant class-action lawsuit against cigarette makers. The judges are considering whether the case can continue, but are not expected to rule for several months. Still, the case has become something of a legal and media circus. [A10.]
 
Salomon Analyst Is Cleared
A Federal judge dismissed insider trading charges filed by the S.E.C. against a Salomon Brothers analyst and his father. But the judge did rule that the analyst, Frederick W. Moran, acted improperly, though not illegally, in using his job to help his father. [D4.]
 
Higher Bid for Diamond Fields
Falconbridge sweetened its offer for Diamond Fields Resources in an attempt to avert a bidding war with its rival, Inco, for a huge metals deposit in Newfoundland. [D8.]
 
An Exodus From Ayer
Two of the three top executives at N. W. Ayer & Partners have suddenly left the venerable advertising agency, which has struggled for years to turn around its flagging fortunes. The two to leave are Mark Fenske, chief creative officer, and Martyn Straw, chief strategic officer. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Fund Enters W. R. Grace Dispute
Calpers, the giant pension fund, is joining a battle against W. R. Grace officers and directors. The California fund is joining suits to recover for the company some of the millions of dollars that were paid to two former executives who left under a cloud. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Pepsi Bets on Foreign Markets
Pepsi-Cola introduced a $500 million promotion and advertising campaign in London that it hopes will make up some ground in pursuit of Coke in world markets. The campaign features an electric-blue can in many countries, though not the U.S. For the occasion, Pepsi painted a Concorde blue. [D5.]
 
Strong Profit at First Boston
CS First Boston earned a record $108 million in the first quarter amid rising markets, booming stock and bond sales and a heavy pace of corporate mergers, according to an internal memo sent to employees. [D2.]

Growing Dangers Of Foreign Travel
Executives traveling abroad are facing graver risks of everything from street crime and kidnapping to credit-card fraud. Russia is one of the most dangerous places, and "downtown Lima is a war zone," said a former C.I.A. agent who now tracks security conditions. Business Travel. [D7.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Sharply Against Yen On Hint of Rate Rise in Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped sharply against the yen yesterday after Japan's top banker suggested that the nation's rebounding economy would push up domestic interest rates, which would enhance the value of the Japanese currency.
The dollar also ended lower against the German mark and most other currencies, despite new signs of declining interest rates in Europe. In a surprise move, the Bank of Spain lowered its benchmark rate by a half a percentage point, bolstering speculation that Germany and other countries would do the same soon. 
 In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 106.91 yen from 107.57 yen on Tuesday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4824 German marks, down from 1.4827 marks. The British pound strengthened to $1.5260 from $1.5227. Traders said volumes were thin, exaggerating currency movements.
The dollar's decline against the yen came early in the trading day, after the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, said that it was natural to assume that the rebounding Japanese economy would result in higher interest rates. The country's benchmark rate is now at a half a percent.
Although Mr. Matsushita never said rates were about to rise, his remarks were interpeted to mean that an increase may be imminent. Higher rates would increase the allure of Japanese investments and the yen needed to buy them.
"What central bankers don't realize is how much impact they can have, even when their words are obvious," said Win Thin, an international economist at HSBC Midland in New York. "The markets are jittery right now, so it was enough to get a reaction."
Others saw Mr. Matsushita's statement as an excuse to sell the dollar, which has risen substantially against the yen in recent months. They also acknowledged the central banker had not said anything new or surprising.
"Japanese rates are at half a percent now; where else are they going to go?" said Elena Shperling, a currency trader at the New York offices of Banco di Sicilia. "It's inevitable that Japanese rates will rise."
Still, she said, "this was the only thing of any excitement that happened."
Trading is expected to remain thin the rest of the week, with many financial markets in the United States and Europe closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday.
