HEADLINE: Market Place;
Emerging markets have begun a comeback from a poor 1995.

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
THE world's emerging stock markets performed a sharp turnaround in the first quarter of this year, while developed stock markets rose at a modest pace when compared with last year.
In emerging markets from Poland and Turkey to China and Malaysia, stock markets did an about-face. According to the Morgan Stanley Capital International index, emerging markets rose 5.8 percent in dollar terms in the first quarter compared with declines in three of the four quarters last year. For all of 1995, emerging markets were off by 6.9 percent in dollar terms. 
 The rebound in emerging markets appears to indicate that investors have shrugged off last year's Mexican crisis, which knocked emerging markets worldwide into a tailspin.
"It sometimes looks as if confidence in emerging markets has built back up to the point where money is flowing not to cautious countries like Chile and South Africa but to high-risk ones like Venezuela and Turkey," said Kathleen Stephansen, an economist with the New York investment house of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Including the United States, the world's developed markets climbed 3.7 percent from January through March in dollar terms. While that was a respectable performace, it was less than any quarter of 1995, when the world index finished up 18.7 percent on the year.
Over all, the Morgan Stanley index shows that markets in 32 industrial and emerging economies rose in the first quarter while slipping in only 13.
As measured in dollars and without dividends being reinvested, Morgan Stanley cites Poland and Turkey as the quarter's best performers among emerging markets, with respective advances of 32.6 percent and 34.4 percent. Both, though, endured mild corrections in late March.
Other strong performers in Morgan Stanley's index included China, which includes Hong Kong; Malaysia; Venezuela; Portugal; Indonesia; Greece, and India, all of which reported first-quarter gains from 10 percent to 14 percent.
A separate index of stock markets in developing countries prepared by the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank's private investment arm, records even higher first-quarter gains, from 41 percent to 49 percent, in Hungary, Poland and Turkey, and rises of between 12 and 15 percent for Mexico, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Czech Republic and Zimbabwe.
The Morgan Stanley index and the International Finance one cover much the same emerging markets, but the two indexes sometimes turn in different results because they pick different stocks and ascribe different weightings to them. But for the first quarter, both indexes showed an overall rise of 5.6 percent for emerging markets.
Chile was the most disappointing emerging market, with a first-quarter fall of more than 8 percent on both indexes. Israel had the biggest fall among emerging markets in March, with a decline of 8.4 percent, as a wave of bombings raised fears for the future of the Middle East peace process; the Tel Aviv stock exchange fell 5.9 percent for the quarter as a whole.
Other emerging markets showing first-quarter declines included South Korea and Taiwan, both affected by political tensions with China, as well as South Africa, Jordan, Argentina, Colombia, Thailand and Pakistan.
Industrial world stock markets turned in solid, if more modest performances. The index of 22 developed countries showed Europe up 3.2 percent while the Far East ended 1.7 percent higher. The first-quarter performance in the Far East has already outstripped 1995, when that index rose just 1.3 percent. But the rise in Europe in the last three months fell short of the 5.6 percent rise in the period a year earlier.
Among industrialized countries, Morgan Stanley's star first-quarter performers are Sweden and France, with respective rises of 9.2 percent and 8 percent, reflecting lower short-term interest rates in both countries and commitments to bringing their public finances under control.
Switzerland had the industrialized world's best performance during March when stock prices rose 8.7 percent following the proposed merger between the pharmaceutical and chemical giants Ciba-Geigy and Sandox, giving the market a 6.5 percent rise for the quarter as a whole.

HEADLINE: Dow Retreats to 5,682.88 In Listless Trading Session

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
In a listless session that ended a holiday-shortened trading week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.86 points from Wednesday's record, to 5,682.88, a close that left it with a surge of 1.7 percent, or 95.74 points, for the week.
The market will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. 
 Traders focused on yesterday's initial public offering of Lucent Technologies, a spinoff of AT&T that climbed 3 5/8 from its offering price, to 30 5/8. With more than $3 billion worth of stock sold to the public, Lucent was not only the largest I.P.O. in Wall Street history, but also the most active initial offering, as more than 42 million shares changed hands on the first trading day. But elsewhere in the market volume was sluggish.
"It was a quiet day before the release of the employment numbers," said John Hammerschmidt, a partner of Turner Investment Partners in Philadelphia. "And they are numbers that none of us will be around to see."
Nevertheless, the Labor Department is scheduled to issue the employment and unemployment statistics for March. Last month, the release of a strong employment report caused stock prices to plunge; traders feared the Federal Reserve would not lower interest rates if the economy was too robust.
In the broader market yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index eased 0.02 point, to 655.86. And the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.36 points, to 1,118.21.
Declines edged advances on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,201 to 1,066. Turnover slipped to 383.4 million shares, from 386.9 million shares on Wednesday.
Bond prices were also lower yesterday, with traders repositioning in advance of today's employment data. The price drop sent the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond up to 6.67 percent, from 6.62 percent Wednesday.
The Big Board, the American Stock Exchange and Nasdaq all observed a minute of silence at noon in memory of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who died on Wednesday in a plane crash in Croatia, along with a delegation of American corporate executives.
Oil service stocks were the standouts yesterday, gaining in line with the increasing demand for oilfield equipment. BJ Services increased 4 1/8, to 37 3/8; Reading and Bates rose 1 3/4, to 22; Diamond Offshore Drilling added 3 5/8, to 49, and Falcon Drilling advanced 115/16 , to 25 1/2.
Airline issues gained, pushing the Dow Jones transportation average up 21.72 points, to 2,206.68. America West closed at 23 1/8, up 1; Delta Air Lines closed at 81 1/2, up 2 7/8, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, closed at 92 3/8, up 2 1/2.
Some financial stocks retreated in keeping with rising bond yields. Wells Fargo dropped 2 1/8, to 259 1/8; J. P. Morgan declined 1 7/8, to 83 1/8, and BankAmerica fell 1 1/2, to 78 3/4.
Telephone companies also turned downward. Pacific Telesis closed at 33 1/4, off 5/8, and Bell South closed at 37 1/8, off 1.
General Nutrition
declined 1 1/2, to 21 1/4, a day after Morgan Stanley downgraded the stock. Nautica fell 2 1/4, to 43 1/2, a day after it was downgraded by Montgomery Securities. And FTP Software sank 2 3/8, to 9 1/2, after saying that it would report a first-quarter loss.
However, Netscape, which held a meeting with analysts yesterday, advanced 2 3/8, to 45 5/8. Amerada Hess, which announced Wednesday the proposed sale of its Canadian unit, increased 2, to 57 3/4. And Amdahl, which said that it would buy Trecom Business Systems, rose 1 5/8, to 10 7/8.

HEADLINE: Exchanges Staying Put: First Coffee, Now Cotton

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
In the climax of months of negotiation and an intense rivalry with New Jersey, New York City officials announced yesterday that the Cotton Exchange had agreed to remain in New York.
In so doing, the Cotton Exchange joined the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in spurning the blandishments of New Jersey and accepting a package of incentives intended to keep both exchanges in New York City for the next 30 years. 
 "The vote by the Cotton Exchange to remain in the city is a tremendous vote of confidence in the city as the financial capital of the world," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said.
"We're ecstatic," said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which was the agency responsible for the city's negotiations.
Mr. Millard said the $98 million in incentives that kept both exchanges and their 5,500 jobs from moving across the Hudson River to Jersey City would be returned to the city in less than a year through economic impact -- "tax revenues, the multiplier effect of dollars spent by people shopping at the corner deli, getting their dry cleaning done, paying their taxes."
He added, "In essence, we are forgoing 10 months of these kinds of tax revenues in order to keep them in perpetuity."
He also said that the $98 million in incentives was not a cash package, but instead represented reductions in rent, reductions in sales taxes when the exchanges built on new sites and reductions in real property taxes.
Stephen Place, chairman of the New York Cotton Exchange, declined to comment last night on the agreement, saying that the matter would be dealt with in a press release to be issued by the Cotton and Coffee Exchanges on Monday.
Last October, by offering one of the most lucrative packages of subsidies ever provided in the city, officials persuaded the board of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchanges to cancel plans to move to Jersey City and instead to build a new trading center in New York City.
Officials described that decision as a critical victory in the economic development war with New Jersey, which had offered a valuable set of incentives to lure both the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the Cotton Exchange to the other side of the Hudson. The relocation plans of the two exchanges had been linked, and when the Coffee Exchange accepted New York's package, the Cotton Exchange agreed to reconsider a decision to move to Jersey City.
The exchanges represent 17 percent of the commodity trading volume in New York City and are planning to replace their current home at the World Trade Center with a new trading center in TriBeCa, on a site bounded by Murray, Warren, Greenwich and West Streets.
John S. Dyson, the departing Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, who had been involved in the negotiations for months, said that between October and yesterday, the city had not enriched its offer to the Cotton Exchange.
"Every once in a while," he said, "being a businessman, I know you have to stand pat and raise the ante. The advantages of New York as a world capital tipped the balance, even though New Jersey was quite desperately trying to get something, anything, to cross the river."

HEADLINE: Day of Barbs and Smirks in a Whitewater Trial

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 4

 BODY:
Beginning their cross-examination of the prosecution's star witness in the Whitewater-related loan fraud trial here, defense lawyers today drew forth admissions that the witness concocted other self-enrichment schemes like those involved in the charges, well before and after the association he said he had had with the defendants.
The fourth day of testimony for the witness, David Hale, was one in which earlier civility and courtliness fell away as Mr. Hale, defense lawyers and prosecutors directed barbs at one other. 
 At one point a defense lawyer, smirking at the jurors, congratulated Mr. Hale on how "slick" he was. At another, Mr. Hale smiled at the jury as he said he was sorry he had "upset" one of his questioners.
"I remember you when you used to be on the other side," said Sam Heuer, the defense lawyer for James B. McDougal, referring with barely concealed venom to the time in the 1970's when Mr. Hale was a prosecutor and, later, a municipal judge in Little Rock.
Mr. Hale, 54, who was president of a Federally subsidized small-business lending company, has pleaded guilty to loan fraud and been sentenced to prison. Prosecutors describe him as a co-conspirator with the defendants in the current trial, Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas, Mr. McDougal and Mr. McDougal's former wife, Susan. All of them were once close associates of President Clinton.
The three are charged with 21 counts of loan fraud and conspiracy; the case brought by the special Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, charges that they used the money from Mr. McDougal's Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan Association and Mr. Hale's Capital Management Services, to shore up sinking real estate deals and support expensive life styles in 1986 and 1987.
Mr. Hale was asked today about more than a dozen loans that his company made to businesses headed, on paper at least, by his bookkeeper, his secretary, the wife of a young associate in his law firm and other business associates. In reality, he testified, the businesses were all created and controlled by him.
The loans, cited in questioning by Mr. Heuer and dating as far back as 1980, totaled more than $1.6 million. Mr. Hale conceded that the loans violated the Federal prohibition against small business investment company operators like himself personally benefitting from the money they lend. In some cases, Mr. Hale testified, he laundered portions of the money he lent to one of the companies he controlled by moving it through several other dummy corporations he had created, only to return it to the lending company as additional money he was investing in it.
In this way, he told the jury of nine women and three men, he could "leverage" even more in Federal contributions to his small business lending operation from the Small Business Administration. Under the Federal regulations for such lending companies, they could receive $3 in Federal money to lend out for every $1 in private money that was put into it.
After describing one of these schemes from a series of 1988 loans and transactions to which Mr. Hale has admitted but was never charged under his plea agreement, Mr. Heuer pointedly asked if his client, Mr. McDougal, had any involvement in the scheme.
"No," Mr. Hale said, adding quickly, "this was a wash through of funds, not like the Madison Guaranty loans."
Mr. Heuer grew angry and congratulated Mr. Hale for "dropping these hints" in the middle of his testimony.
Earlier in the day, W. Ray Jahn, the lead prosecutor, completed his questioning of Mr. Hale without attempting to elicit more testimony touching on whether Mr. Clinton knew about the fraudulent loans or was involved in the scheme. Mr. Hale testified Tuesday that he had had a meeting with Mr. McDougal and Mr. Clinton in 1986, at which the loans were discussed. Mr. Hale had earlier told prosecutors that during a chance encounter on the state Capitol steps, Mr. Clinton pressured him to complete the loan, an assertion that Mr. Clinton has adamantly denied. But that potentially more damaging charge, indicating a greater involvement by Mr. Clinton in an illegal transaction, will apparently not be allowed in court. A defense lawyer later suggested that the judge saw the conversation as irrelevant to the charges against Mr. McDougal and Mr. Tucker.
As Mr. Hale was completing his direct examination, he told of the time in 1987 that he was with Mr. Tucker as he was writing out a check to the Internal Revenue Service for "more than a million dollars."
"He said, 'This is what your small business investment company has done for me,' " Mr. Hale recalled in testimony, saying that Mr. Tucker, who was then in private business had prospered by having the use of the loan money that was supposed to go to minority and economically and socially disadvantaged small businesses. "He was very pleased."
But then in 1991 as Federal bank regulators and the F.B.I. were closing in on the activities of Madison and his company, Mr. Hale was scared and was lying to investigators.

HEADLINE: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: VICTIMS -- A Banker and 3 Others on Ill-Fated Mission;
Lee Jackson, Banking Representative, 37

 BODY:
Lee Jackson was the United States representative on the board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development,
He was 37 and was based in London. 
 Mr. Jackson, who was born in Glen Ridge, N.J., and raised in White Plains, N.Y., spent his early career as an investment banker in New York and San Francisco. He became treasurer of the City of Boston in 1988 and joined the bank in 1993. President Clinton named him United States Executive Director in 1995. The bank promotes free-market economies in formerly Communist countries.
According to Treasury officials, he worked to increase the investment activity of the bank, especially with small and medium-sized businesses in the former Soviet Union and elsewhere in eastern Europe, and to broaden its efforts on environmental infrastructure.

HEADLINE: Study Recommends The Yankees Move To a West Side Site

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
A consulting firm's recommendation that the Yankees move from the Bronx to the West Side of Manhattan was based on the conclusion that a new ball park along the Hudson River would produce a significant increase in attendance, higher prices for luxury seats and an enhanced image for New York City.
The report, jointly commissioned by the city, the state and the Yankees, studied four options, including renovating the current Yankee Stadium, but came down solidly in favor of a West Side stadium with a retractable domed roof that could be used for baseball, football, concerts and conventions. The cost for such a stadium would be $1.06 billion, it said. 
 Although he has insisted that he wants the team to remain in the South Bronx, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has pitched the West Side site as the most attractive lure to keep the Yankees from relocating to New Jersey, and the best way to avoid a repetition of the Dodgers' move from Brooklyn to Los Angeles in 1958.
The Yankees' lease in the Bronx expires in 2002, and the team's principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, has made it clear that he is dissatisfied with the team's 73-year-old home in the South Bronx, complaining about security, parking, traffic and sanitation.
The West Side recommendation is not a surprise and matches the desires of several parties. Since 1993, when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo first proposed it, the site between 30th and 33d streets and 10th and 11th avenues has been deemed by the state and city as the prime option to the team's staying in the Bronx stadium.
The report, by the consulting team assembled by the architectural firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum of Kansas City, Mo., provides an economic argument to bolster that selection. The consultants concluded that a dual-sport stadium on the West Side would produce almost $200 million in annual revenues, compared with $96 million for the existing Yankee Stadium site, and even less for two other sites in the Bronx, Pelham Bay Park and Van Cortlandt Park, both of which were deemed unsuitable. .
Part of the increased revenues would come from higher ticket sales, the study said. It said that in a West Side park, Yankee attendance would grow by 50 percent, to more than 40,000 per game. A renovated or rebuilt stadium in the South Bronx would produce a 30 percent increase, the report said.
The report said a 50,000-seat baseball-only park "would provide a strong image" for the "relocated franchise." A two-sport stadium seating 70,000 "would provide an unparalleled location," and assumes that a football team play there. The Jets' lease at Giants Stadium runs through 2008.
The $600,000 report also considered whether the playing field should be grass or artificial turf. While it made no recommendation of either, it suggested that an artificial surface would allow for more flexible scheduling of conventions and other events and thus produce significantly more revenue.
The new stadium would be owned by New York State and New York City and financed through bonds. Mayor Giuliani said this week that the West Side proposal would be easier to finance than any other site, because "the revenue stream from a stadium in the middle of Manhattan would be off the charts."
Howard Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Steinbrenner, who ultimately must decide whether to stay in the Bronx, move to Manhattan or move to New Jersey, declined to comment last night. "The report speaks for itself and we'll leave it at that," he said.
Two of the biggest obstacles faced by the city and state in building at the West Side are traffic and parking. The site is next to Route 9A, where congestion is heavy and expected to escalate as reconstruction of the scaled-down Westway project takes place into the next century. Road construction around the proposed stadium site is expected to start in 1999.
But the consultants said that the massive traffic jams predicted by opponents of the West Side site can be avoided through improved traffic circulation, coordinating events with the Javits Center and Madison Square Garden and direct ramp connections from the Lincoln Tunnel.
The consultants' report provoked immediate criticism yesterday from some politicians who advocate keeping the Yankees in their current stadium. But it was also greeted by cheers from some business people near the site of the West Side rail yards, a neighborhood where decades of decline have driven residents and merchants away.
"When you pay the kind of money the city paid to get the conclusion they wanted, it should not come as a shock to anyone that they are recommending the West Side of Manhattan," said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, who disputed the report's findings that such a stadium would not create huge traffic jams in the neighborhood.
"The conclusion is utter fantasy," he said. "You would be creating the biggest traffic jam in the Western Hemisphere."
He also charged that the estimate of the cost of building on the rail yards was too low. "They are laying the groundwork for a raid on the city treasury," he said.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, also disputed findings in an executive summary of the consultants' report, which were read to her by a reporter.
"The summary of findings seems suspect. It is not clear to me what transportation opportunities there are on the West Side rail yard. It is clear to anyone who visits the Javits Convention Center now that there is no easy transit access to the neighborhood."
Some business people along Ninth Avenue, near the West Side rail yards, were all but ecstatic over the consultants' findings.
A new stadium "would be the greatest thing that could ever happen to the West Side," said James Dell'Orto, owner of Manganaro Hero Boy, a restaurant that has operated on Ninth Avenue between 37th and 38th streets for 70 years. "God bless the Mayor, God bless Pataki and God bless Steinbrenner."
Financing for the study came equally from the state, city and team, all of whom have an interest in finding the most lucrative way to keep the Yankees from crossing the Hudson. In selecting Hellmuth, Obata, one of the country's top sports architects, for the study, the city and state aligned with a firm that would be qualified to design a new stadium.
The study, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, explicitly says that if the state and city want to issue bonds to build a stadium, it would be just as expensive at any of the other sites that were examined.
According to Hellmuth, Obata, renovating Yankee Stadium would cost $770.5 million. A completely new stadium there, which could be built next to the existing one, would cost $944.8 million. A baseball stadium in Pelham Bay Park would cost $910.2 million; a baseball-football stadium, $1.2 billion. A baseball stadium in Van Cortlandt Park would cost $1.09 billion; a two-sport facility, $1.4 billion.
The Pelham Bay and Van Cortlandt sites were rejected for their negligible transportation and mass transit systems, limited economic impact and environmental problems that could lead to litigation, the report found.
Although critics have raised significant questions about traffic and access, the report takes an optimistic view. The study says the existing nexus of subway and railroad connections "are extensive and afford this site a major advantage for all size events" and "would reduce expected traffic loads on the street network." However, none of the train connections discharge passengers closer than Eighth Avenue.
Limited parking has been a problem at the Javits Center, but the study proposes building garages with 3,000 spaces. It cites game-time availability of 5,000 to 8,000 existing spaces within a 15-minute walk.
A huge shift in how fans travel to games is predicted. Currently, 85 percent of Yankee fans now arrive in the Bronx by car, 15 percent by mass transit.
To get to the West Side, the study assumes that 45 percent to 65 percent of fans to arrive by mass transit, 25 percent by automobile and 10 percent by taxi.
The Yankees are apparently hoping that a West Side stadium will develop new fans, among them tourists in Manhattan and people who do not now go to Yankee games. Currently, about 60 percent of Yankee fans travel from New Jersey, Connecticut, Westchester and upstate, mostly by car.
About 32 percent come from Queens, Brooklyn and Long Island. But only 6 percent come from Manhattan.
The study argues that Manhattan would provide a stunning financial boost to the Yankees. Not only does it predict that a riverfront stadium would spur greater spending on tickets, concessions and parking, it also finds that the West Side option would do the following:
*Generate much more interest in renting high-priced luxury suites. The study predicts that in a baseball-only stadium, 120 luxury suites could be sold for $125,000 each; for a bigger, dual-sport stadium, it says 220 suites could be sold for $175,000 each. Yankee Stadium, which now has 19 suites, would accommodate only 65 suites if renovated or rebuilt.
*Produce greater sales of expensive seats. The study reckons that a West Side stadium could sell 8,000 seats at about $3,000 apiece. In Yankee Stadium, a maximum of 6,000 expensive seats are predicted.
*Make possible the sale of personal seat licenses, one-time fees that entitle buyers of season tickets the right to buy the same seat for a set period of time. The study predicts that 5,000 personal seat licenses could sell for $5,000 each for baseball fans, 15,000 at the same price for football fans. Potentially, a dual-sport stadium could raise $100 million toward construction by selling personal seat licenses.
*Let a company pay more to put its name on the stadium. The study says a company would pay $1.5 million a year for naming rights at a baseball facility, $2.5 million at a two-sport stadium, twice what the other sites could charge.
Although the study greatly favors the West Side, is does not rule out Yankee Stadium. The report discusses renovating it by widening it by 40 feet, building a three-story Hall of Fame and retail-entertainment complex and erecting a Metro-North railroad station.
The plan would also require huge renovations to the Major Deegan Expressway and Harlem River Drive; rehabilitation of the subway stations, addition of a second bridge across the Harlem River and garages with 2,000 new parking spaces.
The study also considered building a new stadium north of 161st Street in Macombs Dam Park and the razing of the old stadium to build three garages. But ultimately it decided that neither plan would come close to producing the money a West Side park would.
"The stadium's current economic impact on the community is limited," the study says, "and the impact of a new or renovated facility is not estimated to result in the development of measurable new commercial establishments."

HEADLINE: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
Bad Equipment Tied to Crash, Perry Suggests

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Defense Secretary William J. Perry suggested today that malfunctioning instruments may have caused the crash of an Air Force jet that took the life of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and at least 32 others in Croatia on Wednesday.
Returning from a trip to Egypt, Mr. Perry told reporters on his plane, "It was a classic sort of accident that good instrumentation should be able to prevent." 
 He did not specify whether he was referring to instruments on the ground or in the plane. Mr. Brown's plane, a military version of the Boeing 737, smashed into a mountain near Dubrovnik, the storied port on the Adriatic Sea.
More than 36 hours after the crash, it was still not clear how many passengers were aboard, though it was evident there were no survivors. After rescue teams searched all Wednesday night and all day today, hampered by fog and rain, Miomir Zuzul, the Croatian Ambassador to the United States, said they had discovered 33 bodies. The Pentagon used the same figure.
But the plane's manifest, issued by the State Department, listed 35 people: Mr. Brown and 11 Commerce Department aides, including Charles F. Meissner, Assistant Secretary for International Trade, whose wife, Doris, heads the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and William Morton, Deputy Assistant Secretary for International Economic Development; Lee F. Jackson, an American working at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development; James M. Lewek, a Central Intelligence Agency analyst; a photographer and an interpreter from the American Embassy in Zagreb; 12 business executives, 6 crew members and Nathaniel C. Nash, Frankfurt bureau chief of The New York Times.
Unable to fully explain the discrepancy, Glyn Davies, a State Department spokesman, said at an afternoon briefing: "We've made every effort with regards to this list to confirm its accuracy, and there are no indications that anyone listed on this manifest was not on the plane that crashed."
Mr. Davies added tonight: "The condition of the remains is such that it's difficult to say with certainty that there are 33 or 35 bodies there."
The cause of the crash was no clearer today than on Wednesday, but a few more details emerged. It was established, for example, that Cilipi Airport, southeast of Dubrovnik, had no instrument landing system -- the sophisticated aid to bad-weather navigation that major airports use. It was a casualty of the 1991 war. But the airport has a less advanced system, a VHF Omnidirectional Radio beacon, or VOR, that should have sufficed.
"People in Dubrovnik say that it was the worst storm they have seen in a decade," said Peter Galbraith, the United States Ambassador to Croatia. "The plane was not where it should have been. It seems to have flown up not along the coast but along a valley one ridge over."
Lieut. Gen. Howell Estes, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that many aircraft had landed at Cilipi without difficulty, including several during the foul weather on Wednesday, both before and after the accident.
No one disputed that the plane was almost two miles off course.
Mr. Brown's body was identified by Gen. Michael Canavan, commander of a special team supervising the recovery, the White House said. Fourteen bodies were carried down from Mt. Saint John, where the plane crashed, to a temporary morgue set up at the Dubrovnik airport, before work was halted for the night.
In Washington, John O'Sullivan, deputy to Daniel S. Pearson, a former judge, who as independent counsel had been heading an investigation into Mr. Brown's financial affairs, announced that the inquiry had been closed. He said a decision would be made soon whether to hand off investigations of Mr. Brown's son, Michael, and some of his business associates to another agency.
President Clinton, still stunned by the loss, attended a brief prayer service for Mr. Brown this morning at St. John's Church, across Lafayette Square from the White House. Along with scores of other Administration officials, the President took part in a responsive reading from Isaiah Chapter 40, verses 28 to 31, which included a passage much loved by the late Commerce Secretary:
"They that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run and not be weary; and they shall walk and not faint."
Noting that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King had been killed in Memphis 28 years ago today, the President declared that like the slain civil rights leader, "Our colleagues in the Commerce Department and the other Federal agencies, United States military and the business leaders who died outside Dubrovnik were answering a very important challenge of this time."
Mr. Clinton spent much of the afternoon on the telephone in an effort to reach the families of all the Americans who died in the crash. Late this afternoon the White House said the President had spoken with relatives of all the Government employees who died and was moving on to the crew and the businessmen.
No funeral plans for Mr. Brown were announced. The family planned to meet today to discuss arrangements, and it appeared probable that the service would be next week.
Inevitably, Washington being Washington, speculation sprang up about a successor to Mr. Brown. The name most mentioned was that of Thomas F. McLarty, the former White House Chief of Staff, a close friend of the President's from Arkansas and an experienced, widely traveled former energy executive.
Although Prime Minister Zlatko Matesa of Croatia said that a voice recorder had been recovered from the tail of the plane, senior American military officers here and in Europe said the plane carried no such equipment. Nor, they insisted, did it carry a "black box" of the type that records technical data on commercial planes. The T-43 plane involved was delivered two decades ago as a training plane for navigators, and when it was converted to carry what the Air Force calls "distinguished visitors," no voice or data recorders were added, according to Maj. Laura Feldman, a spokeswoman for the Air Force.
All the VIP aircraft that operate from Andrews Air Force Base just outside Washington, including Air Force One, carry such recorders, but the plane that crashed was stationed at Ramstein Air Base in Germany.
Representative Ike Skelton of Missouri, ranking minorty member of the military procurement subcommittee of the National Security Committee, said the Air Force had probably skipped the recorders as "a cost saver."
The absence of the recorders will complicate investigation of the tragedy. But some data will be available, including recordings of conversations between the plane and the control tower at Cilipi, which gave no hint of trouble, and recordings made on board an Awacs radar plane that was in the area.
Mr. Brown, 54, was leading a delegation of corporate executives who were exploring investment in the Balkans in the aftermath of the war in Bosnia. Mr. Lewek, 44, the C.I.A. analyst, was a member of the agency's Balkan Task Force. He was on the trip to provide Mr. Brown with detailed information on the possibilities of economic reconstruction in the region.
From 1990 to 1995, Mr. Lewek ran the staff that produces the President's Daily Brief, a very highly classified news digest that the agency distributes to a tiny handful of senior national political and military leaders.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Defect Found in Water Mains
 
A huge water main break in Astoria, Queens, last winter was caused by defective pipe, officials said. Tests show that large sections of the 9,000-foot-long pipe are of equally poor quality, and will have to be replaced or repaired. [Page A1.]
 
Report Favors New Stadium
 
A consultant's recommendation that the Yankees move from the Bronx to Manhattan's West Side was based on the conclusion that a new ball park along the Hudson River would produce a significant increase in attendance, higher prices for luxury seats and an enhanced image for New York City. [A1.]
 
Conflict Seen in Agency Bid
 
When a Queens social-services organization was trying to gain a multimillion-dollar contract with the city, it sent Albert J. Farina, a veteran official with the Department of Employment, to the city agency that was evaluating competing bids. Mr. Farina had been offered a job by the Queens agency, and six months later, Mr. Farina took a $75,000-a-year position with it. Mr. Farina's role appears to have violated city conflict-of-interest rules. [B1.]
 
New Home for Books and Bytes
 
More than one million books -- dealing with business, economics, chemistry, physics and mathematics -- have been moved from the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street to their new home, the Science, Industry and Business Library, at Madison Avenue and 34th Street. The new library, to open on May 2, will be an interactive research institution that may well be unmatched in the access to information it gives to the public. [B1.]
 
A Deputy Mayor Resigns
 
Further consolidating his inner circle of trusted aides in top jobs, Mayor Giuliani said that John S. Dyson would step down as Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and would be replaced by Fran Reiter, a close political confidante. [B1.]
 
Is Mass Transit Slipping?
 
New York's subway and bus system strikes many riders as fraying at the edges once more after years of an inspired comeback. The Transit Authority insists it isn't so, but hours of random subway riding have bolstered a nagging sense that there has been a pronounced, and worrisome, slippage since services were cut and the fare was raised to $1.50. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Abuse Seen in Baby's Death
 
The New York City Medical Examiner said that violent shaking had caused fatal brain injuries to a 5-month-old Queens baby, Mariah Scoon, whose parents fought to keep her on a ventilator after she had been declared brain-dead. The parents have denied that they abused the baby, and their lawyer said that the death of the baby was due to medical problems. [B3.]
 
Cotton Exchange Won't Move
 
New York City officials announced that the Cotton Exchange had agreed to remain in New York. In so doing, the Cotton Exchange joined the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in spurning the blandishments of New Jersey and accepting a package of incentives intended to keep both exchanges in New York City for the next 30 years. [B6.]
 
Court Rules on Notification
 
New York's highest court said that the state could not release the names on a registry of suspected child abusers to adoption and foster-care agencies without conducting a thorough inquiry into the accusations against those listed. The ruling was not expected to affect the way the state runs the 23-year-old registry; changes in the system were made in response to a 1994 decision by a Federal appeals court. [B5.]
 
Remembering a Son of Harlem
 
Ron Brown, the Secretary of Commerce, who died in a plane crash in Croatia, grew up in an apartment atop the Hotel Theresa in Harlem. He may have made his mark in Washington, but his old friends say his heart never left Harlem. [A13.]
 
Police officers shot and wounded suspected robbers in separate incidents in Queens and on Staten Island, officials said. [B5.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Deficiencies Found at A-Plant
 
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has found design deficiencies at the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant in Connecticut. The Commission said the problems were so serious that it had asked the plant's owner, Northeast Utilities, to provide it with information to determine whether the plant's license "should be suspended, modified or revoked." [B5.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Newark Plans Sports Complex
 
City officials in Newark plan to build a 6,000-seat stadium downtown in an effort to revive minor league baseball there, where the Newark Bears drew crowds to Ruppert Stadium in the 1930's and 40's. The ball park will be part of a $20 million complex that will include a soccer stadium. [B4.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Russian Communists Invoke Soviet Era in Their Platform
In Russia Communist members of Parliament have prepared a draft law calling for heavy state intervention in the economy. Like the Bolsheviks 70 years ago, the Communists, if returned to power, favor guaranteed employment, cheap apartments and controls on the price of consumer goods.
They would curtail pro-market changes and reject some key measures Russia has adopted at the insistence of the International Monetary Fund, which recently granted Russia a $10.1 billion loan. [Page A1.]
 
Venezuelan Financier Indicted
A New York grand jury returned indictments charging Orlando Castro Llanes, a well-known Venezuelan financier; his son, Orlando Castro Castro, and his grandson, Jorge Castro Barredo, with a scheme to defraud depositors of more than $55 million at Banco Progreso Internacional de Puerto Rico. [D3.]
 
Daiwa Manager Enters Guilty Plea
Masahiro Tsuda, the former general manager of Daiwa Bank's New York branch, pleaded guilty to a charge that he helped conceal $1.1 billion in trading losses from Federal authorities last summer. He said he was following orders from Tokyo. [D3.]
 
Instrument Problems Cited in Crash
Defense Secretary William J. Perry suggested that malfunctioning instruments may have caused the crash of an Air Force jet that took the life of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 32 others, including a number of business leaders, in Croatia. [A1.]
 
Businesses handled their losses in different ways. Some like Riggs National Bank chose to observe a mourning period before naming successors, while others like ABB Inc., the American subsidiary of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, quickly announced changes. [A13.]
 
Lucent Shares Jump 13%
Shares of Lucent Technologies jumped 13 percent from their opening price of $27 to $30.625. The stock, the biggest initial public offering in history, was the most heavily traded issue on the Big Board. [D3.]
 
The market was otherwise listless. The Dow industrials fell 6.86 points from Wednesday's record, to 5,682.88. For the week it surged 1.7 percent or 95.74 points. [D6.]
 
Emerging Markets Come Back
The world's emerging stock markets from Poland and Turkey to China and Malaysia staged a turnaround in the first quarter of this year, while developed stock markets rose at a modest pace. The Morgan Stanley Capital International index showed emerging markets rose 5.8 percent in dollars in the quarter. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Cotton Exchange to Stay in N.Y.
The Cotton Exchange joined the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in spurning New Jersey's blandishments and accepting a package of incentives intended to keep both exchanges in New York City for the next 30 years. [B5.]
 
Clinton Signs Farm Bill
President Clinton signed a sweeping farm bill that abandons Depression-era subsidy programs. Payments will be guaranteed but decline gradually over seven years. [A22.]
 
Goebbels Book Is Halted
After a storm of protests, St. Martin's Press halted publication of David Irving's book "Goebbels: Mastermind of the Third Reich." The company's chairman called it "inescapably anti-Semitic." [D4.]

HEADLINE: Yet Another Shift in Mayor's Circle: Deputy Mayor for Finance Leaves

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Further consolidating his inner circle of trusted aides in top jobs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that John S. Dyson would step down as Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development and would be replaced by Fran Reiter, a political confidante.
The changes follow by one week Mr. Giuliani's decision to place another loyal ally, Howard Safir, in the Police Commissioner's job, which was part of a flurry of other top-level shifts in the upper ranks of the administration. 
 As Deputy Mayor for economic development, Mr. Dyson negotiated deals to keep businesses in the city and also served as the Mayor's primary voice on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. But Mr. Dyson was also sometimes considered a liability to the Mayor. His acerbic wit and bluntness got him into trouble on more than one occasion, forcing Mr. Giuliani to distance himself from comments made by the Deputy Mayor that were considered to be insensitive.
Ms. Reiter, in her role as Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations, has developed a reputation as a tough negotiator who nonetheless was able to build consensus in the city's notoriously combative constituencies. And since her days as the Mayor's deputy campaign manager, she has been considered one of the Mayor's most loyal appointees.
While the Mayor portrayed the series of resignations and new appointments as a fact of political life in any government, the recent changes reflect an unusual amount of turnover for an administration whose top tier has otherwise remained remarkably stable in the Mayor's 27 months in office.
With his choices, Mr. Giuliani appears to have brought some of his most trusted appointees into his inner circle of advisers. Mr. Dyson, a Democrat, and the departing Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, came into the Mayor's administration as relative outsiders and proved to be lightning rods for attention, and now both have been replaced with appointees much closer to the Mayor as he prepares for an expected re-election bid next year.
"My view of change in an institution is that it's a good thing," Mr. Giuliani said. "Change always means that things get revitalized. People take a fresh look at things."
Mr. Dyson, whose departure had been rumored for months, said he wanted to return to overseeing his family's considerable business holdings, including the Millbrook Vineyards winery in Dutchess County and an investment company founded by his father. Because he is independently wealthy, Mr. Dyson accepted only $1 a year for his services.
The Mayor said Mr. Dyson will remain an unpaid adviser on a number of major projects, including negotiations over a new Yankee Stadium. He will also keep his position as one of the Mayor's four appointees on the M.T.A., where he has vigorously argued against transit fare increases.
Both the Mayor and Mr. Dyson made light of the Deputy Mayor's outspoken nature during yesterday's news conference. While explaining that Mr. Dyson would keep his office in City Hall, the Mayor said, "You'll still have John to kick around, if you want, and the good thing about John is, he'll be here to kick you back."
But Mr. Dyson's outspokenness was not always something the Mayor could smile about. Just months after Mr. Giuliani took office, Mr. Dyson fell under the spotlight with a memorandum on welfare reform that was roundly criticized as racially insensitive. Referring to an article in The New York Daily News that had referred to the Mayor and First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers as "two white men with no City Hall experience who must hold an increasingly diverse immigrant city together," Mr. Dyson wrote in his note to the Mayor, "Do not worry, two white guys have been running this city of immigrants for over 200 years."
Mr. Dyson also attracted unwanted attention when, in a dispute with the New York City Comptroller over whether to rehire a company owned by a black woman to sell the city's bonds, he said, "The Comptroller ought to know the difference between a bid and a watermelon." Mr. Dyson later apologized for the comment, saying he had not intended it to be offensive.
Yesterday, he was more introspective about his sometimes combative style. "I think it's important for people trying to do the things that I'm trying to do to be willing to break eggs to make an omelet," he said. "There's a lot of theory around to never do anything risky, but I don't think that's a role for somebody like myself who's trying to make bold changes."
Ruth W. Messinger, Borough President of Manhattan, said Mr. Dyson was not always considered effective in his economic development work. "He was not seen as an ally by many people in the business community," she said.
Ms. Reiter, on the other hand, "has been responsive to many community concerns and interests," added Ms. Messinger, a frequent critic of the Mayor. "And this will pose a totally new challenge to her."
Raymond B. Harding, leader of the state's Liberal Party and one of the Mayor's closest political allies, heartily praised the promotion of Ms. Reiter, who also is a former chairwoman of the state's Liberal Party.
"She has a trait which is of high value in that she's a closer," he said. "She puts a deal together and all parties are happy, and that's an ability that is highly prized in government."
Ms. Reiter, for her part, seemed undaunted by the prospect of filling Mr. Dyson's shoes.
"I have a pretty well deserved reputation for being outspoken on my own," she said. "In fact, one of the reasons John and I have worked so well together is that while we both have pretty strong personalities, we have had a very common vision of what the Mayor wanted for the city and what we had to do to get there."
Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant, said Ms. Reiter's promotion was a clear sign that the Mayor has chosen to surround himself with loyal people.
"There's no doubt they are circling the wagons here," he said. "And the circle is getting smaller and smaller all the time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the departure of John S. Dyson, center, as Deputy Mayor for finance. His successor is Fran Reiter, right, another Deputy Mayor. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE ISSUES;
Plane Crash in Croatia Silenced A Big Player in Capital Debates

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
When Ronald H. Brown died on a hillside near Dubrovnik, Croatia, on Wednesday, he was in the thick of three battles here that touched the divergent roles he played in Washington.
The first was a continuing struggle within the Administration -- sometimes still heated three years after it began -- over the degree to which the nation's commercial interests should drive its foreign policy agenda. 
 As Commerce Secretary, Mr. Brown often argued fiercely for what he called "commercial diplomacy," the use of America's clout abroad to create jobs at home, a stark counterpoint to the "high diplomacy" of the cold war. But there was always resistance, and many wonder whether, without Mr. Brown's high-profile circuiting of the globe, that approach will prove a permanent legacy of the Clinton Administration, or whether it could slowly dissolve.
His second battle was to save the Commerce Department from a Republican-dominated Congress that viewed it as a ripe target for disassembly or outright abolition. With his trademark passion, Mr. Brown called this "unilateral disarmament" in the face of Japanese and European competition, and was winning the argument. But without him, many in the Administration said today, the issue is bound to arise again.
And the third battle centered on Mr. Brown's true passion in life: politics. His death deprives the Clinton Administration of its most visible black Cabinet member and its bridge to black voters, even though some prominent blacks were concerned that Mr. Brown was a bit too much of an insider, too interested in compromise. Mr. Brown was just beginning to try again to work the magic that he performed as chairman of the Democratic National Committee: to energize both the left wing of the party, which has often been disillusioned by the Clinton Administration, and the conservative, largely white middle class that has its own, very different reservations.
"You just don't find people who have feet planted so firmly in different camps the way Ron did, and who can bridge such yawning chasms," said Mickey Kantor, who worked side-by-side with Mr. Brown managing the 1992 campaign, and then again negotiating the intricacies of a new world of international trade as the United States trade representative. "There are some things in this world you just can't replace."
In the weeks before his death, Mr. Brown was playing down his behind-the-scenes role in preparations for the coming campaign, in part because the financial dealings that were under investigation effectively precluded him from any formal role in the campaign. But it was hardly a secret that he had begun showing up at the small weekly meetings at the White House of the President's closest political advisers.
"I'm really not a political strategist these days," the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee said a few weeks ago, with the broad smile he used to suggest that he didn't believe a word of what he just uttered, and didn't expect anyone else to, either.
"This is a man who had the campaign in his blood," Carl R. Wagner, a Washington consultant and one of Mr. Brown's closest confidants, said today. "And just as he knew that the problem in 1992 was how to focus entirely on the economy, this year he knew that the question was how to energize a re-election campaign and how to get people out of the stands. That's what he was worrying about."
But for Mr. Brown, the campaign and his job at the Commerce Department merged into one. And that was particularly evident in the symbolism of his 15 trips abroad with corporate executives, many of whom would never think of voting for a Democrat for President.
For Mr. Brown, the trade mission was the message, and the message was that the United States would no longer divorce its relationships around the world from the creation of jobs for Americans.
"We are the bridge between domestic and foreign policy," he said of the Commerce Department in December. "And what that means is that commercial interests are now on an equal par with security in the world of foreign policy."
But it was never quite that simple, as Mr. Brown acknowledged in his more candid moments. While Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin all uttered similar sentiments when the discussion was abstract, their institutions often fought back when the issue boiled down to hard cases.
China is a prime example. Mr. Brown would readily acknowledge that the United States had far broader interests than simply selling airplanes or telephone systems.
But often he argued for toning down or delaying criticism of Beijing that might be likely to result in nothing but retaliation against American business interests.
In the mid-levels of the State Department and the Pentagon, Mr. Brown's position was frequently characterized as mercantilist and some feared it would undercut America's moral authority around the world. Mr. Brown and his defenders portrayed themselves as realists.
"There are a thousand issues that can arise in a post-cold-war world -- human rights, the environment, corruption, overseas military bases -- that if they are handled wrong will create great handicaps for the American economy," said Jeffrey Garten, his under secretary for nearly three years. "And I think that if the result of his death is that the scales tip back to the way it was when the Clinton Administration came into office, that would be a setback."
Both Mr. Kantor and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the National Economic Council, said today that would not happen. "There are larger forces at work here and the reality is that no nation can back away from making these kinds of concerns as important as 'high diplomacy,' " Ms. Tyson said. "But I'm sure it won't be a smooth path in that direction, and I don't know of anyone who can articulate the need for this kind of change in public the way Ron could."
Congress discovered that power of articulation this fall, as the Republicans heated up their campaign to slice the Commerce Department to shreds, spreading its vital functions all over the Government and eliminating anything that was left. Mr. Brown, colleagues recall, did not at first consider their threat to be serious. He later decided he was wrong, and began a full-force campaign, enlisting corporate executives he knew from his travels to press their Republican friends to back off.
"There wasn't much support for his position," one colleague recalled today. "So he created the ground swell himself."
Surprised at the reach of Mr. Brown's Rolodex and the success of his gentle arm-twisting, the Republicans backed off. But without him in charge, they have another chance as the 1997 budget is debated.
Meanwhile, even the White House was a bit stunned today by the outpouring of condolences from foreign leaders. Many of them had been on the receiving end of that mix of smooth charm and stiff persuasion Mr. Brown used to close deals for American goods.
"They had seen American diplomats before," one of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers said today. "They had seen canny politicians, and African-Americans with power. They had seen businessmen with order books in their hands. But they had never seen all of that in one package."

HEADLINE: Gene Tests: What You Know Can Hurt You

BYLINE: By Barbara Koenig; Barbara Koenig, a senior researcher at the Stanford University Center for Biomedical Ethics, co-directs the program in genomics, ethics and society.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
Last year, it was discovered that 1 percent of Ashkenazi Jewish women, those of Central or Eastern European ancestry, carry a mutated form of a gene that might predispose them to breast and ovarian cancer.
After this discovery, a surgeon who operates on women with breast cancer told me that a day rarely passes when a patient does not ask about "the gene test." 
 Even with this demand, however, almost all leading scientists and two major commercial testing laboratories agreed informally not to offer the test for the mutation to the general public because widespread testing would do more harm than good.
That consensus was broken recently by Dr. Joseph D. Schulman, director of the Genetics and I.V.F. Institute in Fairfax, Va. The doctor, who advertised the service on the World Wide Web, says it will give women access to valuable information. But in genetic testing, what you know won't necessarily help you -- indeed, it might even hurt you.
As Alice Wexler points out in "Mapping Fate," her book about genetically determined Huntington's Disease, Americans' strong bias for information leads them to believe in genetic testing. Doing something, anything, to counter illness is considered the brave and correct approach.
But testing for the 185delAG mutation does not help most women. A positive test does not mean you will get cancer, and a negative test does not mean that you won't.
Most scientists agree that the mutation occurs in families in which many members have suffered from breast and ovarian cancer. But leaping to the conclusion that a mutation inevitably leads to cancer, especially for women without a family history, reflects a naive genetic determinism and ignores the possible effects of the environment and other genes on one's health.
But let's assume that a woman from a high-risk family tests positive. What then? There is no guaranteed way to prevent cancer or detect it early. Some desperate women do resort to drastic measures such as surgically removing their breasts.
Paradoxically, this isn't the recommended treatment for many women already diagnosed with cancer. For a decade, more doctors have recommended and more women, especially those with small tumors, have chosen instead to have lumpectomies.
Knowing your genetic makeup can also create profound emotional and financial problems. For example, a spouse might use this information in a custody dispute. Or a woman might decide not to have children, for fear of passing on the gene. But if she decides to adopt, will she be approved by an agency? And should a 9-year-old girl be tested for the mutation?
The test brings up other thorny questions that may be better left unexplored. For instance, with current technology, a woman could test a fetus for the gene and then abort it. In his ad, Dr. Schulman suggests that his Genetics and I.V.F. Institute may be able to screen embryos for the gene mutation.
There are also real economic repercussions. Women could face discrimination from employers and health insurers. And most physicians have little experience with ordering and interpreting genetic tests that determine a woman's cancer risk (and in guiding families through the turmoil generated by the results.)
Until basic research on the clinical significance of the 185delAG mutation is complete, there is no justification for widespread screening. Unfortunately, nothing prevents laboratories from offering genetic tests, nor are there any regulations to insure the quality of the tests.
In March, a Federal task force on testing suggested possible regulatory strategies, from requiring Food and Drug Administration approval for new tests to strengthening the laws that govern labs.
Either approach would slow down the premature commercialization of testing. Strict regulation may be unpopular among those who believe that women have a right to this information. But extreme caution should be the order of the day.

HEADLINE: Dollar Up in Thin Trading After Report of Rise in Jobs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose in thin trading yesterday after a report showing strong job growth in the United States convinced currency traders that the Federal Reserve would not cut interest rates anytime soon.
The Labor Department said that the economy added 140,000 nonfarm jobs last month, more than twice what many analysts had expected. It also lowered its estimate of February job growth by a smaller margin than many analysts had anticipated, to 624,000 jobs from 705,000. 
 "Now the Fed won't ease, and it may hike rates," said Karl Halligan, strategic currency trader at CIC Bank in New York. "I think the dollar can go a lot higher."
The prospect of steady or higher rates helps the dollar by making United States deposits more attractive. That is especially true at a time when many analysts think European rates are headed lower.
But trading was very light yesterday, exaggerating price movements. Most European markets were closed for Good Friday and banks in the United States deployed only skeletal trading staffs. European markets will also be closed on Monday.
In shortened New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 107.68 Japanese yen, up from 107.01 yen on Thursday. The dollar edged up to 1.4835 German marks, from 1.4800 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5290 from $1.5313.
A sharp drop in United States bond prices kept the dollar from rising further, traders said. Lower bond prices weigh on the dollar because foreign investors selling American assets frequently convert the proceeds into other currencies.
While the Federal Reserve is now seen as maintaining a steady interest-rate stance, the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, is likely to reduce rates this quarter to bolster growth, analysts said. The German economy contracted in the fourth quarter and probably shrank in the first quarter as well.
To be sure, any rally by the dollar may be hampered if foreign investors dump American bonds, and if weakness among bonds spreads to the stock market, which was closed yesterday.
"My feeling is stocks will get hit hard, which will probably hurt the dollar early next week," said Stephen Jury, chief currency trader at Union Bank of Switzerland.
Still, many traders do not expect the dollar to escape its recent narrow ranges in the next two weeks. For the last month, the dollar has traded between 1.4660 marks and 1.4922 marks and 104.94 yen and 108.00 yen.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Rose Sharply In February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Americans' installment debt grew in February at the fastest pace in eight months as each of the major categories of consumer credit posted sharp gains.
The Federal Reserve said today that consumer installment credit shot up 13.9 percent at an annual rate, the steepest since rising 14.4 percent last June. The $12 billion increase was the biggest since a $12.8 billion advance last May. 
 The increase pushed up total consumer debt to $1.048 trillion, 14 percent higher than in February 1995. Many analysts had expected debt to grow just $10 billion, down from $10.9 billion in January, when credit rose at a 12.7 percent rate.
Consumer credit includes all household debt not secured by real estate.
Analysts contend that consumers eventually will have to rein in their borrowing as debt levels climb and income growth remains relatively slack. In fact, there already have been reports of growing delinquency rates in several areas.
This generates concerns about the pace of consumer spending, which represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Spending grew just 1.2 percent during the final three months of 1995, down from gains of 2.8 percent in the third quarter and 3.4 percent in the second quarter.
But in February, revolving credit, which includes credit cards, jumped $6.4 billion, the biggest advance since $7.4 billion last May. The 19 percent annualized gain was the steepest since 20.5 percent in June. The increase pushed total revolving debt to $407.2 billion.
Automobile loans rose by $3 billion, a 10.3 percent annualized gain, and pushed motor vehicle debt to $359.3 billion.
The credit category that includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations increased $2.6 billion. The 11.3 percent rate of advance lifted this debt category to $281.2 billion.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Will Regret Courting Tobacco

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your April 2 front-page article on efforts by Senator Jesse Helms to make sure North Carolina tobacco gains opportunities in Southeast Asia:
Ambassador Le Van Bang of Vietnam would do well to keep Senator Helms and the tobacco industry at arm's length. Last fall I spent five months in Vietnam conducting surveys about cigarette smoking. We found that 73 percent of the men and 4 percent of the women there smoke. 
 Although Vietnam bans the import of foreign cigarettes, in 1994 it granted licenses to overseas tobacco companies to produce their brands in Vietnam, including Philip Morris's Marlboro and R. J. Reynolds's Camel. We found that 22 percent of Vietnamese cigarette smokers now smoke foreign brands and an additional 16 percent said they would smoke foreign brands if they could afford them.
The record from other Asian countries shows that smoking rates rise steeply soon after foreign tobacco corporations enter their domestic markets, as the domestic cigarette producers mimic the aggressive marketing tactics of the foreign corporations.
With current smoking rates, the Vietnamese can expect about 10 percent of the population to die early from tobacco-related diseases.
Mr. Bang may see some short-term economic and political advantages to welcoming the tobacco merchants. But he should realize that these merchants are desperate to maintain their profits by replacing smokers in the United States who have quit or died.
 
CHRIS JENKINS
San Francisco, April 2, 1996
 
The writer is director of the Vietnamese Community Health Promotion Project, U. of California.

HEADLINE: Bonds Tumble, Sending Interest Rates to 7-Month High

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices tumbled yesterday, driving interest rates to a seven-month high, as the bond market was caught off guard for the second consecutive month by an employment report showing surprising strength.
In a shortened trading session, bond prices fell after the Labor Department reported that 140,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls in March -- more than double what many economists had predicted. 
 While the data pointed to faster growth in the economy, with little pickup in inflation, the figures also crushed any remaining hopes in the bond market that the Federal Reserve would lower short-term interest rates this spring.
Indeed, many traders and analysts are now debating whether the central bank will raise interest rates for the first time since Feb. 1, 1995.
"The market is now beginning to build in the concept that the next Fed move could be a tightening, irrespective of the timing of the next Fed move," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management in New York.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 1 27/32 of a percentage point, to 89 18/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.82 percent, from 6.67 percent on Thursday, as well as a week earlier. The yield on the 30-year bond is used as a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer interest rates. It is at its highest since Aug. 23, 1995, when it was 6.91 percent.
For investors, the drop in prices cost them about $18.43 for every $1,000 invested in 30-year bonds.
Still, the selloff came in trading that ended early, at noon, with many market participants away because of Good Friday or Passover. About $40 billion in Treasury securities were traded yesterday, according to Govpx, a bond pricing service, down sharply from $80.2 billion on Thursday, when trading was lackluster.
"It is important to note that volume was thin today and that price movements could have been exaggerated," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York, a market research and analysis firm.
"While aggressive players like hedge funds were in, those that stabilize the market were not, like the mutuals, banks and other investors who buy, hold and sell to arrange portfolios," he said. "These investment people are basically out today because of the holiday."
Carroll J. Delaney, director of Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said that with many market participants gone for a long holiday weekend and with European markets closed on Monday, "it may well be the middle of next week before the true impact of today's figures can be adequately assessed."
The employment report yesterday essentially confirmed to many in the market that the huge surge in payrolls in February was not a fluke. The report followed other recent data, including reports on industrial production and consumer spending, that have indicated a pickup. Bond yields have jumped a number of times in the last month on concerns that the economy is growing faster than believed earlier in the year.
"However you look, the trend is up in terms of payroll growth," said Ray Worseck, chief economist and manager at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "And that leads people to conclude that the Fed will not ease anytime soon."
Mr. Palash of MCM MoneyWatch said, "What I think the market is focusing on today is that the first-quarter payroll average gain was 206,00, which is above the 142,000 fourth-quarter average."
But he added that it was "not surprising that the first-quarter average exceeded the fourth-quarter average because of special factors like weather-related and seasonal-adjustment problems."
The 5.6 percent unemployment rate showed that underlying growth was 2 to 2.5 percent, he said. "So this kind of growth should not be inflationary," Mr. Palash added.
He said the market's sharp reaction to the employment report was influenced in part by concerns over supply and worries about coming inflation reports. Next week, the Treasury will auction new two-year and five-year notes, and the Government will report on producer prices and consumer prices for March.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.06 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.40 percent, both about a quarter of a percentage point higher than the previous day.
"The bottom line is that Fed policy is on hold and the bond market has to contend with decent growth going into the spring," Mr. Palash said. "Right now the market will have to wait until next week's inflation reports to determine its next level of pricing."

HEADLINE: New Pressures on Airline Crash-Liability Accord

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
The Warsaw Convention governing the liability of an airline when passengers die in a plane crash is crumbling as airlines try to raise the accord's $75,000 limit on damages.
But prospects for a new agreement are uncertain, because the United States Department of Transportation is demanding that the accord provide that damage suits involving Americans be heard in the United States. Some foreign airlines reject that demand. 
 This is the third effort to raise the $75,000 limit, which was set in 1966 and all parties agree is now far too low. Efforts in 1977 and 1988 would have raised the limit several-fold and were eagerly supported by American officials, but the United States did not approve them. Trial lawyers said the higher limits were still too low, and aircraft manufacturers feared high limits would encourage suits against them.
"The amount of time it's taking to do something rational is simply astonishing," said Jeffrey N. Shane, an aviation lawyer who was Assistant Secretary of Transportation for policy and international affairs from 1989 to 1993.
The Warsaw Convention, initiated in 1929 among 29 countries and joined by the United States in 1934, also governs who may sue and where, and details cargo rules. All nations with commercial airlines have signed on, but the airlines agree that the document needs to be updated.
Because of the low liability limit, many airlines are voluntarily paying more, either to spare themselves a lengthy trial at which families will try to show negligence -- which allows higher damages -- or for general good will, or because they do not think the limits will hold up in court.
American Airlines, for example, has told families of the people who died when one of its planes crashed in Colombia in December that it would negotiate as if the limit did not exist; it is doing the same for the 16 passengers on international trips who were on the American Eagle commuter flight that crashed in Roselawn, Ind., in October 1994.
"The message American is sending is, 'We'll do what's fair, because we know a jury will do what's fairer,' " said Barry Lambert Harris, who was an acting administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration in the Bush Administration.
But the airlines would like a realistic limit and uniform system. Representatives of airlines from around the world met this week in Montreal to try to work out the details of a system with no limits. United States airlines have received an antitrust exemption to negotiate an agreement, which would be subject to Government approval.
The airlines and American officials envision fairly simple negotiations with families over "economic damages," the amount that the victim was likely to have earned over the remaining years of his or her life, given normal life expectancy. The sticking point now is which court would resolve disputes if negotiations failed.
Under the current agreement, survivors can bring suit in the country the plane was flying to, the home country of the airline, a country where the airline has its major operation or the country where the contract for transportation was written.
The United States wants a "fifth jurisdiction" for Americans: the United States. Since domestic carriers are based here, they can already be sued here; adding the "fifth jurisdiction" would generally affect overseas carriers.
Hans Ephraimson-Abt, whose 23-year-old daughter, Alice, died in the crash of Korean Air Lines flight 007 13 years ago, and whose case is still in court in New York, said that 147 of the 269 passengers on that flight had had their cases settled for $75,000; among them were a few Americans who could not get access to an American court. Other cases are still pending in Japan or the Philippines. The plane, shot down by the Soviet Union when it strayed into Soviet airspace, was en route to Tokyo.
Mr. Ephraimson-Abt, the chairman of the American Association for Families of KAL 007 Victims, said some Americans on the flight had not bought their tickets in this country and had to sue in South Korea, but the Korean courts had thrown the cases out, a ruling both he and prosecutors in Seoul attribute to corruption.
Mr. Ephraimson-Abt said that without the $75,000 limit, all the cases would have been settled years ago. Instead, he and other relatives of plane crash victims say, cases can drag on so long that victims' small children are beyond college age before any damage awards are made.
Differing economic standards and points of view are also problems, he said. Many people in third world countries "think all Americans are millionaires," and are not sympathetic to them, he added.
Consequently, some foreign carriers are balking at submitting to the jurisdiction of American courts. But not all foreign carriers are hiding behind the $75,000 shield. In 1992, the Japanese airlines voluntarily renounced the $75,000 limit on international flights, and 12 international airlines, meeting in Kuala Lumpur in November, agreed in principle to waive all limits.
"It doesn't wash well anywhere," said George N. Tompkins, an American lawyer who represents Japan Air Lines and other foreign carriers.
But Mr. Tomkins said some foreign carriers would object to any agreement that subjects them to American courts, with traditional American levels of compensation.
On the other hand, Anne H. McNamara, the head lawyer at American Airlines, said, "We are not availing ourselves of the limit because it is so unfair." Still, if the airline is unable to reach a settlement in a damage case and it ends up in court, American may invoke that limit, she said. However, most airlines are buying insurance against such suits, and the insurance companies generally assume that the $75,000 limit will be ignored by American juries.
She added that juries in American courts "like to do rough justice," and will declare an airline negligent if that is what it takes to get around the limit and award higher damages.
But insisting that foreign airlines submit to an American court will be difficult, said Mr. Shane, the former Under Secretary of Transportation, for it would mean making airline tickets different legally from all other kinds of purchases; if those result in litigation, he said, the suit is in the place where the transaction occurred.
