HEADLINE: A Landmark In Detroit May Be Sold

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 5

 BODY:
The owners of Detroit's landmark Renaissance Center are nearing a sale of the giant office, retail and hotel complex, people involved in the negotiations said today.
Gerald Hines and his son, Jeffrey, both Houston real estate investors, are among the handful of potential buyers in talks with investment bankers and lawyers for the center's owners -- four insurance companies and several dozen corporate and individual investors, the people said. 
 J. Joyce Cusmano, a spokeswoman for the Renaissance Center's management, said, "Right now, Renaissance Center Venture does not have a binding purchase and sale agreement, but they are continuing to discuss the sale in earnest with interested parties." She declined to elaborate and said she did not know the names of the potential buyers.
Eric B. Larson, project manager in Detroit for the Hines Interests Limited Partnership, confirmed that his company was bidding on the Renaissance Center. "I do believe a transaction will occur in the near future," Mr. Larson said.
The Hineses have stakes in a number of commercial buildings around the country. They developed the Houston Galleria, among other properties. Here in Detroit, in 1991, the Hineses and five Japanese equity partners built One Detroit Center, a $250 million office building that houses Comerica Bank.
The identity of other potential buyers for the Renaissance Center could not be learned. Any deal would probably be for the entire complex, which consists of five glass towers ranging in height from 39 to 73 floors.
The complex's owners, which include the Ford Motor Company, announced in October 1994 that they were considering a sale or refinancing. The building cost $350 million to build in the 1970's. By last summer, the asking price was $125 million. But with the downtown Detroit real estate market still weak, industry experts are skeptical that it will fetch much more than $80 million or $90 million.
While the Renaissance Center's price has fallen sharply, the sale could signal more than bottom fishing because the troubled property has been on the block for so long. Its sale could mean that the commercial real estate market in Detroit -- a city known for empty skyscrapers with beautiful architecture -- is improving. The once-dismal residential real estate market has picked up in recent years.
The complex, on the riverfront, is often seen on postcards of Detroit and dominates the city's skyline. When the center opened in 1977, Detroit hoped it would spark renewal in a city that had suffered in the decade since the 1967 riots.
Its very name reflects the hopes for urban renewal that city leaders and the complex's developers attached to it from the beginning. But the center has received mixed reviews: some say it has drawn tenants from other downtown office buildings while others contend that it has improved the downtown business climate and reduced the number of companies moving to the suburbs.
The central 73-story tower of the complex houses the Westin Hotel, which has more than 1,400 rooms and is topped by a revolving restaurant. Four 39-floor office towers surround it. Together, they have more than 2.2 million square feet of space. All are connected by several maze-like floors near the ground that house shops and restaurants. Even longtime Detroiters still routinely get lost in the complex.
The property's ownership, like its layout, is complicated, and that has hindered its sale in the past. The Renaissance Center was the pet project of Henry Ford 2d. Then the chairman of Ford Motor, he and 48 other companies and individuals invested in it. Five financial institutions -- the Ford Motor Credit Company, the Aetna Life Insurance Company, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Travelers Insurance Company -- held the complex's original $200 million mortgage.
In October 1983 the ownership was revamped to its current mix. The five first-mortgage holders now hold a 53 percent stake, while the other 49 investors own 47 percent of the complex. East Dil, a real estate investment bank based in Manhattan, is representing the owners in the current negotiations. The managing partner, Wayne L. Maggin, referred requests for comment to Ms. Cusmano.
Ford was closed today and representatives could not be reached for comment. Officials at Aetna and Hancock, the lead mortgage-holders, did not return calls seeking comment. Two nearby, smaller towers are not part of the sale. They were developed by Ford and Rockefeller Center Inc., and were sold to ANR Ren-Cen Inc. in 1984.

HEADLINE: For First Time, Giuliani Picks Black Deputy Mayor

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Rudy Washington as his Deputy Mayor for Community Relations yesterday, placing a black man for the first time in the highest level of his administration.
Mr. Washington, an entrepreneur from Queens and a trusted aide during Mr. Giuliani's campaign, was the city's Commissioner of the Department of Business Services, responsible for encouraging the growth of small and medium-sized companies. 
 He will assume some of the duties of Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who was named on Thursday as the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, replacing John S. Dyson, who resigned. The Mayor said that Ms. Reiter would retain her current authority over planning issues, while Mr. Washington would retain his oversight of small-business issues.
In making the appointment, Mr. Giuliani noted Mr. Washington's work regulating the Fulton Fish Market and in helping to move illegal vendors from 125th Street and other crowded streets into city-owned markets.
Mr. Giuliani acknowledged that Mr. Washington would add diversity to City Hall, but he adamantly rejected the notion that he had promoted Mr. Washington merely to answer criticism for having only white faces among his inner circle of advisers.
"I haven't appointed a black Deputy Mayor," Mr. Giuliani said. "I've appointed Rudy Washington a Deputy Mayor. That's the way I appoint people."
"I believe it's also additionally very good for the city that we have representation of the different communities of the city at the highest level of city government," the Mayor said.
"But," he added, speaking of the appointment, "the principal reason is this man's talent."
Many of the city's black leaders applauded Mr. Washington's promotion and said they hoped that he would now be in a better position to push for the needs of black residents. Some said that while Mr. Washington had proved himself to be an able administrator, he was also noteworthy for his willingness to execute mayoral policies that had not always been popular among blacks, like the dismantling of programs intended to steer city contracts to minority-owned companies.
But some criticized Mr. Giuliani for his track record on minority issues and said that simply appointing a black deputy mayor would not be enough to win the support of blacks.
"Rudy Washington has demonstrated loyalty to the Mayor and he deserves to be elevated," said C. Virginia Fields, a City Councilwoman who represents Harlem. "Maybe now he'll be in position to do even more. But the Mayor has to go beyond just this appointment, because he has sorely neglected the African-American community since he took office."
But Ms. Fields also questioned how much independence Mr. Washington has shown. She noted that plans to move illegal vendors from 125th Street had been developed under the previous administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins.
"It was a ready-made situation," Ms. Fields said. "While we are appreciative that Rudy Washington supported the move, I have not seen evidence of things that have been carried forward that were not already in place."
Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, was critical of yesterday's announcement.
"It's suspicious because it's so late into Mr. Giuliani's administration," he said. "It smacks of tokenism and window dressing." Mr. Meyers said he would have preferred to see a black person appointed to a position with more authority and said he considered community relations "a soft job."
Mr. Washington said that the Giuliani administration had often been criticized for its dealings with minorities, but had not received much credit for its successes.
Pointing to the Mayor's decision to eliminate a practice established under former Mayor Dinkins in which city agencies had a goal of awarding 20 percent of their contracts to companies owned by women or minorities, Mr. Washington said, "All of the stories about how minorities weren't going to get work, how it was going to be a devastating situation, I'm proud to say that every year since I've been here, that program has grown." He said his department was able to increase contracts to female- and minority-owned companies.
Dennis M. Walcott, president of the New York Urban League, said while dealing with that issue, Mr. Washington showed that he was willing to carry out the Mayor's program even though it was extremely unpopular with many minority residents in the city.
"He has been able to sit down and quietly negotiate without being a magnet for heat," he said. "That takes either special skill or a conscious effort to do that. Either way, he has definitely shown responsiveness in carrying out the Mayor's viewpoint."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rudy Washington was named a deputy mayor yesterday. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Three Mid-Atlantic States Show A Jump in Jobless Rate to 6.8%

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Although the national unemployment rate crept up only slightly in March, the rate for New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania moved sharply higher, according to a Federal report issued yesterday. The regional rate jumped to 6.8 percent from the 6 percent level of both February and January.
The jump reflected a regional economy that was too weak to accommodate a burst of job seekers, according to the data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of people employed in the three states did rise, by 225,000, to 17.1 million. But the number of job seekers rose much more. 
 Since the unemployment figure measures the number of people actively looking for work and unable to find it, the increase may provide evidence of optimism that has drawn out more job seekers.
"It probably just means that more people were in the market for jobs," said John L. Weiting, the New York regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. He added that the surge in job seekers might have reflected the less oppressive weather in March after the blizzards and cold of January and February.
Still, Mr. Weiting said, "in many cases, job applicants found that the market was not strong enough."
The release of regional data is a part of the revisions in the reporting procedure that were made in January; separate data for New York City and State and New Jersey are no longer provided on the day that the national employment data are reported. Instead, the Government lumps together New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, which are among the large industrial states that it used to track individually.
The change resulted partly from Federal budget cuts, which reduced the size of a survey conducted by the Census Bureau. That survey is now too small to be statistically reliable on the city and state level.
Unemployment figures for New York City and the states of New York and New Jersey are still provided, drawn from a larger survey, but they now come out three weeks after the national report.
The most recent figures for the city and the states are for February. Unemployment then was 8.1 percent in New York City, 6 percent in New York State, 6.4 percent in New Jersey and 5.1 percent in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Mayor Sees Costly New Stadium as No Burden to Taxpayers

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The stadium that a consultant has recommended building for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan would likely be the most expensive in the nation's history, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it could be built at little or no cost to the city's taxpayers.
Experts in sports financing and some city officials, however, expressed skepticism yesterday that any new stadium could be built in New York City without taxpayer money, noting that most of the stadiums built in recent years have required some public financing. 
 Although the details of financing a new stadium remain sketchy, the Mayor and his aides say the city and state could issue bonds for it and pay them off by tapping revenues from ticket sales, luxury boxes, advertising and even the exclusive rights to sell beer.
In doing so, however, the city and state could come into direct conflict with the Yankees' owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, who clearly hopes to use those same revenues to increase his own income from the team.
In fact, it is Mr. Steinbrenner's dissatisfaction with the money-making potential of Yankee Stadium that is driving his effort to seek a new home.
At a news conference yesterday in City Hall, where the future of the Yankees was once again a dominant topic, Mr. Giuliani said the promise of a vast new market of fans now unwilling to make the trip to the South Bronx made the proposal for a multi-use stadium on the West Side of Manhattan the most enticing alternative to Yankee Stadium. That was so, he said, even though it was the most expensive of four proposals the consultant considered, coming with a price tag of more than $1 billion.
"Purely from a financial analysis point of view," the Mayor said, "the place where the city could build a new stadium at virtually no cost to the taxpayer or very little cost to the taxpayer would be in Manhattan. Because the value of property in Manhattan is so great, you can finance it at very little cost. There might even be ways to finance it at no cost or a profit."
Such a method of financing has been used by other cities in recent years in the desperate race to keep or lure sports franchises, but sports experts said that in many of those cases public money -- either from taxes or lotteries -- helped build the stadiums. And they pointed out that the cost of those stadiums was about a quarter to a third of the price that the consultants estimated for a new Yankee Stadium.
"A stadium normally cannot be supported by direct revenues from the stadium itself," said Anita B. Morrison, vice president of Hammer, Siler, George Associates, a consulting firm in Silver Spring, Md., that worked on plans for a new Tiger Stadium in Detroit.
The study of possible sites for a new Yankee Stadium -- conducted by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum of Kansas City, Mo., and financed jointly by the city, the state and Mr. Steinbrenner -- did not directly address the question of paying for them.
But officials in New York and Albany have proceeded on the assumption that the city and state would issue bonds -- probably through a public authority -- to cover the staggering costs. The bonds would be paid off with money from a dedicated stream of revenues.
The question of where exactly those revenues would come from will be the most intense subject of negotiations between Mr. Steinbrenner, the city and the state. Like most baseball owners, Mr. Steinbrenner would like to keep as large a share as possible of those revenues for himself.
"The selection of the site is by far the easiest part of the conversation with the Yankees," said John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
For that reason, the Mayor's office and the Yankees declined yesterday to discuss exactly how revenues from a new stadium might be divided. David W. Sussman, the general counsel for the Yankees, said it was premature to discuss possible financing schemes since none had been presented to the team.
In the consultant's study and in the remarks by the Mayor and other officials, however, it was clear that a new stadium could produce lucrative sources of revenues from features that have become standard in new stadiums, like luxury boxes, licenses for special seats and even the rights to the name of the stadium. In San Francisco, for example, Pacific Bell recently promised to pay $50 million to put its name on a new stadium for the Giants.
Asked yesterday if he would allow a company to pay for the right to change the hallowed name of Yankee Stadium, the Mayor replied with a laugh. "It depends on the amount of money," he said.
Mr. Dyson said other possible sources of revenue could come from a surcharge on tickets or even a dedicated tax. But he added: "Increasing taxes is not the first, second, third or fourth resort. Taxes might be the last resort."
By emphasizing the potential sources of revenue, the Mayor and his aides seemed to be trying to head off criticism that the city and state can ill afford a huge expense for a stadium at a time when Mr. Giuliani's budget director recently ordered a 25 percent cut in capital spending.
Some elected officials -- including Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, and Fernando Ferrer, her counterpart in the Bronx -- have already rained doubt on the Mayor's claims. They say that improvements around a new stadium were unlikely to be covered by revenues from tickets and concessions alone and would almost certainly fall on taxpayers.
The study by Hellmuth, Obata estimated the cost of renovating Yankee Stadium at $770 million and rebuilding a new stadium next to the current site at $944 million. The cost of a new West Side stadium next to the Hudson River between 30th and 33d Streets would cost $847 million if used for baseball alone, while one suited for baseball and football would cost $1.06 billion. The firm rejected stadiums at two other sites in the Bronx, in Van Cortlandt Park and Pelham Bay Park, that would have cost even more.
By contrast, other new stadiums have been built for far less, including Jacobs Field in Cleveland for $215 million and Coors Field in Denver for $214 million. The most expensive stadium thus far -- Skydome in Toronto, which has a retractable roof and other amenities envisioned for a new Yankee Stadium -- cost about $500 million.
Marc S. Ganis, the president of Sportscorp Limited, a stadium development consultant in Chicago, said that when he heard of the proposed costs for a new home for the Yankees he "thought somebody added a zero by mistake."
"The notion of spending a billion dollars for a baseball stadium is even by today's standards outrageous," said Mr. Ganis, whose company was involved in the relocation of the Rams from Los Angeles to the new TWA Dome in St. Louis last year.
But the Mayor said, "When you look at these numbers, the amounts don't mean as much as the ability to finance it and therefore not have to cost the taxpapers any money, or a minimum amount of money."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Payrolls Rose in March; Hopes Dashed for Rate Cut
Employers added a hefty 140,000 new jobs to their payrolls in March, providing solid evidence that the economy is in better shape than it appeared a couple of months ago. The jobless rate was little changed, edging up one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent. 
 The jobs gain meant that the huge jump of more than 600,000 jobs that occurred in February was not a fluke, economists said, and apparently dashed hopes that the Federal Reserve would relax monetary policy any time soon. Some analysts even suggested that the Fed might move to tighten credit later in the year if the economy continued to advance at a brisk pace. That, in turn, raised fears that the stock market, which was closed for Good Friday, could slump next week. [Page 1.]
 
The jobless rate for the region encompassing New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania moved sharply higher, to 6.8 percent. [36.]
 
Installment Debt Jumps
Americans' installment debt grew in February at the fastest pace in eight months as each of the major categories of consumer credit rose. The Federal Reserve said consumer installment credit shot up 13.9 percent at an annual rate, and increased by $12 billion in the month. [36.]
 
Bloch Is Ordered to Return Money
A Federal judge ordered Irwin H. "Sonny" Bloch, the former financial talk show host, his wife, Hilda, and six of his companies to return $3.9 million collected from listeners they persuaded to invest in three radio stations in Florida and Connecticut. The judge has not decided whether to impose any fines against Mr. Bloch, who is accused of defrauding investors in the three stations. [37.]
 
NBC Wins Ruling on Crib Report
NBC does not have to turn over unused videotaped interviews from a "Dateline" report that questioned the safety of a combination cradle and baby swing, a Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan. The decision quashed a subpoena and overturned a $5,000-a-day fine against NBC. The videotapes were sought by Graco Children's Products, the maker of the cribs, but the ruling has no practical effect on Graco, which has since settled the cases brought against it. [37.]
 
Law Rattles Investors in Cuba
The latest weapon in the battle between Cuba and the U.S. is the Helms-Burton Act, which tightens the 34-year-old embargo against Cuba by trying to restrict non-American foreign investment here. It is having an effect on ventures like Etecsa, owned by the Cuban Government and a Mexican company. Company officials say that the uncertainty raised by the new law makes it far more difficult for them to raise $300 million they need to go forward. [3.]
 
Cow Disease Isolates Britain
Britain's mad cow problems at first brought forth a show of solidarity with its European Union partners, but it now appears that Britain feels isolated as never before. The British see the European reaction as bossy interference, and are especially put out at the idea that the European Union can stop Britain from exporting beef and many products with beef extract to third countries having nothing to do with Europe. [5.]
 
Fraud Ring Got Personal Data
A ring of individuals got personal data from Social Security employees and was able to commit credit-card fraud, running up huge bills at merchants including J & R Music World and Bergdorf Goodman. Several employees of the Social Security Administration passed information on more than 11,000 people to the fraud ring, according to prosecutors. A case worker in New York has been charged with fraud. [6.]
 
Jobs Report Lifts the Dollar
The dollar rose in thin trading after a report showing strong job growth convinced currency traders that the Federal Reserve would not cut interest rates anytime soon. "Now the Fed won't ease, and it may hike rates," said Karl Halligan, a trader in New York. "I think the dollar can go a lot higher." The dollar climbed to 107.68 yen, from 107.01 yen, and to 1.4835 marks, from 1.4800 marks. [38.]

HEADLINE: Asian Immigrants Help New York Thrive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Queens Old-Timers Uneasy as Asian Influence Grows" (March 31): I don't understand why Councilwoman Julia Harrison finds the growing Asian population in Flushing, Queens, so "discombobulating, very upsetting." Her beliefs that the many Asians coming to the United States have entered illegally and are ungrateful, affluent profiteers looking to exploit this country are unfounded.
According to 1994 Immigration and Naturalization Service figures, the 10 largest illegal immigrant groups in New York State did not even include Asians. 
 According to a 1994 report by the Asian Pacific Public Policy Institute, more than 30 percent of Southeast Asian households in the United States depend on welfare for their survival, giving them the highest rate of welfare dependency of any racial or ethnic group. In Manhattan's Chinatown, the 1990 unemployment rate was 6 percent, but nearly 25 percent of all families were living in poverty and working in jobs with low pay and no health insurance.
According to the Korean American Small Business Service Center in Flushing, only half of all Korean-owned businesses break even.
Unable to attain financial stability in the United States, thousands of Asians have returned to their native countries, contrary to Ms. Harrison's claim of an Asian invasion. But those immigrants choosing to remain in the United States have actively participated in their communities.
 
MICHAEL I. RHEE
Washington, April 3, 1996
 
The writer is a member of the Conference on Asian Pacific American Leadership.

HEADLINE: New U.S. Curbs Sound Alarm for Cuba Investors

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
Bolted to the front of the old phone company headquarters in this city's crumbling center is a bronze plaque commemorating Resolution No. 1 of Cuba's revolutionary Government: the nationalization of the telephone system on Aug. 6, 1960.
But so much of the old tower's ornate trim is flaking off and coming down that the sidewalk in front of the building had to be closed. 
 Both the plaque and the plummeting plasterwork put this relic of Havana's past squarely in the cross hairs of the latest weapon in the ideological battle between Cuba and the United States -- the Helms-Burton Act. The law tightens the 34-year-old embargo against Cuba by trying to restrict non-American foreign investment here.
Inside the 10-story phone company building are offices of Etecsa, a joint venture of the Cuban Government and a Mexican company called Grupo Domos, which bought 49 percent of the decrepit national system in 1994 for $750 million. It is by far the biggest foreign investment in Cuba since the Communist Government of Fidel Castro began courting investors.
While company officials say they have no intention of pulling out, they admit that the uncertainty raised by the new law makes it far more difficult for them to raise the $300 million they still need to go forward with their project, which is considered essential for Cuba's development.
 
Cuba Coming to See Law's Chilling Effect
Shaking confidence in Cuba is exactly what the law's drafters were after. The Cuban Government initially derided the law as powerless but later conceded the chilling effect it would have on foreign investment, while using it as provocation for a crackdown on economic reforms and political dissent.
The Helms-Burton Act was written and passed after intense pressure from anti-Castro Cubans in Miami who hoped to undermine the Castro Government. But many of the most vocal supporters of the bill also operate businesses. They want to weaken rival businesses, raise the cost of investing in Cuba and scare off non-American investors so that they can rush in after Mr. Castro falls and pick up the spoils.
No foreign project has been canceled yet, but international investors are nervously waiting to see how the United States will enforce the law, which takes effect Aug. 1, or whether President Clinton will use his authority to suspend its implementation until after the November elections.
"We're still doing our evaluations," said Arturo Lopez, manager of the Havana Investment Fund, which had raised almost $35 million before the law was passed. "This law is going make an investment here a little more difficult perhaps, but it will not stop it."
Cuban officials say they have attracted $2 billion in foreign investments, although Western diplomats here estimate the true figure to be half that. Whatever the real figure, all investments has been thrown into question by the Helms-Burton Act, which was signed by President Clinton just weeks after Cuban pilots shot down two unarmed planes flown by anti-Castro Cuban-Americans on Feb. 24, killing four men.
Many business executives here note that the law could hinder the kind of transition to a market economy that Washington seems to want. Since Cubans were given the right to own dollars and foreign companies were allowed to invest in Cuban businesses, dollars have been buying everything in Havana, from extra food to a working telephone line.
The 33 exchange at the start of most business telephone numbers here is now known as the money exchange because it means the holder pays the bill in dollars, and calls almost always get through. Not far from a sign in Havana proclaiming "Socialism or Death" is an outdoor billboard for Adidas shoes.
Basically, the Helms-Burton Act gives American citizens the right to sue Domos and other foreign companies in a United States Federal court for profiting from property that was illegally confiscated during the Cuban Revolution.
Javier Garza Calderon, president of Domos, said in an interview in Mexico that he does not believe that the law applies to his company because he simply rents space in the old phone company building. It is now owned by the Government but used to belong to the American company ITT and the Cuban Telephone Company, which it ran, until the revolution. ITT has a $130 million claim outstanding for all the property it lost in Cuba.
Domos is rapidly renovating alternate space -- in a building that never belonged to Americans -- just in case. But the new law so broadly interprets deriving benefit from confiscated property -- it uses the term "trafficking" -- that Mr. Garza Calderon concedes that Domos could have trouble because some equipment, telephone lines and even the heavy black rotary dial phones still in use in some Cuban households once belonged to ITT.
"They could be considered to be deriving benefit if a call from Miami to some woman in Camaguey Province was made on the same old telephone her grandmother had," said a Western diplomat in Cuba. "No matter what their lawyers say, can they be sure that a Federal court somewhere in the United States will feel the same way?"
Cuban-American leaders in Miami have already installed Domos into what they call their "Hall of Shame."
"Here you have a foreign company buying at cut-rate prices property owned by American citizens, intending to share profits with Fidel Castro and then laughing all the way to the bank," said Jorge Mas Canosa, head of the powerful Cuban American National Foundation.
But Mr. Mas Canosa may have had more than politics in mind. His Florida-based telecommunications company, Mastec, has been expanding aggressively in Latin America, and the entrance of the Mexicans represents increased competition.
 
Signs of Concern From Many Corners
Domos faces other potential problems. Under the law, Mr. Garza Calderon and his family could be denied visas to enter the United States, where his children now study.
Canon, Bayer, Benetton and dozens of other corporations that occupy space in confiscated Havana mansions also could face similar restrictions if former property owners have since become American citizens.
The Canadian Government has been among the most vocal opponents of the new law, asserting that it violates the terms of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Latinvest Securities reports that stock in the Canadian mining company Sherritt International, which operates a nickel mine in Cuba, dropped 24 percent after the two planes were downed.
At first the Cuban Government minimized the effect of the law. Officials declared outright that there were no American properties in Cuba, and called the law "Helms's dream," after its sponsor, Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican from North Carolina.
But as investors expressed their concerns, the Government was forced to reconsider. Roberto de Armas, an economist in the Foreign Ministry, now concedes that the flow of capital will probably slow until the United States makes clear how it plans to enforce the law. But he said the Government's policies will not change.
"The biggest blow to the Americans and their law will be when we give the figures for economic growth at the end of the year and they see that growth continues, albeit with problems in some sectors," Mr. de Armas said. The expected growth rate for 1996 is between 4 and 5 percent, depending on the sugar harvest, now under way.
The stakes are high for Mexico, which has taken a lead in Cuban investments. It was during a state visit by Carlos Salinas de Gortari, then the President, in June 1994 that the Domos deal was announced. A project to rebuild the Cienfuegos refinery was also announced then but it was suspended last September.
An investment like Grupo Domos's was considered an important first step in strengthening both the Mexican and Cuban economies.
 
Company Scrambles To Save Its Venture
It turned out that the anchor of Cuba's economy that Domos bought was a rusting and battered one. For instance, Domos found that when the air conditioning in critical switching centers failed, workers had simply opened the windows, letting in dust and salt air that corroded contacts. Only 18 percent of the long distance calls made to Cuba were completed.
Because Grupo Domos lacked operating experience, it sold 25 percent of its stake to the Italian phone company Stet last April for $291 million.
Domos wanted an American partner. Since 1992, a change in American law allowed long distance companies like AT&T and MCI to provide direct service to Cuba. They are doing so well that on Feb. 26, two days after the planes were shot down, a record 43,000 calls were registered between the United States and Cuba.
The signing of the Helms-Burton Act squelched any deal with an American company. The law specifically prohibits debt-for-equity swaps and bans any American company from investing in the domestic phone network in Cuba.
Since Domos has already earmarked $180 million for direct investment in Cuba, it has little choice but to remain. The uncertainty caused by the Helms-Burton Act makes it virtually impossible for Domos to finance the $300 million it still owes the Cuban Government. But it now seems that the Mexican Government, which strongly opposes the new law, will find a way to help Domos, and Cuba, save face. Although it once turned down Domos, the Mexican Government's export bank, Bancomext, is expected to come up with a loan for most of the $300 million.
Mr. Garza Calderon said the Cuban-Americans in Miami who pressured President Clinton to sign the law are confused. He would like to invite Mr. Mas Canosa, with whom he does not see eye-to-eye either economically or politically, to Monterrey to discuss the improvements already made in Cuba: higher salaries for workers, new switching stations, better service and more lines.
"It is ridiculous that Mr. Mas Canosa opposes all those benefits for those Cubans living in Miami and those in Cuba as well," he said. "He's just taking the negative point of view."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The old telephone company building in Havana, left, is a target of the new United States law that would allow Americans to sue companies profiting from illegally confiscated property in Cuba. Barriers at the building's corner protect pedestrians from falling plaster. (Anthony DePalma/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Cash Keeps Children of Poor From Leaving Special Education

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
In the last four years, New York City's Board of Education and the Human Resources Administration have aggressively steered thousands of poor students classified with learning difficulties or emotional problems off municipal welfare and onto Federal disability payments, saving the city and state $5.2 million.
But now, children's advocates and educational experts say the effort to cut costs takes special education's defects and makes them worse, encouraging families and officials to keep children in dead-end special-education programs --when many would do better in regular classrooms -- just because they are poor. 
 The incentive for both the city and the families is financial: families get far more per child -- up to $470 a month -- from the Federal disability program, Supplemental Security Income, than from municipal welfare, worth about $80 a month.
The Board of Education's official policy is to move as many special-education students as possible into regular classrooms, where they are thought to have a better chance to graduate and get jobs.
School officials say the system is a dumping ground for students whom teachers find bothersome, with disproportionate numbers of black and Hispanic boys classified as learning disabled, which includes attention deficit disorders and reading difficulties, or emotionally disturbed. They would like to see special education reserved for the roughly 10 percent of those now in special education who are seriously disabled or physically handicapped.
But some social workers, parents and children's advocacy groups argue that the Federal benefit pulls policy in the opposite direction: ever since a 1990 Supreme Court ruling made it easier for children with mild disabilities to qualify for S.S.I., special education has played a role in qualifying children for the program. Even as New York school officials say they want to shrink special-education enrollment, S.S.I. provides a new incentive to maintain the status quo.
"It raises a whole host of questions about establishing a systemic conflict about what's best for a child and what's best for the purse strings of the schools," said Galen Kirkland, executive director of Advocates for Children, a nonprofit organization. "There's no doubt it's good for some kids. But the history of dysfunction in public education in the city of New York -- if it teaches us anything, it teaches us to be extremely skeptical and rigorous in our questioning of programs predicated on financing streams that could retard the educational development of children."
Roy Laird, a social worker at St. Marks Place Institute for Mental Health, a Manhattan clinic that treats disabled students, said he worried that parents would be caught in an impossible bind. "If the child overcomes the disability, the family loses the income," he said.
But city and school officials contend that the city is simply making parents of disabled children aware of their entitlements -- and that the city's fiscal crisis dictates this measure, part of a larger push to trim local welfare costs by shifting eligible people to disability or other Federal programs. Under the city-school effort, more than 11,000 children in special education have gone from local welfare to Supplemental Security Income. Local welfare in New York City, primarily Aid to Families with Dependent Children, is paid half by the Federal Government and one-quarter each by the city and state.
"It is a way of saving local money in these lean times and making the Federal Government responsible for assuming some of the costs on its own," said Steve Allinger, the lobbyist for the New York City Board of Education in Albany. "We've been extremely aggressive. We're doing a mitzvah, a good deed."
"The city saves money on the public assistance grant, and the client benefits from a more generous S.S.I. program," he continued. "It's nuts for us not to claim S.S.I. for kids in special education. For too long, New York City has played the role of sucker vis-a-vis Washington."
Michael Casserly, a spokesman for the Council of Great City Schools, a Washington group that represents the nation's 50 largest school systems, said he was unaware that any other school system in the country was involved in such a joint city-school effort to shift costs to the Federal Government. He said the New York City school system's unusual financial dependence on the city might put it in a better position to carry out such an initiative. Most school systems operate independently of city governments.
The effort to sign up special-education children for Supplemental Security Income was not an issue until the 1990 Supreme Court ruling. Before then, S.S.I. covered only those with crippling physical conditions, chronic illness or profound retardation. But as a result of the ruling, the program can cover any poor child whose impairment substantially reduces his ability to function at a level that is "age appropriate" -- a category that includes attention deficit disorder, emotional disturbance and behavioral problems.
In New York City, an independent panel recommended in December that tens of thousands of special-education students, now isolated in separate classrooms, should be returned to regular classrooms, where they would receive extra help. Most students in the city's special-education system are not deaf, blind or classified with any other readily defined disability. Instead, 70 percent are labeled "learning disabled" or "emotional handicapped," classifications that many academics say are vague and loosely applied.
The special-education system, which has more than 130,000 students, is driven by a financial incentive that rewards the city for each additional child it places in special education. Once there, students are almost never "decertified" and allowed to return to regular education. Most never finish high school.
Enrollment in special education makes it far easier to get the documents needed to qualify a child for Supplemental Security Income, though it does not guarantee eligibility, say officials with the Social Security Administration.
In New York City, more than 11,000 children have been signed up for the disability benefit since 1992, about 2 percent of the children on welfare in the city and about 8 percent of the children in special education. To promote the Federal program, coordinators have been stationed at special-education offices in all 32 school districts. They go to schools, visit homes and walk parents through the application forms.
Some experts are wary that mildly disabled children being shifted into the program might never reach their potential. "It could lead them to be dependent for the rest of their lives," said Pamela Loprest, an economist with the Urban Institute in Washington, a bipartisan research center concerned with domestic social policy.
A Brooklyn parent, Blossom Richards, who had been fighting to get her son, Shawn, out of exclusively special-education classes, decided to battle the system when a caseworker told them to fill out some forms for Supplemental Security Income two years ago. Her son, then a senior at South Shore High School in Canarsie, was classified as emotionally disturbed.
"He told me that Shawn would be getting S.S.I. for the rest of his life," said Ms. Richards, a hotel housekeeper. "I told him that Shawn is not handicapped, that Shawn can work, but the guy said that doesn't matter. He could sit at home and get money and it would be increasing instead of decreasing."
She said she later told the staff worker that they were not interested. "The caseworker said I was making a fool out of myself," she recalled. "But if I take something like that, it means I am telling them that I have a handicapped child."
Nationwide, the number of children in the Federal disability program tripled in the five years after the 1990 Supreme Court ruling, to about 900,000 from 300,000, most of them classified with some form of mental impairment.
In recent years, the childhood disability program has received intense scrutiny in Congress and school circles. Reports have surfaced across the country about "crazy checks" and "dummy dollars," cash going to children who have been coached to fake mental impairments by misbehaving or doing poorly in school.
There is now bipartisan agreement in Congress that eligibility requirements need to be tightened, but how much remains a matter of impassioned debate.
Childhood benefits are one aspect of the larger Supplemental Security Income program, which was created by Congress in 1972 to defray expenses for poor adults too old, ill or disabled to work. The tax-free cash payment, which is supposed to help families struggling to raise handicapped children, by law replaces the much smaller welfare grant if a child is accepted.
School and city officials say they search for candidates for Supplemental Security Income in the city's special-education system because children there are already classified as handicapped and a large percentage of them are on public assistance.
For Selma Askin, whose son suffers from sickle-cell disease, the push to qualify some special education students seems unfair. Her 11-year-old son, Kariym, qualified for the Federal benefit only after a four-year fight that went to an administrative judge because despite his frequent hospitalizations, his illness did not seem severe enough.
"There are some people who don't need it," said Ms. Askin, a single mother of three children in Long Island City, Queens. "They drag their kids in there and say they have a psychological problem, and all the kids need is love. It makes it bad for other children."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: GROWTH OF JOBS STRONG IN MARCH, CONTINUING TREND

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Employers added a hefty number of new jobs to their payrolls in March, the Labor Department said today, providing solid evidence that the economy is in better shape than it appeared just a couple months ago.
The gain of 140,000 jobs last month meant that the huge jump of more than 600,000 jobs reported in February was not a fluke, economists said. The revival, coming after a final quarter in 1995 when the economy was essentially flat, apparently dashed hopes that the Federal Reserve would relax monetary policy again any time soon. Indeed, some analysts suggested that the Federal Reserve might even move to tighten credit later in the year if the economy advanced at a brisker pace. 
 "Make no mistake, if the rate of job growth we have seen so far in 1996 were to persist, the Fed would move quickly to pre-empt any acceleration in wage and price pressures," economists at Bankers Trust advised clients.
The bond market, which constantly worries that stronger growth might bring higher inflation, was unsettled by the latest job figures. With trading curtailed by the Good Friday holiday, prices of fixed-income securities dropped sharply as interest rates on the Treasury's 30-year bond jumped to 6.82 percent from 6.67 percent on Thursday. [Page 35.]
Stock markets in the United States were closed today. But there were some fears that when the stock market reopens on Monday, Wall Street might be in for at the least a mild echo of last month's one-day swoon. The report last month that payrolls had swelled in February caused a fall in the Dow Jones industrial average of 171 points. The stock market, however, has since regained the lost ground and climbed to new peaks.
In its report on jobs, the Labor Department said the unemployment rate was little changed, edging up one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent, well within the narrow range below 6 percent of the last year and a half. The slight jump in the jobless rate reflected a sudden surge in the labor force, prompted perhaps by greater optimism that jobs could be found.
The Clinton Administration fastened on the latest Labor Department figures to boast of revived economic fortunes and continued low inflation.
"Our economy has weathered the slow patch of late last year and shaken off any lingering effects of the Government shutdowns and the January blizzards," Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's chief economic adviser, said in a statement. "These numbers, combined with other recent evidence, indicate that the economy is poised to move ahead at a sustainable pace."
Job growth averaged 206,000 a month for the first quarter of 1996. That is at the high end of economic performance over the last five years, though down from an average of 226,000 in the corresponding period a year earlier. For all of 1995, monthly job growth averaged 144,000.
The job gains of the last two months, however, were unevenly distributed and came despite another decline in the number of factory jobs that was only partly the result of a strike against General Motors. Geographical disparities, in fact, seem to have become unusually wide.
The unemployment rate in the Middle Atlantic states of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania jumped to 6.8 percent from 6 percent last month even as the rate for New England stood at 5 percent or barely above for the fourth consecutive month. Joblessness in the Midwest region edged down to a record low of 4.3 percent.
The March payroll expansion of 140,000 was relatively modest but it was still about twice what many had expected. Moreover, specialists noted, the February jump was revised downward by relatively little, to 624,000 from an initial estimate of 705,000, and January's decline is now less than previously thought -- 146,000 instead of 188,000.
At the same time, the department's survey of households, which until recently has been registering less job growth than the payroll figures, posted a thumping 488,000 gain last month on top of a 437,000 gain in February.
All in all, commented Donald E. Maude, economist for Scotia Capital Markets in New York, "it now seems clear that the upward shift in employment growth during the first quarter is not a mere aberration."
He predicted that the Federal Reserve's January cut in short-term interest rates, the third since it began trimming last July, would be the final one in the current cycle and that "the next move should be upward."
But not everybody was convinced.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a banking company in Minneapolis, disagreed with forecasts that the Federal Reserve would increase short-term interest rates during the second half of 1996. "Given moderate economic growth, we don't expect that will happen," Mr. Sohn said. "We expect another cut or two in interest rates later this year."
And some analysts said that the Federal Reserve was likely to do little but pat itself on the back for steering the economy through the turbulence.
"This is an economy that is behaving in a way that central bankers dream about," Robert Dederick, chief economic consultant at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, told The Associated Press. "The soft landing is going to be followed by a soft takeoff."
Payroll increases last month were mainly in health, recreation, engineering, computer and other private services that have accounted for 87 percent of all job growth during the five years since the end of the last recession in March 1991.
Temporary-help workers, a group that has expanded sporadically over the year, fell by 8,000 last month. Some analysts said this could reflect newly confident employers' willingness to hire permanent workers.
Manufacturing lost 62,000 jobs, about 35,000 of these auto workers who were off payrolls for the entire survey period. Ultimately, 177,000 workers were idled by strike-related shutdowns at General Motors, plus tens of thousands more at suppliers, but most worked at least part of the survey week and were thus considered employed. Now that the strike is over, the industry is beginning to pick up the pace of production.
Department stores and automobile dealers posted job gains but employment at restaurants and bars fell by 33,000 and construction jobs dipped slightly after the big February rise.
The length of the workweek, which was significantly affected by the G.M. strike, fell 12 minutes at factories and 6 minutes for the private sector as a whole, today's report also showed. Factory overtime dropped 18 minutes.

HEADLINE: New Leaders in Poland Gaze Intently Westward

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, April 5

 BODY:
To mark his first 100 days in office, President Aleksander Kwasniewski recently invited reporters to the living room of his private quarters, held a news conference standing before a handsome wall tapestry and then handed around flutes of champagne.
The media-friendly Mr. Kwasniewski was showing that he and his fortysomething colleagues at the top of the Polish Government are different from the other Communist retreads now ruling in Central Europe. 
 Mr. Kwasniewski, 41; Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz, 46, and Foreign Minister Dariusz Rosati, 49, appear to have shed their Communist heritage so well that their opponents call them yuppies.
"Kwasniewski makes the impression of a young, open-minded person, likable -- a Polish yuppie," said Janusz Onyszkiewicz, who was on the other side of the ideological barriers to Mr. Kwasniewski in the 1980's and is in the parliamentary opposition to the President's party. "They say they have become social democrats, and I think they have."
Unlike Ion Iliescu, the 65-year-old President of Romania, and Gyula Horn, the 61-year-old Prime Minister of Hungary, both of whom received university degrees in the Soviet Union, Poland's new leaders say they barely believed in Communism.
In the 1970's and 80's, they chose the United States for study or vacations. And now, to stress their drive for Poland to become part of Western European institutions, they picked Bonn, Paris and Brussels over Moscow as their first ports of call after coming to power.
Since becoming President in December and after the resignation of Jozef Oleksy, Mr. Kwasniewski acquired Mr. Cimoszewicz as Prime Minister and chose Mr. Rosati as Foreign Minister.
All three are known in Poland as the "Boys From Ordynacka," a reference to the Warsaw street where the Communist Party's Association of Polish Students had its headquarters. Most Polish university students belonged to the association, including Roman Catholic student activists.
It was a grouping, according to the magazine Polityka, of those "who did not believe in socialism but did not believe in its collapse either."
In the 1970's under the Communist Prime Minister, Edward Gierek, the students saw hope that socialism could work: more goods were in the stores and visas and scholarships were available for travel to the West.
Mr. Kwasniewski, who studied economics, followed a common route for those days. He earned money as an unregistered worker in Sweden to pay for a trip to America for the bicentennial celebrations. In the early 1980's, Mr. Cimoszewicz, a law graduate from Warsaw University, won a Fulbright scholarship to Columbia University, where he studied for five years. And Mr. Rosati, a graduate of the Warsaw School of Economics, won a Fulbright and attended Princeton University in 1987.
Thus when Richard C. Holbrooke, the former Assistant Secretary of State, visited Poland in February, Mr. Kwasniewski was able to regale him with stories about traveling through more than 30 states, including some in the South, as a driver delivering cars.
Mr. Cimoszewicz, according to some of his colleagues, could be considered so modern that on his return from the United States, he dropped out of politics and for four years retreated to the family pig farm in eastern Poland.
He turned it into a model operation -- of the capitalist kind. "My in-laws thought we were insane and that we degraded ourselves socially," he said recently. "But we were tremendously successful financially."
Now that they are in power, the "boys" from the Communist students' club are getting mixed reviews on economic policy. Poland's growth rate of 7 percent was the strongest in Europe last year, and Mr. Cimoszewicz talked tough this week about bailing out the beleaguered Gdansk shipyard. "The days when a Government department runs an industry are over," he said, indicating that the Government was seeking a foreign buyer.
The three men acknowledge that they are not automatically accepted in the West as the social democrats they say they are. With the Alliance of the Democratic Left, the party that Mr. Kwasniewski built on the ashes of the old Communist Party, controlling the presidency, Parliament and the prime ministership, the three men must allay fears of a one-party country.
"The various centers of power -- the Foreign Affairs Ministry, the Government and the President -- all see eye to eye," Mr. Rosati said. "But it's very clear that making the current political arrangement credible in the eyes of those abroad is still an open question. I'm under the impression that we're constantly being tested by the West."
For all his Western demeanor, Mr. Kwasniewski does not seem able to kick speech habits learned as a junior minister in the Communist Government of the 1980's. An analysis of his statements in the first 100 days by Rzeczpospolita, the national daily, revealed old-style syntax like "competent organs are to decide about sanctions against the guilty prescribed by law."
Mr. Kwasniewski meant: the law should prevail.

HEADLINE: The Tax-Reform Obsession

BYLINE: By Paul R. Krugman; Paul R. Krugman is a professor of economics at Stanford University. His last article for the Magazine, "Stay on Their Backs," was in February.

 BODY:
STEVE FORBES'S PRESIDENTIAL CAM-paign may have crashed and burned, but tax reform lives on, and on, and on. Should President Clinton lose in November, a flat tax will become a top priority in Congress. Even if he should win, Republicans will spend the next four years blaming the tax system for all our economic failings. Either way, we will continue to hear a lot about taxes, which raises a question.
Why are Republicans so obsessed with tax reform? Why don't they promise instead to eliminate traffic jams? 
 This is not a silly question. The case for doing something about traffic is based on impeccable free-market economics, every bit as solid as the argument for reforming our tax system. Tax reform, however, is an iffy business -- the flat-tax plans peddled this year by Forbes and others would probably do more harm than good.
By contrast, traffic reform is a $40 billion sure thing. But traffic congestion, along with a number of similar issues like pollution management and water rights, goes unmentioned in current political discussion. And when such issues do come up, conservative politicians are often on the wrong side, which tells you something important about the blinkered vision of many people who fancy themselves champions of free markets.
Serious tax-reform advocates point out that the current system has two main flaws that harm economic efficiency. First, some people pay a "marginal" tax rate as high as 40 percent -- that is, of every extra dollar they earn, 40 cents goes to the Government. This surely discourages people from working as hard as they might. Second, because the Government taxes interest and profits, the system discourages people from saving for the future. So theorists have devised alternative tax systems that might lead to greater work effort and higher savings, and might therefore expand the American economy.
But how big would these gains be? A lot of savings are already tax exempt, because of special tax breaks for retirement accounts. And we can't do away with taxes altogether: like it or not, we still need to pay for the government services we want. This limits the scope for reducing marginal rates. For example: a realistic flat tax, one that would raise as much money as the current income tax, would still have to involve a marginal rate of well over 20 percent. That's lower than the 40 percent rate some people now pay, but most people don't pay that rate anyway. And even that 20-something rate is possible only if we eliminate the tax deduction for interest on home mortgages -- which means that while the economy might gain from the new tax, millions of middle-class families would lose.
The fact is that serious tax analysts believe that the net benefits from even a complete overhaul of the tax system would be modest -- almost surely less than a 1 percent increase in the nation's income, or about $60 billion a year -- and that while most people might gain, many would lose. In practice, the prospect of middle-class outrage means that schemes like the flat tax are usually sold with the promise of unrealistically low tax rates. And while a realistic flat tax might help the economy a bit, a Forbes-style proposal, with its promise to provide large tax cuts for the rich without any increases for the middle class, would create a huge budget deficit, thereby doing the economy far more harm than good.
Now let's talk about traffic. Traffic congestion is not a minor annoyance. Last year Americans lost more than eight billion hours to traffic delays, at a total cost of more than $80 billion -- mainly in the form of wasted time, but also through extra consumption of gasoline, wear and tear on autos and so on.
But aren't traffic jams just a fact of life? No. In large part they are the result of a system that, like the tax system, encourages people to make economically inefficient decisions.
CONSIDER, FOR EXAMPLE, MY OWN antisocial actions a few weeks ago. A colleague and I were going to a meeting in San Francisco, 30 miles away. At the cost of some minor inconvenience we could have traveled together. But we didn't, and by taking my own car I added marginally to the already world-class traffic congestion on Highway 101.
I probably didn't delay any individual's morning commute by more than a fraction of a second, but that tiny delay was imposed on each of thousands of cars crawling along the freeway behind me. It's a good bet that the total delay that other people suffered for the sake of my slight convenience was more than an hour.
There ought to have been a way to make a deal: I wouldn't clog the freeway, and other drivers would compensate me for the inconvenience of car pooling. Since the cost I imposed on other people by driving during rush hour was much greater than the benefit I derived, such a deal could have made everyone happier. Of course, it is impractical to make such a deal directly, but we can try to reproduce its results.
The classic economist's prescription for dealing with traffic is for the government to impose "congestion fees," tolls for using roads during periods of overcrowding. With modern technology, such tolls could even be collected without tollbooths: an electronic sensor could pick up the signal from a tiny gizmo on your dashboard, or a low-powered laser could read a bar code on your windshield. The fees could then be rebated to the public. Realistic estimates suggest that such fees could cut the cost of traffic congestion considerably, and leave the great majority of people better off. Most of those deterred from rush-hour driving would be more than compensated for their inconvenience through the rebate scheme. Those who continued to drive would be compensated for the extra tolls with a much faster trip to work.
I know what some conservatives are thinking -- this is just another government intrusion into daily life. But think of it another way: what we have here is a problem of inadequately defined property rights. Space on Highway 101 during rush hour is a scarce resource, just like waterfront real estate. Unfortunately, nobody holds clear title to that resource, and so it is overused.
So why don't we try to establish a properly functioning free market in road space? Suppose we issue registered drivers in a metropolitan area a specified number of "rush hour points," which they are free to sell at their discretion, and require anyone who drives during rush hour to present (electronically) the appropriate number of points. Let us also create a market in these points. Some people will continue to drive every day; they will need to purchase extra points. Others will find new ways of getting to work and will sell their points for whatever the, ahem, traffic will bear. How market-oriented can you get? And such a scheme, like congestion fees, would make most people better off, either because they get extra money by selling their points or because the cost of buying points is more than offset by a quicker commute.
The reason that creating a market in road space and imposing congestion fees would produce similar results is, of course, that -- as any bright Econ 1 student can tell you -- they are essentially equivalent. Either way, what you are doing is creating a market incentive for people like me to take into account the costs we impose on others by driving during rush hour.
The benefits of such a scheme would not be small change. Traffic experts tell us that a sensible system of congestion fees could easily cut the annual cost of highway delays by $30 billion or $40 billion. These savings are offset to a degree by the inconvenience to those who are deterred from driving. But the net benefits could be $15 billion a year or more. Tacking on fees for heavy trucks that damage highways and for air travel to overcrowded airports yields a middle-of-the-road estimate (and what other kind of estimate would you want?) that traffic reform could enrich the American public by $40 billion to $50 billion every year.
There are other places where properly defined property rights could yield a big payoff. Water is a very scarce resource in the American West. Under the current system, thirsty cities are rationed even while desert farmers feed irrigated alfalfa to their cattle. Why not create a free market in water rights? Another example is the airwaves, which used to carry only radio and television but are increasingly in demand to allow wireless communication among people and computers. Broadcast rights could be traded in a free market but -- despite the recent auction of a limited slice of the spectrum -- mostly aren't, with the result that a bandwidth that could be carrying vital business data is carrying infomercials instead.
So why isn't there a major conservative politician out there campaigning on a platform of extending free-market principles, of creating property rights where they should exist but don't? Such a politician could promise to raise national income by $60 billion, $80 billion, even $100 billion a year -- and could do so honestly, without the slippery arithmetic that underlies the promises we hear about tax reform.
To be fair, many conservative economists have advocated the kind of reforms I have described. (So have many liberal economists.) But for the most part they have been ignored.
The reason, I believe, is that the political appeal of economic conservatism really has very little to do with the virtues of free markets. Instead, it is about the promise of something for nothing -- a rejection of the idea that taxes must be collected, that scarce resources must be conserved. The reason the electorate likes tax- reform schemes is that they always end up being tax-cutting schemes, based on the premise that the voters pay taxes but someone else gets the benefits -- even though anyone who looks at where the money actually goes quickly realizes that Pogo was right: we have met the enemy, and he is us.
As a result, not only do prominent conservatives rarely support proposals to extend the range of the market, but also they often actively oppose them. For example, the supply-side guru George Gilder has vociferously campaigned against plans to auction off a limited slice of the airwaves. Instead, incredibly, he advocates anarchy -- let anyone broadcast on whatever frequency. This is crazy. What it reflects, one suspects, is a basic unwillingness to accept the idea that there are any scarce resources, any limits that must be respected.
So the next time you encounter a conservative who likes to talk about the virtues of the free market, ask him what he thinks about creating a market in rights to drive in rush-hour traffic, or to use Western water. If he demurs, then he doesn't really believe in free markets -- he believes in free lunches.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Long Live the Monarchy!

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
THE NEW YORK TIMES HAS EXISTED FOR 145 years, but it is preparing to celebrate a centenary. The first of three commemorative Times Magazines this year will appear next week, to be followed by four major museum exhibitions, a centennial Book Review, a major Times donation to education and a royal feast for staff and friends. Royal indeed, because it's a monarchy we're toasting -- the 100th year of control of this notable enterprise by a single family descended from Adolph S. Ochs.
It was 100 years ago this spring that the 37-year-old Ochs set out to repeat in New York his success in Chattanooga at reviving a moribund newspaper named The Times. Though burdened with debt from failed real-estate ventures, he quickly proved the soundness of his strategy: to publish copious and impartial news for "thoughtful, pure-minded people" while commanding the authority to reinvest his profits in journalistic ventures of long-term value. 
 By August 1896, he had control of The New-York Times and promptly rekindled the spirit of its staff. In September, he created a magazine to illustrate the news; in October, a book review with the news of ideas. In November, he listed the arrival of out-of-town buyers, heralding a yearlong expansion of business coverage. Within four years, he hugely multiplied The Times's circulation, doubled its advertising and earned his contractual reward of a majority of the company's voting stock.
"Now I am monarch of all I survey," Ochs told his family, and so, too, have been his heirs. They have followed his teachings and hoarded their regal authority through wars and depressions and technological revolutions, in lean years and fat, despite divorces and heart attacks, estate taxes and stock vacillations. They are among the last of a vanishing breed, publishers who make money to support their journalism at a time when most publishers practice journalism to make more money.
FAMILY-OWNED NEWSPAPERS WERE ONCE THE norm in America. But the laws of man and nature gradually took their toll, taxing away estates and diluting gene pools. Three-fourths of the nation's 1,550 papers are now owned remotely, by chains, and large chains are swallowing smaller ones. To diversify their sources of income, even some family papers like The New York Times and the Grahams' Washington Post have themselves acquired newspaper subsidiaries, and papers alert to a gradual loss of family control, like the Taylors' Boston Globe and the Danielses' News and Observer in Raleigh, have sold themselves to the most attractive bidders.
Family ownership, of course, is no guarantee of distinguished newspapering. And The Wall Street Journal is daily proof that corporate ownership need not be the enemy of quality. But most chain owners decree no journalistic mission or political line for their wards. They demand only a relentless growth on the bottom line. And since the benefits of automated printing have now been largely realized, many publishers look to maximize profit by saving on the costs of paper and staff, which means stinting on the volume and quality of the news.
Recent increases in the cost of newsprint have been widely used to justify layoffs of reporters and editors, cuts in newsroom budgets and even the closing of newspapers. The Times Mirror Company, for example, not only decreed serious reductions at such venerable papers as The Los Angeles Times, The Hartford Courant and The Baltimore Sun. It altogether abandoned the enterprising New York Newsday, whose prospects were hardly worse than The Times's when Adolph Ochs arrived. But as intended, the heirs of the founding Chandler family and their managers doubled their stocks' value in just a few months.
Add the demand for higher stock prices to the lures of stock options, and you get the pressures that now drive most newspaper corporations. Some chains have pooled resources to improve their news gathering, but many more have consolidated to cut expenses, thereby reducing the number of observers who stand watch over public affairs.
In a chorus of despair, even editors at unchained papers report that they are under pressure to put concern for Wall Street ahead of their responsibility to Main Street. They say they are being judged not by how well they spend the company's money but by how much money they manage not to spend. Hiring freezes and attrition schemes proliferate, as if any cub reporter could easily replace an experienced correspondent and as if computers and faxes could shorten the time it takes to pursue a hidden truth. Newsrooms are being subjected to the scrutiny of efficiency experts, who define talent as a cost instead of an asset and some of whom declare that they can find economies in inherently inefficient creative labors like investigating, interviewing and writing.
Given this history, I strongly favor a newspaper monarchy over every form of stockholder democracy. The Ochs clan are no spendthrifts. And as significant holders of Times stock, they are hardly indifferent to its market value. But imbued with the royal blood, they instinctively weigh the interests of today against the obligations to tomorrow. Their self-esteem is wrapped in newsprint; the paper's character becomes their own.
The Times's current chairman, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, has prudently disciplined all his operations with budgets, financial plans and business managers. But when Iraqi troops mobilize, Berlin walls topple and Oklahoma buildings explode, no one hesitates to deploy platoons of reporters, photographers and editors and to clear the pages for their accounts. Disfavor awaits only those who fail to harvest the news in The Times's customary, inherited manner.
Faced with limited press capacity in World War I, Adolph Ochs rejected more than 60 columns of advertising a day to accommodate vital news. As Elmer Davis recorded from his perch on the editorial board, the publisher felt "compelled" to make that choice. Similarly, in World War II, with newsprint rationed, Ochs's son-in-law and successor, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, annually printed three million more lines of news than his competitors, watching them grow rich on the ads he relinquished. Since The Times has outlived its rivals, it is easy now to celebrate these decisions as both noble and shrewd. Why, then, have not more publishers followed that pattern? Why do so many sacrifice news coverage to pay for paper?
The answer is that only a few publishers have inherited both the values and the authority to override the clamor of stock market analysts and prophets. Only a few are still able to balance their obligations to readers against their obligations to shareholders. And only a very few live to preserve the legacy of their ancestors for the enlightenment of their posterity. Long live those monarchies!
