HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Terrell Ward Bynum;
The Internet: In Need of a Value System

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
TERRELL WARD BYNUM is a professor of philosophy and director of the Research Center on Computing and Society at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven. Since 1978, Dr. Bynum, has been conducting research in computer ethics. He was a chairman of Ethicomp 95, an international symposium at De Montford University in Leicester, England, and is one of the organizers of a new computer ethics consortium that has brought together scientists from all over the world.
Working with a laptop at home -- a MacIntosh Powerbook with a 1.7 gigabyte hard drive and video capabilities -- and several desktops at his office, Dr. Bynum and his colleagues are trying to develop a set of ethical rules to guide people through the information age. 
 Dr. Bynum was interviewed recently on the Southern campus. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Are there any extreme examples of unethical use of computers?
A. Well, right after Elvis Presley's death, computers were used to dial up people who had purchased tickets to Presley's concerts, and they were sold mementoes.
Personally, I think it's outrageous that companies are collecting data on the Internet and selling it.
At a local supermarket someone asked me if I wanted to fill out a form for a free electronic coupon card. Every time you check out they run this card through a slot, and after you've purchased a certain number of cans of tuna fish, you get 30 cents off, automatically.
Everyone thinks it's great -- you don't have to clip a coupon, you don't even have to think about it. But the company is collecting information and that information can be used to learn all sorts of things about you -- what's your age, your economic bracket, do you have health problems? Do you have pets or children? I think that's a horrendous invasion.
Q. Has the information industry attempted to address computer ethics?
A. Yes. In the late 1960's, Don Parker was shocked to discover programmers were being indicted for embezzling money through computers. As a member of the Association for Computing Machinery, the largest professional organization in the world for computing, he wrote the first code of computer ethics. It was revised in the late 1970's, and in the late 1980's.
The International Federation of Information Processors has also tried to put together a code of ethics, but they discovered they couldn't come to agreement, at least not yet.
Q. Have laws kept pace with the growth of technology?
A. There isn't any way to keep pace. The most recent law passed in this country on telecommunications made a mistake by trying to restrict pornographic materials.
Any attempt to regulate morality generally fails, especially in a country with the First Amendment. And it doesn't work anyway; the Internet is so easy to get through and around.
It's a very interesting problem for countries like China and Iran, which want the benefits of the Internet but don't want their people to get information off it.
Q. What about controlling particularly heinous points of view?
A. For the moment at least, the ideas keep canceling each other out. It's like a huge town square, where everyone can come and say whatever they want. The citizen can then pick and choose what he wants to believe. That's why I think trying to censor our Nazis and others is the wrong way to go. What we need to do is counter bigotry with education.
Q. So what kind of law is going to prevail on the Internet?
A. If you try to build your ethical principles on any particular constitution, or a particular religion, it's not going to work. One of the founders of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, John Barlow, has said that in cyberspace, the American Constitution is a local ordinance. It's one country out of 100, 150 on the Internet, and whose law prevails? Nobody's. For the first time in history we're challenged to develop ethical and social principles that are genuinely global.
Q. Is that possible?
A. Well, we don't know, but if there is no set of behavioral guidelines, there's going to be chaos, and a great resource will be lost.
The major ethical theories of today have been traced to the evolution of printing, which suddenly made it possible for people all over Europe to read and decide for themselves, as well as the Industrial Revolution, which enabled people to travel.
Now there's a theory that the Internet will be the birthplace of the next major wave of ethical thinking.
Q. Has there ever been a cultural or social revolution to rival what is happening with computers?
A. I don't think so. Information technology is the most powerful and the most flexible technology ever invented; powerful technology always has a major social impact.
Probably the only thing that comes close to rival it would be farming, which gave people the ability to stay in one place and build communities and write books and have a place to keep them and so forth. That totally changed the world.
Q. What's kind of issues are you trying to work out, as a philosopher?
A. Take the concept of ownership. When computer software came along, we had to decide who owned software, and what kind of ownership you get -- there are copyrights, and patents, and so forth. And what do you own? Do you own just what you originally wrote? Do you own any translation of that? Do you own the algorithm behind it?
Q. Why do so many of your writings focus on privacy issues?
A. If you surf the World Wide Web, your name and address are known to the owners of the Web pages that you view. If you get onto Yahoo, for example, because you're interested in buying an automobile or in gay rights, Yahoo records that you were there, and what pages you were interested in, and how long you stayed on each page. They take that information and sell it to companies that figure out your interests and try to sell you goods and services. We're giving away our privacy.
Q. Do people realize how much they are disclosing about themselves?
A. No, they don't. If people did, probably they wouldn't search with the kind of abandon that they have now. Even if someone doesn't have AIDS, they might be interested in the subject, and search dozens of pages. Someone is going to suspect they have AIDS, and when they try to get insurance or look for a job, it might come back to haunt them.
Q. Are we creating a society where there are two classes of people -- those with access to information, and those without?
A. That is one of the major ethical considerations in computing, the haves and have-nots. And the gap is getting wider and wider, more and more quickly.
It seems to me it's the ethical responsibility of the government of every industrialized nation to see to it that all their own citizens have access to information, and in their foreign policy to see the have-not nations of the world get access.
Q. Is there a way to guarantee equal access to information?
A. Not one way, but lots of ways. For example, the government could do what it did with the phone companies years ago -- give a monopoly in a particular region, but only if the service is made cheaper, so that anyone can afford it.
In public libraries, it used to be that even the poorest person could go in and read the newspaper, become self-educated, and so forth. So another policy would be to see to it that as the public library system moves into cyberspace, access for the poor remains in place.
Q. So information technology should become a regulated utility with universal service?
A. You can make a case that in the long run, wiring up everyone makes sense. We're either going to pay to wire them up and educate them, or we're going to pay to put them in jail.
Decreasing the gap between the haves and have-nots is much wiser. I'm not saying do that out of the goodness of your heart, do it out of concern for your own pocketbook, out of concern for your safety and the safety of your children.
Q. Are we going to obtain access to so much information that we can no longer assimilate it?
A. That's inevitable. What we need to do is develop new tools to handle information overload. These days I can find 500 pieces of E-mail in my box in the morning. There isn't any way I could read that much and still do my job. So I began to develop new information processing skills.
Q. A recent divorce case cited E-mail messages from a married woman to someone she had never met. Should E-mail be a sign of infidelity?
A. Certainly it is a sign of infidelity, if you're actively flirting with someone, and sharing fantasies with them. It's a symptom there's something wrong.
But all of this went on with love letters before. They were used to blackmail people, and they certainly led to divorces and so forth.
The issue is, it will become even easier to engage in even more fantasies. There is now apparatus that you can attach to your body that can be controlled from a distance, so you can stimulate a partner a long distance away, so you can not only talk about your fantasies, you can act them out in some physical sense.
Eventually there will be virtual reality where you can put on a data suit and reach out and touch someone, and they will feel your touch. Five or 10 years from now, you will be able to have very real physical encounters with someone thousands of miles away.
Q. Is it time to back off from technology?
A. Even if it was, there's no way to back off. The economic and social advantages are too great. You're not going to stop it, but you've got to realize what the issues are and come up with policies to deal with them, and your policies cannot be too repressive or restrictive.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terrell Ward Bynum specializes in computer ethics. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1273 words

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Hesmat Majlessi;
Beyond the Cosmetics in Varicose Veins

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IT is estimated that as many as 80 million people in the United States have varicose veins, 90 percent of whom are women. To many, these twisted, discolored veins are just a cosmetic problem or something that causes a little discomfort. But all varicose veins have the potential for serious complications and, therefore, should be examined by experts, said Dr. Hesmat Majlessi, a vascular surgeon who heads the Rye Vein Care Center in Rye.
Dr. Majlessi is a member of the American Phlebology Society of America and adapted his techniques of treating varicose veins from Dr. George Fegan of England, a pioneer in the field. He is skeptical of common methods of treating varicose veins because, he said, they do not usually cure the problem but just treat the symptoms. 
 Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Dr. Majlessi, who is affiliated with United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester:
Q. What are varicose veins and why are they more than a cosmetic problem?
A. Varicose veins are normal veins that have become much more dilated and tortured and twisted. They become very unsightly at the beginning. Then they develop their complications. This starts as swelling in the legs and then progresses into phlebitis, which is formation of clots in the legs, which a few hundred thousand patients a year develop. There are other complications as well, which can be disabling and can cause about $2 billion annual health care costs to the U.S. economy. Another result is a change in the color of the skin, which is called dermatitis. This can be of great concern cosmetically. But it is not only cosmetics; it can cause life-threatening complications.
Q. Is it only in legs, or can one get varicose veins in other parts of the body?
A. You could have them in other places, but I would say over 99 percent of them are in the leg because of gravity due to standing.
Q. If a person sees a little bit of a protrusion from a vein, is that necessarily a varicose vein?
A. Not necessarily. I see a lot of young girls who come with protruding veins, and they are young and very active, and they are thin and have a light-colored skin. So the normal vein protrudes because of their daily strenuous activities. I tell them that they should not be treated at all. It's only a cosmetic thing.
Q. What does a true varicose vein look like in contrast?
A. When the patient stands up, especially, you can see the veins, which are more protruding than usual. If you touch them, they are very tender due to the increased pressure in the veins from a leak in the leg. They are tortured, which means they are not straight; they are twisted.
Q. What causes this leaking?
A. The important and crucial part that has to be known and found during diagnosis and treatment is the source of the varicose vein, which I call a leak. Scientifically, they are called reflux valves. They are connections between the small veins in the leg and the big veins inside, which carry a small valve inside. There are typically 200 to 300 of these in the leg and the thigh. Any time any of these valves does not do its job properly, blood flows backward, meaning from the inside to the out, from the big veins to the small veins. This gradually makes them larger and twisted. Any time that varicose veins are treated, whether by surgery -- which is called stripping -- or by my method, the leak or leaks have to be identified and controlled. And that's what the drawback of stripping is. It does not find and control the leaks.
Q. What is stripping?
A. The patient goes to a hospital under a major anesthesia usually; many cuts are made in the leg, between 10 to 40 or 50, and the veins are taken out. This includes a very important vein called the saphenous vein, a long vein from the groin down to the ankle on the inside. This vein is taken out traditionally, but this is a major drawback to stripping. This vein has to be preserved for possible future bypass surgeries in the leg and in the heart. In most cases, this vein can be preserved without actually touching it.
Q. Is stripping a cure?
A. Not at all. The chance of recurrence is actually great. I see about 300 to 400 patients a year who have had one or more strippings. They have a recurrence of varicose veins in the same leg. Obviously, these are not the old veins, because those were taken out. It's because the leak in the valve has not been found in the leg or the thigh or the back of the knee. And the varicose vein has been taken out by stripping, but the leak opens up some other vein, because there are tens of thousands of veins in the leg.
A treatment that is done by dermatologists is called sclerotherapy. This is good for the spider-size veins -- it basically closes them -- but not for the large varicose veins. It makes sense that when you get a treatment that you cure the condition. You don't want the patient to come back to your office with the same problem. In order to accomplish that, the doctor should have the expertise to not only treat the large varicose veins but to find the source -- and close the source -- as well. Sclerotherapy is, in my opinion, an out-dated method that should no longer be done.
Q. What is your procedure for treating varicose veins?
A. What I do is called comprehensive compression sclerotherapy, which involves identifying all the veins and perforated vessels. The technique combines the injection of a special sclerosing solution with prolonged compression of the vein. The solution irritates the inner wall of the blood vessel, causing healthy scar tissue to develop. The scar tissue seals off the vessel from further blood flow, and the vein structurally dissolves. Whether the vein is small, medium or large, it can be treated and the recurrence rate should be far, far less because I find the source of the leak. That is why a consultation takes an hour and half. I can put my fingers over a couple of the leaks, and all the veins disappear.
Q. Why are women more likely to get varicose veins than men?
A. About 90 percent of the cases are in women, and these are mainly due to two factors: heredity and pregnancy. If your mom, grandma, sisters, aunts had varicose veins, it increases the chance that you will have varicose veins. Pregnancy causes pressure in the pelvic vein, and a lot of patients develop varicose veins during pregnancy. But in the majority of such cases they go away after delivery. So it should not be treated at the time of pregnancy.
Q. Is obesity a factor?
A. Yes, any factor that increases pressure in the veins. Standing, weight lifting, these can theoretically increase pressure in the veins, and if there is a leak they can speed up formation of varicose veins.
Q. Is it always important for people to seek treatment for what is apparently a varicose vein? Or if cosmetics are of no concern, can it be ignored?
A. At certain stages it is really cosmetic in nature, although it can have a tremendous impact on a patient's life style. Young people, especially, who have them do not wear shorts, do not go swimming. It affects how they feel about themselves. But this is purely cosmetic. But if they leave it alone -- and there is no exception to this -- it will progress, unfortunately. It will leak gradually and enlarge and then the aching will start and the night cramps will start and then the phlebitis and clots, which sometimes, although rarely, could be serious. Then, patients have changes in the skin, and there is bleeding. There are complications. The patient has to make the decision to wait until that point or to prevent it. I always leave that up to the patient.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Hesmat Majlessi, a vascular surgeon who heads the Rye Vein Care Center, in his office. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1899 words

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
Ethnic Influences Fuel a Takeoff In Houston Dining

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER, a former restaurant critic for The Times, writes about food.

 BODY:
HOUSTON is identified by two industries, one undergound (oil), the other high above (space). They fuel the economy -- and civic pride -- in America's fourth largest city, yet something else is happening, this time at street level: a flourishing multi-ethnic restaurant scene.
Texas cuisine, Tex-Mex, American, French, Italian, Vietnamese and Chinese all can be found in this highway-laced metropolis of 600 square miles. Just five years ago Houston's business scene was flatter than the Texas panhandle, and the restaurant industry was stagnant. But as the city diversified its economic base, restaurateurs were able to hitch a ride on the national recovery. 
 Today the Houston food world is crackling, although the city has a way to go before it can be called a dining destination. Luxury restaurants are scarce (partly a reflection of the city's casual style of living) and some of the second-tier establishments suffer from overambition and lack of focus. Visitors can find some of the most authentic regional fare in vest-pocket cafes like Berryhill in the River Oaks section and at the cafeteria-style Goode Company Texas Bar-B-Q in the Westpark neighborhood.
Like many other American cities, Houston has gone steak crazy, with some of the top-rated including Brenner's Steakhouse, Lynn's Steakhouse, Kelly's del Frisco, Ruth's Chris and Taste of Texas, to name a few. Mexican influences are pervasive no matter what the cuisine, so one should be vigilant for jalapenos.
Houston restaurants offer giant portions at moderate prices -- and Houstonians would accept nothing less. Micro-brewed beers are well represented at most establishments, and wine lists, for the most part, look toward California.
The price ranges listed for the restaurants below are for a three-course dinner for two, including a glass of wine and 8.5 percent tax (but no tip).
 
Cafe Annie
When restaurant buffs talk about Houston, this name always comes up -- with good reason.
The handsome mahogany-paneled Cafe Annie is the creation of Robert Del Grande (the chef), his wife, Mimi, and their partners, Lonnie and Candice Schiller. Entering its 17th year (six at this location), Cafe Annie's refined tone and sharp service support Mr. Del Grande's intellectual approach to Southwestern cooking.
He once described his food as styled after chuck-wagon cooking, which is like calling the Astrodome a covered playground. Mr. Del Grande, a former biochemist and a self-taught cook, creates dishes with striated flavors that romp across the palate.
Exceptional dishes on the voluminous menu are the crabmeat tostada tinged with Tabasco and served with avocado relish and a tomato salsa; a moist and tasty enchilada of rabbit atop a pool of bracing red chili mole; and lovely mussel soup flavored with a cilantro-serrano cream.
Outstanding main courses include the grilled quail with white beans and fennel, and pan-seared red snapper garnished with crabmeat and accompanied by a wild-mushroom tapenade.
One of Mr. Del Grande's signature dishes is worth trying, too: a black-angus filet rubbed with coffee grounds that give it a sharp, earthy edge.
Cafe Annie has a good selection of wines by the glass; the bottle list is well selected and fairly priced. Two bargains are, in white, a slightly tart 1994 Sancerre (Domaine Des Corbillieres, $26), and in red, a full-bodied 1993 Zaca Mesa syrah ($24).
For dessert, try the chocolate-cappuccino meringue encasing a rich chocolate mousse core or the smooth cream-cheese flan.
Dinner for two at Cafe Annie ranges from $80 to $100.
 
Rio Ranch Steakhouse
The Del Grandes and their partners in Cafe Annie, the Schillers, opened this steakhouse, a more casual restaurant with a Texas ranch-house style, in January 1993. The airy, rustic dining room is adjacent to the Westchase Hilton.
Mr. Del Grande has described his goal as serving home-style regional dishes. First-time visitors will feel at home in this terrific place -- that is, if their mothers routinely whipped up dishes like quail rubbed with ancho chilis, homemade venison sausage and applewood-smoked turkey salad.
The full-time chef at Rio Ranch is San Hemwattakit, a 10-year veteran of Cafe Annie. His bold and well-calibrated sauces are a delight, whether in the shrimp with an earthy salsa of roasted tomatoes, onions, garlic, pepper and avocado, or the mesquite-grilled chicken served in a little cast-iron skillet with guacamole and a side of soft tortillas. If you have never tried that Southwestern classic, chicken-fried steak (or have only had a greasy, leaden version), the rendition here will be an epiphany. It is lightly coated in a buttermilk batter, golden and almost puffed, and served with mashed potatoes and creamy black-pepper gravy. Rio Ranch's California-style wine list is well matched to the food, and priced well.
Dinner at Rio Ranch Steakhouse runs between $60 and $85 for two.
 
Tony's
Tony Vallone is the self-styled host of Houston, a man on hand-kissing terms with the city's social elite, who for a quarter-century has cosseted princes and presidents, magnates and movie stars. His newly refurbished dining room, which reopened last September, is a startling chamber of red with an undulating mahogany wall near the bar. The room looks as if the architect started out to created a retro supper club, then reversed direction in mid-project to make it more contemporary. (Mr. Vallone also owns three more-casual spots in Houston: Anthony's, La Griglia and Grotto).
Mr. Vallone darts around the room greeting his guests; his staff is equally vigilant and friendly. Typical of Tony's classic French-Italian fare is the signature lobster souffle, which has lots of lobster flavor but is thick and too heavy. An herby artichoke torte suffered from a floury, undercooked crust. Try something lighter, like the half-moon pasta with asparagus and leek stuffing in a shrimp sauce.
Main courses to watch for include a flavor-packed osso buco and snapper topped with crabmeat over sauteed spinach. The wine list is big on Bordeaux, especially older vintages, and California cabernet sauvignon. Prices vary but are generally reasonable. Dinner for two: $80 to $110.
 
Goode Company Texas Bar-B-Q
For authentic Texas barbecue that you can eat on long picnic tables outside, accompanied by twangy country-western CD's, try Goode Company Texas Bar-B-Q on 5109 Kirby Drive (with a second branch at 8911 Katy Freeway).
The tiny cabin, redolent of mesquite smoke, has about a dozen cramped tables, farm tools on the walls as well as historic photos and beer signs.
Customers line up cafeteria style and choose from barbecued brisket (the best), smoked turkey, ham, pork ribs, barbecued duck and much more. Sides include cole slaw, zesty red rice, jalapeno pinto beans and baked beans. The brisket is lean, delicately smoked and wonderfully moist. Smoked turkey is extraordinarily moist, too. Pork ribs are meaty and tender with a dark, smoked crust.
You can eat like a ranch hand, including a beer and good pecan pie, for less than $15 a person.
 
Berryhill Hot Tamales And Baja Fish Tacos
This is another tiny spot worth seeking out. About the size of a gas station office, Berryhill, at 2639 Revere Street, is a clean and cheerful cafe done in a Mexican folkloric theme. Somehow it seats about 30, plus a dozen tables outside.
Berryhill is locally renowned for its catfish taco, a perfectly fried fillet garnished with shredded red cabbage, cilantro and a dab of tartar-like yogurt-based sauce. For $2.75 you can't beat it. The chicken version is equally savory. Try some well-seasoned black beans and the fluffy rice. The menu includes enchiladas (chicken and corn) and quesadillas (salmon with green beans, chicken with cheese). Beer and a small selection of wines are served.
Two can have a sizable meal at Berryhill, including a beverage, for less than $25.
 
Americas
 One of the more eccentric-looking and lively restaurants in Houston is on Post Oak Boulevard. Owned by Michael Cordua, who is also the chef, the restaurant is dedicated to indigenous food of the Americas, including potatoes, tomatoes, corn, peanuts, rabbit and chocolate. Thankfully, the food at Americas is not limited to just that.
The dining rooms are meant to evoke the mystical lands of South America. Snaking wood panels on the ceiling are modeled after rope bridges of the South American jungle; the ground-level tapas bar is built of mesquite. Stalactite chandeliers add an eerie touch.
I had time only for a tapas tour, but judging from those alone, a visit would be worthwhile. That is, if you don't mind the din on busy nights.
Grilled shrimp with a sweetish pimento sauce was refreshing; so were the various empanaditas, the golden pastry pockets filled with assorted meats. Among the main courses to watch for are pan-roasted Gulf snapper encrusted with fresh corn kernels, grilled lamb tenderloin served with arepas (Peruvian flat bread) and a mint salsa, and salmon fillet encrusted with crushed plantains and served over black beans.
Mr. Cordua also has two South American steakhouses in Houston, called Churrascos. Americas offers a selection of South American wines, as well as California and Australian labels. Ranging in price from $24 and up, the South American wines offer good value. Dinner for two at Americas runs from $45 to $60.
 
La Reserve
For luxury dining, this restaurant, in the Omni Hotel, is one of the favorites in the city. The dining room is comfortable, if institutional-looking, and service is formal and vigilant. The chef, Tim Keating, has a no-holds-barred approach that sometimes is more cloying than captivating -- a tower of lobster and foie gras was one example. A Dungeness crab cake with shiitake mushrooms and truffle essence was moist but oddly bland. Lamb shank is a meaty and rich entree, although it did not need the merguez sausage and gummy risotto. Stick with simple entrees. The wine list is extensive and well-chosen, especially among California labels, but it is priced on the high side. Desserts are lovely, especially the tangerine parfait with citrus compote.
Dinner for two at La Reserve runs from about $100 to $125.
 
From Southwestern to souffles
The following restaurants accept all major credit cards. Unless otherwise noted, reservations are accepted.
Cafe Annie, 1728 Post Oak Boulevard, at San Felipe; (713) 840-1111. Open for lunch Monday to Friday, dinner Monday to Saturday. Closed Sunday.
Rio Ranch Steakhouse, 9999 Westheimer, at Briarpark adjacent to the Westchase Hilton Hotel; (713) 952-5000. Breakfast, lunch and dinner daily.
Tony's, 1801 Post Oak Boulevard, (713) 622-6778. Dinner Monday to Saturday.
Goode Company Texas Bar-B-Q, 5109 Kirby Drive, between Route 59 and Bissonnet Street; (713) 522-2530. Lunch and dinner daily. No reservations are accepted.
Berryhill Hot Tamales and Baja Fish Tacos, 2639 Revere Street, at Westheimer near Kirby Drive; (713) 526-8080. Lunch daily, dinner daily except Sunday, breakfast Saturday and Sunday. No reservations are accepted.
Americas, 1800 Post Oak Boulevard, at Ambassador Way (Saks Fifth Avenue Pavillon); (713) 961-1492. Lunch and dinner Monday to Friday, dinner on Saturday.
La Reserve, Omni Hotel, 4 Riverway, Woodway and South Post Oak Lane; (713) 871-8177. Dinner Monday to Saturday. B. M.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2250 words

HEADLINE: Broadway's Producers: A Struggling, Changing, Breed

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
THE PRODUCER ROBERT WHITEHEAD, at 80 one of the grand old men of Broadway, was approached recently by his 23-year-old son, Charlie, with a proposal that both flattered and confounded him.
"Charlie said to me, 'Dad, I feel I want to get into what you've done,' " recalled Mr. Whitehead, whose work over the last 50 years has ranged from the original productions of "A Member of the Wedding" and "A Man for All Seasons" to the current hit "Master Class." 
 Mr. Whitehead did not know what to say to his son. Could he in good conscience encourage the young man to become a Broadway producer? The business has changed drastically since he entered it in 1947, when Broadway was a fertile field for new plays and their impresarios. Now, the field seems hard and unyielding. The current season's crop of original dramas and musicals, once an annual bounty in the dozens, is thin. Revivals and long-running mega-musicals predominate.
"So I said to him," the father recounted, " 'I don't know how you do it, Charlie. I don't know how you make a life of it anymore.' "
Mr. Whitehead was not only imparting personal wisdom; he was defining a reality. What he considers producing, the Broadway tradition of taking an original play or musical and shepherding it from the written page to the Broadway stage, has all but ceased to be a career. Indeed, that fact has inspired a mantra repeated by some of the most respected artists in the theater: "There are no real Broadway producers anymore."
Gone are the days when producers were as much Broadway luminaries as the actors and composers they hired, when showmen like David Merrick, Kermit Bloomgarten and Billy Rose had the stature and business savvy to singlehandedly bring new plays to the theater district. Gone, too, is the era when producers could afford to mount new works each year and thus acquire the skills to shape scripts and the time to learn from their mistakes.
Where have all the producers gone? Some have fled to Off Broadway, where costs are lower. Others have pulled up stakes and headed for Hollywood. Those who remain, including a few from the old school of producing, are mostly occasional presences on Broadway; others are specialists in musical spectacles or wealthy investors. The only ones who produce from year to year are members of the new Broadway power group: nonprofit institutions like Lincoln Center Theater and the Roundabout Theater Company.
An up-to-the-minute snapshot of the Broadway Producers Class of '96 is a portrait of transience. Although a few of the faces would make it into a class picture any season, most would not. The producers pictured here (each one representing a show on Broadway) are a varied lot and, along with the many partners in their productions, so numerous that it would take an entire photo album to include them all.
They come from the worlds of theater and finance, from rock-and-roll, movies, academia and even the circus. Some, like the Theater Guild, producers of the film-to-stage musical "State Fair," are vestiges of the old days; the organization has not produced on Broadway since 1976. Others, like Allan S. Gordon, Jeffrey Seller and Kevin McCollum, the producers of the musical "Rent," are making their Broadway debuts.
Producing commercially, year in and year out, "is a craft that has fewer and fewer representatives," said Barry Weissler, who with his wife, Fran, produces on Broadway, primarily revivals. "It's becoming more and more difficult to find hands-on producers, the Robert Whiteheads of the world."
The impediments to producing are a reflection of the theater's harsh realities. The long-running musicals now tie up the best musical houses for years, if not decades, and the audience for the traditional Broadway play is drying up. But money is the biggest obstacle. At a time when the bargain-basement price for mounting a Broadway play is $750,000, when the cost of musicals can exceed $10 million, the complex job of bringing a production to Broadway has become more a matter of economics than taste, a game of deep pockets rather than long commitments.
These days, in fact, raising money is such an overwhelming part of producing that it has skewed the notion of who a producer is. A Broadway show no longer has one or two producer names above the title but a dozen. Producers do not come to Broadway with resumes. They come with stock portfolios.
"Everybody has different reasons for being here," said Michael David, a partner in Dodger Productions, which has produced a string of well-received musical revivals, including "Guys and Dolls" and "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." That "we have a team that enables us to do it at all" is what matters, he said.
Take the revival of "The King and I," in which Mr. David is involved. When the original production opened on Broadway in 1951, the only producers were Rodgers and Hammerstein themselves. The cost of the show was $360,000. The 1996 production opening on Thursday -- same book, same music -- costs $5.5 million. And the list of producers reads like the result of a Wall Street merger: "Dodger Productions, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, James M. Nederlander, Perseus Productions with John Frost and the Adelaide Festival Center, in association with the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization . . ."
"It has become a money business rather than a creative business," observed James B. Freydberg, a longtime producer who is mounting one of the season's most expensive musicals, the $10 million "Big," opening later this month. "People are producing in groups of 10 or 11, and the problem in many cases is, there is nobody in charge; it's a very impersonal relationship to the show. There's no such thing as a personal relationship with 11 producers."
GERALD SCHOENFELD, chairman of the Shubert Organization, Broadway's biggest landlord, says producing today is "a business primarily of itinerants," where the players shift constantly.
At first glance, this might seem like a sign of vitality. But the reality, many in the theater say, is that an essential aspect has been lost in the breakup of the traditional producing fraternity: stability and the sense of belonging that leads producers to invest not only in the next potential mega-hit but in the creative people vital to the future of theater in America.
George C. Wolfe, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, who directed both the musical "Jelly's Last Jam" and the drama "Angels in America" on Broadway, believes that the commercial theater no longer has the infrastructure to find and nurture original work consistently.
On Tuesday, Mr. Wolfe's musical, "Bring in da Noise, Bring in da Funk," a downtown hit he created from scratch last fall with Savion Glover and a group of other tap, rap and blues artists, begins performances at the Ambassador Theater on Broadway. Mr. Wolfe said that without the financial cushion provided by his own nonprofit theater, the show could not have been created.
"If I had gone into the commercial arena and said, 'O.K., I have this idea for a show and I want to work with Savion and we don't have a clue -- can you give me the money?,' it never would have happened," Mr. Wolfe said.
The problem is no secret on Broadway. Elizabeth I. McCann, who made her reputation in the 1970's by moving prestigious London productions to New York, said financing is a major problem. "I believe the difficulty in raising money has become so horrific," she said, "that -- forget commercial -- even if you look at the not-for-profit theater, half the plays are being produced someplace else before Broadway.
"Who in God's name is finding the baby in the bullrushes?" she asked.
CONSIDER THE CURRENT SEASON. Of the 33 plays and musicals that will have opened by May 1, the official end of the 1995-96 season, only six are, in essence, original works that were produced specifically for Broadway: "Chronicle of a Death Foretold," "Sacrilege," "Master Class," "Moon Over Buffalo," "Victor/Victoria" and "Big," and the latter two are based on hit movies.
The rest are either revivals (18 in all), one-person shows like Jackie Mason's "Love Thy Neighbor," or original plays and musicals created in nonprofit, regional or London theaters (like "Rent," "Getting Away With Murder" and "Racing Demon") that subsequently received productions on Broadway.
This is not what Broadway was supposed to become. "When you talked about the New York theater, you talked about the 12 or 15 plays that were on Broadway," Mr. Whitehead said. "Maybe there were three musicals, but when people came to see the theater, what they meant was the plays.
"And a producer," he continued, "seemed to me to be someone who had a point of view about what he produced, and his plays had a connection, one with the other, because it all had something to do with his taste."
Aside from a handful of today's biggest producers, like Cameron Mackintosh, Andrew Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Company and Dodger Productions, there are few who are independent, with the vision or clout to put shows on again and again.
Into the producing vacuum on Broadway has rushed the organization. More and more it is institutions, whether corporate or nonprofit, that raise the capital to put on shows, many of which are lavish, highly commercial musicals or remakes of old plays. The past on Broadway belongs to the likes of the 84-year-old Mr. Merrick (who, despite the effects of a stroke, is back this year as a super-investor in the musical "State Fair"), but tomorrow belongs to Disney and other large companies. Disney has one of the most expensive musicals on Broadway, "Beauty and the Beast," and is restoring a Times Square theater in which to stage others.
Playmaking, a craft that producers like Mr. Whitehead once dominated, is now a Broadway business centered on staging revivals: call it playremaking.
"I think there's a very strong undercurrent of turning Broadway into a theme park," said John Hart, a producer of "How to Succeed." "Nickelodeon can come in and do 'Beavis and Butt-head: The Musical.' Ted Turner can come in and do 'Gone With the Wind: The Musical.' It's the only thing that makes sense, unless you find another way to really make this work, the way that a Broadway show should work, and everybody can make money doing it."
Before you can make money, though, you have to raise it. And in truth, many of the people listed as producers of Broadway shows are not producers at all. They are investors who have been granted producing credits as concessions to vanity.
"The backers are the producers today," insisted Alexander H. Cohen, who has been producing Broadway plays for more than 50 years. "Whether it is someone in the fish business or in the theatrical business, if they've got the $250,000, their name goes up there."
Increasingly, too, the theater owners, seeking productions to fill the 32 commercial houses of Broadway, are being compelled to invest in and even produce shows. The Shubert Organization produced "Cats" and has loaned money to the Shakespeare Festival to move "The Tempest" and "Bring in da Noise" to Broadway; Jujamcyn Theaters is a producer of five current Broadway productions and the Nederlander Organization is a producer of two others.
That the landlords must help finance the productions is a function, according to some producers, of the changes the theater owners foisted on the producers in the 1970's. At one time, theater owners shared the weekly costs of running a show with producers. Now, producers say, little is shared, and the additional burdens have pushed some producers out of the business. "I have to pay for the light bulbs," complained one frustrated producer. "I have to pay for new doilies around the ushers' necks."
SO WHAT OF BROADWAY'S FUTURE? Does the decline of the visionary showman mean the death of Broadway?
Already, the street is seeking ways to reinvent itself. Companies like Walt Disney Theatrical Productions and Livent, a Toronto-based concern headed by Garth Drabinsky ("Kiss of the Spider Woman" and "Show Boat"), are operating like musical production studios, commissioning composers and lyricists to write new stage musicals to fill theaters they plan to operate on 42d Street.
Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, not only invests frequently in the productions his theaters house but supports the younger generation of producers. For example, he provides office space to producers like Elizabeth Williams ("Moon Over Buffalo") and Margo Lion ("Jelly's Last Jam"), both of whom are developing projects for Broadway.
Broadway is also looking at itself for answers. A commercial theater institute sponsored by the Theater Development Fund trains young producers each year through weekly seminars. And a team of analysts from Bain and Company, a Boston management consulting firm, has been hired by the city and a broad coalition of Broadway landlords, unions and producers to study the way Broadway operates. Its mandate is to come up with proposals for a theater trust fund, envisioned as a means of helping producers finance new musicals and plays.
Producers these days need all the help they can get to stay in the game that many of them say they still love.
"It's a very complex business, and it requires an astute understanding of so many disciplines," Mr. Drabinsky said. "But opening a new theater is exhilarating. And opening a new show is even more so."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 838 words

HEADLINE: How About These Mets!

BYLINE: By Allen St. John; Allen St. John formerly covered the Mets and the Yankees for The Village Voice. He is a contributor to the forthcoming book "The Way Baseball Works."

 BODY:

HIGH AND TIGHT
The Rise and Fall of Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry.
By Bob Klapisch.
Illustrated. 236 pp. New York:
Villard Books. $22.
THE challenge in writing an expos is that you have to have something to expose. In "High and Tight," Bob Klapisch, who used to cover the Mets for The Daily News, promises to tell all about Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden. Too bad it's all been told already. 
 Sports Illustrated revealed in February 1995 that the Mets clubhouse was once rife with cocaine and amphetamine abuse. The commissioner's office has informed us that Gooden and Strawberry drank and used drugs. Mr. Klapisch, unfortunately, doesn't have much to add. We find out that Strawberry contemplated suicide not once but twice; we learn that Gooden took Prozac after his stay in the Betty Ford Center. But "Ball Four" this ain't.
Instead of revealing new debauch-eries, Mr. Klapisch spins a tale of addiction and redemption that was supposed to dovetail with the duo's triumphant return to New York, older, wiser and now wearing pin stripes. Describing Strawberry hitting a home run for the Yankees, Mr. Klapisch lays it on thick: "Moments such as these made it possible to see Strawberry's career as a miniature tragedy. So much talent, so much of it traded away for a cheap high. . . . But he at least was willing to understand that 'the last few years of my career can be dedicated towards finishing strong.' "
Couple that with a clean and sober Gooden racking up strikeouts, and you have Mickey and Whitey for the 90's -- except that the Yankees released Strawberry last fall, and Gooden has hardly looked like the Doc of old. Not the stuff of which movies of the week are made.
Once you get past the not-so-revelatory revelations and the morality play sans happy ending, "High and Tight" does have its moments. The portrait Mr. Klapisch draws is of two men at odds with their reputations. Strawberry reveals a soft side -- he finds a hotel room for a street couple (only to have the man attack him) and puts unemployed siblings on his payroll (although he can hardly pay his own bills). Outside the clubhouse, Gooden displays a hard streak. When Mr. Klapisch shows up unannounced at Gooden's home in Tampa, Fla., the pitcher seems ready to sic his bodyguards on the reporter. "That street-tough side of Gooden, even the way his Mercedes was appointed, with oversized chrome rims, suggested aggression," Mr. Klapisch writes.
In fact, the book's two strongest moments concern threats of violence. Facing a possible prison sentence on a tax-evasion charge, Strawberry debates killing himself. "I never did anything to hurt anyone, except myself," he laments, only half-fibbing. After his arrest on charges of resisting arrest and battery of a police officer in 1987, Gooden gets in a car with some friends who have a .38-caliber pistol and a mission: to attack the first police officer who harasses them.
But by staying so close to the who, what, when and where of this story, Mr. Klapisch largely misses the why. He gives a nod to Freud, citing Strawberry's absent father and Gooden's demanding dad. But mostly Mr. Klapisch tells this as a story of two easily swayed individuals in a clubhouse that was out of control, and leaves it at that.
"In a sense, the two were easy prey," he writes. "These were two players who never had to rely on hard work to succeed and never grasped how fleeting physical skill can be." That's an explanation that will play on sports talk radio, but the reality is more complex. Why was the future Dr. K able to resist a cocaine dealer at the age of 17 in Tampa and not two years later as a Met? Why was the next Ted Williams able to negotiate the streets of South-Central Los Angeles, but not the Mets clubhouse?
In addition, Mr. Klapisch, who skewered Mets management in "The Worst Team Money Could Buy," his 1993 book written with John Harper, is strangely reluctant to take the team to task for its handling of its overhyped prodigies. If the '86 Mets really were the kind of speed-popping, coke-snorting, beer-guzzling thugs that Mr. Klapisch recalls almost sentimentally, then the general manager, Frank Cashen, should have done something, 108-victory season or not.
FINALLY, Mr. Klapisch glosses over one crucial fact. While you can argue that drugs and drinking ruined Strawberry's life, and Gooden's too, it is not accurate to say that their vices killed their careers. Gooden hasn't had a winning season since 1991 not because he snorted coke, but because of a torn rotator cuff that can be traced back to throwing too many innings when he was a teen-ager. Similarly, it was ruptured disks in Strawberry's back, not tax evasion, that put his career in jeopardy.
But while weakness of the will makes better copy than failure of the flesh, the reason we're still interested is that it's impossible to look at Gooden or Strawberry and not wonder about what might have been. Unfortunately, "High and Tight" raises a lot more questions than it answers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: HIGH AND TIGHT (BOOK)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (90%); FLORIDA, USA (72%); 

CITY: TAMPA, FL, USA (72%);

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/From 410 Park Avenue to 280 Park Avenue;
Why the N.F.L. Chose to Keep Playing in Manhattan

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT seemed but a typical staged event -- until one realized what was left unsaid.
Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League's commissioner, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, beamed as they announced the N.F.L.'s decision to keep its headquarters in New York City. The Mayor talked about New York as a "business, sports and tourist Mecca," Mr. Tagliabue thanked the Mayor for his "personal support" and the economic development office for its "professional guidance." All told, not stop-the-presses news -- and indeed, both the N.F.L. and the city have expressed disappointment at how little coverage that March 6 meeting received. 
 But, in fact, the meeting was unusual, not in what transpired but in what did not. There was no talk of tax breaks, no promises of new jobs, no mention of the fact that last fall the city did offer a tiny incentive, worth no more than $1 million over 15 years, and that the N.F.L. turned it down.
"It would have taken weeks to work it out, and we just wanted to get our real estate deal done," said John Buzzeo, the N.F.L.'s director of administration. Someone else familiar with the negotiations offered another reason, albeit only upon promise of anonymity: "The N.F.L. did not want to appear to be taking money from its fans and giving it to wealthy football team owners."
In a sense, the N.F.L.'s decision to remain in New York conflicts with what many consider to be two hard-and-fast real estate rules: One, that New York cannot hold onto any prestige tenant without sweetening the pot, and two, that companies move where their owners or chief executives live.
Mr. Tagliabue's roots are in Washington, and Neil Austrian, the league's president, lives in Connecticut. And the N.F.L. is an association of 30 football teams and their owners, any one of whom would have loved the league to come to his or her hometown -- and some of whom own office buildings.
The N.F.L., which has been at 410 Park Avenue, near 54th Street, since 1968, took everyone's preferences into account. Yet in the end, it is moving just one ZIP code away, to 280 Park Avenue, near 48th Street. And that decision can serve as a heartening tale to anyone worried that any organization looking to contain costs will quickly scurry away from New York.
"Sure, moving the N.F.L. out of New York would save money," said Carmen A. Policy, president of the San Francisco 49ers. "But there is a presence, an energy, a stature and dimension, that New York adds to the N.F.L. that cannot be duplicated anywhere else."
That was even more true 36 years ago, when Pete Rozelle first moved the league here from Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. E-mail and video conferences had not been invented, so the best way to promote football was to be in the home of the networks and major newspapers and magazines.
Football's popularity, and the league's growth, have certainly soared since then. In 1960 the N.F.L. comprised 13 teams; today it has 30. The league has 17 separate departments, handling such diverse operations as scheduling games and licensing products. And it has formed a World League with the Fox Network that already has signed up teams in Barcelona, Edinburgh, London, Amsterdam, Dusseldorf and Frankfurt.
The staff has burgeoned. In 1960, when the N.F.L. moved to a tiny office in Rockefeller Center, it had seven people. When it moved to part of one floor at 410 Park eight years later, it had 17. Today it has 360 employees, scattered across nearly 12 floors.
"We just grabbed whatever space came open, taking 5,000 square feet here, 8,000 square feet there," Mr. Buzzeo recalled. "Organizationally, it just wasn't any good."
So, about three years ago, with its lease a year from expiration, the N.F.L. started looking for a building where it could consolidate on five floors, tops. Almost immediately, the team owners started putting in their dibs.
"We heard, 'If you come to Dallas you could get space for $11 a foot,' or, 'If you come to Chicago you'll be central to the whole country,' " Mr. Buzzeo recalled.
The timing could not have been worse. The league was in the midst of contract talks with the players, it was negotiating new television contracts, and it was struggling to superimpose checks and balances on its hodgepodge of autonomous divisions.
"We just weren't prepared to do an indepth study of where we should be," Mr. Buzzeo said.
MEANWHILE, New York was exerting a visceral push-pull effect on everyone involved. Mr. Buzzeo remembers countless employees begging the league to stay put. Indeed, with 55 percent of its employees living in New York City -- and 42 percent of those right in Manhattan -- no one's heart was really in leaving New York.
Yet, with New York rents so much higher than anywhere else, no one was ready to commit the league to staying. The N.F.L. came close to taking space at 1325 Avenue of the Americas, on 54th Street, but backed out at the last minute. Instead, it took yet another half a floor at 410 Park, and extended its lease for two years.
A little over a year ago, the N.F.L. again started looking for a new home. But this time, it did it methodically.
It made cursory passes at cities that were plane rides away, but no one could find a truly compelling reason to leave the New York area. The league thought about expanding a studio building it already owned in Cherry Hill, N.J., but ruled that out as too inconvenient for everyone. It quickly ruled out Long Island and the rest of New Jersey, too, because they entailed horrendous commutes for many N.F.L. employees.
Westchester and Stamford, Conn., remained in the running. They were easy to get to, and they had a lot of good, reasonably priced space looking for tenants.
Still, everyone's emotional pendulum kept swinging back to New York.
"Costs simply did not drive the deals as much as the N.F.L.'s overall sense of where the people they interact with are, and where their employees want to be," said Franklin Speyer, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director who was the N.F.L.'s broker.
Nor did the individual team owners fight hard to get the N.F.L. onto their turfs -- particularly since Mr. Tagliabue had begun rotating the locations of many of the league's meetings, rather than forcing everyone to come to N.F.L. headquarters every time they had to talk.
"They had a great deal in an I.B.M. building a block from my summer house, yet I voted that they stay in Manhattan," said Preston Robert Tisch, an owner of the Giants.
"Even those of us that have to fly from the West Coast felt it was better to stay in New York," Mr. Policy said. "Pete Rozelle's original reasoning still applies."
Still, the New York rent costs stuck in the N.F.L.'s organizational craw, particularly since the N.F.L. had decided early on that its image called for an upscale building.
Thus, the idea of asking the city for incentives got born. "We knew we just had 360 jobs, but we also knew we were an important, high-profile tenant," Mr. Buzzeo said.
City officials say the N.F.L. never really pressed the point, though. "They weren't screaming that they have one foot out the door," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "If we had believed that the N.F.L. was serious about leaving, we probably would have put something on the table."
By the time the city made its offer, the N.F.L. was already close to signing a 16-year lease for 205,000 square feet -- 85,000 square feet more than it has now -- on four and a half contiguous floors at 280 Park. And, it was loath to stymie the dealmaking process while it haggled with the city and coped with the inevitable paperwork and legalese that accompanies city incentives.
"Sometimes, just getting something done is worth more than the money on the table," Mr. Millard said.
The incentives would never have made up for the costs the league is about to entail, anyway. Annual rents at 280 Park generally average in the low $40's per square foot, and the league is expected to pay somewhere around $125 million in rent over its 16 years. That's a lot more than Dallas, or even White Plains, would have cost.
"But moving would have been penny wise and pound foolish," Mr. Buzzeo said.
In preparation for its move, slated for next March, the N.F.L. checked whether its reporting hierarchy needed any fine tuning, and studied which departments should be adjacent to each other. It will put the treasury and accounting functions of the different divisions next to each other so that one accounts payable department can serve them all. It is installing video conferencing centers, so that neither Commissioner Tagliabue nor the owners need get on a plane every time a few of them want to meet. And it has rejiggered lines of authority between NFL Enterprises, which handles the league's pay-per-view, satellite transmissions and other modern-day methods to air football games, and NFL Properties, which handles product licensing.
"This operation is really pulling together," Mr. Tisch said. "We are getting set to run a big, big business."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Prospect Lefferts Gardens;
Racial Harmony and Rich Architecture

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A STORY of racial harmony set against some of the finest residential architecture in Brooklyn resounds from the wide, parking-friendly streets of Prospect Lefferts Gardens.
Situated near the southeast corner of Prospect Park in the Flatbush section, the racially mixed, predominantly middle-class, richly West Indian neighborhood holds at its core a 600-home historic district, designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1979 and restricted by deed covenants to single-family-home owners. 
 People who live there say the historic district, where long-time residency has been common, promotes a stability welding the district and surrounding streets into a seamless whole that defeats the black-white racial divide common elsewhere.
They also say people get along. "There isn't that friction here," said Lenore Briggs, the owner and director of the Lefferts Gardens Montessori School on Rogers Avenue, where 50 children aged 2 1/2 to 6 attend classes.
The housing bargains, real estate agents declare, are remarkable. "There is a wonderful relationship between price and value," said Paul John Skrobela, associate broker at the William B. May Company. He said two- or three-story houses in the district generally ranged from $200,000 to $300,000.
"People who are looking in Park Slope can get just as nice a house here for a lot less," said Mary Kay Gallagher, an independent broker from Prospect Park South. "And I mean a lot less."
For all that, the area is surprisingly unheralded. "It's sort of a little secret," said Harriet A. Robinson, an associate broker at Century 21 Joseph T. King Realty in Park Slope.
In contrast to thematic, nearly all-Tudor Forest Hills Gardens in Queens, another architecturally notable area, houses in and around the Prospect Lefferts Gardens historic district range freely, if with restraint, through revival styles popular from the 1890's to the 1920's, when most were built.
Most are modest versions of style-setting, opulent homes built for the rich before and during this period on Manhattan's Upper East Side.
Brick, brownstone and Indiana limestone exteriors in Romanesque revival, Colonial Revival, neo-Georgian, neo-Tudor and neo-Federal style share single blocks. Uninterrupted stretches of the district's signature limestone rowhouses, with their rounded bays, give way on some streets to free-standing homes, some quite large. Everywhere, cartouches, foliate panels, classical moldings and other detailing enliven the eclectic mood.
The Grace Reformed Church on Lincoln Road and Bedford Avenue is typical of the high architectural standards and diversity of styles within, and to a degree beyond, the historic district. Built in 1893, the church is a small, neo-Italian Renaissance-style brick building with terra-cotta trim, stained-glass windows by Tiffany, a cruciform design and corner towers.
B UILT for the professional middle class in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when farms in the old town of Flatbush sprouted a final crop of houses, the area now called Prospect Lefferts Gardens grew apace with the coming of new rail links to Brooklyn and Manhattan.
The Brooklyn, Flatbush & Coney Island Railroad, originally designed for seasonal excursions, was by the turn of the century an electrified commuter line serving Flatbush.
The opening of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883 and proximity to Prospect Park, built in the 1860's to rival Central Park, had already set the stage for development.
In 1893, James Lefferts, a descendant of the Dutch family that settled here in 1660 when the area was part of the Dutch settlement of Midwout, divided his estate into 600 building lots. To assure only high quality, single-family homes would be built in the area, to be called Lefferts Manor, deeds carried restrictive covenants.
T HE covenants halted the march of two-family houses at the borders and barred commercial development, which explains the absence of stores. Prospect Lefferts Gardens shopping areas are along Nostrand Avenue and Flatbush Avenue.
The covenants also withstood legal challenge and resulted, a century later, in a housing stock in generally good repair that was unaltered by interior subdivisions even during the depths of the Great Depression.
Two-family houses are the norm outside the district, where prices are lower. Owners frequently live in one unit and rent the other. Rentals in two-family houses or in the area's liberal sprinkling of five- and six-story apartment houses range from $700 to $900 for two bedrooms.
Patio Gardens, a twin-tower, 460-apartment rent-stabilized building on Flatbush Avenue, was donated by the former owner, Donald J. Trump, three years ago to the National Kidney Foundation of New York and New Jersey. Two-bedroom apartments rent from $750 to about $900 a month.
The community draws its name from Prospect Park, the Lefferts family and the nearby Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
Mr. Skrobela, who has lived in the Lefferts Manor section of the historic district for 13 years, described the community as economically and ethnically diverse, and -- as from its beginnings -- mostly middle class. "You may have a Transit Authority worker living on the same block as the head of a college math department," he said.
"It's a very integrated community racially and attracts people for whom that's important," said Barbara L. Solomon, who moved into the historic district from the Upper West Side 15 years ago with her husband, Eliot, the current president of the Lefferts Manor Association.
"Some people say they don't understand this place where black lawyers, doctors and real estate agents live next to white ones," she said. "It seems to be terribly unique, and I'm not quite sure why."
Blacks moved in in large numbers during the late 50's and 60's, sometimes encountering hate fences -- high corrugated plastic barriers erected by whites in that era. But the white flight that occurred in other areas did not happen there, and eventually the hate fences fell. Today, Asian and Hispanic residents add to the mix.
The neighborhood was heaven for Brooklyn Dodger fans when the din from nearby Ebbets Field filled the air.
There was pandemonium in 1955 when the Dodgers won their first World Series at Yankee Stadium. "We all ran out of our houses screaming," said Ms. Gallagher, the realtor, who used to live on Maple Street.
In some ways, life here is no more perfect than in many other inner-city areas. People know distant popping sounds in the night may not be firecrackers. And at the Honey Bee Farm fruit and fish store on Flatbush Avenue, a burly fruit-watcher employed by the Asian owners draws the line at chasing young crackheads. "An orange is not worth a knife in the heart," he said.
But for the untimid, there is much consolation: Eye-pleasing architecture, ample curbside parking, proximity to Prospect Park, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the Brooklyn Museum, good subway links to Manhattan and a self-contained neighborhood where people know each other.
"You have friends who are friends with your other friends," said Jennifer Plassman, a volunteer at the 28-student Maple Street School preschool for children 2 to 5, a parent cooperative on Nostrand Avenue.
P ROSPECT LEFFERTS GARDENS is in School District 17, an academically troubled district whose schools have generally ranked low in reading and math scores. The district was taken over by the central Board of Education in 1994.
At P.S. 92 on Parkside Avenue, where the principal, Robert Evans, responded with "no comment" to a request for information, 1,233 children attend prekindergarten through 8th grade. Scores in math and reading are below city-wide averages, but the district's Superintendent, Barbara Bryd-Bennett, said they had been improving for the last five years.
Three city high schools -- Prospect Heights, Erasmus Hall and George Wood Wingate -- are near Prospect Lefferts Gardens. All are below city averages in mathematics and verbal scores on the Scholastic Assessment Test.
Some residents send their children to nearby private schools. The Berkeley-Carroll School in Park Slope, with 693 students in pre-kindergarten through grade 12, offers academic rigor and a summer day camp for children aged 3 to 8. It was designated a blue-ribbon school by the Federal Department of Education, the only private or public school in Brooklyn to win the accolade for general excellence.
Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights, also from pre-kindergarten through grade 12, prepares its 830 students for top-rank colleges, as do Berkeley-Carroll and another institution, St. Ann's School, both competitive-admission schools for gifted children.

HOUSE TOUR: For the last 25 years, house-proud residents of Prospect Lefferts Gardens have thrown open their doors once a year to visitors. This year will be no exception the 26th annual tour, a self-guided event with an itinerary of at least 10 homes, is set for Sunday, June 2, from noon to 5 P.M. Guides will be on hand at each address. Tickets cost $15 at curbside or $10 in advance from the Lefferts Manor Association at 135 Midwood Street, Brooklyn, 11225. Further information is available by calling the association at (718) 284-6210. "We want people to know about our neighborhood," said Robert A. Marvin, a tour organizer. "It's still relatively unknown." Mr. Marvin said he and his wife, Elaine, had purchased their limestone-and-brick rowhouse with its Renaissance revival exterior with Romanesque touches after taking the tour in 1974. "I'm sure if we hadn't gone on that tour we wouldn't be living here now," Mr. Marvin said. He added that they were only the third owners since the house was built in 1899.

HEADLINE: In Hartford, the River Is Beckoning Once Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
ALONG Interstate 91 in Hartford, concrete columns are rising out of the mud, forming the pillars that will support a 1.25-acre landscaped plaza that will allow people to walk from downtown, over the highway, to the edge of the Connecticut River.
Off East River Drive, on the other bank, bulldozers and backhoes are smoothing over gray silt and red clay, putting the finishing touches on the land around a new 350-seat amphitheater that looks out over the water and is scheduled to open June 19. 
 Those are the most visible signs yet of years of effort by Riverfront Recapture, the organization dedicated to improving public access to the Connecticut River in Hartford and East Hartford. The group has raised or lobbied for more than $220 million of clean water projects and recreational amenities, although until now most of the major work has only been on the drawing board.
Joseph R. Marfuggi, executive director of Riverfront Recapture, said professional planners agree that any waterfront revitalization takes a 20-year commitment; his group celebrates its 15th anniversary this week.
"We're really ready now," Mr. Marfuggi said. "We're poised to take advantage of all the work that's been done and use it as the centerpiece of a major economic development project."
The group offers programs that teach city children how to fish and build boats. It sponsors riverbank concerts, jogging and biking outings, and two triathalons. It offers a program modeled after Outward Bound where young people are challenged physically and emotionally on obstacle courses.
"It's such a new world for them, so many of them are not even aware there's a river on the other side of the highway," said Craig Mergins, programs and operations manager for Riverfront Recapture. "Some of these programs are keeping them out of trouble, and the thing is, a lot of them probably don't even realize that."
The organization's efforts have also brought it national attention. Last year it brought the first major bass fishing tournament in New England to the river. This year it will bring in a water skiing competition, next year a National Rowing Association convention, and the year after that a meeting of the American Fisheries Society.
"For a long time, there was a lot of skepticism and pessimism," Mr. Marfuggi said. "We would take our models to fishing and boat shows, and people would say, 'It'll never happen in Hartford.' But as more of it becomes available and people are seeing things like the Bassmaster Tournament come in, we're getting a lot more believers."
Henry G. Thorpe, vice president and general manager of Deep River Navigation Inc., which operates the steam-powered riverboat Lady Fenwick for day and dinner cruises in the summer, said interest in the river is clearly picking up. "When we started in 1986, Riverfront Recapture was just getting underway, and we lost money -- but we knew we were going to lose money," Mr. Thorpe said. "We ran a trip every hour, and a ticket was $3, but it was just to get large amounts of people down there."
Last summer, for the first time, the Lady Fenwick offered dinner cruises with jazz bands on Friday nights, he said.
"It sold out every single Friday night, 75 people on board every trip," Mr. Thorpe said. "For years, we were happy to have 10." This year, the dinner cruises will be offered Thursday nights as well.
He said people are surprised to find the river water is clean, and just a few miles from Hartford its banks are lined with trees, and animals are often seen coming down for a drink. "You wouldn't know you're within 100 miles of a city," Mr. Thorpe said.
Now Riverfront Recapture has teamed up with the Capitol Region Partnership to develop an organization that will manage, maintain and improve on the foundation it has laid.
"It doesn't take long for something like this to deteriorate if you're not protecting it," Mr. Marfuggi said. "But if you do protect it, you can leverage it many times, and the benefits are going to spill out across the whole region."
A committee of business and political leaders has been meeting since late last year to develop a strategy for raising an operating budget estimated to range from $3.5 million to $5 million a year starting in 1997, and to support improvements like a campground in East Hartford, a freshwater aquarium, a fishing hall of fame and a Hartford exposition center.
"Now that this thing is on the cusp of becoming reality, we need to ask ourselves -- what is the best organizational structure for the future?" asked R. Nelson Griebel, president of the Bank of Boston Connecticut, and chairman of the committee.
"If we can lay out a plan that is clear and makes sense, we'll get the funding for it," said Mr. Griebel. "This whole program makes sense to me, as a businessman, because it's going to give the whole region a healthier economy."
An oil painting of Hartford from 150 years ago shows tall ships and steamboats lining the 26 wharfs along the riverfront, a time when the river was "the front door of the city," the center of commerce.
But river traffic declined, and the 1936 and '38 hurricanes flooded the downtown so badly a 38-foot concrete dike was build to control the flooding. Then Interstate 91 was built between the dike and the downtown, all but eliminating access.
"The rivers were polluted, dirty and smelly, so people didn't use them for recreation," Mr. Marfuggi said. "Commercial uses had died for the most part when railroads replaced river shipping. And so when people looked for a place to put a highway or anything else no one wanted in their backyard, they put it near a river. No one cared."
Until April 9, 1981, when Riverfront Recapture was formed to be an advocate for reopening access to the Connecticut.
"People are rediscovering rivers and waterfronts all over the country," Mr. Marfuggi said -- in Baltimore and Boston and Portsmouth. In Cleveland -- the butt of many bad jokes after the Cuyahoga River caught fire in the 1970's -- a cleanup has prompted a riverside redevelopment known as The Flats that attracts 7.5 million visitors a year.
And Hartford will be next, supporters contend.
"The whole package is coming together -- the clean water, the clean parks and the new amenities, all at the same time," Mr. Marfuggi said. "It's only as limited as your imagination, and we're telling people, 'Think big.' "
One of the group's first projects was to reclaim the 62-acre, 100-year-old Riverside Park, designed by the sons of Frederick Law Olmsted, but then cut off from the rest of the city and left to deteriorate.
The group lobbied the Federal and state highway departments and economic development agencies for $33.6 million for projects like Charter Oak landing, the Interstate 91 platform, and the East Hartford amphitheater. At the same time, the Metropolitan District Commission has poured $83 million into river cleanup, and plans $90 million more.
Riverfront Recapture has a campaign underway to raise another $14.3 million for construction of riverside walkways north to Windsor and south to Wethersfield.
And fund raising is just one of the challenges, Mr. Marfuggi said. Being in a flood plain, "We have to design everything to spend part of the year underwater," he said. The boathouse, for instance, has louvers in the side that can be opened. The amphitheater is on concrete, so it will not be washed away. Everything is built with rot-resistant pressure-treated lumber.
And, working in a flood plain means dealing with a host of Federal and state environmental agencies.
"You can't imagine the permits we require just to plant a tree," Mr. Marfuggi said. "You have to show what the impact is going to be downstream, and how it's going to add to the cumulative impact of the project."
He said another problem has been convincing people that the Connecticut River could be a major asset to Hartford. Because people have been cut off from the river for so long, many do not realize how much conditions have improved since the 1960's, when it was often characterized as an open sewer.
"When we said we were working to bring the bass tournament in, the first question everyone asked was, where are you going to get the fish?" Mr. Marfuggi said. "But we didn't have to stock a single fish."
In fact, anglers say, there are strong populations of large- and small-mouth bass, muskellunge, catfish, carp and other species filling the river.
And the professional angers' spouses and children -- who were used to being stuck out in the boondocks -- found themselves instead in an urban setting where they could go shopping, to theaters and restaurants.
Despite the impediments to reopening the waterfront, ideas often build on one another. When plans were announced to build a Science Center on the east bank of the river, the group suggested it also build a floating dock for water taxies. That got the group thinking: Why not a permanent research vessel that could take the next generation of scientists out onto the water for exploration?
"It is a very ambitious project," Mr. Marfuggi said. "But we're doing it incrementally. Each year there's a little more of the river for people to see and use, and we're developing a variety of programs, from passive to very active recreation."
Mr. Marfuggi contends the improvements will spark a cycle: people will visit or move to the city for concerts and water sports and recreation, which will bring in businesses that want to serve those people, which will bring even more people.
A triathalon last summer, in which contestants swam almost a mile of the river, brought in 1,100 competitors from 31 states and six countries. None of them came alone, Mr. Marfuggi said -- they all brought spouses and children and friends.
"The hotels were jammed, the restaurants were jammed," he said. "These are the kind of events that can really revitalize the economy. And they bring in national television coverage, and that kind of exposure brings the city even more business."
Thomas W. Miner, executive director of the Connecticut River Watershed Council, said it's impressive that Riverfront Recapture has tried to build as wide a constituency as possible for getting and keeping the river clean.
"There's been a very purposeful effort to bring the whole community to the river," Mr. Miner said. "The boating and music and other programs show a real appreciation of Hartford's need, as well as the economic development opportunity the river presents."
He says his concern is that the committee exploring how to keep the effort going counts no representatives of environmental groups among its members.
But given the record of Riverfront Recapture, he said, his organization is not worried that environmentalists will be ignored. "We continue to use Riverfront Recapture as an example to other communities up the river, particularly Springfield, of what can be done when a community really sets its mind to it."
