HEADLINE: Facing Cutbacks, Professors Seek Raise

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
WHILE the future of state-supported higher education waits under the ax in New York, Purchase College faculty members here are grappling with a more immediate issue.
The 114 full-time teachers and 184 part-time teachers, who are among the lowest paid in the state university's 12 four-year colleges, say it is next to impossible to raise a family and live on their salaries in or near Westchester County. Despite what they acknowledge to be bad timing because of budget cutbacks, the teachers are asking for raises across the board to redress what they call a 25-year-old problem. 
 "There has been historical inertia at Purchase," said Leonard Stokes, a professor in the visual arts division and the presiding officer of the faculty. "Salaries started low and never changed. Many of us feel trapped in this situation, myself included."
Many regard the Purchase faculty as one of the college's best kept secrets, calling teachers in both the College of Letters and Science and the School of the Arts a highly accomplished and dedicated group. The teachers, too, say they thrive on the school's diverse and enthusiastic student body and the freedom to follow their own principles in teaching.
But according to a recent report, prepared by Mr. Stokes, called "The Brick Ceiling," the average faculty salaries at Purchase in the 1994-95 year were tied for seventh place among the 12 four-year colleges, while salaries for full professors were tied for ninth place. The rankings showed some improvement over a similar study done in 1990 when Purchase salaries were at the bottom of the list.
Purchase salaries, which range from an average of $36,400 for assistant professors to an average of $55,900 for full professors, are especially low in light of the high cost of living in and around Westchester, Mr. Stokes said. The report shows that the faculty's average salary of $45,100 in 1994 lagged behind the average Westchester County family income of $58,900 in 1989. By contrast, the average faculty salary at SUNY Plattsburgh was $14,000 higher than family incomes in that college's surrounding county, Clinton.
The discrepancies are even worse, said Dr. Peter F. Bell, an associate professor of economics, when real wages are adjusted for inflation. "All the employees who were at SUNY Purchase during the 1970's, because of low or stagnant wage increases and very high rates of inflation, suffered conservatively a 50 percent drop of real income or purchasing power," said Dr. Bell, who joined the faculty in 1972.
Mr. Stokes, who has been at Purchase since 1973 and has been a full professor since 1993, recently received a raise and now makes $50,000 a year. Like many of his colleagues, Mr. Stokes, who lives with his wife and two high-school-age sons in Pleasantville, rarely travels on vacations with his family. The family hardly ever eats out together, he said, and restaurant meals just for him and his wife are rare events. Mr. Stokes said his wife, a former teacher, decided to stay home and raise their children.
"I can speak for the entire faculty," he said. "I am trying to refocus interest in this issue."
Librarians at Purchase are also underpaid compared with their colleagues elsewhere. According to a survey conducted by the librarians themselves, they are paid the least of librarians at five comparable two-year and four-year schools in and around Westchester. While the average salary for Purchase librarians -- excluding the library director -- last year was $34,700, their peers at Westchester Community College, for example, were paid an average of $58,100.
Westchester Community College, one of 30 community colleges in the university system, also pays its faculty members an average of $14,000 more than Purchase teachers receive. The faculty at Westchester Community College has its own union, which negotiates with the county.
Fenghua Wang-Schaefer, one of the newest librarians at Purchase, said she loves Westchester and the college but has had to move three times in the last seven months to find living quarters she can afford. Ms. Wang-Schaefer, whose husband is in China, now makes a half-hour drive to Purchase from Purdys. "Compared to my colleagues, that's close," she said.
Both the Purchase faculty and the librarians hold an impressive number of credentials. Nearly all the professors in the College of Letters and Science have doctoral degrees and among them have published 51 books in the last 10 years, said Dr. Alfred Hunt, dean of Letters and Science. Four of the five librarians hold two master's degrees, while many teachers in the School of the Arts are prominent in their fields. The 19 full-time and part-time faculty members in the division of visual arts, for example, have among them garnered 8 Guggenheim Fellowships, 10 National Endowment for the Arts Fellowships, 3 Fulbright Fellowships and a long list of other awards.
Carry Kyzivat, the local president of United University Professions, the statewide union representing all faculty members and professional employees in the system, said that the union sets minimum salary requirements. Beyond that, she said, it was up to the discretion of the campus administration to set salary levels. Ms. Kyzivat, who works as library acquisitions coordinator at Purchase, said it was an awkward time to lobby for higher salaries because of the "strong possibility that positions will be cut and faculties and employees will be retrenched."
Currently, the union is negotiating with the state university system's central administration to obtain a new contract for all faculty members and other professionals. They have been without a contract since last June.
Bill Lacy, president of Purchase College, said it was important to rectify the salary issue. "It may seem to people an inopportune moment, given the dark cloud hanging over SUNY right now and budget cuts always on the horizon," he said. "But this problem has plagued this particular college since its beginning, and I intend to address that."
He said he would work with Richard Staneski, the college's vice president for finance, and Dr. Gary Waller, the new vice president for academic affairs, not only to allot more money for salaries but also to balance discrepancies on the campus. Compounding campus resentment is the fact that teachers in the College of Letters and Science are paid on average $1,180 more than their peers in the School of the Arts. Women are also paid less than men of comparable rank; in the most glaring discrepancy, female full professors of the arts are paid nearly $7,000 less than male full professors of letters and science.
Dr. Waller said Purchase had "never had a collegewide plan for adequate salaries," and that "previous administrations really didn't pay attention to this as a collegewide problem."
He added, "My initial reaction when I got here six months ago was how incredibly low the salaries were in comparison with comparable places."
Mr. Staneski said improvements could be made "without regard to the bleak budget environment" by strategies like salvaging money from faculty vacancies and starting a salary pool.
Dr. Bell described morale among the faculty as "awful, terrible" and said many teachers had taken second jobs to make ends meet. He said the faculty's workload had increased as its purchasing power had dropped; in addition to their course work, Purchase teachers set educational policy by serving on college committees, conduct searches for new faculty members and administer their own programs with a dwindling support staff.
Despite feeling underappreciated, faculty members said their strong hand in college matters helped to offset their complaints. "The faculty do have control over the curriculum and can generate programs they have respect for," Dr. Bell said.

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
In City Services, Privatize and Beware

BYLINE: By MOSHE ADLER; Moshe Adler is a professor of economics at the Rutgers University Graduate School of Management.

 BODY:
IT is no surprise that a $43 million contract let by the City of New York to a private organization to enforce the city's welfare rules -- signed last summer and canceled last month -- ran into trouble amid suspicions of cozy dealing. This has been the pattern of privatization efforts stretching back through the 19th century. Privatization has, in fact, been the norm, not the exception, through much of that time in this country -- and equally common has been the need for the government to take over these services after failure by private providers.
The current advocates of privatization contend that these early failures actually teach us a way to make "outsourcing" work. What is new in the current efforts, according to Professor E. S. Savas of Baruch College, a consultant to governments here and internationally, "is introducing competition into the delivery of public services." The fastest privatizer in the country, Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, has argued that the past failure of privatization was due to monopolization. 
 There is only one problem with these ideas: measures to make outsourcing competitive already litter the history of private-sector provision of public services and all have failed. If there is a lesson, it is that the incentives for a public servant who hires a contractor are inherently different from the incentives for a private entrepreneur who hires a contractor. The entrepreneur is interested in performance and nothing else. The public servant may trade performance for a personal gain. In the end, governments have proved to be the most efficient when their services are produced by public employees rather than private contractors.
One of the most compelling examples of the failure of such privatization is street cleaning in 19th century New York. With the cost of equipment low, the number of potential competitors large and the contractors' work visible to all, what could be simpler than choosing a contractor through competitive bidding and dismissing him if he failed to perform? But when Mayor Philip Hone wanted to replace a street-cleaning contractor and stop payments in 1826, the City Council, after "mature reflection," resolved that, notwithstanding the company's failure to do its job, "it was best to compromise the matter."
The same occurred in 1842 when, in response to Mayor Robert Morris's attempt to penalize another street-cleaning contractor, the City Council removed the penalties from the law. And in the 1860's, a contractor was allowed to continue his contract for an additional two and a half years even though he had failed to clean the streets on half of the days for which he had contracted, used city piers to store garbage and dumped huge quantities of manure in city parks.
The problem, of course, was that councilmen relied on contractors for political contributions and, occasionally, for bribes. It is hardly surprising that they were reluctant to conclude that privatization could not work. Instead, they offered panaceas -- always some competitive measure or another -- to mollify their critics.
IN the 19th century, such measures included requirements that contractors post bonds and that their contracts have a maximum of three years. In 1825, the city was divided into several cleaning districts to encourage competition, and the lines were redrawn in 1842. (Panaceas are often rediscovered.)
Yet the streets continued to be filthy. In 1860, the City Inspector concluded that the contract system "has in every instance proved a failure." But private contractors would continue to perform public services for 20 or more years.
Privatization did not fail only in New York. The head of the Chicago Board of Health declared in 1892 that "there are few if any redeeming qualities" attached to the "vicious" contract system.
In the same year, Mayor Hazen Pingree of Detroit researched the process and concluded that "most of our troubles can be traced to the temptations which are offered to city officials when franchises are sought by wealthy corporations, or contracts are to be let for public works."
At the end of the 19th century, the situation in New York City had so deteriorated that business leaders entered politics to "clean house." Over a three-month period in 1874, Mayor William F. Havemeyer, of the sugar-refining business, vetoed 250 bills, including bills for street improvements, Board of Education contracts and appropriations intended for public charities. But the consensus of the Mayor's contemporaries was that his vetoes crippled the city. The reform movement turned to public ownership of public services.
Across the country, franchisees and contractors fought reform efforts tooth and nail. They fought in the courts. They appealed to the public's sense of patriotism. St. Louis newspapers even argued in 1900 that the public exposure of corruption in private contracts would create a bad name for the city and would be bad for business. Another tactic was diversion: Mayors who were in favor of public ownership were portrayed as soft on crime.
But journalistic and academic studies showed that prices in cities that owned their utilities were universally lower and that the quality of these services was universally higher than in cities served by franchises. Although public ownership involved patronage, this was not sufficient to offset its benefits. City after city adopted public systems to provide public services.
In New York City, citizens' groups lobbied successfully for a separate street-cleaning department with its own staff, headed by a commissioner appointed by the Mayor. The operation, established in 1881, continues to this day.
In 1996, few people would argue that public services cannot be improved. But we may find again that today's solutions may create tomorrow's crises. As more governments weigh privatizing their jails, as New York City looks to contract out parking-meter management (again!), as municipalities everywhere grasp for ways to privatize to cut their budgets -- the experience of the past is worth considering.

HEADLINE: Preserving the Legacy Of Modernist Design

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
HOLLY GOLIGHTLY looked wistfully on the face of Manhattan as she prepared to depart for Rio. "Years from now, years and years, I'll be back," she declared. "Me and my nine Brazilian brats. I'll bring them back, all right. Because they must see this."
"This" in the 1961 movie "Breakfast at Tiffany's" was not Central Park or the Brooklyn Bridge or Rockfeller Center. It was the steel-and-glass corporate canyon of postwar Park Avenue. 
 Those International Style skyscrapers -- Lever House, the Seagram Building, the Union Carbide Building -- epitomized New York at the peak of its economic might and worldwide prowess. In their cool sophistication, they were an ideal complement to Audrey Hepburn, who played Holly, and a fitting backdrop for her valedictory stroll.
Not everyone felt kindly toward this crop of architecture, to be sure. The building boom of the 50's and 60's had replaced so much of the city's historic fabric that it spurred a popular preservation movement, culminating in the landmarks law of 1965. But even those who said "glass box" with a sneer would have thought the Park Avenue towers would always be part of the skyline.
How surprising, then, that their day of reckoning may already be at hand, along with branch banks and airline terminals and cultural institutions of the same vintage. And how paradoxical that many are now old enough -- 30 years or more -- to qualify for landmark status.
That raises critical issues with which owners, architects and urban historians are only beginning to wrestle. Which postwar buildings merit preservation? Can they be economically and usefully maintained in anything resembling their original forms? Or are they destined for rehabilitations that leave them substantially altered or totally unrecognizable?
The list of buildings in question starts with an official landmark: Lever House, 390 Park Avenue, between 53d and 54th Streets. This tower, designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, may need an entirely new exterior after 44 years.
At 43d Street, significant interior alterations are being made to the former Fifth Avenue branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, also designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Dubbed the "Glass House" when it opened in 1954, it is under consideration for landmark status.
And a tremendous amount of reconstruction is required at Eero Saarinen's 34-year-old Trans World Airline Terminal A at John F. Kennedy International Airport, another landmark, which cannot efficiently serve jumbo jetliners.
At worst, such buildings are hopelessly out of date. At best, they are challenging and expensive to maintain. (The owners of the Seagram Building pay roughly double the operating costs to conserve its deceptively simple luster.) Constructed with systems that are growing obsolete, to serve a corporate culture that no longer exists, they tend to be extravagant in their consumption of energy and their use of space, something few owners can tolerate.
W HILE some were recognized as classics on the day they opened, most have long since slipped out of fashion. Because they are so spare and clean in design, their esthetic qualities can be radically transformed by the simplest change in materials -- tinted glass, for instance, instead of clear.
Few are candidates for demolition, possibly excepting smaller structures like Two Columbus Circle, the former Gallery of Modern Art, which was commissioned by Huntington Hartford and designed by Edward Durell Stone.
Instead, owners are more likely to recreate the buildings. For instance, the former ITT Corporation World Headquarters at 320 Park Avenue, between 50th and 51st Streets, has been transformed over the last two years from a plain-vanilla corporate glass box designed by Emery Roth & Sons into a pyramid-peaked post-modern ziggurat by Swanke Hayden Connell Architects. It is now the headquarters of the Mutual of America Life Insurance Company.
No one much mourned the disappearance of the Emery Roth design as a single work. But Robert A. M. Stern, the architect and architectural historian, is quite troubled by the compromise to Park Avenue as an urban ensemble.
"Individually, they're not great buildings," he said, "but collectively, they're incomparable. We all lambasted the loss of the Beaux-Arts Park Avenue. But there is no collection of metal-and-glass corporate modernism like it anywhere else in the world. And now we're going to tear it all apart again."
Eight years ago, at a preservation symposium in the New York Public Library, Mr. Stern argued that landmark status ought to be given to buildings like "Black Rock," the CBS Building at 51 West 52d Street; the stainless-steel-clad former Socony-Mobil Building, 150 East 42d Street and the Ford Foundation, 321 East 42d Street.
Almost as devil's advocate, he went so far as to say that the Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue, might merit landmark consideration as "a telling lesson of how not to build a city."
"The monuments of postwar modernism have now been subjected to the passage of time and have achieved a place within the very continuum of history they so determinedly sought to destroy," Mr. Stern said in 1988.
Since then, he has become a de facto leader in the modernist preservation movement. He has written its manifesto and 1,374-page guide book, "New York 1960: Architecture and Urbanism Between the Second World War and the Bicentennial" (Monacelli Press, 1995), with Thomas Mellins and David Fishman.
A ND his sense of urgency is growing, Mr. Stern said in an interview last month. "These buildings were conceived to last the life of a mortgage or a refinancing," he said. "They were designed to fall apart. And they are falling apart -- just as they are becoming eligible for landmark designation."
They need not be torn down to be lost. "The detailing is very precise," Mr. Stern said, "and they were built with single-pane glazing in a period when energy costs were not a major consideration. When you thicken mullions -- or, worse yet, tint the windows -- you change the impression of the building."
Mr. Stern conceded the incongruity of his championing postwar design, since his own work draws so heavily on more classical styles. "We've got to struggle to get above taste," he said. "It's just about when a building is 30 years old that a new generation comes along to discover it. Landmarking is not to select what's pretty, it's to select what's significant."
Jennifer Raab, the chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said she discerned "a growing interest in postwar, modern architecture." She noted that the commission last year designated the former Pepsi-Cola Building, 500 Park Avenue, at 59th Street. It was designed by Gordon Bunshaft and Natalie de Blois of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and completed in 1960.
T HE Municipal Art Society has formed a "postwar-architecture working group," said Ned Kaufman, the associate director of issues, and will hold meetings this spring with a new group known by the unwieldy acronym of Docomomo -- Documentation and Conservation of the Monuments of the Modern Movement.
Mr. Kaufman allowed that this was something of a sea change for the society's members, who long battled the very forces behind the buildings they are interested in saving.
"Preservation being what it is," he said, "we now have to look at some of the work of that period as a legacy."
That is only where the challenges begin.
"We're going to have to deal with functional obsolescence," said Theodore H. M. Prudon, an associate professor of historic preservation at Columbia University, partner in Swanke Hayden Connell and member of Docomomo.
That means finding new tenants for corporate headquarters that have been emptied, new uses for branch banks that have been superseded by automated teller machines and new layouts for airline terminals that have been pushed well beyond their capacity.
It also means re-examining attitudes about conserving structural details. "In traditional preservation there is an inherent significance in the original materials, both as artifacts and often as pieces of craftsmanship," Mr. Prudon said. "I have a hard time bringing up the same respect for a precast concrete panel."
Ultimately, glass is the premier material of this era. And that raises another complication: What goes on within a building can have an enormous effect on the look of its facade.
"The problem with the preservation of modern architecture is that there's no difference between the inside and the outside," Mr. Prudon said.
David M. Childs, a partner in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, noted that structural problems could arise in early curtain walls, built of many separate elements rather than in modular units.
"Stainless steel is great but the glue that held things together is wearing out," he said. "There are tremendous heat and freezing cycles on the sides of the buildings. The trouble is, once water gets in, it expands and corrodes."
Although he was not referring specifically to Lever House, that landmark is known to have problems. Designed by Bunshaft and completed in 1952, the 21-story building is essentially two perpendicular slabs, clad in stainless steel and blue-green glass panels, with horizontal window ribbons.
Last year, Unilever, the household-products company that still occupies the building, proposed a new curtain wall, saying the original had been "untested and experimental." The company said 40 to 50 percent of the glass had already been replaced and that there was extensive corrosion in the underlying structural steel due to leaks from bad joints and deteriorating drains.
The plan called for building the new wall around the existing skin and then demolishing the old curtain wall from within. That proposal raised more than a few eyebrows and Unilever withdrew its application to the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
Today, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill is working on the project, although Mr. Childs said the firm had not yet made any recommendations. And a lawyer for Unilever, Gordon J. Davis, said the company would have no comment -- not about future plans, the withdrawn application or even existing conditions.
B UT two notable neighbors of Lever House give a glimpse at how complicated it can be to maintain a building whose allure rests on its simplicity.
"Vigilance, diligence and consistency are the keys," said Philip R. DiGennaro, managing director of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, owners of the Seagram Building, 375 Park Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, which was completed in 1958 to designs by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson.
To insure a uniform exterior appearance, tenants are given no choice in ceiling treatments at the building's perimeter. The first 15 feet from the window must consist of a row of solid panels, beyond which comes a row of luminous panels, all on a uniform grid. (The Alleghany Corporation, which moved in earlier this year, had to give up the idea of hanging brass chandeliers.) The only window coverings allowed are Venetian blinds, whose blades are fixed at a 45-degree angle. The mechanisms permit three positions: completely closed, half-drawn or fully open.
The bronze-sheathed exterior is oiled by hand once a year, with a lemon-based oil, by workers on window-washing scaffolds. The process takes two and a half months, said Mike Angeliadis, the property manager.
The terrazzo floors in the elevator lobbies are polished every month by cloth and every few years by stone. The travertine walls in public areas are cleaned five times a year and get a poultice treatment annually. Marble benches on the plaza are washed weekly and honed, polished and covered in sealant as needed. Faucets, spigots and door handles are custom made.
All told, such extraordinary measures roughly double the operating cost, to about $15 a square foot, Mr. DiGennaro said. But the rents are also higher than in other Park Avenue buildings, around $50 a square foot, said Douglas P. Lawrence, senior real estate manager for the association, and the building is 84 percent occupied.
Five blocks south, at 270 Park Avenue, is the world headquarters of the Chase Manhattan Corporation. This 52-story tower, with its black and silver curtain wall, was completed in 1960 as headquarters of the Union Carbide Corporation, to designs by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.
The building underwent a $75 million renovation in 1983 to become headquarters of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. After a 1991 merger, it served as headquarters of Chemical Bank, which it remained until Monday, when the Chase-Chemical merger took effect.
When it was built, the corporate world operated on a 9-to-5 schedule. Buildingwide systems would be turned on and shut off accordingly. "Today, we're into 24-hour buildings," said William F. Treanor, a bank vice president. "You have to go out for new ways of bringing in heating and cooling so the staff can function at 10 o'clock at night."
Union Carbide set aside only 5,000 of the building's 1.5 million square feet for a data-processing center. At the time of remodeling, the assumption was that one employee in four would have an automated work station. Today, there is a computer at almost every desk. "The electrical consumption is a continuing challenge," Mr. Treanor said.
All told, however, Mr. Treanor said much of the original infrastructure "has carried that building through today," a tribute in part to the fact that an owner-occupant lavished more money on its headquarters than a developer would have sunk into a speculative tower.
"Many aspects of the International Style are still looked for by tenants: large amounts of glass, flexible systems," Mr. Childs said. "They might want more span to the core and more room for mechanical systems, but the buildings are reasonably up to date."
THE former Union Carbide tower is one of three modernist milestones in the real estate portfolio of the new Chase bank. The others are One Chase Manhattan Plaza in lower Manhattan and the "Glass House," which is best known for the audacious touch of displaying a Mosler safe door, designed by Henry Dreyfuss, in plain view behind plate glass on Fifth Avenue. Above the safe, the second floor seemed to float in space, since it was set back from the exterior curtain wall.
A major alteration of the interior is nearing completion. Along 43d Street, more than 3,500 square feet of retail space has been created. "We're looking to maximize our revenue stream," said Barbara A. Voda, a bank vice president. On Fifth Avenue, an A.T.M. center has been built, with a partition separating it from the safe. A ceiling has been extended from the slab of the second floor to the exterior wall, closing up the space beneath. And the openness of the main floor has been diminished somewhat by new office partitions.
Since the building is under consideration for landmark status, Ms. Voda said the bank consulted closely with the staff of the landmarks commission. And Ms. Raab concurred, saying the bank had been "extremely cooperative in working with us to maintain the architectural integrity of the building."
Alterations are on the horizon at the arching, gull-winged T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy International Airport. "The first phase is mostly cosmetic and comfort level," said Marvin B. Mitzner of Davidoff & Malito, a lawyer for the airline. But major reconstruction will follow.
Because jumbo jets are too big to fit at adjoining gates, planes have to park on the field, forcing passengers to use buses, Mr. Mitzner said. "There's no question that it's an obsolete terminal," he said. "The objective is to find a happy medium between destroying architectural features and allowing the terminal to become useless."
I T is unclear what use can be made of Two Columbus Circle, a white marble box with perforated edges, a loggia at top and an arcade at the bottom. Last October, Forrest R. Taylor, the chief of staff for Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, said the city was preparing a request for proposals to develop the site, which it owns.
Preservationists like Mr. Stern worry that the 10-story building will be torn down. But Mr. Taylor will not discuss the redevelopment project now. He will not even say whether the request for proposals had been completed.
There is one minor modernist monument that is virtually assured of demolition. Unknown to and unseen by most New Yorkers -- even though thousands pass underneath it every day -- is a two-story penthouse suite that I. M. Pei and William Lescaze designed for the real estate giant William Zeckendorf in 1952.
Largely concealed by parapets, the penthouse crowns the long-vacant Knapp Building, 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets. This block-square property, a prime candidate for redevelopment, has been at the center of a fierce struggle for control among Bear, Stearns & Company, the al-Babtain family of Saudi Arabia and the British developer Howard Ronson.
The authors of "New York 1960" described the Zeckendorf penthouse as "the era's most extraordinary offices." The chief feature is a circular dining room with floor-to-ceiling windows and a cylindrical elevator shaft. Here, with a wide-screen perspective on mid-Manhattan, the legendary developer held court, offering guests three-course lunches and fine wines.
Zeckendorf's own office was on the floor below this turret, in a teak-lined drum 25 feet in diameter. One of his grandsons, William Lie Zeckendorf, recalls that the inner sanctum seemed to him as a child as if it must have been 60 feet wide.
"It's amazing how many people I run into almost daily who have never forgotten that office," the younger Mr. Zeckendorf said last week. "But I'm told by people who've been up there that it's been so altered over the years that it bears no resemblance to what it used to be."
From the outside, it does indeed look forlorn, a reminder that it takes little in the way of neglect to transform modernist cynosures into nondescript shells. Mr. Kaufman put it succinctly: "They don't make good ruins."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Wild Ride Fails to Sway Many Market Forecasters

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
IF early March seems like a long time ago to investors, no wonder: Ever since the Dow Jones industrial average took a 171-point plunge a month ago tomorrow, it has pumped itself up faster than did certain Presidential candidates in the early primaries. Not only did the Dow recoup much of its dip in a single day -- March 11 -- but as of the market's close on Thursday it had completely erased the drop and then some.
Sure, there have been tense moments in between, with 50-point swings in a day now more of a rule than the exception. Still, while some bears saw the March 8 fall as the start of a correction, perhaps of 10 percent or more, the market has risen about 4 percent in the last month. On top of the market rise before the dip, that puts the Dow up more than 11 percent for 1996. 
 What do the experts say now? With a month's hindsight, has the one-day drop and the subsequent rise swayed them or changed their views?
For the editors at Standard & Poor's Outlook newsletter, the March drop looms less large than it did at first. In a newsletter that was published the week after the event, they emphasized that they expected the bull market to continue -- but at the same time warned readers that a decline of 10 percent should not come as a surprise.
Lately, though, the newsletter has retained its bullishness but dropped its cautionary stance. "At this point in the market, you're better in than out," said Joseph Tigue, the managing editor.
Similarly, at PDI Strategies in Short Hills, N.J., Mark Stumpp, the chief investment officer, was unfazed by the market drop and remains bullish.
"Just because we had a major rally in 1995 doesn't mean we're automatically going to have a correction this year," he said. Two factors, he added, greatly lessen the likelihood of a serious correction. First, he said, unlike the situation before the market crash in 1987, when interest rates and the stock market rose to giddy heights together, the fundamentals of the economy today, while weak, are still sound. And, Mr. Stumpp said, investors are taking a longer-term perspective toward the market.
Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Van Kampen/American Capital, said he believed -- both before and after the March drop -- that good earnings were behind today's market. And he said he was as bullish on that score as he was before.
"There might be selective earnings disappointments in sectors such as computers and software," he said, "but overall earnings will probably come out a little bit better than expected."
He said he was holding to his prediction -- made just after the March dip -- that the market had seen as much of a correction as it would for the rest of 1996.
Gail M. Dudack, United States chief investment strategist at UBS Securities in New York, said she was also sticking to her guns. But she is bearish. Right after the March 8 fall, she said, she believed the Dow could drop to 5,000 or even lower; today, she said, "I haven't changed my view." What makes her pessimistic is what makes Mr. Froelich optimistic -- earnings.
"Earnings are not growing as fast as some people think," she said. The earnings in the fourth quarter of 1995 "were way below what people expected them to be," she added, and so she sees the estimates for this year and next as likely to be too high.
"In this kind of environment, with expectations so high, a 10 percent correction is a normal situation," she said. "The market is likely to hit 5,000 before it hits 6,000."
Morgan Stanley's chief domestic investment strategist, Byron R. Wien, is staying the course with his pre-drop prediction that the market will decline in 1996. Last Monday, he advised investors that the "U.S. equity market could become a more nervous place" later this year "when and if interest rates move above 7 percent, and the zeal of the baby boomers for sure-thing mutual funds subsides."
But before then, Mr. Wien, who anticipated the recent rise in economic activity, is willing to allow the Dow one more jump. "I still think it could rally close to 6,000," he said.
While the March drop and the subsequent rise have not greatly altered the views of the experts, it has had some impact. Sparked by a jobs report that some faulted as skewed, the dip added fuel to skepticism about both the soundness of economic numbers and the market's reaction to them.
Many analysts cite a "crisis of the month" mentality in the market, whether it involves the recent Government shutdowns or the General Motors strike.
But other analysts perceive jumbled numbers as well as market jitters. "I don't think the credibility of these numbers is what you would have seen a year ago," Mr. Froehlich said of recent statistics. "We haven't had a good, clear month for collecting information for an entire year."
Mr. Stumpp said money managers were "truly puzzled" by the seemingly incongruous economic data. Last week alone, the numbers pointed to weak manufacturing and construction spending even as the index of leading economic indicators shot up 1.3 percent -- the biggest jump in 20 years.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2512 words

HEADLINE: Radio New Jersey: Is Everyone Listening?

BYLINE: By DAVID CORCORAN 

 BODY:
TURNPIKE traffic, 10:30 in the morning. There's a car fire at Exit 18, and rubberneckers are backing up in the southbound lanes. The radio pops and snorts, and then, as the signal comes into focus, it begins to snarl.
"Ray in Chester, you're on New Jersey 101.5." Topic A this morning on 101.5 FM in Trenton, the state's top-rated talk station, is the recent killing of a Monmouth County schoolteacher; the suspect is a 17-year-old who was caught driving her car the next day. 
 "I think this little dirtbag just hit the jackpot," Ray tells Dennis Malloy, the station's host from 10 to noon. "Whereas before he probably had no chance to amount to anything in life, afraid of his own shadow, he's now got the opportunity to get a college education, watch cable TV all night in an air-conditioned cell, have conjugal visits, get married to some loser woman with an infatuation for prisoners . . . He'll never see the death penalty, and if I had the chance I'd do it myself!"
"All right, Ray, thank you. I think you're 100 percent right."
Not all radio in New Jersey is anywhere near this angry and raw. But much of it is just as vital. From one end of the dial (WBGO at 88.3 FM, the region's premier jazz station) to the other (WJDM at 1660, a pioneer of the newly expanded AM band), broadcasters blanket the state with a hugely varied quilt of sound, some of it professional and polished, some of it automated and bland, some of it quirky and specialized, some of it folksy or silly or just plain weird.
Radio in New Jersey is a $150 million business, with more than 80 stations from Cape May to Newton. They exist in the shadows of the nation's largest and fourth-largest radio markets, New York and Philadelphia, and for the most part they get along by carving out a niche -- not just a particular format, like talk or gospel or rock, but a particular audience, like Haitians or fundamentalist Christians or Bergen County adults over 45.
"The F.C.C. in its great wisdom allowed all these little stations to drop in wherever they'd fit on the dial, without any regard for economics," said Art Camiolo, president of Allur Communications, which owns three stations in Atlantic and Cape May Counties. "You have to have a niche if you're going to be successful, and smaller stations just can't survive all by themselves."
That struggle for survival has forced many stations to consolidate with bigger companies or frantically switch formats. One of the largest, WPAT-FM (93.1) in Paterson, was recently sold to the Spanish Broadcasting System, which already owns one of New York's top-rated Hispanic stations, for $83.5 million, and its studios were moved to New York. (The state's largest station by far, WHTZ-FM or "Z-100" in Secaucus, is for all practical purposes a New York rock station.)
And more consolidation is on the way, since the recent overhaul of Federal communications law has all but eliminated restrictions on the number of stations a company can own.
But in struggling, some broadcasters have managed to push the limits of the medium, pioneering new formats or finding creative ways to stay on the air.
There is Gerry Turro, founder and president of WJUX (103.1 FM) in Dumont, who dreamed as a teen-ager of starting an FM station in Bergen County and managed to cobble one together out of records and equipment salvaged from a Manhattan station's garbage bins -- and a network of transmitters so convoluted and Rube Goldbergian that the F.C.C. may disallow it.
There are WNWK (105.9 FM) and WNJR (1430 AM), both in Newark, "multicultural" stations that make their money by leasing air time to producers from a mosaic of immigrant groups. "Portuguese, Russian, Arabic, Jewish, Polish, Chinese both Mandarin and Cantonese, Haitian, Vietnamese," said Maury Warshauer, general manager of WNJR. "If you have any ethnic hang-ups, this is not the place to work."
There are mom-and-pop broadcasters, like WKMB (1070 AM) in Stirling, Morris County, which became the metropolitan area's only country music station this winter when WYNY in New York abruptly changed formats. (The little station's switchboard lit up with delighted phone calls.)
And there are noncommercial stations, probably the most inventive of all, often hanging on by their fingernails at a time of dwindling government support and competing demands on individual and corporate supporters.
Consider WBGO, the jazz station in Newark, whose on-air appeals for money are so frequent and desperate that a musician once suggested its call letters should be WBEG. Or WFDU at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck (89.1 FM), whose traditional American format -- blues, bluegrass and folk -- has inspired a fanatical following but which has to leave the air at 3:45 P.M. every weekday because it shares a transmitter with another college station.
When you ask radio people what draws them to the medium, they invariably talk about the magical way it acts on a listener's imagination.
Carl Kraus, general manager of WFDU, grew up in Haddonfield, listening to distant AM stations like WBZ in Boston, falling asleep to "the incandescence of the filaments in the radio." Years later, he still speaks of radio's "inexplicable mystery, its theater of the mind." (He can be forgiven a rhetorical flight or two: his station is the only one that still broadcasts from the fabled 425-foot tower in Alpine from which the inventor Edwin Howard Armstrong launched FM as a broadcast medium in the 30's.) What follow are the stories of several stations that are keeping that mystery aglow.
 
TALK
The 800-Pound Gorilla
It seems to be a point of pride at WKXW-FM, universally known as New Jersey 101.5, that it was not Gov. Jim Florio's tax increase that made the station what it is today. Still, it may well be 101.5 that made Mr. Florio what he is today: a former Governor.
Press Broadcasting Company, which also owns The Asbury Park Press, bought WKXW in July 1989, a few months before Mr. Florio's election. With the help of Walter Sabo, a New York radio guru who served as the company's consultant, the station's successful but bland "adult contemporary" format was retooled to emphasize New Jersey: New Jersey talk, New Jersey traffic, New Jersey weather.
"Walter's genius was in putting together a New Jersey format and calling it New Jersey," John Dziuba, the station's general manager, recalled recently. "When people asked, 'What is your format?' the answer was simply 'New Jersey.' "
A full-time meteorologist was hired, to give the weather in Teterboro and Plainsboro and Scotch Plains. The station began giving traffic reports every 10 minutes, pointedly ignoring tie-ups on the West Side Highway and the Schuylkill Expressway. On-air hosts were told to talk about New Jersey and encourage listeners to do the same. Ratings began to climb before Mr. Florio took office.
But it was the new Governor's $2.8 billion tax increase, in spring 1990, that made the station explode into the public consciousness. "Until then we were talking about not very serious things," said Jim Gearhart, the morning host, a burly, bearded veteran of New York talk radio whose pear-shaped tones make him sound like Reverend Jim, radio preacher. "Best pizza, worst potholes and the like. But then people started calling in about the tax increase, and it started building. It was wild."
The flames of the tax rebellion were fanned by the New Jersey 101.5 hosts, who were anything but reasoned and neutral. The afternoon drive-time hosts encouraged tax protesters to start a movement, Hands Across New Jersey, which in turn staged one of the largest, fiercest rallies the State House has ever seen. Not everyone remembers the station's role fondly.
"Reasonable people couldn't call in and talk reasonably," said Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's press secretary at the time, who was repeatedly branded a liar on the station. "They didn't really respect their audience; they just wanted to arouse and inflame it."
Political life in the state is calmer these days, and without an unpopular governor to beat up, New Jersey 101.5 often has to fall back on what Andrew Santoro, general manager of the more earnest WCTC in New Brunswick, tartly calls "fluff talk -- why do guys pick their noses when they drive on the highway, that kind of thing." One recent week, a midday host tried to auction off his pants to the highest bidder, and the afternoon hosts staged a "duh" hour, asking callers, "What's the dumbest thing you've ever done?"
Still, when a particularly brutal killing shakes the state, New Jersey 101.5 is there, a sounding board for New Jersey outrage. "Sometimes when I hear things on the air, I kind of cringe and wish I could take them back," said Mr. Dziuba, the station manager. "But these are things that have to be said. We can't just focus on what's right with New Jersey. Talking about what's right doesn't give anyone a reason to listen. This is a way to vent."
And while WKXW's ratings have slipped somewhat, at least in its core area around Trenton, it is still widely admired in the industry for its boldness and success. "They managed to carve out a New Jersey market and set themselves apart from the heavy hitters in New York and Philadelphia," said James Duncan Jr., a radio analyst in Indiana. "It's an exceptional property."
 
NOSTALGIA
Big-Band Wars
In the Wizard of Oz world of radio, where all images exist in your head and things are seldom what they seem, WJUX in Dumont ("Jukebox Radio") is some kind of champion.
For one thing, its transmitter, the site that actually broadcasts its signal, is 60 miles away, in Monticello, N.Y. In crowded Bergen County, only one transmitter, WFDU's in Alpine, is licensed to originate FM signals; to get around that restriction, WJUX relies on a series of translators, tiny transmitters that are meant to beam signals from large stations to areas that would otherwise lack FM service.
It sends its signal through phone lines to Monticello, where the transmitter sends it through the air to a translator in Rockland County, which in turn sends it to a translator on a high-rise apartment building in Fort Lee. That translator is only 34 watts (most FM stations are 1,000 or more), but it manages to cover most of Bergen County and some of Manhattan and the Bronx.
The format is something of an accident, too. The founder and president, Gerry Turro, a veteran engineer who has spent more than half his 41 years at radio stations around the metropolitan area, heard that WNEW was moving its studios and discarding its records and equipment. "They said, You have three days to get whatever we left behind," Mr. Turro said. "I loaded a console, furniture, a record library, 300 boxes of stuff in my Subaru station wagon."
The records happened to be heavily big-band era, music of the 1930's, 40's and 50's. As it turned out, that fit neatly into the demographics of Bergen, which has a large population of affluent adults who grew up listening to those songs in their Chevies, Ramblers and DeSotos.
"We built this radio station out of the garbage!" Mr. Turro said. "And now we're No. 1 on the weekends in Bergen County! It's pretty gosh-darn amazing."
At WVNJ, Mr. Turro's closest rival, they are not amused. The station (1160 AM in Teaneck) recently changed its format to big band, hired several announcers from the heyday of big-band radio in New York, and announced plans to double its signal strength, to 20,000 watts. It has complained to the F.C.C. that WJUX's transmitter arrangement violates the rules on where a signal may originate.
"You're not supposed to send programming through a translator," said Ron Lustberg, WVNJ's general manager. "We're the ones who are licensed out of Bergen County." The F.C.C. is expected to rule on the complaint shortly.
Talk of the dispute momentarily darkens Mr. Turro's disposition. "WVNJ cloned us," he said. "No one listens to them anyway. Don't blame us for your failure. Look in the mirror."
 
WHATEVER
Never a Dull Moment
At any given time on WFMU, you might hear post-industrial rock from a band like Combustible Edison or Voodoo Queens or Beatnik Termites, bachelor-pad music from the early 1960's, five minutes of hog calls, a discourse on baseball's changing strike zone, Connie Francis singing "Stupid Cupid," a rabbi discussing whether milk made from rice can be kosher, or "Meet Me in St. Louie, Louie," played on a 1906 Victrola.
If it is hard to lump all this under a single format, or even a dozen, it is no easier to explain how WFMU has managed to survive for nearly half a century -- let alone flourish, having been named best radio station in the United States in four successive critics' polls by Rolling Stone magazine from 1991 to 1994.
Founded as the student station at Upsala College in East Orange, it was infiltrated and eventually taken over in the late 60's by what Ken Freedman, the 37-year-old station manager, calls a band of "artists, hippies, weirdos and musicians." They installed the free-form ethos that still governs the station, and it has prevailed through years of battles with the college, creditors, rival noncommercial stations and even the elements -- the transmitter was once torn in two by an ice storm.
"We just keep bouncing from one horrible crisis to another," Mr. Freedman said. "It's really quite ridiculous. We've survived two or three situations that would have killed another station."
The worst crisis came last year, when Upsala filed for bankruptcy and then swiftly closed its doors, auctioning off the entire 40-acre campus. WFMU had already become independent by buying its license from the college in 1994, but the bankruptcy created a host of new problems. "We couldn't even imagine it," Mr. Freedman said. "We couldn't get our mail delivered. Our donations were going to a college that didn't exist. The electricity was messed up because we were still tied into the college's infrastructure."
The station is still housed in the one building on campus that isn't boarded up -- a fading Greek Revival mansion that would look quite splendid if the setting weren't so eerie. But that too is in jeopardy, because the bankruptcy trustees want to sell it.
To raise money for operations and living quarters -- preferably elsewhere, Mr. Freedman says -- the station just completed a two-week fund-raising marathon that took in $367,000, enough to insure its survival for at least a while. (The annual budget is $600,000, and the station also raises money with a mail-order catalogue and a record fair.) "We're too used to this to truly panic," Mr. Freedman said.
By now, it seems clear that WFMU's devoted corps of volunteers and listeners will find a way to keep the station alive. It is hardly a typical New Jersey radio station, but its pluck and grittiness might be a typical New Jersey story, inspiring even to those who wouldn't know the Voodoo Queens from the Lennon Sisters. "New Jersey's an underdog state," said Chris Tsakis, the operations manager at WFMU. "We're an underdog radio station."

HEADLINE: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
Nobody's Happy When Autumn's Leaves Are Picked Up in the Spring . . .

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
The trees may not have even begun to bud yet, but foliage enthusiasts should have no trouble finding their fill of leaves this April: they're blanketing the front lawn and lying in heaps in the gutter.
They're last year's leaves, of course. Between a late leaf drop (because of a warm summer) and the snows that began to fall in late November, many homeowners never were able to finish raking their yards. As a result, towns across the state are spending the tail ends of their 1996 public works budgets on an unappointed and unwelcome round of leaf collection. Consider it one last cruel gift from a cruel winter. 
 "We've been in leaf season going on seven months now," said Brian Koenig, Public Works Director in Paramus, sighing as he watched one of his employees kick a soggy brown pile into the path of the slowly advancing maw of a vacuum truck Tuesday morning. "Every time it stopped snowing we'd be picking up leaves, and look at what we still have here."
Normally, Mr. Koenig and his men would be spending the month of April readying their snowplows for summer storage and unclogging storm drains. But since March 18 -- shortly after the last major snowfall -- all hands have been dispatched to the leaf trucks and the loaders, setting off chain reactions of inconvenience.
The leaves, sodden with spring rains, keep jamming up the vacuums. To make collection even more difficult, several major winter windstorms have littered lawns with sticks and branches, which Paramus residents have not hesitated to add to the piles despite pleas from the town to bundle them separately.
Mr. Koenig is trying to be understanding.
"People feel like they got cheated last fall on leaf pickup," he said, noting that many piles that were swept into the street were pushed back onto the curb by snowplows. "In the spring, people are supposed to put their leaves into bags and barrels for Wednesday pickup, but we got so many complaints that we decided to add more days. But we're going through town one more time and then everybody's just going to have to bag it."
In the end, Mr. Koenig said, the town may not get to patch as many roads as it would like to this summer, which could have unpleasant ramifications next winter.
"It's just a mess," he said. "That's all I can say."
Schedules have been thrown off everywhere.
In neighboring Glen Rock, the public works director, Roy Nordstrand, said that spring maintenance on baseball fields and athletic tracks has been sacrificed in the name of leaf pickup.
In Scotch Plains, the public works director, Walter DiNizo, said that in addition to the leaves, his crews are having to repair damage done by their own snowplows during the winter.
"Sometimes when you can't see the edge of the road for the snow, the plow will make a close turn around the corner and nick off a piece of lawn," he said. "Some of our plows loosened up chunks of Belgian block. And we're finding a lot of asphalt debris. There's just a bag of tricks out there."
In Paramus, Mr. Koenig said that his operating budget for the year that began Jan. 1 is nearly exhausted already.
"We've had so much overtime the guys don't want anymore," he said.
Spirits did not seem high Tuesday morning. The vacuum truck creeped and stopped, creeped and stopped. One crew member, Kevin Revicki, reached into the plucker and pulled out a small log.
"Look at this," he said shouted over the din of the machine, pointing to a pile of debris -- including a pair of old shorts -- that he had cleared from the vacuum. "People will throw anything out."
A little farther up the street, Rudy Heydt, an unemployed ironworker, came out of his house to say hello to the workers. Mr. Koenig warned him about the sticks in his leaf pile. Mr. Heydt said that he had a bad back and that his wife had been doing the raking. Mr. Koenig said he understood.
"Just think," he said on the way back to his car. "In six months we get to start all over again."

HEADLINE: Out-of-State Students And What They Add

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your story on the eight state colleges and Montclair State University contained a phrase that might be misinterpreted by some readers. 
 While it is true that students who are not residents of New Jersey pay higher tuition than those who live within the state, that is not the reason universities are pleased to have them enroll. Montclair State is happy to have out-of-state and international students attending because they bring another dimension to our campus, broaden the educational experience of our students, and provide a different perspective on many topics. For those reasons, geographic diversity is a goal of most universities and colleges.
As a public university, our primary goal is to provide an excellent education for New Jersey residents. Most out-of-state and international students come here because they have heard of our reputation for offering a fine education at an affordable price, and they contribute to New Jersey's economy during their stay with us.
 
DR. GREGORY L. WATERS
Vice President for I nstitutional Advancement
Montclair State University

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB;
The Language Barrier as Mount Everest

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Remember that old song, the one that said little things mean a lot? How true that is, especially in foreign travel. Just when business people hope to be on their best behavior, a word here or a gesture there can turn them into boors or laughingstocks. Read on.
On his first day of work in Hong Kong, Mike McKeown of Mineola, L.I., politely informed his plant manager that there was no need to brave the traffic to drive him back to his hotel. "I'll take the subway," Mr. McKeown said. "I grew up in New York City and have been riding the subway since I was a teen-ager." The plant manager looked at him strangely but let him go. 
 "As I exited the building, I saw a blue sign with a figure walking, and it said 'subway,' " Mr. McKeown recalled. As he proceeded in the indicated direction, he soon saw railroad tracks. "This was too easy," he remembered thinking.
"I walked into an underground walkway beneath the train tracks, and on the other side I saw the same blue sign with 'subway' on it," he continued. There was no train, though, and Mr. McKeown soon figured out his mistake. "I realized that the English version of subway was not the New York City version," he said.
"I took a cab home that night."
Shelley H. Brauner of Manhattan spent the second half of 1995 working at a major advertising agency in London.
"Besides the obvious, to go over there and do a great job, I was also anxious to fit in socially," she said. "So I was very pleased to be invited to a party one Friday evening, at a club in Soho, to celebrate a co-worker's birthday. Still unfamiliar with the streets of London, even with my trusty 'A to Z Guide' in hand, I jumped when I overheard a colleague mention he had his car and would be driving to the party.
"I ran over to him and asked, 'Could I get a ride with you?' As he turned bright red and his eyes popped out of his head, he said, 'Lucky for you I know what you meant.'
"Unbeknownst to me, I had actually requested a sexual encounter with him and not a lift to the party."
While visiting South Korea on a business trip a few years ago, Charles Stahley of North Wales, Pa., was in an elevator in a new office building when his partner pointed out a technical error: there was neither a light nor a numeral for the fourth floor.
"The Koreans in the elevator loudly responded: 'You Americans. What happened to your 13th floor? Why is 13 bad for you -- like 4 is to us?' " Mr. Stahley wrote. "The elevator became silent and my partner red-faced."
"In the United States, we are accustomed to making a certain hand gesture to express the thought 'well done,' " wrote William G. Voorhes of Stuart, Fla. "This is accomplished by bringing the tips of the thumb and forefinger together to form a circle while the other three fingers remain extended."
Several years ago, while in Rio de Janeiro for three months on a consulting project, Mr. Voorhes ate lunch daily in an executive dining room where the woman in charge graciously asked whether he had any special requests. Yes, he did: some hot sauce to pep up the black beans and rice.
"The next day she mixed up some sauce and asked me to try it," Mr. Voorhes recalled. "It was excellent, and I raised my right hand to give her the 'well done' sign. Just before bringing thumb and forefinger together, I saw a look of shock beginning to form on her face. Fortunately, I was able instead to ease into the 'A-O.K.' hand signal, widely used in Brazil, in which the fist is clenched while the thumb is extended vertically. Her face relaxed into a broad smile."
Later Mr. Voorhes learned that, in Brazil, his "well done" gesture refers not to what was tops but to people's bottoms. Indeed, when the movie "Top Gun" played there, Tom Cruise was, so to speak, the butt of the joke. People laughed uproariously each time he flashed the "well done" sign.
When Sandford Borins, the chairman of the division of management and economics on the Scarborough, Ontario, campus of the University of Toronto, was taken out to lunch in Tokyo by some Japanese business people, they made a point of asking him what he wanted.
"Thinking I would show them how much at home I was with their culture, I ordered tempura," he wrote. "They all proceeded to order tempura. Something didn't feel right.
"The next time -- there was a next time, but with a different group of Japanese business people -- they asked me what I wanted. The penny dropped. I ordered steak; they all ordered steak. All were very happy -- and, of course, the company paid."
"I am afraid you have been caught unawares yourself," wrote Nancy Morgenstern of Glendale, Ariz., referring to the name of this column. "About a year and a half ago, a companion who is a professional in the field and I attended Cordon Bleu in London for classes. I attended demonstrations, while she actually had hands-on experience in their kitchens. One session involved chocolate, and I, of course, went up to help grade the creations. In the course of our sampling, I remarked that there was a chocolate factory near us where you could eat all the chocolates you wanted 'on the job.' "
When the laughter subsided, Mrs. Morgenstern, somewhat bemused, asked what the joke was.
"I was informed," she said, "that the only ones 'on the job' in England were prostitutes."
 
Let's Meet, People!
Teams huddle. Bishops convene. Felons conspire. No matter the business, it has its meetings. That's why so many people have tales of this workplace fixture -- oafish behavior, stunning utterances, bizarre meeting rituals, meetings with no apparent point, sneaky strategies for enduring them. Send your most gripping memory to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send it by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Selling When the Tune Changes

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WHILE investors hang onto their mutual fund shares for many reasons -- benign neglect is a common one -- most fund purchases are not lifelong commitments.
But determining when a fund has outlived its usefulness in a portfolio is no small task. While poor performance is one obvious sign, there may be other clues, like a manager who suddenly shifts gears, or a change in market conditions. 
 Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., says he is usually patient with managers. Once he researches a fund and buys it, he will stick with it through two years of bad times if performance seems likely to improve. But he dumps funds immediately when managers change their stripes, say by adding big foreign positions or by switching from a growth to a value approach in stock selection.
Sometimes Mr. Evensky drops a fund simply because he believes he can do better in another type of investment, given global economic conditions. Such is the case with Pimco Foreign Bond, which Mr. Evensky is swapping for Warburg Pincus International Equity because he foresees a brighter future overseas for equities than for bonds. He expects the foreign economies that have been lagging behind the United States economy to catch up over the next three to five years, boding well for foreign stocks.
For the second quarter, Mr. Evensky and two other investment advisers are changing managers in the hypothetical retirement portfolios they created for The New York Times in the summer of 1993. The two remaining advisers remain content with their selections for now.
Jack Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who specializes in "socially responsible" investing, is dropping three of his eight funds. A fund that takes the socially responsible mantle aims to steer clear of things like tobacco stocks and companies that it deems to have poor records on environmental concerns or human rights issues. High-minded as such investing attempts seem, many funds in this category have been among the worst performers in recent quarters.
Performance is also leading Eric Kobren, editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter in Wellesley, Mass., to make a change. He is getting rid of the Fidelity fund that was the biggest drag on his portfolio in the last quarter.
 The contest is being tracked quarterly, although that is much too short a time to evaluate the portfolios, which were intended to grow for 20 years. During that time, the ups and downs in various types of assets should work themselves out.
ALL the portfolios made money in the first quarter, but four lagged behind the 5.3 percent gain for the Vanguard S.& P. 500, a benchmark equity fund. The exception was the no-load portfolio designed by Sheldon Jacobs of Irvington, N.Y. He was up 6.5 percent, helped by a surge in Mutual Discovery, which is a fifth of the portfolio.
Perhaps because of that strong showing, Mr. Jacobs decided not to make changes this time around. "I think the next two to three quarters will be winners or, if there's a correction, it will be less than 7 percent," he said. "The market isn't overvalued, and there's plenty of cash around."
Mr. Jacobs leads the group so far with a gain of 55 percent, from $50,000 to $77,228, since the contest began. On average, the portfolios have gained 41 percent, about 15 percentage points behind the overall market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500.
The portfolio performance, tracked by Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J., excludes taxes, because many people invest retirement money in tax-deferred accounts. Transaction costs and sales charges are also excluded.
 Like Mr. Jacobs, John Rekenthaler, editor of the Morningstar Investor, is not dropping or adding any funds to his portfolio. Each quarter, he rebalances, meaning that he adjusts the weighting of each fund to his original goal. In the near term, the odds slightly favor blue-chip stocks, Mr. Rekenthaler said. But small companies and international companies -- which his portfolio favors -- have more growth potential over the long term, he said.
Mr. Brill's portfolio has been the laggard over the long term and for the latest quarter, along with the category of socially responsible funds in which he specializes. Now he is making a major overhaul.
Calvert Strategic Growth falls off his list because it missed out on the entire bull market of 1995, Mr. Brill said, forcing him to re-evaluate, and ultimately reject, the technical analysis and market timing approach used by the fund.
Similarly, Parnassus has underperformed its aggressive-growth group since the start of 1995, a result of several stock choices. Mr. Brill said the fund's manager told him that he was repositioning the portfolio. For that reason, Mr. Brill is going to get out, at least until the changeover is completed.
He is also removing MMA Praxis Growth, although not because of the fund manager's decisions. Given the other changes, Praxis had "too much overlap with other funds in the portfolio," he said, citing its big blue-chip holdings. Upon rethinking, he also decided that the fund was too conservative.
Mr. Brill likes Citizens Emerging Growth, which is invested heavily in emerging technology and health care companies, because "it is appropriate for a retirement portfolio to have a small percentage of its assets invested aggressively."
Taking fourth place for the last quarter was Mr. Kobren, whose all-Fidelity portfolio rose just 2.9 percent. His return was weighed down by Fidelity Export, which has struggled because of several stock picks, Mr. Kobren said. "No one hits consistent home runs," he said, "but the manager has had a couple of incidents that call into question his investment decisions."
So Export is being replaced by Fidelity Growth Company, which will improve the overall quality of the portfolio, he said. The new fund also fits better with his economic forecasts. It "should fare well in the kind of moderate growth environment that we see ahead," he said.
As for Fidelity Value, which recently got a new manager, Mr. Kobren recommends patience. The new manager, Richard Fentin, ran the fund in the past and is now the team leader of the growth and income group at Fidelity. Mr. Kobren said he was convinced that Mr. Fentin would be a terrific fit.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Mixing Religion and Capitalism, Sometimes Uneasily

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
IT'S the season of Easter and Passover, of Holy Scripture and Haggadahs -- an apt time to look at some recent books that try to combine religious teachings and business tenets.
I say "recent," because books that mix Judeo-Christian concepts and commerce pop up regularly in America. 
 And why not? After all, the Talmud is bursting with issues of business ethics (many of them, of course, agrarian: how best to share the wool of jointly raised sheep, for example). And The New Testament highlights the views of Jesus on charity, labor's fruits and the difficulty of a rich man's reaching Paradise.
Add to this that the United States is among the most religious of the industrialized countries.
Americans have also long been influenced, regardless of their faiths, by a powerful Protestant work ethic. Benjamin Franklin was the first American to market a book about piety and success, says the business historian Peter Baida in his book, "Poor Richard's Legacy: American Business Values From Ben Franklin to Donald Trump." Franklin's 1757 book, "The Way of Wealth," was a compilation of proverbs from editions of Poor Richard's Almanack. Franklin published the book as a "speech" by a fictional old man. It was hugely popular.
About 130 years later, Americans were snapping up copies of "In His Steps," by Charles Sheldon. In this novel, the hero walks out on a successful business to live as Jesus did. True to the Protestant ethic, his highly moral action brings him even greater material wealth. The book, says Michael Zuckerman, a professor of American history at the University of Pennsylvania, is "a rip-roaring critique of business in the age of the robber barons and of the Gilded Age."
By the early 20th century, we see quite a different approach in "The Man Nobody Knows," by Bruce Barton, which casts Jesus as a brilliant adman for God's cause. The author, who later was a founder of the innovative BBDO advertising agency, spun out this idea at a time when Americans were infatuated with business and the stock market.
Now, pulling on that strand in a slightly different direction, come the latest books: "The Management Methods of Jesus" by Bob Briner (Thomas Nelson Inc., $14.99) and "Jesus C.E.O.," by Laurie Beth Jones (Hyperion, $16.95).
The idea of Jesus in the executive suite strains the imagination, even in the 1990's, when the metaphors out there in management land are already pretty attenuated. These days, executives are being urged to buy books on the "management" wisdom of basketball coaches, medieval despots and Winnie the Pooh.
The Briner and Jones books -- if we can judge them by their covers for a minute -- try to keep Jesus from being seen as just another name on that list. Both works are hymnal-sized, both use the words "ancient wisdom" in their subtitles and both are jacketed in purple, a color closely associated with religious garb in Western Christian traditions.
But neither can quite overcome the banality of comparing a much-worshipped religious figure with the guy in the corner office.
In "The Management Methods of Jesus," Mr. Briner, a television sports producer and freelance writer, does urge his readers to emulate Jesus by getting their companies to serve -- in this case, customers and employees. But too often, he views Jesus through the lens of management, instead of the other way around.
A result is that he winds up trivializing, to put it mildly, the religious lore he means to revere.
A chapter titled "Watch Your Timing" describes how Jesus planned his entrance into Jerusalem during Passover, when Jews from every nation came into the city. It concludes, in part: "New products should be introduced at the most opportune time. Where appropriate, tie them into significant anniversaries and public holidays."
Similarly, "Eat With the Troops" cites nothing less than the Last Supper to remind readers that "meals with those who work with and for you should be a part of your schedule."
With "Jesus C.E.O.," the myopia problem starts with the title. The author bases her premise on the fact that Jesus "trained 12 human beings" to "accomplish the tasks he trained them to do."
But the book has a bit more substance than the Briner work. The examples from the business world are more developed, so, as lessons, they have beginnings, middles and ends. Still, while the book takes the time to talk about setting noble goals and living up to Jesus's equality standards, it, too, can be jaw-droppingly mundane.
In one example, titled, "He Was Keenly Aware of His Resources," the author alludes to the Gospel's account of Jesus' feeding of 5,000 people with five loaves of bread and two fishes. The "resources" lesson for readers? Update those Rolodexes.
This brings us to a brief mention of another new book, "God Wants You to Be Rich," by Paul Zane Pilzer (Simon & Schuster, $23). Brief because, despite its title, it is much more about economics than theology. The author, who was the co-author of "Other People's Money: The Inside Story of the S.& L. Mess," sets out to prove that technology creates unlimited physical resources and that "an increase in wealth for an individual almost always represents an even larger increase in wealth for society at large."
So why mention God in the title? Perhaps because the author does touch on his religious beliefs from time to time. Or perhaps because, as Professor Zuckerman points out: "There are a lot more people in America who believe in religion than believe in business."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: REGO PARK;
After 2 Stores Open, Business Strolls Back to Queens Blvd.

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
When Alexander's department store closed its doors in 1992, it took with it much of the surrounding foot traffic along Queens Boulevard and left a big void in Rego Park. Without its overflow of shoppers, many long-time merchants followed suit and closed their doors. Those who clung on said sales dropped by 20 percent. Their hopes were all but dashed when Caldor declared bankruptcy in the fall and withdrew its plan to open in the Alexander's building.
"The empty store was an eyesore," said Jay Parker, president of the Rego Park Forest Hills Community Development Corporation. "Longtime stores were closing left and right. We had 55 members before Alexander's closed. When we reopened six months ago, there were only three original members left." 
 But in the last three weeks, since the opening of two national retailers, Sears and Marshalls, the discount chain, businesses owners are once again optimistic about their future.
"It has been great," said Wendy Pan, a manager at Baskin-Robbins ice cream store across the street. Ms. Pan said that in the three weeks that Sears had been open, business had almost returned to the levels when Alexander's attracted store-packing foot traffic.
Eric Robinson, the spokesman for the Queens Chamber of Commerce, said Marshalls and Sears were expected to create about 700 full- and part-time jobs. But he said the stores' economic impact went beyond the immediate neighborhood.
"Destination stores like Sears and Marshalls can attract other businesses as well," Mr. Robinson said. "It gives confidence to other companies thinking of opening up in the borough."
Apparently what's good for the area is also good for Sears and Marshalls. Alan Koch, store manager for Sears, said the store's opening last month was the most successful opening day in Sears' history.
"Our customer base is about 3 million shoppers within the five-mile radius," Mr. Koch said. "The demographics -- middle-class working families -- are exactly what we are looking for."
Sears occupies 200,000 square feet in the cellar and part of the first floor of the former Alexander's site. Marshalls, with 80,000 square feet, shares part of the first floor with Sears. The second floor, with 120,000 square feet, remains empty.
On the opening day of Marshalls last weekend, customers jostled and pushed their way through piles of discounted dresses and pants. Two customers, Kim White and Elise Jones, said they previously had to drive about two hours to Long Island to shop at Marshalls. JANE H. LII
