HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
ITT Gets Gussied Up For a Fling In Casinos

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
Few companies have reflected prevailing Wall Street fashions as consistently as the ITT Corporation. So get ready for the corporate equivalent of bare midriffs and ankle tattoos as ITT spends heavily again to remake itself in the image of the market's latest thing, a gambling-and-leisure behemoth.
Not so long ago, investors were put off by the garish temptations of Las Vegas, but America's sudden embrace of casinos has that other casino, Wall Street, delighted. And so ITT is in negotiations to bulk up with the acquisition of Bally's, a deal that could cost nearly $3 billion. The deal is given 50-50 odds by some people close to the talks, but even if it does not come off, ITT, which already owns the Sheraton hotels, is planning a major expansion in Las Vegas that will cost hundreds of millions of dollars. 
 "It is patently obvious to us that we have to invest in the best brand name in Las Vegas," said Robert A. Bowman, the company's president. He would not comment on the Bally's reports, but, he added, referring to ITT's Caesars World gambling unit, "The company has not been adequately invested in in the past."
It has been a long strange trip getting here. Telecommunications? As some gray hairs can recall, that was how the company got its start, when international telephone calls dazzled investors. Conglomerates? When they became the rage, ITT stood out at buying and selling companies like so many trading cards. It collected everything from Wonder Bread to Avis car rental to lawn seed and insurance.
When ITT's chairman, Rand V. Araskog, was criticized for paying himself millions while the stock lagged behind, he caught the next wave and "de-conglomeratized" -- last year, he broke up the blob into four companies, and remained at the helm of the one that seemed fairest to Wall Street, the hotel and gambling company.
The stock has soared and ITT has made a spate of acquisitions -- among them last year's purchase of Caesars World and a half interest in Madison Square Garden, which includes the Knicks and the Rangers. And, of course, Mr. Araskog is getting richer. Last year, he received compensation of slightly less than $11 million for leaving behind the company he had helped build and fashioning a new one.
Analysts are fairly unanimous in their view that ITT overpaid for some of its assets, but they tend to be positive about where it stands and its prospects in an industry growing more and more central to the national economy: leisure and entertainment.
"Leaving aside the issue of whether the old ITT overpaid for the assets, they now have a collection of businesses that will enjoy strong and sustained growth," said Mark Manson, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities. "The growth prospects in the leisure industry are greater than they've ever been."
Indeed, Las Vegas is growing at a spectacular pace. In the next few years, about 16,000 new hotel rooms will be constructed, many of them attached to casinos built around entertainment themes ranging from "Star Trek" to, believe it or not, the streets of Manhattan.
Wall Street is not the least bit daunted by such competition, or the thought that vacationers may grow as tired of the strip's neon attractions as they once did of lava lamps.
"Las Vegas is the No. 1 destination in the world, and it is going to remain so," Mr. Bowman said. "We are going to invest to get our fair share of that market."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Nothing Seems to Stop the Flow at Stock Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
DESPITE piling one gain upon another in 1995, managers of mutual funds that invest primarily in American stocks did something in the first quarter of this year that they were unable to do most of last year: outperform the market average.
Mutual funds that specialize in domestic equities rose 5.6 percent on average in the first quarter, according to Morningstar, the Chicago fund trackers. That beat the 5.3 percent total return, including reinvested dividends, of the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the benchmark for most equity fund managers, and marked the fifth consecutive quarter of gains. 
 International funds, helped by a resurgence in emerging markets, gained the same as their domestic counterparts.
But shareholders of bond funds, whose returns last year rivaled those of stock funds, suffered one of the worst markets in two years. The average taxable bond fund fell 0.58 percent in the first quarter, while municipal bond funds lost an average of 1.56 percent.
Even the winning equity performances mask a growing divergence among fund returns, differences that, if they continue to grow, could mean an increasingly rough ride for investors.
Consider that the equity fund numbers pale in comparison to what might have been. While the S.& P. 500 rose more than 5 percent, big stocks gained at a much faster pace. The Dow Jones industrial average recorded a total return of 9.9 percent, nearly double the broader market average.
Much of the first quarter's gains were apparently fueled by the deluge of cash into mutual funds. Domestic equity funds collected more money in the first two months than they had in any previous three-month stretch.
With demand for stocks soaring and many American companies continuing to repurchase their shares, fund managers are looking well beyond the biggest stocks for shares to buy. The lists of best performers over the latest quarter and year are littered with funds that invest heavily in small initial public offerings, and are remarkably devoid of the biggest and most widely held funds, which have been attracting most of the new cash from 401(k) retirement plans.
"I don't know why there aren't more larger-cap names in there," said James McCall, manager of the PBHG Large Cap Growth fund, lamenting the lack of similar funds on the lists of the quarter's top performers. "The money flows into mutual funds are very strong, and managers have to put money to work quickly. Often the only way they can do that is to buy big names. And foreign dollars flowing into the market also like large-cap companies."
But funds that focus on the biggest stocks have performed moderately at best so far this year. Some, like the Fidelity Magellan fund, the country's biggest, looked downright dismal. The Magellan fund rose 1.7 percent, placing it near the bottom in its category.
The divergence between the funds receiving the most money and those performing the best might eventually breed unrest among American investors. What history shows, however, is that investors rarely pull back from mutual funds before the market turns.
"Even in 1987, money started flowing out only after stock prices fell," said Melissa R. Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities. "When you get big surges of money flowing into the market, that's when the market seems to peak."
None of those cautions, however, seem to dim the ardor of the fund managers who lead the list of winning stock funds in the latest quarter. Randall E. Haase, co-manager of the Alliance Capital Quasar fund, the best-performing diversified stock fund in the latest quarter, said the recent outperformance of large-cap stocks gives him hope that the smaller stocks he prefers will move back into the spotlight.
The Quasar fund reaped much of its 18.75 percent first-quarter gain from what Mr. Haase called contrarian bets on two sectors that had been badly beaten down in recent years: natural gas drilling contractors and airlines.
Looking ahead, selected stocks in similarly out-of-favor industries, like retailing and, more recently, solid-waste disposal, could be further contributors to the Quasar fund's success, Mr. Haase said. Those winning ways date back beyond the most recent quarter. The fund has gained 64.6 percent over the last year, better than all but three other diversified stock funds tracked by Morningstar.
"We try to keep away from companies that have big valuations and that are 'story' stocks," he said. "We don't buy microbreweries, we don't buy 'concept' restaurants, we don't buy satellites and wireless cable companies. As a result, we've been able to keep away from many bombs and disasters."
Which is not to say that the fund, which outperformed its next closest competitor by more than three percentage points, avoids initial public offerings. A big winner has been Diamond Offshore Drilling, which went public in October at $24 and has since doubled. But even there, Mr. Haase said, the Quasar fund bought the offering "at a time when drilling stocks were out of favor, and the deal was not in demand."
The Dreyfus Premier Strategic Growth fund similarly benefited from some less-recognized initial public offerings. "Most people think of the overnight effect when they think of I.P.O.'s," said Michael Schonberg, manager of the fund, referring to the practice of "flipping" the highly coveted shares of a hot offering by selling when they soar in the first day of trading. By contrast, Mr. Schonberg said, "we have tried to focus on those that have very strong long-term stories."
Mr. Schonberg said that the fund's size, about $55 million, allows it to get a bigger performance benefit from I.P.O. shares than larger funds might. Shares of Fuisz Technologies, a drug-delivery researcher that went public in December at $12, more than tripled in the next three months. That has made the stock the Strategic Growth fund's biggest holding, at 6 percent of assets.
Other recent I.P.O.'s whose price gains contributed to the fund's first-quarter returns include Ultrafem, a developer of feminine hygiene products that went public in February at $10 a share and subsequently traded as high as $16, and Pharmaceutical Product Development, which sold shares to the public in January at $18 each and now trades at more than twice that level.
David Nicholas, manager of the Nicholas Limited Edition fund, another top performer in the most recent quarter, said that his fund tended not to buy I.P.O.'s and stayed far away from technology stocks. The latter aversion helped the fund immensely, as technology-heavy funds, last year's biggest gainers, were the biggest losers in the first quarter.
But the Nicholas fund did ride the coattails of some relatively recent public offerings. While the fund's biggest holding, International Speedway, has been in the portfolio for five years, its shares were pulled along last quarter in the excitement over Penske Motorsports, a new public offering, and Speedway Motorsports, which made an additional public offering. Both auto racing stocks have posted big gains this year.
While the lists of best-performing stocks and funds in the first quarter contain few household names, one prominent manager did surface: Ron Baron of the Baron Asset fund.
That fund's 14.8 percent gain, as well as the 11.8 percent increase achieved by the Baron Growth and Income fund, came in part from a heavy investment in companies that provide temporary workers for corporations and medical care concerns. In a period when corporations are reluctant to increase their payrolls even as the economy expands, the temporary-help business appears to have secured a permanent place among growth industries.
A similar permanence seems to have settled over equity mutual funds, which have not suffered a quarterly loss of more than 5 percent for more than five years. The gains have come, in part, from growing amounts of cash flowing into mutual funds.
But those trends are far from immutable. "Of course, it's better to have the strong mutual fund cash flow than not to have it," said Ms. Brown, the Prudential analyst. But in 1986, 1987 and in 1990, she noted, fund flows slowed down or turned negative only after the market did. "Some people believe that the money flowing in means stocks can only go up," she said. "I don't buy that."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
Tenants Wanted: Koreans Sought At Empire State

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The Empire State Building is known throughout the world. Don Dongpil Kim is not. But if all goes according to Mr. Kim's plan, he will be known in certain circles as Mr. Empire State Building. And the landmark tower he is marketing will have fewer "office for rent" signs.
Mr. Kim, 56, and his assistant, Christopher Lee, both Korean-born, are trying to persuade Korean and Korean-American businesses to move into the Empire State Building, which has had an unusually high vacancy rate in the last year -- up to 20 percent, or nearly double the 11 percent for other midtown office buildings, according to a real-estate brokerage firm. Part of that was attributable to the departure of a major tenant, Visiting Nurse Services of New York, which occupied an entire 60,000-square-foot floor. 
 Mr. Kim, who was born in Seoul and attended its university before singing with the Boston Pops and becoming a real estate salesman in Manhattan, recently returned from his first business trip to Korea, where he met with three dozen prospective tenants. "They were attorneys, accountants, exporters and professors," he said. "Everybody knew the Empire State Building."
He and Mr. Lee also advertise the building in Korea's newspapers and on cable television programs throughout the nation. And Mr. Lee is directing their pitch to more than 2,000 computer-selected lawyers, accountants and import-export businesses.
The men stress that the building, completed in 1931, is made up of offices that are smaller than the suites characteristic of newer towers. The design, they say, is well-suited to the small businesses favored by Koreans and Korean-Americans.
The Empire State Building's managing agent, Helmsley-Spear, is also banking on the strength of the Korean economy, which has been doubling in size nearly every 10 years since the Korean War, and the loosening of investment restrictions.
Until last year, Korean businesses could not deposit money abroad. Now they can deposit as much as $100 million, according to Euidong Chung, a consular official at the South Korean consulate in New York. Korean businesses can also invest up to $100 million in foreign real estate and other ventures, up from $50 million.
The area around the Empire State Building, especially between 24th and 39th Streets, has more than 400 Korean and Korean-American businesses.
"Thirty-second Street looks especially like Koreatown because so many people are in the jewelry, garment, watch, hat and wig businesses," said Jin Hyoung Seo, a leather importer and the president of the New York Society of Korean Businessmen. "The Empire State Building will look good to Koreans."
So far, Mr. Kim and Mr. Lee have leased only 3,100 square feet on the ground floor, to a school that trains Korean beauticians. "It will take some time to establish a network here and in Korea," Mr. Kim says. "But if all goes well, we may be able to lease 7,500 to 10,000 square feet a month."
Others, though, are skeptical. "Korea is a nice marketing theme," said Josh N. Kuriloff, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, a real-estate services firm, "but I don't think the market is as deep as they think it is." ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Less Cash, Large Losses: Apple's Dwindling Dollars

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
WILL Apple Computer run out of cash soon? David Dreman, the chairman of Dreman Value Advisors in Jersey City, thinks so. "The company can't continue on as it has for another 60 or 90 days," he said. "The cash drain will cause a crisis. Or force an enormous scaling back or the sale of the company."
Many are more optimistic than Mr. Dreman. But while much of the talk about Apple these days focuses on how it could restore consumer confidence and reacquire its former glory, the nation's No. 3 computer maker may be facing a more mundane and immediate problem: an empty wallet. 
 For nervous Apple shareholders and bargain-hunting investors, the stakes may be great. Shares of Apple, which were as high as $35 earlier this year, closed Thursday at $24.125. If the product and leadership problems that propelled this drop turn into a cash crunch, the stock may fall further.
And there are many worries on that front: shrinking sales and cash reserves soaring costs and payment troubles.
Hobbled by an industry slowdown as well as its own troubles, Apple expects revenues for the quarter ended March 29 to fall below the $2.6 billion of the corresponding period last year. The company will not release its quarterly results until April 17, but Eric R. Lewis, an analyst for the International Data Corporation, estimated that the company would take in $2.5 billion, or even less, this quarter.
Apple's bank account is getting thinner, too. From $1.5 billion in cash just 15 months ago, Apple had just $1.1 billion on hand in December, and it may have even less now. "It used to have an unbelievable amount of cash," said Todd Bakar, an analyst for Hambrecht & Quist. If it becomes cash-strapped, Apple may sorely miss those flusher days as it seeks more revenue in a tough market. "It was a competitive advantage" to have a lot of cash, Mr. Bakar said.
Moreover, Apple said last month that it expected a record $700 million loss after taxes for the quarter just ended. Of course, the loss means smaller tax payments, and more than half of the charge involves inventory write-downs that do not cost the company cash out of pocket. But the balance of the $700 million, split equally between layoffs and other revamping charges and operating losses, do deplete cash.
Compounding these problems, in late March Standard & Poor's and Moody's downgraded to junk-bond status Apple's $304 million in long-term debt.
"The downgrading of public debt isn't going to help them with getting new low-cost money," noted Pieter Hartsook, publisher of the Hartsook Letter, a computer industry newsletter in Alameda, Calif.
Even more pressing for Apple is $400 million in bank debt owed by its subsidiaries in Japan and the Netherlands. A $187 million note, due in March, has not been paid, and a $203 million i.o.u. falls due this month.
These problems have put cash flow uppermost in the minds of some Apple analysts. "If they continue to bleed," said Scott Stagg, of the Delaware Bay Company, "there could be a liquidity problem."
But Apple is not sitting still. For one, it is renegotiating its debts, including the past-due $187 million note and the other foreign-subsidiary debt. "We are extremely encouraged about our ability to renegotiate," an Apple spokeswoman, Lynne Keast, said.
Even if lenders agree to extend the loans, the terms are likely to be more onerous, Mr. Lewis said. "The bigger problem," he added, "will be restrictions on credit itself, which could reduce Apple's flexibility."
To conserve cash, the company has also suspended its dividend -- saving $60 million a year -- and asks its suppliers to allow stretched-out payments. The latter strategy was begun by Michael Spindler, who was dismissed as chairman in February.
And Apple's new chairman, Gilbert F. Amelio, hopes to bolster sales with a policy opposite the price-cutting approach that got Mr. Spindler ousted and got Apple into cash-flow trouble. Mr. Amelio plans to develop machines so reliable that customers will be willing to pay premium prices for them.
For the last two months, however, Apple has also been selling products at very low prices to cut inventory and raise cash, said Kimball Brown, an analyst with Dataquest. And the company is proceeding with layoffs and other revampings that will ultimately lower its expenses, even if the moves result in one-time charges.
Will Apple's efforts save it from a cash crunch? Some analysts agree with Mr. Dreman, but others feel that it is too early to answer. "I can't extrapolate from previous quarters," said Martha Toll Reed, of Standard & Poor's. "I find it hard to judge until I find their cash position this quarter."
David Wu, an analyst with the Chicago Corporation, is more firm in his opinion. He compares Apple's troubles to those of Dell Computer, which was able to reverse a few money-losing quarters in 1993 by liquidating discounted inventory. "Very fast, Apple will be cash-flow-positive," he predicted.
And Apple has other options, Mr. Brown believes. "If it's a sticky cash squeeze, they'll have to borrow," he said. "It's not insurmountable." The company also is asset-rich, and can raise cash by selling off some of those assets -- as it did just last week when it agreed to sell a laptop and circuit-board factory to SCI Systems Inc.
Given all these options, "It looks like they have a cash-management issue," Mr. Lewis said. "It doesn't look to me like they're running out of money."
But some are more worried. Craig Fit, an analyst for Moody's, cautioned that Apple might not be moving swiftly enough to align costs with revenues. "This company is in a stress scenario, rapidly changing," he said. If Apple's revenue assumptions fall short, "one can have less confidence that one restructuring charge is enough."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Little Off the Top and the Bottom Helps Mid-Cap Stocks

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
CALL it this year's squeeze play. The winning streak that large companies have bragged about for the last two years is causing many portfolio managers to scour smaller stocks for better values. At the same time, managers of small-stock funds who are being flooded with fresh cash have been reaching up to larger stocks.
Basking in this attention from above and below are the stocks squarely in the middle, known as mid-caps. Stocks like Olsten and Charles Schwab have jumped since January, and the Standard & Poor's 400 Midcap Index has risen 6.53 percent this year, slightly outperforming the large-cap S.& P. 500. 
 Analysts said the squeeze pushing more money into mid-caps will probably continue all year and help drive up their prices, but it could end abruptly. If investors become nervous about the economy -- and the market -- they will seek the stability of larger stocks.
Although the mid-caps are not as cheap as the smallest stocks, several portfolio managers said they remain a good buy. Claudia E. Mott, an analyst with Prudential Securities in New York, said mid-caps are trading at the same price-earnings ratio as large stocks, about 15 times the per-share earnings forecasted for this year, despite their superior growth prospects. This year, mid-caps are expected to achieve earnings growth of 17 percent, compared with 13 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500.
Mid-caps have also proved to be good investments over the long haul, noted Brian W. H. Berghuis, who manages the T. Rowe Price Mid-Cap Growth Fund in Baltimore. Their returns are less than half of a percentage point below those of small stocks, gaining an average of 11 percent a year since 1926, but with much less risk. Unlike small companies, which are usually fledgling outfits that may depend on a single product or service, mid-caps are typically established businesses.
There is no universal definition of what constitutes a mid-cap, but portfolio managers tend to describe them as having market capitalizations of $1 billion to $5 billion.
Among the managers buying them is Patrick S. Adams, who runs the Founders Blue Chip and Balanced funds in Denver. He has been finding large-company stocks like Merck or Coca-Cola too expensive for his taste. "I think the mid-cap sector looks much more appealing," he said.
Mr. Adams points to the Foster Wheeler Corporation, an engineering and construction company. Capitalizing on the building boom in Asia and other emerging markets, the company earned $28.5 million on sales of $3.1 billion last year. The stock is selling at 18 times its estimated 1996 earnings, the same commanded by General Electric, which is in similar businesses. But Foster Wheeler is expected to grow faster. Wall Street projects earnings growth of 15 percent annually over the next five years, compared with 12 percent for G.E., according to Zacks Investment Research.
John W. Ballen, the manager of the small-cap MFS Emerging Growth Fund, likes mid-caps, but for a different reason. "A lot of new money in the market has gone into mid-caps rather than small-caps because it's easier to put that money to use," he said. Because funds generally have limits on how much of one company they can own, fund managers can invest big sums in larger companies more easily than in smaller companies. It is also easier for a manager to invest $50 million in one or two larger stocks than in five smaller ones.
While Mr. Ballen thinks the stocks of smaller companies are cheaper, he has bought some mid-caps that offer strong earnings growth. Office Depot is a fast-growing chain of office products superstores that has been selling supplies to the growing legions of small businesses. The company is reporting double-digit gains in sales and earnings, and made $132 million on sales of $5.3 billion last year. The stock is selling at 18 times forecasted earnings, although the company is expected to increase its profits by more than 25 percent annually over the next five years.
Gary Pilgrim, the manager of the small-cap PBHG Growth Fund in Wayne, Pa., likes the Cognex Corporation, which has a market capitalization of $1 billion. The company makes machine vision systems that industrial companies use to spot product defects.
Though the company originally sold its systems mostly to semiconductor manufacturers (and the stock was beaten down recently along with semiconductor stocks), it now sells to other businesses, including pharmaceutical and consumer electronic companies. "They seem to have a very dominant position," Mr. Pilgrim said.
Mr. Berghuis of T. Rowe Price is less interested in snagging highflying stocks than catching what he describes as "plodders," companies that may not generate a lot of excitement but that have plenty of cash flow that they use to make smart acquisitions. One such outfit is Quorum Health Group, a hospital management chain that has been buying two or three hospitals a year. Quorum, which earned $60 million in the last 12 months on sales of nearly $1 billion, is trading at only 19 times forecasted earnings. Profits are expected to grow 19 percent a year.
FOR managers who concentrate on buying the least expensive stocks, there are plenty of opportunities in mid-caps, according to Robert D'Alelio, a portfolio manager who looks for cheap small-company stocks for Putnam Investments in Boston. Unlike large-company stocks that become bargains when investors flee after some disappointment, smaller equities tend to suffer more from Wall Street's neglect than its wrath, he said. "There is an element of inefficiency here," he said.
Among the midsize companies that Mr. D'Alelio thinks are being ignored is Universal Foods, a Milwaukee company that went public 15 years ago. With $800 million in revenue, the company specializes in making colors and flavors for the big food companies. The stock is selling at 16 times this year's forecasted earnings. It is inexpensive because Wall Street has been slow to recognize the company's shift from frozen french fries to a more profitable enterprise.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
Major 'Head-Rearranging' Caps Board 3's Fractious Year

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
While less bloody than the purging of the Romanovs, a long expected shake-up at Community Board 3 was announced last week as the elected officials who control appointments to the tempestuous board dropped a half-dozen members.
Among those who were removed was the chairman, Albert Fabozzi, who was hit in the face with a cake last fall during a meeting of the notoriously unruly and faction-ridden board, perhaps the city's most fractious. Neither Councilman Antonio Pagan nor Borough President Ruth W. Messinger chose to reappoint Mr. Fabozzi to a third term. Council members recommend names for half the board's 50 slots; the borough president has the final say on all appointments. 
 Mr. Fabozzi, who was elected chairman after his predecessor was dumped by Ms. Messinger last May, said he believed that his stubborn independence over issues like a local needle exchange prompted his removal. Mr. Pagan supported the program; Mr. Fabozzi was against it.
Mr. Pagan said he chose not to reappoint Mr. Fabozzi in an effort to rein in the board, which represents the heterogeneous and troubled Lower East Side. While the neighborhood is wracked by AIDS and drug addiction, housing is its most divisive issue, specifically how to develop nearly 500 city-owned sites.
Another Pagan appointee, Robert A. Strong, said he believed that he was dropped from the board because of his comments about the Councilman's leadership in a recent article in Crain's New York Business magazine. "I put my foot in my mouth by criticizing Antonio," said Mr. Strong, who headed the board's economic development committee.
Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed dropped three sitting members, including the secretary, Adam Silvera, and a 24-year board veteran, Richard Ropiak. "C.B. 3 needs monumental head-rearranging," Ms. Freed explained. "I'm interested in people who are logical, nonpolitical and understand the need to compromise."
Several board insiders, however, maintain that like Mr. Pagan, Ms. Freed dropped members who did not vote to her liking. Ms. Freed agrees that she was angry at Mr. Ropiak for not supporting a proposed men's shelter on the Bowery.
Most members believe that when the dust settles, they will be left with the same querulous monster. "The political divisions on this board are just too great," a member, Lisa Ramaci, said."I think we'll always be the fractious brat board of Manhattan." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

TELECOMMUNICATIONS
 
One Giant Buys Another
In the logic of the Republican Congress, fewer competitors result in more competition, so long as the giants are well muscled. Chalk up another victory, then, for competition: SBC Communications, the former Southwestern Bell, said it would acquire Pacific Telesis for $17 billion, creating the nation's second-largest phone company after AT&T. More than 30 million customers from Texas to the West Coast will be served by the new company, as well as 80 million potential customers in a nationwide cellular market. The deal assures that what had been two adjacent regional phone companies will not make inroads on each other's home base.
 
INSURANCE
 
Aetna to Buy U.S. Healthcare
In a sign of just how big a challenge managed care represents to established medical insurance plans, Aetna Life and Casualty agreed to pay $8.8 billion for U.S. Healthcare, which is known for its tough cost controls on doctors and hospitals. The resulting company will provide various types of health insurance to 1 in 12 Americans.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Accelerating Again
For the second month in a row, the Labor Department reported that more jobs were created than had been anticipated, and that increase came despite the 17-day strike at General Motors. The new jobs, though far fewer than those created in February, sent the bond market stumbling. Last month's report hammered bonds and then brought a 171-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average; this month's impact was more muted, with the stock markets closed for Good Friday. In another sign that the economy might be picking up steam, the index of leading indicators soared 1.3 percent in February, the biggest increase in years.
 
THE AUTO INDUSTRY
 
As Talks Near, Hard Line by Union Leaders
Factoring in the Big Three auto makers' $30 billion in cash reserves and their determination to cut costs, the United Automobile Workers union made clear that concessions and compromise are not what it has in mind as it prepares for summer negotiations on new national contracts. The president of the U.A.W., Stephen Yokich, and other union officials said they would press for more hiring to reduce unwanted overtime and try to curb the auto makers' ability to turn to nonunion suppliers for parts.
 
COMPUTERS
 
Hold That Line!
Under its new chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, Apple Computer may be planning to step aside from the personal computer industry's price wars and to try to rebuild its cachet and regain the attendant higher prices it has historically commanded, internal company documents suggest. Because of its higher research and development costs, Apple is ill situated to compete head on with the makers of Windows PC's.
 
AGE DISCRIMINATION
 
High Court Broadens a Law
Workers who are replaced by younger people -- even if the replacement workers are older than 40 -- may be entitled to sue their employers, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously, even though the Federal law specifies that such complaints have merit only if the replacement workers are younger than 40.
 
WATCHDOGS
 
A Corporate Voice At Investors' Group
Members of the Council of Institutional Investors, a leader in the shareholder rights movement, elected as co-chairman Martin A. Coyle, executive vice president and general counsel of TRW Inc. Union members of the council had opposed having one of the top three posts filled by a corporate representative.
 
TRADE BARRIERS
 
Mexico Closes Some Doors
After months of opening its economy to outsiders, Mexican legislators, backed by labor unions, have demanded that foreign companies be prohibited from managing pension funds that will be created next year as part of broad changes in Mexico's social security system. The Mexicans fear that outsiders would be inclined to invest the pension money outside of Mexico.
 
ROLLOUTS
 
Giant Step at AT&T
In the biggest initial stock offering in history, AT&T spun off its equipment subsidiary, which includes Bell Laboratories, under the name Lucent. Shares were offered at $27 each and closed the first day of trading up 13 percent. The initial offering raised about $3 billion, which will be used to pay debt; AT&T will spin off the balance of the shares to its shareholders by year-end.
 
CLASS ACTIONS
 
Judge Blocks Settlement by Drug Makers
A Federal district judge threw out an agreement by 15 drug makers to pay $409 million to settle a class action that contends they conspired to fix prices charged to pharmacies. The retailers contend that drug makers offered such steep discounts to hospitals and health maintenance organizations that retail pharmacies could not compete. Federal District Judge Charles P. Kocoras in Chicago ruled that the retailers had presented enough evidence to warrant a trial on the complaint.

GRAPHIC: Photos: PASSAGES -- 'With Wings Like Eagles' -- With handshakes, smiles, charm and a good deal of political muscle, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown waged a war on two fronts, against the Republican movement in Congress to disband the Commerce Department, and against his counterparts elsewhere in the Federal Government who did not see their mission as the creation and preservation of American jobs through its foreign relations. HEADLINE: Dangerous Abstractions

BYLINE: By John Allen Paulo; Jogn Allen Paulo, a professor of mathematics at Temple University, is the author of "A Mathematician Reads the Newspaper."

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
At first glance, a Ph. D. in mathematics, the subject often called the handmaiden of science and engineering, seems an odd credential for a Luddite. Yet Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspected Unabomber, received such a degree from the University of Michigan in 1962. What are we to make of this?
Certainly Mr. Kaczynski's arrest (coming, coincidentally, just before Mathematics Awareness Week) does not enhance the public image of mathematicians. Indeed, it furthers some of the worst stereotypes. Believe it or not, most of my colleagues are humorous, not asocial loners. The only time most use the phrase "blow up" is when they consider division by zero. Still, is Mr. Kaczynski's background as anomalous as it appears? 
 Several aspects of mathematics suggest that it isn't. The subject and its subdisciplines are axiomatic -- that is, they are based on a few fundamental assumptions from which all else follows logically. Thus, mathematicians often view themselves as "radical" thinkers in the literal sense of the word: They get to the root of the matter.
In a similar sense, the Unabomber's manifesto, which shows a mathematician's meticulous attention to detail, has the feel of an extended proof based on a few presuppositions about what constitutes the good life -- personal control, self-reliance, minimal environmental impact. From these elements he attempts to derive a radical alternative theory of society -- a non-Euclidean approach, if you will, to our social problems.
Another obvious characteristic of mathematics is its abstractness; and the subdiscipline in which Mr. Kaczynski got his degree, complex analysis, is abstract in the extreme. (In fact, complex analysis has little to do with the common meanings of either word. Analysis is the branch of mathematics that grew out of calculus, and complex refers to complex numbers, a generalization of our number system that accommodates so-called imaginary numbers.)
The ability to think abstractly is a precious one too often absent from public debate. (England's panic over mad cow disease is fueled by its citizens' failure to calmly consider the slim chances of contracting the disease.) Nevertheless, abstract thinking has been associated with various pathologies, and it is easy to see how one trained in such reasoning and in thrall to an ideal could come to justify murderous acts as a nebulous "good."
Mathematics is also beautiful, but its esthetic -- minimalist, austere -- can blind one to the messiness and contingencies of real life. To use mathematical principles to devise a grand socio-economic theory, one must simplify. In doing so, mathematicians can forget that their mathematical or economic model is not the real world.
Reality, like the perfectly ordinary woman of Virginia Woolf's essay "Mr. Bennett and Mrs. Brown," is infinitely complex and impossible to capture completely in a model. Thus, it is hardly surprising that, for all the Government's high-tech surveillance and analysis, the real break in the case came out of the murky realm of family dynamics.
Of course, Mr. Kaczynski may not be the Unabomber. If so, my speculations are but another example of a mathematician's failure to produce a model that works in the real world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The World;
Donors of Foreign Aid Have Second Thoughts

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso

 BODY:
THE 1990's have proven a grim time for foreign aid as we know it -- the grants and loans that are the traditional form of international development assistance. Everywhere these days, it seems, support for such aid is dwindling, and once-generous donors are focusing their energies inward.
It hasn't helped, of course, that three decades of foreign development assistance in the third world has failed to lift the poorest of the poor in Africa and Asia much beyond where they have always been. 
 Alarmed by the downward spiral of their budgets, and chastened by the lack of results, many of the world's leading aid agencies have begun the most serious rethinking of their efforts since the boom days of the development aid business began in the 1960's.
 
 
 
Two New Approaches
 Most dramatically, they are beginning to suggest something that once was heard only from outright enemies of foreign aid: that big cash outlays to central governments may only pave the way to corruption.
Part of the reason for this shift is competition from another approach to development altogether. The United States has moved far from the original notion of shipping money to governments (in competition with Moscow) so they could finance showpiece projects. For a decade and a half now, budget-conscious officials in Washington have been putting far more emphasis on revising trade rules and promoting direct investmant by American companies.
Increasingly, direct grants and loans are coming from other countries, such as Japan and Germany, or from pooled sources like the International Monetary Fund and World Bank (often with strings attached). And in those quarters, illusions of quickly transforming an entire country's economy from the top down through aid have faded.
At the same time, a tendency to lend money for big projects -- visible things like bridges and dams, which often prove ruinous even though they mean fat supply contracts for companies in the donor countries -- is giving way to a new emphasis on projects to improve the welfare of ordinary people.
In the future, lenders see themselves spending more on skill-building projects, like professional training programs and basic education. The World Bank and its wing, the International Finance Corporation, for example, are lending money and training people to create local credit unions and small businesses.
One of the most frequently heard buzzwords in this emerging discussion is "capacity building." The underlying philosophy is that development has been held back in the world's poorest countries by a lack of qualified local officials and entrepreneurs. Implicit in this change, too, is the idea that working through central governments is a recipe for waste.
Many donors say they want to encourage decentralization and reinforce democratic practices, to which most lenders have paid only lip service in the past.
"For too long development cooperation has focused on the economy and not on the polity," said James Gustave Speth, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, which has just launched a $25 billion development program for Africa that is is driven by a "capacity-building" ethic. "Without a functioning political system and effective governance, the best-laid economic plans are not going to succeed."
 
 
 
Fattening the Elites
 Many critics of international development assistance are far from certain that this shift will make aid "work" in the future. But what is certain, they say, is that the approaches of the past have mostly failed.
In a research paper published last fall, Peter Boone, a professor at the London School of Economics, concluded that development assistance had fattened political elites and spawned a thriving global community of non-governmental organizations, but had done little to improve living standards in poor countries. "In terms of human development, I looked at things like primary school enrollment, infant mortality and life expectancy in 97 countries between 1970 and 1990, and there was no correlation between these sorts of indicators and development assistance," Mr. Boone said.
The study also compared French-speaking West Africa with its English-speaking neighbors. Although the Francophone countries have consistently enjoyed higher levels of foreign support, Mr. Boone's study indicates that they have little to show for it.
What most separates countries that lift living standards of the poor and those that don't, Mr. Boone concludes, is not the amount of funds, but rather the dedication of third-world governments to resolving basic quality of life issues. "If you look at Chile, they reduced infant mortality by 70 percent because they decided they were going to make that their priority," Mr. Boone said. "A leftist government in Kerala state in India did the same thing."
 
 
 
A Source of Anger
 In the developing world, calls to bypass central governments and impose closer scrutiny on the use of aid funds have already brought one unexpected type of response: anger at the perceived cynicism in how the West has used development monies in the past for the good of companies and privately-run groups known as non-governmental organizations (like the Red Cross or Church World Services) back home.
"Experience in many places suggests that there are many who are jumping on the N.G.O. bandwagon for reasons that have nothing to do with development as such," said Kwesi Botchway, a former Ghanaian minister of finance who spoke at a major international conference on development in Maastricht, Holland in November. "Some promote narrow sectarian interests even as they purport to advance popular aspirations. Some see N.G.O.'s as plain business."
Other advocates of profound reforms in foreign aid see a self-interested West as the root of many past failures as well. "A lot of the aid given in the 70's and 80's was fueled by cold war competition or by the ambitions of the French," said Mats Karlssen, Sweden's Under Secretary of State. "If you really wanted to make an impact on things like child mortality or illiteracy, I could have told you from the beginning that that kind of aid would not have any impact." He also said donors shouldn't continually impose their own thinking about development, and instead need "stronger policies from the borrowers themselves."
Where these two schools of thought come together is in the need for foreign donors to give greater encouragement to countries where real democratization is taking place -- places. Mr. Boone said, where "the poor are more empowered," and where "this induces governments to provide more basic services."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 591 words

HEADLINE: The Freedom to Marry

 BODY:
Chances are that Americans will look back 30 years from now and wonder what all the fuss was about. At the moment, however, the question of opening the institution of marriage to homosexuals is the subject of an emotional national debate taking place at family dinner tables, state legislatures and in the press.
A "marriage protection" rally in Des Moines on the eve of the Iowa Republican caucuses drew predictable support from Patrick Buchanan in person, but also written support from the party's presumptive nominee, Senator Bob Dole. Opponents of same-sex marriages invoke religious tradition and family values. Allowing same-sex couples to marry, they assert, would somehow diminish the meaning of marriage for heterosexuals. These arguments, uncomfortably similar to those raised in resistance to repealing miscegenation laws a few decades ago, cannot obscure the entrenched anti-gay bigotry underlying much of the public dialogue. Nor can it disguise the fundamental unfairness of government denying a whole class of citizens the important benefits that flow from civil marriages. 
 What brings the issue to the fore is the likelihood that a court case in Hawaii will soon lead to that state's legal recognition of same-sex marriages. In 1993, Hawaii's top court ruled -- not unreasonably -- that the state's refusal to marry same-sex couples violated Hawaii's constitutional guarantee of equal protection. Unlike its Federal counterpart, Hawaii's Constitution explicitly prohibits discrimination based on sex. The state now has the burden of showing in a trial court proceeding that it has a "compelling interest" in perpetuating the state ban on same-sex unions -- an appropriately high hurdle that experts predict the state will be unable to meet.
Indeed, if the state has a "compelling interest" here, it is to foster stable, long-term relationships and to clarify important legal and economic issues. Allowing marriage by same-sex couples would surely do that on matters of joint property, inheritance, insurance coverage and other important household business. Contrary to rhetoric on the other side, this is the real family values issue.
Unhappy with the direction of the court ruling, the Hawaiian Legislature passed a new law asserting that marriage is "intended for the propagation of the human race by man-woman units." But that rationale collapses under the reality that many heterosexual couples are infertile, choose not to have children or simply marry past childbearing age. On the other hand, many gay and lesbian couples do end up raising children. In other contexts, the U.S. Supreme Court has said that civil marriage rights do not flow from procreation but from the commitment and choice of couples.
Meanwhile, opponents led by religious fundamentalists have mounted a pre-emptive campaign aimed at getting other states to enact laws to prevent recognition of same-sex marriages performed in Hawaii. Last week, Georgia became the fourth state to enact such a law. Though similar measures have failed in 12 states, battles still rage in 15 others. This could create an absurd, demeaning and unconstitutional situation where marriages lawful in one state would suddenly be void when a couple crossed state lines. The backlash against same-sex marriages is driven by social intolerance, but it also poses an ominous challenge to the nation's Federal system of laws, and the basic requirement in the U.S. Constitution that states give "full faith and credit" to the legal actions taken by other states.

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
The Cost of Luxury Could Blow Sky-High

BYLINE: By JON E. HILSENRATH; Jon E. Hilsenrath is a Knight-Bagehot Fellow in economics and business journalism at Columbia.

 BODY:
There is a dirty word in real estate markets that probably won't be uttered by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or by the Yankees owner George Steinbrenner in the months ahead, as the terms of a new baseball stadium are negotiated. The word is overbuilding.
With his remarks last week about building a new stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan, Giuliani joined a legion of municipal officials nationwide who have pledged hundreds of millions of dollars to build lavish new stadiums for their teams. 
 Nearly $7 billion has been committed or spent in the last three years to build or renovate more than 30 major sports facilities across the country, according to Marc Ganis, the owner of SportsCorp, a Chicago-based sports consulting firm. And that does not include the millions more committed to build smaller facilities in cities like Newark, which announced last week it plans to build a 6,000-seat stadium downtown to revive minor league baseball in the city.
One of the secret ingredients in almost all of these deals is the luxury box. Each of these plush suites produces five- and six-figure revenue streams that help finance the stadiums. They also produce rich rewards for the owners who oversee them.
The proposed Manhattan facility would include 120 to 220 luxury boxes, compared with the paltry 19 boxes in 73-year-old Yankee Stadium, which is near the major league low.
But sports business professionals quietly say the industry might be going through a period of overbuilding. They say there is a limit to the amount of money that businesses are willing to spend to entertain clients and executives in suites that loom over playing fields.
"Companies are not going to double their sky-box budgets," said Allen Sanderson, a University of Chicago economist who also teaches sports business. "I think overbuilding is a legitimate risk."
These markets, after all, are subject to outside shocks. Consider, for example, the luxury-box business in Dallas. Today, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, wields 360 luxury suites at Texas Stadium, the most in professional sports. They helped generate $37.3 million in stadium revenues in 1994.
But luxury suites were not always a boon to the Cowboys. In 1989, when Jones bought the team, the Texas economy was in a deep recession, the team was 3-13 and the Cowboys were having trouble making money on those deluxe boxes. Tex Schramm, formerly the general manager and president, had built 108 new suites in 1985. By 1989, 102 of them were still unsold and many could not be leased, said George Hays, vice president of marketing for the Cowboys. Sales improved only as the economy and the Cowboys did.
What happens when the economy slows? Will corporations be able to justify $250,000 suites for football games? What happens if labor-management strife continues? Last year, several baseball teams saw longstanding suite residents cancel their subscriptions when the strike delayed the start of the season.
Very often, taxpayers will get hurt if municipalities and teams over-build. Stadium expansions are often publicly financed and suite revenues help make payments on the debt needed to pay for the construction. Furthermore, in some places, like St. Louis, teams have been guaranteed revenue from the suites.
"I don't think with luxury suites, it's an if-you-build-it-they-will-come scenario," said Robert Caporale, a partner in Glan Plan Inc., a Boston-based investment banking and consulting firm. His firm was an adviser in the recent construction of the new Fleet Center in Boston. Caporale said a great deal of planning and marketing went into the construction of the 104 suites in the Fleet Center. But he worries that in many other cities, suites are being constructed at great cost and in great haste, but with little foresight.
"In many of these communities, nothing is happening on the planning side," he said. "Who's going to buy them? Who's going to sell them?"
Consider the rapid expansion under way at the Oakland-Alameda County Stadium in California, home of football's Raiders and baseball's Athletics. It is in the process of expanding its luxury suites from the 45 currently available to 140 for the next football season, an increase of 311 percent.
Ezra Rapport, Oakland's deputy city manager who is involved in marketing the suites, said the expansion is a "roller-coaster ride." He added, "Everything we do is on a really tight schedule."
And now, in the midst of that rapid expansion, voters across the bay in San Francisco have approved plans for the construction of a privately financed stadium for the baseball Giants. "It's not just the number of new facilities, it's how closely together they are being built," said SportsCorp's Ganis.
In the Baltimore-Washington area, a basketball and hockey arena is being constructed in downtown Washington. A
new football stadium for the Redskins is planned for Maryland. And Washington has long sought a baseball team. When the Browns move to Baltimore and become the Ravens, the Baltimore-Washington area could have close to 600 sky boxes for rent. That dwarfs the 328 luxury suites available in the New York market, an area with more teams, more events annually and a much larger business community.
"Where are all of the corporations going to come from?" asked Jeff Turner of Brailsford Associates, a Washington-based sports consulting firm. Are there enough lobbyists in Washington to fill all of these suites? Perhaps.
Bill Dorsey, executive director of the Association of Luxury Suite Directors, acknowledges that he and others are concerned about overbuilding in some markets. "There's been a lot of talk about saturation, and what the market will bear," Dorsey said. His association has grown from 13 members six years ago to 250 members today.
So far, the classic signs of overbuilding have not emerged. The most important indicator of overbuilding in real estate markets is the vacancy rate in office buildings. During the last recession, vacancy rates were more than 30 percent in some parts of Texas, and more than 20 percent in parts of California. But Dorsey said luxury suites are a healthy 90-95 percent full nationwide.
Another important indicator is leasing rates. When markets become saturated, it becomes more difficult for developers to raise rental prices. But Dorsey said rental prices have generally been rising, as the quality of the suites also rises. Lease rates range from $15,000 in cities like Green Bay, Wis., to $250,000 in Toronto and Boston, according to Dorsey.
But overbuilding happens when markets are booming.
Dorsey said he worries about places like Tampa, which is in the midst of a rapid expansion in luxury suites. In the fall, the Tampa Bay Lightning hockey team will move to a new arena with 72 additional suites. Baseball's expansion Tampa Bay Devil Rays will occupy the Thunderdome with more than 70 new luxury suites. The N.F.L. Buccaneers house 57 suites at Tampa Stadium, and ownership is looking for more.
"Corporations, like individuals, just have so many dollars to go around," said Larry Silver, a spokesman for Raymond James & Associates, a Tampa-based brokerage firm. He said Raymond James has begun splitting time in luxury boxes with other firms. "This community is stretched, like a lot of communities," he said.
"The market is very competitive," said Charlotte Martin, manager of corporate sales and marketing for the Lightning, acknowledging that many local companies are complaining that they are "really strapped."
To date, the Lightning has leased 54 of 72 suites at the Ice Palace, which is scheduled to open in October. Can the Buccaneers fill the suites if ownership gets the stadium it is looking for?
"I don't know if they're going to sell them," Martin said.
"You just can't bleed a stone," Silver said.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Ronald H. Brown;
How to Elect a President: The Campaign Strategy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
WHEN Ronald H. Brown died in a plane crash in Croatia last week, the nation lost an energetic and successful commerce secretary -- a man who crisscrossed the globe with American business executives, arm-twisting foreign governments to buy anything stamped "Made in U.S.A." But for President Clinton the loss was particularly acute: He called Mr. Brown the single most important strategist in the 1992 Presidential campaign.
His talent was honing a message, reducing it to its essence. Recently Mr. Brown worried in private meetings that that the current re-election campaign -- which he could not formally join because of investigations into his financial dealings -- still lacked energy, a sharp focus, a clear message, a tactical plan. 
 A confidential memo he sent to Democratic leaders four years ago, before Bill Clinton emerged as the party's nominee, provides an intriguing insight into the workings of Ron Brown's political mind. As the following excerpts suggest, it is also filled with advice that both President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole might consider in 1996, as well as a few passages that may make the White House wonder if it is now vulnerable to similar charges to the ones it leveled at George Bush.
Mr. Brown, who was then the Democratic National Chairman, suggested belittling Mr. Bush's argument that his foreign policy focused on creating jobs at home. Just the week before the memo was written, Mr. Bush had taken a bickering gang of auto executives to Tokyo in a trip that turned out to be politically damaging. As Commerce Secretary, Mr. Brown turned similar trips into a political asset. To Mr. Brown, who seemed to light up whenever conversation turned to election strategy, that was the kind of political irony that made Washington interesting. DAVID E. SANGER
 
Extremely Confidential -- Draft 3 -- Extremely Confidential
To: Senior Democratic Leadership
From: Chairman Brown
Date: Jan. 17, 1992
Re: Some Strategic Thoughts About the Message That Helps Bring About George Bush's Defeat
 
George Bush has suffered the biggest one-year collapse of approval ratings of any President in history. George Bush has presided over the lowest growth Presidency of the postwar period. . . . However, we should have no illusions. Defeating a sitting President, especially one who has himself "won" a war, is a difficult challenge indeed.
 
What We Have to Do in 1992
Identify and understand the concerns of the voters who are open to a Democratic appeal. No matter what we say or do Barbara Bush and about 40 percent of the country will vote Republican. Our message focus is on the remaining 60 percent: both ticket-splitting, "persuadable" voters as well as the Democratic base -- voters who also need to be "asked" and mobilized.
Fortunately from a message perspective, the country's economic and domestic social problems are so pervasive that the level of agreement between ticket-splitters and Democratic base voters is the highest it has been in decades.
Virtually all (more than 95 percent) of these potential supporters -- no matter what race, gender or income/employment status -- think of themselves as middle class. Frankly, the middle-class tax cut has more value to use as a "strengthening chord" to expand our middle-class identification than it does as an element of Democratic economics, where it also helps.
Every instance where Bush sounds defensive (e.g. "I really do have a domestic agenda; I really do know the pain that ordinary Americans, and especially the unemployed who have exhausted benefits, are feeling") is an example of forcing BUSH into the Democratic message framework. By doing such, in effect, we are forcing the theme of "I'm not who the Democrats say I am" into the G.O.P. Message Structure. . . .
 
Stick to a unified criticism of Bush's leadership failures. I believe, on the basis of substantial survey evidence as well as my own travels across the country, that by working together we have already established three things:
 
1. Bush is way too concerned with foreign policy at the sacrifice of his domestic and economic responsibilities to the American people. In effect, his foreign policy "strength" is being made into a weakness. Our success is measured by the amount of effort they are spending trying to counter this theme with their recent "foreign policy is really an economic and domestic jobs-creating effort" message.
 
2. The elitist George (Herbert Walker) Bush favors the rich and powerful special interests and just doesn't understand what the lives and problems of ordinary Americans are like now. His inaction is a natural consequence of his just not "getting it."
 
3. Most of what Bush is saying and doing is POLITICAL, designed to halt his support hemorrhage and snare votes in the short term. It is all "photo ops" expressing a superficial concern by someone who is dodging the real changes that need to be made -- changes that will hit his pals and his interests hard if they are ever to help the ordinary American.
 
WE MUST KEEP POUNDING AWAY AT SEVERAL MORE THINGS.
A. What is wrong with the country is exactly what is wrong with George Bush's leadership. He and his Administration are drifting, maybe with his heart in the right place but WITHOUT THE ABILITY TO GET THE JOB DONE, WITH PLENTY OF TALK BUT NO FOLLOW THROUGH. Do they understand that "the buck stops here" is the core of the modern Presidency? ...
B. Trickle-down, supply-side economics is making us a second-class economic power and is killing the middle class. But BUSH DOESN'T KNOW IT. HE IS INCAPABLE OF CHANGE. It is the end of a Republican JUNK-BOND VALUES era, and they are OUT OF IDEAS, OUT OF GAS, OUT OF LUCK, and soon to be OUT OF OFFICE.
Answer immediately and ferociously every G.O.P. slur. When they use "wedge issues," racial code words and "exotic" social value charges, we must denounce these tactics as the un-American politics of demagoguery. This garbage trivializes a fundamental decision time in our country's history and will prevent us for another four or more years from confronting our real challenges. LAY THESE GROSS G.O.P. tactics at Bush's door.
 
OUR MOST IMPORTANT MESSAGE TASK
Put forth a CLEAR, ALTERNATIVE, AFFIRMATIVE, POLICY AGENDA and DIRECTION for our country's central challenges AND FIGHT FOR IT. . . .
 
We Democrats need to speak frankly and often about personal responsibility, knowing right from wrong and being prepared to punish wrong, loving our country and the American ideal, hard work, and caring about those who need help (the safety net has been shredded).
Policies that Are Important to Our Future Which Strain the Republican Presidential Coalition
* pro-choice
* environment
* children and poverty
* anti-racism
* fair trade and job exports
I believe that anti-incumbency is centrally tied to the appearance of lots of Washington time and work on things voters see as marginal to their lives in this time of economic threat. If we keep our eyes on the prize and approach the major, basic issues with common-sense approaches, then we will, in 1992, elect a larger Congressional majority -- as well as a Democratic President.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
And Now, the Kinder, Gentler Merger

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
PACIFIC TELESIS and SBC Communications made a bit of history last week -- and not just because they became the first of the Baby Bells to grow up and get married. In announcing their $17 billion merger, the two regional Bell telephone companies promised not to dismiss any workers.
In fact, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the plain-spoken chairman of SBC (originally Southwestern Bell), said the deal would generate 1,000 new jobs in California, where SBC plans to offer long-distance telephone service. "The union of these companies is not about layoffs," Mr. Whitacre declared. 
 In this decade of downsizing, such a pledge sounds almost heretical. By promoting the merger as a job creator rather than a job destroyer, Mr. Whitacre is flouting the conventional wisdom on Wall Street about how to sell such deals to shareholders. But he feels that SBC's broader horizons will enrich its 100,000 workers -- everyone from cable splicers to senior executives -- bringing both a robust share price and swift government approval of its deal.
To many industry experts, Mr. Whitacre's rhetoric is the latest evidence that downsizing is itself being downsized, at least up to a point. In addition to SBC, several other companies have either soft-pedaled the role of layoffs in their new corporate combinations, or held up their commitment to job security as a virtue in announcing mergers.
For that, rank-and-file workers can probably thank the odd combination of a politician and the nation's largest phone company. In January, AT&T said it would slash 40,000 jobs, one of the biggest corporate bloodlettings ever. Patrick J. Buchanan promptly made downsizing, and the anxiety it causes, a theme of his Presidential campaign.
With his harsh criticism of AT&T's top executives, Mr. Buchanan managed to turn the company's layoffs -- which it had blandly justified as a response to technological change -- into a symbol of corporate America's ruthless pursuit of profits over the welfare of the worker. Newsweek even placed AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, in a police lineup of chief executives on its cover, under the headline "Corporate Killers."
"AT&T has had to face withering criticism," said John Challenger, vice president of Challenger, Grey & Christmas, a Chicago "outplacement" firm, which helps companies find jobs for employees who have been laid off. "We're beginning to see some authentic efforts to redress the loss of good will that has come from downsizing."
 
Reading Political Tea Leaves
But if these companies are astutely reading the political winds -- and backing it up with a real commitment to saving jobs -- they may not be pursuing the soundest business course. The economic pressures that drive corporate downsizing have not gone away. Indeed, few companies face the triple whammy of global competition, technological change and demand for stock performance more keenly than the Baby Bells. Given that, some industry experts wonder if all the talk about jobs is merely a public-relations ploy.
SBC is not the only company that has tried to turn the ambient fear over layoffs to its advantage. First Bank recently used the threat of downsizing as ammunition in its takeover battle for a big Los Angeles bank, First Interstate. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, had mounted a rival bid for the bank, contending that it could extract huge savings by shutting down 400 neighboring branches and dismissing the employees.
So First Bank, which is based in faraway Minneapolis, took out full-page ads in California newspapers to dramatize its more benign intentions. The bank said it would reduce only 6,000 positions, while it claimed that Wells Fargo would whack 10,000 jobs. In case the arithmetic didn't make the point, the ads carried a headline warning: "It's not a fire, flood, or an earthquake. But it could be a disaster for California." In the end, First Bank lost out to Wells Fargo's richer bid.
After weeks of drubbing from Mr. Buchanan and other critics, AT&T has tried to put a human face on its financial engineering. In a recent Newsweek column responding to the magazine's cover story, Mr. Allen wrote about the personal anguish he suffered in ordering the cutbacks. The company also recently published full-page ads in The New York Times and other newspapers urging other companies to consider hiring people laid off by AT&T.
"If this were a prize fight of 12 rounds," said Burke Stinson, an AT&T spokesman who has helped shape the company's strategy, "I would say we lost round one; we lost round two; we fought to a draw in round three; and pretty soon, we'll start winning rounds."
Even companies that are still promoting deals because of their cost savings are playing down layoffs. Aetna Life and Casualty, which announced last week that it would acquire U.S. Healthcare, promised to generate $300 million in savings by melding the two insurance companies. But in the same press release, Aetna said, "We will be sensitive to the interests of our employees."
Such warm but vague pledges make some observers wonder how sincere the companies are about about their promises. Executives at rival phone companies, for example, said they doubted that SBC could avoid wholesale cutbacks. "You just know there are headquarters staffs and other corporate functions that will overlap," Mr. Challenger said.
Times Mirror has devised a novel way to deal with such skepticism. The publishing company, which has announced sweeping job cuts at its newspapers, recently announced that it would sell its educational publishing division. But Times Mirror wants these employees to stay in their jobs. So it awarded them a $1,000 bonus to remain with the company through its transition to a new owner. Of course, once the company changes hands, all bets are off.

HEADLINE: Suicide Rates Are Rising for the Unpopular, Harassed Police Force in Paris

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 5

 BODY:
Parisians do not have warm feelings for their police. Older people remember them as collaborating with the German occupiers. Middle-aged Parisians still resent their rough repression of the 1968 student movement.
To some young people, "les flics" are walking emblems of the state, who are fun to taunt, insult and, when possible, bombard with bottles and stones. 
 But an emerging secret is making the police look lonely, harassed and vulnerable -- in short, more human. According to their union, a growing number of French police officers are committing suicide.
Last year, a record 60 police officers took their own lives, 50 percent more than the average for the last decade. At least 24 have killed themselves this year. The rate is highest in Paris -- almost twice the rate for New York City's police.
These cases are not normally reported here, but a spate of suicides last month, set off uncommon news coverage and alarmed and embarrassed the Government. Within one week, one officer was found hanging in his garage in the northern city of Arras, while near Paris two others killed themselves with their service revolvers. In January, an officer shot her three children, then herself.
"The cops are scorned by the public and badly treated by their superiors," said Dominique Borde, a prominent Paris lawyer. "No wonder they feel bad."
Jean Louis Debre, the Interior Minister, has hastily promised more psychologists and more medical check-ups to monitor stress among the men and women in uniform and pledged that higher-ups would pay more attention to the needs of the rank and file.
"The police are under constant stress," said Guy Maurin, a police union official. "And they take their stress home, so there are a lot of domestic problems."
The strain is all the more unrelenting, Mr. Maurin said, because there are few places to turn for counseling. "If someone is troubled, is quiet or is depressed, well, that is his problem. There are exceptions, but many bosses are rigid and aloof. All they do is order or punish their staff."
From conversations with police officers on the street and with union and social workers, a picture emerges of a profession in which no matter how tough some of its members appear to be, they in many ways have become scapegoats for the growing anger in French society.
The police say the pressure brought on by economic crisis, joblessness, racial tension and drug abuse often falls on them. Increasingly, they have to cope with angry youths and tough gangs in big city suburbs, which are France's social equivalent of America's inner cities. Pressures on the police worsened last year, when the country suffered a wave of terrorist attacks in the summer and national strikes accompanied by unruly demonstrations in the winter.
The police say that as their duties have grown more difficult, their professional work conditions have worsened. Because of cutbacks, they say they are understaffed and underpaid, and many feel chronically stressed.
In turn, they have often been accused of brutality, which helps explain some of the public's hostility. In a recent report, Amnesty International said the French police were especially abusive toward North African youths in poor neighborhoods.
On a dark corner near the St. Lazare train station the other night, two young officers, speaking on condition of anonymity, talked of their troubles.
"It's the stupid way our bosses treat us," said one, explaining that he had just finished four days of guard duty at a Government building. This meant he had to stay in one spot. Yet at the end of his tour, his boss reprimanded him for not delivering his quota of fines.
Police officers on street duty in Paris are expected to collect at least 10 fines a day for driving offenses. "Otherwise you're not considered a good cop," one said.
Morale problems are biggest in the Paris region, where young recruits are brought in from the provinces because public contempt for the police makes it hard to find local men and women. Mr. Maurin, the union official, said that of the 24,000 police officers stationed in the Paris area, 14,000 have asked to return home.
"We're cut off from our family, cut off from our friends, and we get insulted here," said a young rookie from Nice, who was patrolling an area of rowdy nightclubs behind Bastille Square.
The other officer, from Brittany, said he could not wait to get back there. In Paris, he said, he and his wife and two young children could hardly survive on the standard salary for rookies, about $1,500 a month, or 20 percent more than minimum wage. By comparison, a rookie in New York City, which is less expensive than Paris, earns $2,300.
"I had a lot of illusions about being in public service," he said. But some days, he said, he feels surrounded by hostility on the streets. Some days he ends up fighting running battles with demonstrators.
Back at the station, there is the hazing and barking from his superiors. "There seems to be no way ever to decompress," he said.
The suicides that were reported have involved the country's 120,000-member National Police. There have been similar troubles among the gendarmes, the paramilitary police who number about 80,000 and are under Defense Ministry jurisdiction, but their suicide numbers have not been disclosed.
At the union office of the National Police, Mr. Maurin's list of grievances is long. The union has asked for improvement of the "archaic training" at the one-year Police Academy, where much time is devoted to learning laws and when to levy fines. "We need courses on how to communicate with people, how to understand the behavior of immigrants from other cultures," Mr. Maurin said.
A black female officer from the French West Indies has complained to the union of racism, saying that at the station, her colleagues spray the rooms when she walks through.
One officer, whose wife had just left him and their three small children, said he had explained his difficulties to his superiors, but was punished every time he arrived late.
Another has repeatedly asked to move back to Auch, his hometown in the southeast, because in Mantes-la-Jolie, a Paris suburb, he says his wife is harangued on the street and his children are pestered in school because of his job.
Interior Minister Debre has argued that police officers have no higher suicide rates than other French citizens. But in a recent report to the Interior Ministry, Frederique Mezza-Beliet said the suicide rate among police officers, most of them of low rank and aged 30 to 40, was one-third higher than that of others of similar age. She cited unstable family lives, job stress and easy access to firearms.
Officers often leave suicide notes, according to Patrick Oribes, who is in charge of investigating these deaths. One recent note was left by an officer who two years ago was accused of killing a man unnecessarily during a gunfight. The investigation and trial took eight months. By the time the court agreed that the officer had acted in legitimate self-defense, he had fallen into a deep depression.
A few weeks ago, he was involved in an almost identical situation. In his suicide note, he said he could not bear to relive the episode.
"He got no support or understanding from his superiors," Mr. Maurin said. "They might well have saved his life."
