HEADLINE: The Right to Suicide, Some Worry, Could Evolve Into a Duty to Die

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Now that two Federal appeals courts have lifted bans on physician-assisted suicide, many in medicine are struggling with a tormenting question: Will the right to die become the duty to die?
They wonder if the sick and the disabled will feel pressure -- either self-imposed or from relatives -- to choose suicide over prolonged and inevitably futile treatment, particularly at a time when health care dollars are increasingly limited. They even raise the specter of the right to assisted suicide leading to euthanasia. 
 "People who are sick already feel that they are a financial and emotional burden to their families and to society," said Lisa Gigliotti, a lawyer for the Michigan Protection and Advocacy Service, a lobbying group for people with disabilities. "Now society is telling them, 'You have an option. You have the right to die.' For them, this translates easily into an obligation to die."
Society is already grappling with the imposition of economic limits on medical care. To save money, managed care plans often dictate which doctors patients can see, limit access to costly tests and demand shorter hospital stays.
But the decision on Tuesday by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, freeing doctors to help terminally ill patients commit suicide, raises the stakes and the fears in that struggle: Death is suddenly not an unfortunate result of treatment withheld, but a real option in the treatment arsenal.
To some doctors and patients, that option is a blessing, offering a quick end to those with agonizing illnesses. But there are many who worry that even if the state regulates assisted suicide, sick patients, afraid of bankrupting their family, will feel it is their only choice.
These opponents of the ruling, which struck down parts of a New York ban on assisted suicide, say they fear that doctors, poorly trained in pain treatment and pressed by managed care companies to avoid such costly therapies, will put implicit pressure on their patients to choose suicide by not offering them acceptable alternatives.
"In an era of economic limits, the consequences of this decision are limitless," said Burke Balch, director of medical ethics for the National Right to Life Committee. "The acceptance of death as a medical management option in an era of health care limits and managed care creates a duty and not merely a right."
Furthermore, critics of the decision say it can lead to involuntary euthanasia through the use of surrogates. Existing law allows surrogates to withhold life support for mentally incompetent patients. Now, will it also allow surrogates to decide that a terminally ill person should be given a lethal dose of medication?
Surrogates could gain this power, the the critics pointed out, as an expansion of the court's ruling, which held that there was an inherent inequality in existing law, which allowed terminally ill patients to hasten their deaths by withdrawing or withholding life sustaining treatment; for those whose illness did not demand such treatment, however, there was no avenue to a quicker death. Patients in each of those situations, the court ruled, should be treated equally.
Ms. Gigliotti said euthanasia was the extreme danger of allowing terminally ill patients to hasten their death by "commission rather than omission."
She and others question whether such decisions would be made in the best interest of patients, or because of economic pressures.
"I'm scared of the whole medical system in terms of economics," said Rashi Fein, a professor who teaches the economics of medicine at Harvard Medical School. "This is an area where there is tremendous economic advantage to not getting involved with keeping people going. But I come down grudgingly on the side that regulation can come much closer to keeping us honest than the unregulated, underground system we have now."
Critics of assisted suicide -- among them many religious leaders -- think the danger of economics motivating the decision to choose suicide or to impose it on a mentally incompetent person are too acute to be regulated safely. The National Conference of Catholic Bishops, for one, has promised to wage a campaign against assisted suicide equal to the group's efforts opposing abortion, including pressing for an appeal to the Supreme Court and trying to influence political debate.
Laurence Tribe, a professor of constitutional law at Harvard and an expert on health law, said such fears were exaggerated. "There are far greater economic pressures on patients who must maintain expensive life-sustaining treatment than on those forced to endure painful, drawn-out illnesses where no such therapy is available," he said. "And there has been no evidence that people in those situations are being pushed to withdraw treatment because of the high cost."
Regulating assisted suicide might actually reduce the need for it, said Dr. Howard Grossman, a Manhattan internist who was a plaintiff in the New York lawsuit. The laws, he said, would probably compel insurers to pay for more psychiatric care and pain management therapy than they do now, mitigating a patient's desire to die. Any rules, he explained, would probably require that before acceding to a patient's request to die, doctors must exhaust other treatments, evaluate a patient's mental health and demonstrate that the patient's wishes were not swayed by efforts to control pain.
"There are some very valid fears that need to be addressed, but I think we can address them through regulation," said Dr. Grossman, who conceded that some doctors have quietly defied the ban on assisted suicide and helped terminally ill patients eager to end their doomed and painful lives.
There are those, however, who say that the ruling by the court in New York and a similar decision by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco should provoke a much-needed, though generally avoided, debate about the economic realities of the current health care market. Leonard M. Fleck, a professor of philosophy and medical ethics at Michigan State University's medical school, contends that in an era of limited financing for health care, assisted suicide is a legitimate option for doctors to offer terminally ill patients near the end of life.
"The need for health care rationing is inescapable because the parameters for adding care expand each day," he said. "The moral challenge is to come up with approaches that are open, rational and democratic, but that limit marginally beneficial and non-costworthy care. In my opinion, there are no good options given the current situation, but assisted suicide is the least worst option."
Daniel Callahan, the president of the Hastings Center, a research institute that focuses on biomedical ethical issues, is repelled by the thought of assisted suicide as an answer to limited health care resources. "It is one thing to talk about cutting corners to find cheaper ways to handle the soaring costs of health care," said Dr. Callahan. "But we are talking about forcing death, or at the very least, coercing it or encouraging it."

HEADLINE: New Poll Finds Strength for Dole On Personal and Political Traits

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
Though Senator Bob Dole was ridiculed by his rivals in the Republican primaries as unelectable in November, he shows considerable strength against President Clinton on many traits, including leadership, personal values and his vision for the country, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
The findings set the stage for what could be a closely matched general election contest. Despite Mr. Dole's greater personal appeal, Mr. Clinton continues to maintain a comfortable lead over him in trial heats, in part because many voters say they want the President re-elected if for no other reason than to have a check on the Republican Congress. 
 The poll also found that if Ross Perot entered the race as a third-party contender -- and if the race were held today -- he would take votes evenly from Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, and would draw 18 percent, almost matching the 19 percent that Mr. Perot won in 1992.
Another reason that Mr. Dole's relatively high personal ratings might not be translating into broader support at this early point is that the public's image of the Republican Party has sunk to 41 percent favorable, the lowest level since The Times and CBS News began asking the question 12 years ago.
For months, voter surveys have hinted at an emerging disenchantment with the Republican Party. Polls show that voters blame Republicans for the shutdown of the Federal Government last fall and winter, and that the fractious Republican primaries compounded their concerns.
Many continue to say they are impatient with Speaker Newt Gingrich, who is considered by nearly one-third of voters to be the leader of the Republican Party. The decline in good will toward Republicans has occurred since August, the last time Mr. Dole prevailed over Mr. Clinton in a head-to-head matchup.
Yet, in terms of personal qualities, Mr. Dole might be enjoying a burst of popularity because he has the aura of a victor after rolling over his rivals in the last two dozen primaries.
The survey also suggests that Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, has succeeded in emphasizing his roots from a poor family in a small town in Kansas who understands the hardships of ordinary Americans.
And he has maintained that image even though he had to endure vituperative attacks from Steve Forbes, the magazine publisher who spent millions of dollars in a television blitzkrieg in the early primaries, and Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator. The President, on the other hand, did not face a primary challenger this year.
Now that the primary phase is abruptly over and the candidates gear up for the general election, Mr. Dole's standing with the broader general electorate moves to the forefront. The Times/CBS News Poll of 1,257 adults nationwide was conducted from March 31 to April 2 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The survey found that Mr. Dole scored better than Mr. Clinton among registered voters in several areas. Seventy percent said Mr. Dole has a vision of where he wants to lead the country; 62 percent said that of Mr. Clinton. (By comparison, earlier polls of Republican primary voters found that they were split over whether they believed Mr. Dole had new ideas.)
The new poll also found that 70 percent believe Mr. Dole shares the moral values most Americans try to live by; 59 percent said that of Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Dole matched or exceeded Mr. Clinton on the question of leadership, even though incumbent Presidents have historically had the advantage. Sixty-three percent said Mr. Dole has strong qualities of leadership; 58 percent said that of Mr. Clinton.
The President does a bit better than the presumptive Republican nominee when voters were asked if each man cared about the needs and problems of people like them. Sixty-one percent cited Mr. Clinton; 51 percent said that of Mr. Dole. But Democrats almost always score better in this category; Mr. Dole's showing was seven percentage points higher than that of President George Bush in 1992.
The poll shows that both the President and the Senator are closely matched on issues of public policy. Mr. Clinton is viewed as somewhat more inclined to make sure that the Social Security system has enough money to provide benefits for current contributors, but the difference is only 54 percent to 46 percent.
By a similarly close margin, 41 percent to 33 percent, voters believe Mr. Dole is somewhat more likely to reduce the deficit. When asked if each candidate was likely to change welfare the way the voter would like, likely to improve the economy or likely to deal competently with an international crisis, both men were viewed as about equal.
Moreover, while Mr. Dole was viewed as moderate to conservative and Mr. Clinton as moderate to liberal, neither candidate was seen as extreme in his political philosophy.
In trial heats with Mr. Dole, the President has had an advantage since October, and he still does, although the Senator has picked up some support since clinching the Republican nomination. If the election were held today, 49 percent of registered voters said they would back Mr. Clinton, while 39 percent would support Mr. Dole.
One reason Mr. Dole is trailing Mr. Clinton in a head-to-head competition is that many voters seem to want the President as a brake on the Republican Congress. Fifty-three percent said it would be better to re-elect Mr. Clinton as a way to limit the power of Republicans in Congress.
Voters remained divided on legislation produced by the Republicans' Contract With America. And the public's opinion of Mr. Gingrich remains quite negative: 49 percent of voters disapprove of his job performance, while only 32 percent approve.
In a follow-up interview, one of the poll's respondents, Sandra Arnold of Tiverton, R.I., a 39-year-old military researcher, explained her qualified support for Mr. Clinton: "To be honest, Clinton isn't really doing too much for us right now. But I think Clinton would give the Congress a good balance. Republicans, no matter who they are or what their views are, tend to think of themselves as godlike."
Anna Toth, 67, a retired nurse from Pittsburgh, said, "I just don't think it's good for the country if one party has complete control, making all the decisions."
Although the Republican Party's image has waned, both parties are somewhat at parity now: 46 percent hold a favorable view of the Democratic Party, while 41 percent have a favorable view of the Republicans.
In further evidence that the Clinton-Dole matchup might shape up to be especially competitive, the job ratings of both men are quite similar. The President's overall job performance rating is 48 percent approval, while Mr. Dole's is a statistically indistinguishable 52 percent. Mr. Clinton's personal favorability rating is 50 percent, compared with 37 percent for Mr. Dole. But when those with no initial opinion were pressed, Mr. Dole's personal favorability rose to 52 percent, about the same as Mr. Clinton's.
There are, of course, numerous other factors that could affect an election that will be held seven months from now. One-third of the registered voters said, for example, that Mr. Dole's age would be an obstacle to his being an effective President. The Kansan is 72 years old and, if elected, would be the oldest President ever to take office for the first term.
Some voters were far from enthusiastic for Mr. Dole, but they viewed him as their only opportunity to oust Mr. Clinton from the White House.
"It doesn't matter to me if they're Democrats or Republicans, as long as it's not Clinton," said Jim Nareau, a 46-year-old stockbroker from Fort Myers, Fla. "I don't like Clinton's leadership, his personality or his moral standing."
The poll also showed that Democrats should be no less worried than Republicans about Mr. Perot's entering the race. In a three-way trial heat, Mr. Clinton drew 44 percent, Mr. Dole won 33 percent and Mr. Perot got 18 percent. the Texas billionaire's entry reduced Mr. Clinton's vote by five percentage points and Mr. Dole's by six percentage points.
This pattern of pulling evenly from both parties is reinforced when current Perot voters are examined more closely: one-half are independents, one-fourth are Republicans and one-fourth are Democrats.
Despite Gen. Colin L. Powell's insistence that he will not be Mr. Dole's running mate, speculation about such a pairing persists. A trial heat between a ticket of Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore versus Mr. Dole and General Powell was a statistical tie.
One of the respondents, Michael Morganelli of Bullhead City., Ariz., said he was not fond of any of the contenders but would back Mr. Dole because he prefers Republicans.
"A Republican President would work with Congress and sign the bills that would limit the Government," said Mr. Morganelli, 46, a retired construction worker. "Dole's a moderate and would probably bow to special interests. But what choice do we have?"
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 31 to April 2 with 1,257 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,035 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democrats or Republicans or independents taken as a separate group.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in the wording of questions or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
America's Cup Mischief Drives Winner Away

BYLINE: By WILLIAM I. KOCH; Bill Koch is both a member of the New York Yacht Club and the San Diego Yacht Club.

 BODY:
Bill Koch recently decided to abandon any further efforts to race for the America's Cup. Koch successfully defended the cup as skipper in 1992 under the America3 banner, and in 1995, he organized an America3 women's team. That group lost the cup defense trials to Dennis Conner and his Stars & Stripes team. The next America's Cup competition is scheduled for 1999-2000 in New Zealand, but Koch will not be there. His America3 Foundation syndicate will continue to sponsor Olympic sailing, but the America's Cup portion of the office has been closed. Here he explains why.
The America's Cup is the oldest, and reputably the most prestigious trophy in sporting history. As the ultimate sailing trophy, it has been said to represent the greatest in gentlemanly sportsmanship and fair play. Quite the contrary, it represents the worst. 
 To understand this, you have to look at both the history of the cup and the economic impact on the community where the competition is held.
The America's Cup competition started in 1870 when it was deeded to the New York Yacht Club by a group of club members (my ancestor was one of them) who had won it as a result of a gambling venture in 1851. Although the Deed of Gift had the noble purpose to foster "friendly competition between foreign countries," it provided that only yacht clubs could challenge for the cup and that races would be conducted in the home waters and managed by the yacht club that was defending the cup.
The New York Yacht Club had the longest winning streak in sports history, 132 years, winning in 1851, and successfully defending 24 times from 1870 to 1983.
The New York Yacht Club was accused, both unjustly and justly, of changing the rules during the competition, of stacking the jurors and other nasty shenanigans.
During the time the cup went to Australia in 1983 and then to San Diego in 1987, the charges of foul play were so intense that it took a number of lawsuits and four years for the competitive yacht clubs to come to an agreement on how the races should be conducted.
However, that did not change things. In 1992 the race committee of the San Diego Yacht Club moved a mark during one of the defender trials to benefit its favorite competitor. This was the equivalent of moving one competitor's goal line.
As recently as 1995 the San Diego Yacht Club, directly contrary to the rules, gave permission only for its favorite competitor to change his boat by making it faster during a playoff series. All of this greatly detracted from the cup and has turned off the viewing public.
To win the America's Cup requires outstanding management, state-of-the-art technological development, superior athletes and a lot of money. In fact, one of the reasons most nations compete so fanatically for it is that the America's Cup stands for a nation's strength in management, technology and athletics.
If the America's Cup represents a country's nobility and is to foster "friendly competition" among nations, why is there so much unsportsmanlike conduct and even blatant cheating?
The answer is simple. Under the Deed of Gift, the defending yacht club manages the event, and the event itself means a lot of money to the local community. In San Diego, the America's Cup in one year alone produced between $250 million to $500 million in tourist-related business, construction, marina rentals, boat repairs, etc.
That is not inherently evil. What is evil is the fact that the defending yacht club, whose members stand to gain greatly, manage the event. That is equivalent to the hometown picking not only the location of the Super Bowl, but also the field, the referees, umpires and scorekeepers.
Is that fair? No, simply because it asks too much of normally good human beings to resist such overwhelming temptations. As Lord Acton said, "Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely."
Ironically, in spite of all this money, there is very little money for the competitors, except very modest endorsements for the winning skipper. Corporate sponsors get a return for their advertising, but they get much higher returns for advertising on the winning boat. An individual financial backer gets no returns except for whatever psychic gain that comes from the competition.
With the high costs ($25 million to $50 million per team) and no returns for individuals, the sport is no longer for the fabulously wealthy but is now the exclusive domain of the professional sailors/managers and the sponsors. As a result, there is more pressure to win at all costs.
There is a simple way to fix what is wrong with the America's Cup. The competition should be managed by a professional organization that has no interest financial or otherwise in the outcome. That is what every professional sport has done: the N.F.L., the N.B.A., the N.H.L., etc.
Unless the management of the event is changed, the America's Cup in New Zealand in 2000 will be just another version of America's Cup lack of sportsmanship. The cup will continue with its tarnished image. My advice to any competitor is to have such a fast boat, and such a good crew, that you can win no matter how much cheating is done against you. Maybe winning against all those odds is something to be proud of.

HEADLINE: Raymond S. Rubinow, 91, Master of Civic Causes

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Raymond S. Rubinow, a longtime political gadfly and New York civic leader who fought with equal zeal to save Carnegie Hall and demolish Tammany Hall, died on Tuesday at his home in the Esplanade Hotel on West End Avenue in Manhattan. He was 91.
A self-styled philanthropoid who made a science of giving away other people's money, Mr. Rubinow coined the term in Chicago in the 1930's while working for the Julius Rosenwald Fund, the foundation endowed by the founder of Sears, Roebuck. 
 Mr. Rubinow elevated his work to a high art in New York two decades later when he joined the J.M. Kaplan Fund, which had been established in 1947 by Jacob Kaplan, the self-made businessman who had made a fortune by reorganizing the Welch's grape juice company.
As executive director of the fund from 1955 to 1977, Mr. Rubinow was soon in the forefront of virtually every do-good cultural, social and civic cause in the city, often as chairman of some long-named committee seeking to preserve, advance or create a piece of the city's heritage.
His first major success came in the late 1950's when, as chairman of the Joint Emergency Committee to Close Washington Square Park to Traffic, he succeeded in blocking a plan to extend Fifth Avenue through the Greenwich Village park.
Another came in 1960 when, as chairman of the Citizens Committee for Carnegie Hall, he helped save the venerable concert hall from the wrecker's ball after it had been abandoned by the New York Philharmonic for Lincoln Center.
His work to keep traffic out of Washington Square Park made Mr. Rubinow something of a hero to many residents of Greenwich Village, particularly the artists, writers and upscale newcomers whose interests often clashed with those of the older Italian-American community there.
Mr. Rubinow, who had helped form the first citizens' committee to support the election of Mayor Robert F. Wagner in 1953, was soon in the thick of the so-called reform movement to depose Carmine De Sapio, the entrenched leader of the Manhattan Democratic Party whose political power base was in Greenwich Village.
As chairman of the Democratic Mobilization in 1963, Mr. Rubinow helped a young lawyer named Ed Koch defeat Mr. De Sapio as district leader. Together with Mayor Wagner's famous break with the political bosses that year, the victory effectively shattered the power of the Tammany Hall political machine and laid the groundwork for Mr. Koch's later career in Congress and at City Hall.
For Mr. Rubinow, a native of Washington who grew up in New York, his role as an adviser to public figures like Mayor Wagner was something of a family tradition.
His father, I.M. Rubinow, a Russian-born physician who became an eminent American economist and social theorist, is regarded as an intellectual godfather of Social Security, which was created by the Wagner Act of 1936 after being pushed through the Senate by Mayor Wagner's father, Senator Robert F. Wagner.
Mr. Rubinow, who graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received a master's degree in economics from the University of Wisconsin, took a while to hit his stride. But after working briefly for the National Recovery Administration and the Social Security Board in Washington and teaching economics at Swarthmore, he found his niche in foundation work, initially as a consultant and later as an executive of a series of foundations before finding a permanent home with the Kaplan fund.
In the pitched battles between preservationists and developers, Mr. Rubinow was often on the winning side. As chairman of the Emergency Action Committee to Save the Beach at Breezy Point, for example, he helped preserve the Queens beach from development in 1963 and he had a similar triumph in 1965 as chairman of the Committee to Save Madison Square Park.
Not all his campaigns were successful, however. In 1967 he was chairman of the Emergency Civic Committee to Oppose a World Trade Center.
Mr. Rubinow, whose wife, Consuelo Kamholz, died in 1993, is survived by a sister, Dr. Olga Lurie of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 8, 1996, Monday

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Municipal Bond Funds May Be Perking Up

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
THE year did not start out well for municipal bond funds. A roller-coaster ride in interest rates -- especially the sudden rate surge in mid-February -- whipsawed them far more than corporate bond funds.
But in the months ahead, municipal bond funds may begin to provide investors fewer bumps and better returns, many bond analysts say. "Looking out for the next six months, I think it's a pretty decent environment for municipal bonds," said Thomas Kenny, director of the municipal bond department at the Franklin/Templeton fund group. 
 What is behind these changes is a nice improvement in the economic environment: Inflation remains steady and low, keeping a lid on sudden shifts in interest rates; investors are becoming skittish about the sky-high returns on equity funds and are beginning to seek some less-risky tax-free income; yields on municipal bonds hover around an attractive 6 percent range, and investors in some high-tax states can do better on an after-tax basis investing in municipals than in Treasuries.
"As you start seeing those municipal bonds reaching yields of 6 percent, you are beginning to see some buying interest by retail investors," said Mary Miller, a managing director at T. Rowe Price Associates.
The first quarter was truly terrible for municipal bond funds, which vastly underperformed taxable bond funds. According to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company, the average taxable bond fund lost 0.59 percent in the first quarter, compared with an average loss of 1.56 percent for municipals, which are tax free. At the same time, investors who put their money into domestic equity funds enjoyed a 5.58 percent gain, on average.
Municipal funds did even worse than the bonds themselves. In general, said Guy Davidson, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, municipal bonds outperformed Treasury bonds in the quarter on an after-tax basis. But that rosy situation did not extend to municipal funds because so many are filled with bonds of longer maturities -- 20 to 30 years -- which suffered the most because of their sensitivity to sudden shifts in interest rates.
For instance, the Lehman Brothers municipal bond index shows that the average five-year municipal bond had a total return of zero for the quarter just ended -- compared with a 1.6 percent loss for the five-year Treasury bond.
Other factors that depressed the municipal bond market have changed as well. The bonds took a beating in 1995 because of concerns that a flat tax could wipe out their value as tax-exempt instruments and because of creditworthiness questions raised by the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif. But now that the flat tax appears to have become a notion of the past and that Orange County is wending its way out of bankruptcy, investor sentiment appears to be improving. And about half of all new municipal issues are now backed by bond insurance that promises to pay investors even if a municipality goes belly-up.
With municipal bonds, the truism is that funds with shorter-term bonds are less volatile, while those with longer-term bonds are more sensitive to interest-rate swings. When rates rise suddenly and prices drop, as they did in the first quarter, the yields of longer-term funds plummet more than funds with bonds of shorter maturities.
Analysts expect this situation to change in the months ahead, and recommend that investors opt for funds with longer-term bonds -- and then hold them. "We expect low volatility in municipal bond prices over the next nine months," said Ian MacKinnon, a senior vice president at the Vanguard Group.
"We think that it's a good time to be buying municipal bonds, and we are encouraging investors to look at intermediate- and longer-term bonds," he said.
Many municipal bond investors judge their investment on how much after-tax income they receive relative to how much they would get if they put the same amount in a Treasury security. For the last half of 1995, municipal bonds were trading at levels that equaled about 95 percent of Treasury securities -- which gave municipal bonds a far superior after-tax return, especially for high-income investors.
Since, then, as municipal markets have calmed, the ratio has changed. Municipal bonds are now trading at 70 to 85 percent of Treasury securities, depending on the maturity.

HEADLINE: Health Care In the Era of Capitalism

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
FOR all the much-discussed emphasis on the need to cut costs, the health care system still is rich enough to excite deal makers. Witness the $8.9 billion agreement last week for the purchase of U.S. Healthcare Inc., one of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations. The would-be buyer, the Aetna Life & Casualty Company, is an even bigger health insurance company.
Aetna's plans were announced only a few days after a big for-profit hospital chain, the Columbia-HCA Health Corporation, announced an important agreement to buy most of the business of Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield, a policyholder-owned insurance company. 
 Both deals ride the wave of shifting market forces that have shaken health care in the last few years. The movement toward managed care that was so important to the the Clinton Administration's failed attempt to remake the system has in fact accelerated since then, as the percentage of Americans in H.M.O.'s has risen to about 22 percent, from 16 percent in 1992.
 
 
 
Squeezing Doctors and Patients
 During that time, the race to cut costs has brought robust profits for many insurers and hospitals, a squeeze on doctors' incomes and a trend toward tighter discipline for sick Americans, who typically must pay a greater share of their medical costs and have less say in choosing their doctors.
"Market-driven health system reform is occurring faster than Federal legislation and regulators can measure, much less control," said Alain C. Enthoven, a Stanford University economist, in an article he wrote with Sara J. Singer for the spring issue of Health Affairs, a policy journal.
About 58 million people are enrolled in H.M.O.'s and 81 million more in less tightly disciplined varieties of managed health care, by the count of the American Association of Health Plans, a managed care trade group. H.M.O. enrollment is growing by about six million a year, said Rich Hamer, the director of Interstudy Publications, a Minneapolis-based H.M.O. research firm.
Health maintenance organizations have kept a lid on their costs by requiring patients to choose from a limited list of primary-care doctors, who typically must approve any diagnostic tests or referrals to specialists. In most cases, the primary physician is paid a set fee for each person assigned to him by the H.M.O. In many of these arrangements, the doctor may lose money if too many patients require expensive treatment. This can be an incentive to deny needed care, although some H.M.O.'s reward doctors whose patients say they received good treatment.
Most U.S. Healthcare doctors work under this system, and most Aetna doctors do not. Securities analysts expect Aetna's H.M.O.'s to switch to the per-patient model.
Kenneth S. Bernstein, a health care securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said that U.S. Healthcare had trouble getting the best doctors for its network until it started paying more generously two years ago. The higher payments cut into the company's profits, so "the doctors liked them and then the investors hated them," Mr. Bernstein said.
Close to 12 million Medicaid recipients, or 32 percent, are enrolled in H.M.O.'s, as are about four million elderly Americans on Medicare, or about 10 percent of the total. Both Medicare and Medicaid H.M.O.'s are already growing rapidly, and their business would really take off if Congress passes legislation to encourage managed care as a cost-saving measure.
The growth of these H.M.O.'s threatens hospital revenues as they cut back on treatment and hospital stays. Hospital executives said one reason for Columbia-HCA's bid for Ohio Blue Cross was to find a way to start hospital-owned Medicare and Medicaid H.M.O.'s. Columbia would also get Blue Cross-insured customers for its Ohio hospitals.
Naturally, competing hospitals as well as employers who are Blue Cross customers are not thrilled by Columbia's strategy. Some employers also take a skeptical view of the Aetna-U.S. Healthcare deal. "The question is, will it mean lower premiums for the patients and the purchasers?" said Helen Darling, a health care executive with the Xerox Corporation.
 
 
 
Whose Savings?
 John F. Holahan, a health policy expert with the Urban Institute, a research center in Washington, also questioned whether the cost savings from competition among managed care plans "will be eroded through mergers and consolidation."
Nor will any improvements in efficiency help the uninsured, who by most counts now exceed 40 million.
Stuart Butler, a health care economist with the Heritage Foundation, a conservative policy center in Washington, said his concern with the current system was that employers, not patients, pay for health care and call the tune. For example, he said, small employers with a high turnover are unlikely to care about the long-term health of employees' children. Indeed, many small employers no longer insure employees' families.
Mr. Butler would like to make health care benefits less dependent on employer financing, possibly through tax breaks for groups of church or union members.
Uwe E. Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton, lamented that restraints on "raw and joyful entrepreneurship" are falling away. "We can compete brutally on price," he said. "We can allow well-to-do people to have free choice of doctors, and middle-income and lower-income people to lose that free choice. We no longer trouble either the entrepreneur or anyone else over the issue of social equity and over the people who fall through the cracks."

HEADLINE: CUNY, the Vocational University

BYLINE: By Sandi E. Cooper and Dean Savage; Sandi E. Cooper, a history professor at the College of Staten Island, is chairwoman of CUNY's faculty senate. Dean Savage is an associate professor of sociology at Queens College.

 BODY:
Facing the second year of a financial emergency, many faculty members of the City University of New York are worried about the university's direction.
Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds's reorganization is further diminishing its liberal arts orientation and emphasizing vocational preparedness. The students will lose in the long term. 
 America's third largest university system, CUNY is not Traditional U. The student body consists predominantly of poor minority members and poor women. Last year, the valedictorian at City College was a Caribbean-born grandmother.
 We have opted to serve this population an intellectual diet that barely resembles what past graduates feasted on. This is not a result, as conservatives might crow, of political correctness driving curriculum decisions. This is the result of 20 years of fiscal crises, during which several administrations have de-emphasized the liberal arts and introduced numerous vocational programs.
This direction is particularly marked in the newer colleges. In 1976, York College, in Jamaica, gave fewer than 10 percent of its degrees in vocational programs; in 1992 (the latest data available), the figure exceeded 70 percent. In that period, the College of Staten Island's vocational degrees rose from 8 percent to more than 40 percent, and those at Medgar Evers College, in Brooklyn, went from 13 percent to 57 percent. This tendency is also found at the golden oldies -- City College, Queens College and Brooklyn College. (At Hunter College, vocational degrees declined, though it is not clear why.)
Albany insists that the only new programs it will finance are job-related. To attract this financing, liberal arts faculty members are continuously reminded that they must find ways to make their courses "relevant to a job outcome." So sociology develops a tie with social work or market research. Economics survives in an alliance with business management.
The administration maintains that the curriculum shift is consumer-driven -- that it reflects what students want. But what they really want, as a sociologist's recent survey of 1,400 Queens College graduates demonstrated, is the ability "to learn new things rapidly," "to write clearly and effectively" and "to analyze problems." What they don't need is training for jobs on equipment that might be obsolete on graduation day.
A sound education presupposes good faculty. One obstacle is that many professors rightly fear for their jobs. At Harlem-based City College, CUNY's flagship, the liberal arts banquet that once rivaled Columbia's is threatened with extinction.
Just when the faculty begins to mirror the diversity of the students, the university begins to talk about electronic classrooms. Just when the majority of the student body consists of minority members and women, the commitment made in 1847 -- "to educate the children of the whole people" -- is redefined. CUNY should return to its roots.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
When Elderly Buddies Take Politics Seriously

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON 

 BODY:
If P. T. Barnum's law on the ratio of the birth of suckers to time (one per minute) worked for Ross Perot in his 1992 Presidential campaign, the producers of "The Shattering" must have hoped it would apply to theater audiences as well. That's the only apparent reason for the vanity staging of this inept exercise by Mark R. Shapiro at the Players Theater.
The play concerns the conversion of Harry and three of his buddies, all near retirement age, into Perot zealots and how their lives are shattered (hence the title, one supposes) when Mr. Perot pulls out of the race. 
 The first act plays like a bad infomercial. Although all four men have jobs and live comfortably, they complain about the "recession." They want a "change" and a "voice" in the Government, without ever thinking about what they want changed or what they would say if anyone listened to them. Harry becomes such a disciple of Perotism that he cashes in his life insurance policy so he can pay out of his own pocket for Perot-for-President T-shirts, placards and bumper stickers.
Mr. Shapiro, who is a Washington lobbyist in real life, should know more about politics than he lets on through these cardboard characters. The writing is so vapid it would make daytime soap opera seem inspired. When Mr. Perot quits the campaign, the men's sense of betrayal couldn't be greater if Ronald Reagan suddenly announced he was a Communist.
The one possibility at turning any of this into a real play comes in the realization that Harry and one of his friends both have sons who are among those still missing from the Vietnam War. They seem to think Mr. Perot will find their boys and bring them home. There is some dramatic potential in a brief scene in which Harry and his wife and married daughter confront the realization that the son is probably dead and that it was Harry himself who pressured the boy into "doing his duty" for his country. But Mr. Shapiro abandons it before it is fully developed.
There's not a lot a director or actors can do with such material. Kenneth Elliott, the director who has enjoyed success staging Charles Busch comedies, has Harry shout and throw things around from time to time, but it mostly serves only to keep the audience awake. Marge Redmond is longsuffering as Harry's wife. Robert Hogan, who played the role at a press preview, portrayed Harry as though he were Clint Eastwood doing an Archie Bunker impersonation.
 
THE SHATTERING
By Mark R. Shapiro; directed by Kenneth Elliott; sets by Edward T. Gianfrancesco; costumes by Robert Mackinosh; lighting by Phil Monat; sound by Fox and Perla Ltd.; production stage manager, D. C. Rosenberg; general management, William Repicci. Presented by Shelmar Productions LLC. At the Players Theater, 115 MacDougal Street, Greenwich Village.

HEADLINE: Raymond S. Rubinow, 91, Master of Civic Causes

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Raymond S. Rubinow, a longtime political gadfly and New York civic leader who fought with equal zeal to save Carnegie Hall and demolish Tammany Hall, died on Tuesday at his home in the Esplanade Hotel on West End Avenue in Manhattan. He was 91.
A self-styled philanthropoid who made a science of giving away other people's money, Mr. Rubinow coined the term in Chicago in the 1930's while working for the Julius Rosenwald Fund, the foundation endowed by the founder of Sears, Roebuck. 
 Mr. Rubinow elevated his work to a high art in New York two decades later when he joined the J.M. Kaplan Fund, which had been established in 1947 by Jacob Kaplan, the self-made businessman who had made a fortune by reorganizing the Welch's grape juice company.
As executive director of the fund from 1955 to 1977, Mr. Rubinow was soon in the forefront of virtually every do-good cultural, social and civic cause in the city, often as chairman of some long-named committee seeking to preserve, advance or create a piece of the city's heritage.
His first major success came in the late 1950's when, as chairman of the Joint Emergency Committee to Close Washington Square Park to Traffic, he succeeded in blocking a plan to extend Fifth Avenue through the Greenwich Village park.
Another came in 1960 when, as chairman of the Citizens Committee for Carnegie Hall, he helped save the venerable concert hall from the wrecker's ball after it had been abandoned by the New York Philharmonic for Lincoln Center.
His work to keep traffic out of Washington Square Park made Mr. Rubinow something of a hero to many residents of Greenwich Village, particularly the artists, writers and upscale newcomers whose interests often clashed with those of the older Italian-American community there.
Mr. Rubinow, who had helped form the first citizens' committee to support the election of Mayor Robert F. Wagner in 1953, was soon in the thick of the so-called reform movement to depose Carmine De Sapio, the entrenched leader of the Manhattan Democratic Party whose political power base was in Greenwich Village.
As chairman of the Democratic Mobilization in 1963, Mr. Rubinow helped a young lawyer named Ed Koch defeat Mr. De Sapio as district leader. Together with Mayor Wagner's famous break with the political bosses that year, the victory effectively shattered the power of the Tammany Hall political machine and laid the groundwork for Mr. Koch's later career in Congress and at City Hall.
For Mr. Rubinow, a native of Washington who grew up in New York, his role as an adviser to public figures like Mayor Wagner was something of a family tradition.
His father, I. M. Rubinow, a Russian-born physician who became an eminent American economist and social theorist, is regarded as an intellectual godfather of Social Security, which was created by the Wagner Act of 1936 after being pushed through the Senate by Mayor Wagner's father, Senator Robert F. Wagner.
Mr. Rubinow, who graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received a master's degree in economics from the University of Wisconsin, took a while to hit his stride. But after working briefly for the National Recovery Administration and the Social Security Board in Washington and teaching economics at Swarthmore, he found his niche in foundation work, initially as a consultant and later as an executive of a series of foundations before finding a permanent home with the Kaplan fund.
In the pitched battles between preservationists and developers, Mr. Rubinow was often on the winning side. As chairman of the Emergency Action Committee to Save the Beach at Breezy Point, for example, he helped preserve the Queens beach from development in 1963 and he had a similar triumph in 1965 as chairman of the Committee to Save Madison Square Park.
Not all his campaigns were successful, however. In 1967 he was chairman of the Emergency Civic Committee to Oppose a World Trade Center.
Mr. Rubinow, whose wife, Consuelo Kamholz, died in 1993, is survived by a sister, Dr. Olga Lurie of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING;
All-Black Crew Finding Its Horizons

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
Responding to a wish from his mother that he take up collegiate sailing, Byron Gully Jr. of Chicago tried out for the team last fall during freshmen orientation at Hampton University.
Unlike the football and track he had competed in at De La Salle, a Chicago high school, Gully found that making the sailing squad at the Hampton, Va., college did not involve much more than showing up at a meeting. That was lucky for Gully, since he had never set foot on a sailboat before. 
 As it turns out, he was not the only fledgling sailor. Eight other students have since joined Gully to form the first intercollegiate sailing team at a historically African-American university. Hampton was founded in 1868 to educate freed slaves.
Competing this month in their first round of spring competition, the five men and four women on the all-black team have about as much cumulative sailing experience as a youngster enrolled in his first yacht club summer camp. And yet, they have beaten a few other collegiate sailing teams.
"I did this as a favor to my mother," the 19-year-old Gully said recently. "It sounded like something different. When I went out on a boat for the first time, I capsized twice that day. And then I realized this wasn't going to be boring."
Gully's unfamiliarity with the sport, despite having grown up in a city neighborhood minutes from the shores of Lake Michigan, is not uncommon for African-Americans. As with tennis and golf, sailing has been marked by mostly white participation at country clubs and yacht clubs.
"There has been a dearth of African-Americans in sailing because of the kind of sport it is," said Dennis Thomas, athletic director at Hampton. "You don't catch many African-Americans going out and buying a sailboat. You're talking a different kind of economic strata there."
The doors are opening now for African-Americans as club memberships become less exclusive, and as community sailing programs flourish. But Hampton chose not to wait but to lead. An effort by Hampton professors and administrators developed a program for the 1995-96 academic year. Through Gary Jobson, an ESPN sailing commentator who is also a member of Hampton's board of trustees, the school received donations that included a fleet of 13- to 14-foot dinghy sailboats, including 11 new Lasers and eight Club Flying Juniors (FJ's).
An even greater addition to the Hampton program was the hiring of Gary Bodie, a sailing coach with impressive credentials in yacht racing as well. Having left the United States Naval Academy last fall after a decade as a sailing coach, Bodie left behind a legacy of 14 intercollegiate championships and 34 all-America honors. Bodie concedes that his new team is struggling. But competition among the 35 sailing squads in the Mid-Atlantic Intercollegiate Sailing Association has taken his team beyond the beginner's stage.
"Sometimes I get impatient because I know from my Navy experience that No. 1 is way off," Bodie said. "But when I step back, I think our progress is pretty amazing."
Bodie has also started to recruit students from countries where black and minority students are more likely to have been brought up sailing. That includes Bermuda, the Virgin Islands, the Dominican Republic and Central as well as South America.
"At Navy, you didn't make the team if you weren't recruited," Bodie said. "I was getting a major player every year with lifelong experience. But sailing is not a scholarship recruitment program. You're pretty much selling a program, and a good education."
The students at Hampton came to the team with uneven experience and expectations, he added. Granted, Devin Walker, team captain, had raced occasionally on a Cal 25 owned by Benjamin Cuker, an associate professor of marine science who was also instrumental in organizing the sailing program. And Jennease Hyatt had taken a few sailing lessons one year in a community program on the Charles River in Boston. But the others had barely got their feet wet.
The reality of sailing competition hit them in a cold, wet rain at the start of spring training in mid-February. In the beginning, the students had little or no gear to ride out their occasional dunkings in the murky Hampton River, and nothing to protect them from the windchill on Hampton Rhodes Harbor, a nearby waterway that leads into Chesapeake Bay. Now they have dry suits, synthetic body warmers, spray tops and sea boots.
Gully says he doesn't capsize much anymore. He can swim, an accomplishment that even Dennis Conner, who has raced for the America's Cup seven times, says he hasn't mastered. But the fact about Conner doesn't matter much to Gully, who asks matter-of-factly, "Who's that?"

HEADLINE: As a Hospital Is Fixed, A Wound Is Healed

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
For 20 years the old Morrisania Hospital building has loomed grim and vacant over its Bronx neighborhood, sheltering only junkies, homeless people, huge rats, even a family of hawks. With its outlying buildings, the hospital complex occupies an entire city block. When the central structure rose 11 stories above the neighborhood in the booming 1920's, it was a symbol of the borough's ascent. When it was abandoned in 1976, it became an equally potent indicator of decline.
But on a frigid day late last month, a crowd of politicians, neighborhood advocates and urban-renewal specialists gathered at the base of the hospital's neo-Renaissance facade to celebrate the start of what local officials say is the last major renovation job left in the Bronx. Construction is under way, and in 14 months the former hospital is to reopen as an apartment building, complete with social services for the tenants. 
 Cashmere coats were much in evidence among the nattily attired crowd, the buffet table was loaded with fancy cheeses and fruits, and there was a buzz of purposeful chatter in the air. All this, set against the South Bronx tenements, seemed like something from another planet.
This wasn't science fiction, however, though it was something of a miracle.
For the story of how a brand-new advocacy group snared the largest single grant in the history of New York State's housing agency -- $6.3 million -- negotiated the shoals of local politics and kept alive the idea of renovation for the hulk in the face of skepticism and attempts at sabotage, is a surprising one. It is a lesson in how political finesse, combined with a certain vision, may result in change for even the most recalcitrant patches of urban blight.
There is the cost of the project, $24 million, nearly half in state funds. There is the fact that the building has never been used for housing. But mostly, there is the ambition of this scheme, which aims not only to provide pleasant, inexpensive apartments, but to give their occupants jobs and training, right in the grand old structure itself. The developer, the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, has detailed plans -- with money in place -- to train local people, not just the new tenants, in commercial food preparation, nursing and child care.
For Nancy Biberman, mastermind of the project, faith was an integral ingredient from the beginning. A housing lawyer who was a student leader during the 1968 strike at Columbia University, she became haunted by the beautiful old hospital building while directing, for the Archdiocese of New York, a housing rehabilitation project in nearby High Bridge in the late 1980's.
In 1991, she struck out on her own, founding the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, or Wedco, to devote herself to reconstituting neighborhoods not just with renovated apartments, but with jobs and services for the people who were to live in them.
The new organization was looking for what Ms. Biberman calls a "signature project." The Florentine arched windows of Morrisania Hospital were on her brain. "I said, 'Like, why not?' " Ms. Biberman recalled recently.
But local people, bureaucrats downtown, housing renovation experts -- all told her to forget about it. She was plied with vague insinuations about a political "fix" on the building. Nobody could point to anything specific. Nonetheless, some of the truth of these allegations was later borne out.
"Everybody said, 'Don't even think about it; it's way too political,' " Ms. Biberman remembered. "There were all sorts of rumors about it, that every single plan that had been advanced had always bit the dust. It was cursed, in a way."
An initial visit was discouraging. She climbed in through a hole in the gate. "It's dark. It's scary. It's truly scary," Ms. Biberman recalled. "There were people sleeping in there. It was a mess, filled with debris. It was disgusting. Lot of dogs running around."
Visits to the local community board -- its approval was vital in getting control of the site from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development -- were hardly more encouraging.
Community Board 4 in the South Bronx, which represents an area where almost half the population is below the poverty line, was not interested in more low-income residents in the neighborhood. All through the 1980's, renovation dollars had poured in. Tenants with few resources had followed. That era, local officials felt, was over.
"The initial response was, 'Hey, we don't need more housing,' " said Robert Hannibal, chairman of the board. Mr. Hannibal remembered his youth, when neighboring 167th Street bustled and there was an Automat instead of today's shabby bodegas. That was what he wanted to bring back.
While lobbying the community board, Ms. Biberman discovered a potentially critical ally: Public School 235, a local bilingual elementary school that was born in a vacant supermarket in 1970 and had been rootless ever since.
Providentially, school officials had identified the old Morrisania Hospital site as the best place to build a home for P.S. 235. The problem, from their point of view, was the hospital building itself, a white elephant.
Wedco turned the elephant into a draft horse. A marriage was born: "A blessing," said Sylvia Rosario, former president of the Parents' Association of P.S. 235. The old hospital would be apartments and economic development; the outlying buildings would be torn down for the new school.
Meanwhile, Wedco was begging another critical player, Borough President Fernando Ferrer, for his support. Without it, the whole project would collapse. But this gift would not come easily. "I didn't know Wedco from a hole in the wall," Mr. Ferrer recalled.
As word of Ms. Biberman's plans spread through the borough in 1992, rival plans for the hospital began to surface.
One was hatched by a local politician, whom neither Ms. Biberman nor Mr. Ferrer would identify, who had connections to his proposed developer. As Wedco gained the upper hand, the incensed politician made phone calls to officials in New York and Albany, attempting to kill the women's plan, Ms. Biberman and Mr. Ferrer said.
"It was a very nasty business for a while," Ms. Biberman remembered. "He really tried to sabotage us."
Mr. Ferrer recalled, "I came under intense lobbying by some of my colleagues in government." They thundered, in his recollection: " 'This isn't a Bronx group, this isn't a group of people of color, they come out of nowhere.' " Ms. Biberman acknowledged, "We're white girls, after all."
Hovering in the background, there had always been the matter of procuring $24 million to finance the grandiose scheme.
Early signs were not promising. The city turned Wedco down: no money left in the housing till. But the group had an initial trump up its sleeve. Forty-eight of the 132 new apartments were planned for homeless families.
This part of the scheme was in tune with Wedco's goal of helping those on public assistance. But it was also strategically savvy. Ms. Biberman knew that the state agency that subsidized housing for the homeless was sympathetic to her plans, and was likely to speed her money request. She had worked with them before. They liked her.
The strategy proved correct. In July 1993 the Department of Social Services' Homeless Housing Assistance Program came up with the initial grant of $4.5 million, "a nice commitment," Ms. Biberman said. Housing for the homeless, the part of the plan perhaps least attractive to local officials, provided the financial breakthrough.
Money attracted support. Two months later, Community Board 4 signed off. In November 1993 the city turned the building over to Wedco.
But that still left the biggest hurdle of all: persuading the state Department of Housing and Community Renewal to make its biggest-ever housing grant and part with half of its annual New York City allotment for a single project, an unprecedented action.
Finally, on a fall day in 1994, more than three years after the idea was conceived, there was a phone call to Wedco's offices in lower Manhattan: The money was theirs. But the jubilation proved to be short-lived.
In November, several days after a ceremony in front of the building, disaster struck: the Democratic administration of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that had agreed to finance the renovation was defeated. The new administration had every right to rescind commitments made by the old. Throughout 1995, the staff at Wedco waited with dread for that phone call. Every detail of the Morrisania project was once again picked over minutely.
Four months ago, Ms. Biberman got the word: The project was on. She was too exhausted to feel much relief. That same month the contractors went to work.
On the day the fancy crowd showed up to make speeches, residents hung out their windows or paused on the street. "This is great," said Pearl Matthews, a retired city worker. "That place is rat-infested. People are using it for shelter."
Ms. Biberman, assessing the outcome of the five-year struggle and her stake in it, said: "I don't think it compares to anything other than after you've given birth to a child."

HEADLINE: A Moment in the Sunset For Heroes of the Slopes

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: KEYSTONE, Colo., April 2

 BODY:
To the spring-break college crowd, snowboarders in baggy pants and ski bunnies in pink ear muffs, the sight must have seemed strange: a dozen aging men, wearing white camouflage, descending a ski run in a slow, serpentine formation, making the wide, graceful turns popular in the 1930's.
In World War II, these crack ski troops of the United States Army's 10th Mountain Division were known as the invisible men in white. After the war, they were the heart of an extraordinary boom in recreational skiing. From 200,000 skiers at the end of the war, the number has grown to about 10 million skiers in the United States, according to the industry. 
Before the sun-creased septuagenarians schuss into the sunset, they are being hailed with a shower of ski passes, documentary movies, coffee-table books, memorial highways and ski-run dedications.
"For the second generation of the ski business, we can be especially grateful that they came home and founded many of the 500 ski areas in the country," John Rutter, a vice president of the Keystone Resort, said recently as sun shone off packed powder at the resort's 11,640-foot summit. "They touched every ski area in the nation."
Moments later, a white-haired former drill instructor barked, "Hoods up, tips down," and the camouflaged veterans, as old as 84, glided under an arch of ski poles to dedicate another ski run to their old unit. Watching the reunion of a few of the division association's 3,500 members, Dean G. Carmichael, 70, the group's president, said in a choking voice: "I hope our name will live on long after we are gone from these slopes."
In a state with a young population and many new residents, Coloradans are waking up to the deep impact made on the Rockies by the 10,000 men who trained in the mountains 35 miles from here in World War II. Postwar demobilization did more to promote skiing than the simple flooding of sports stores with Army surplus skis, boots and parkas.
"The 10th Mountain Division introduced a lot of us to the Rocky Mountains, to the West," said one veteran, Peter W. Seibert. 71, "and to the desirability of the weather and snow here." A native of the White Mountains of New Hampshire, Mr. Seibert came back here after the war. In 1962, he opened the Vail ski resort, now the nation's largest. Other 10th Division veterans returned to Colorado and started ski resorts at Aspen and Steamboat Springs.
"Tenth-Mountain vets founded 12 major ski areas, managed 17 others, and directed 33 ski schools," said Beth Gage, who last year produced and directed with her husband, George, a documentary film on the unit, "Fire on the Mountain."
Overall, 2,000 10th Division veterans moved to ski areas where they worked as instructors, patrolmen and managers, according to unit historians. In New England, unit veterans founded Sugarbush in Vermont, ran Waterville Valley, N.H., and directed ski schools in the Vermont resorts of Bromley and Stowe. The first publisher and the first three editors of Skiing Magazine were 10th Mountain veterans. Promoting mountain sports and conservation, division alumni include David Brower, who became executive director of the Sierra Club; Bill Bowerman, who founded Nike shoes, and Paul Petzoldt, who founded the National Outdoor Leadership School.
In politics, Francis Sargent became Governor of Massachusetts, and Bob Dole became a Senator from Kansas and the presumed Republican Presidential nominee.
"There are very few examples in our country's history where a military division has had such an impact on the culture, economy and spirit of a region," said John Frew, president of Colorado Ski Country USA. This ski resort association was founded in 1963 by Steve Knowlton, another veteran of the 10th Division.
With the unit lending its name to a wilderness trail system in Colorado and stretches of highway in Colorado, New York and Texas, a veritable industry has grown up around telling the unit's tale. Barbara Walton, director of the 10th Mountain Division Resource Center at the Denver Public Library, said 40 books and three major movies had been brought out about the unit.
Mr. Gage, the filmmaker, of Telluride, Colo., said he was stunned to see teen-agers "mesmerized" by his documentary. "People are looking for heroes," he said. "In the last five months, we have sold 2,500 videos out of our garage." The film is to be shown this summer on TNT's National Geographic Explorer.
The 10th Division's story began in 1940 when Charles Dole, founder of the National Ski Patrol System in 1937, watched with admiration as Finnish ski troops exacted heavy casualties from Soviet troops who had invaded in a territorial dispute. Mr. Dole, no relation to the Senator, wrote to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, urging him to set up a mountain division to protect "snow-bound America" from an invasion.
After being given the green light, Mr. Dole decided to turn skiers into soldiers, rather than to turn soldiers into skiers. Using the ski patrol as a recruiting agency, he enlisted Ivy League ski team captains, exiled European athletes and cowboys of Scandinavian origin who had grown up herding cattle on cross-country skis.
Since few American teen-agers could afford a $2 lift ticket during the Depression, skiers tended to be from the upper class.
At the training base, Camp Hale, recently listed on the National Register of Historic Places, soldier-mechanics developed the nation's first snowmobiles and snowcats. But members of the unit slogged on snowshoes with skis and 100-pound packs on their backs, climbing the same mountains that skiers today ascend in 10-minute gondola rides.
In contrast to the current high-tech equipment, the mountain soldiers used hickory skis and bamboo poles. Square-toed leather boots were clamped into bear-trap bindings.
"The maple skis were damn good, but of course that was too expensive for the Army," John McLellan, a 73-year-old veteran, as he rode a ski lift.
As the war evolved, it became clear that German commandos were never going to parachute into the Rockies. Instead, in December 1944, the 10th Mountain Division, strengthened to 14,000 soldiers, with most of the additions non-skiers, crossed the Atlantic to join in the attack on German forces in the northern stretches of the Apennine Mountains in Italy.
Spearheading the campaign, division troops made a daring 2,000-foot ascent of Riva Ridge. They overran German units there, helping to break the back of the German defenses. But victory came at a great cost. In only five months of fighting the division had 992 killed and 4,154 wounded -- a 37 percent casualty rate.
"I went on two ski patrols," Howard R. Koch, an athletic 71-year-old, said, in a gondola interview. "You'd get over the tree line in the Apennines, the Germans would see those ski tracks, and they wouldn't let you have any fun -- Kaboom!"
On the night of April 14, 1945, Lieutenant Dole, a 22-year-old replacement officer with only two months experience with the unit, was cut down by German machine-gun fire, suffering near fatal wounds.
"This Kansas soldier never did learn to ski," Senator Dole stated in a foreword to Soldiers on Skis, a pictorial book on the unit published in 1992 by Boulder's Paladin Press.
But at the reunion luncheon at Keystone, unanimity prevailed over Mr. Dole's full membership in the 10th Division fraternity.
"Dole may have been a flatlander," said Mr. Carmichael, the association's president, "but when he walked into those mountains and got shot -- he was a Mountain man."

The unit's members helped create the postwar skiing boom. (Photographs by Ellen Jaskol for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Armed North Korea Troops Again Violate the DMZ

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, April 7

 BODY:
Heavily armed North Korean troops entered the sensitive buffer zone between North and South Korea tonight for the third day in a row, violating the armistice that ended the Korean War, United States and South Korean officials said.
The actions by the North Koreans have heightened tensions on the heavily fortified border, where the cold war has never thawed. But some American and South Korean officials have said the North, by thumbing its nose at the armistice agreement, appears to be making more of a diplomatic gambit than actually preparing for war. 
 "We view these activities of the past three evenings as a series of continuing serious armistice violations, but we see nothing that would warrant particular alarm," said Jim Coles, a spokesman for the United Nations Command, which encompasses American, South Korean and other allied troops in South Korea. In Seoul, people appeared to be calm tonight.
[In Washington, a spokeswoman for the Defense Department, Lieut. Comdr. Karen Jeffries, called the latest incursion by North Korean troops "a serious violation of the armistice, though not unprecedented." She said American officials had not seen an increase in military activity to suggest that North Korea was preparing for war.]
Mr. Coles said between 150 and 180 North Korean troops entered the joint security area at the village of Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone at about 8:05 P.M. and appeared to be engaging in training exercises. They were carrying weapons including AK-47 assault rifles, rocket-propelled grenades, recoilless rifles and mortars, but left at 10:45 P.M. without firing a shot.
Officials at South Korea's Ministry of Defense gave a similar account. But one of them said there was some speculation that the number of North Korean troops might have been as high as 400, based on the capacity of the six small trucks and six large trucks used to transport them.
The armistice agreement allows only 35 soldiers from either side from entering the joint security area, and they may carry only sidearms.
North Korea, which has violated the 1953 truce agreement in the past, has made little secret over the years that it wants to dismantle the pact and replace it with a peace treaty between itself and the United States, bypassing South Korea.
On Thursday, the day before the incursions at the demilitarized zone began, the secretive Communist nation declared that it would abandon its role in maintaining the demilitarized zone.
In response to the recent incursions, the United Nations Command has heightened its surveillance over North Korean actions. But Mr. Coles said that contrary to some reports, troops on the border had not gone to a higher level of combat readiness and that there had been no unusual troop movements on either side of the 151-mile-long border other than the Panmunjom incursions. "It's business as usual, even on the North side," he said.
Washington and Seoul are talking about stationing an American Awacs in South Korea or having the South Koreans buy one. Awacs, which stands for airborne warning-and-control system, is a plane with sophisticated equipment for monitoring a battlefield. Mr. Coles said such discussions had been going on for months.
South Koreans also say they hope that the meeting between President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam set for early next week on Cheju Island will send a sign to North Korea that the United States, which has 37,000 troops in this country, remains committed to defending South Korea.
At first the White House had said Mr. Clinton had no time to stop in South Korea on his trip to Japan and Russia. But after South Korean officials pressed for a visit, Mr. Clinton's schedule was changed.
Some analysts said North Korea must realize that Washington would not negotiate a peace treaty without involving Seoul. So the North's recent saber-rattling might be intended more to solicit economic aid to help the Communist country cope with famine and a crumbling economy, just as its threatened nuclear weapons development led to an agreement to supply it with modern atomic power plants and fuel oil.
They said it also could be an effort by Kim Jong Il, who is believed to be the de facto ruler of North Korea, to show his toughness before formally ascending to the high titles held by his late father, Kim Il Sung.

HEADLINE: The U.S. Must Pay Its Dues

BYLINE: By Boutros Boutros-Ghali; Boutros Boutros-Ghali has been Secretary General of the United Nations since 1992.

 BODY:
The United Nations is on the brink of financial disaster. Americans need to know what's going on, because their country took the lead in creating the organization, and its delinquency in paying arrears is threatening it.
When I took office, major challenges lay ahead. With the cold war over, vast new responsibilities were heaped on the United Nations. But resources needed to carry them out were inadequate because many member states were not paying their dues. In addition, the Secretariat, which was underproductive, needed reform. 
 For four years, the Secretariat has carried out its mandates under near-impossible conditions. A perpetual but not very successful effort has been made to convince members to pay up.
In this period, the organization has been streamlined -- as far as the Secretary General's powers permit. The staff is leaner, procedures have been simplified and waste and duplication have been sharply reduced.
For 18 months, I have focused on reducing the operating budget. My proposed $2.5 billion budget for 1996-97 is $98 million less than the previous year's budget. In December, the members asked for $154 million more in cuts. Since then, the we have identified $140 million in cuts, and the rest can be found.
The staff will be reduced. Originally, I had planned not to fill 200 Secretariat positions, but now 800 more must be vacated. In making cuts, I cannot favor one operation over another, and I have to carry out all mandates substantially as required. But no wizardry can achieve cuts of this magnitude without reducing the extent and quality of the work the members want done. The General Assembly, which approves the budget, will not help matters if it nitpicks.
The financial crisis has not been made any easier by the refusal of many to pay dues. The United States and Russian Federation dominate the past-due list. I am grateful that the Federation decided last month to pay $400 million, including its full regular assessment of $46 million for 1996. But America owes $1.5 billion in dues and assessments. Thus, even with the Russians' payment, the United Nations will run out of money by the end of 1996. Incredibly, our cash on hand is under $100 million.
Borrowing from the peacekeeping budget to meet regular operating needs cannot continue much longer. Huge sum are owed to states that have provided troops and equipment for peace operations. Besides, while we carry out old mandates new ones keep coming.
It would be counterproductive to cut off important operations such as democratization in Haiti and the promotion of human rights in Guatemala. These operations are precious for the peoples involved. They are also United Nations success stories.
Still, the stark truth must be faced. Something has to give. If the Haiti and Guatemala operations are to go forward, other obligations must be scaled back or dropped. The members must make that hard call. If they don't, we will run out of money before long.
When the League of Nations collapsed, many members were surprised. They did not understood the depth of its problems. Today, the United Nations, created 51 years ago, is in deep trouble. This time around, there should be no surprises.
