HEADLINE: Hanoi Seeks Western Cash but Not Consequences

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, April 7

 BODY:
In Da Nang, the favored paint color seems to be electric blue. Here in the city still popularly known as Saigon it is mostly white. On storefronts and billboards all over the country, neat swatches of paint have recently been applied, under Government orders, to blot out the brand names of foreign consumer products.
Even as Vietnam hustles desperately for foreign investment, it has launched a campaign to obliterate one of the most visible indicators of its success. In a two-month-old campaign against what the Government calls "social evils," foreign advertising has been demonized along with prostitution, gambling and illicit drugs. 
 The seeming contradiction is the product of a watershed moment for Vietnamese leaders. They are engaged in a far-reaching debate as they pause to assess the effects of an economic and social transformation that they themselves unleashed. Their experiment in economic liberalization -- called "doi moi" -- is succeeding in textbook style, but it has brought with it unruly market forces and social changes that threaten the dominance of the Communist Party.
A party congress scheduled for June is expected to take a hard look at the new Vietnam that is emerging. Foreign and Vietnamese analysts say a struggle has already begun over the future direction of the country's policies and over the composition of the leadership itself.
"It is a particularly important moment in Vietnamese history," said Bradley O. Babson, the resident representative of the World Bank. "It has taken on a significance beyond the normal five-yearly party congress. They are coming out of a period of very aggressive openings to the outside world, and the consequences are beginning to become real for them."
As the Government seeks to define its own version of Communist Party control with an open marketplace, one Western ambassador said, the mostly aging leadership is surveying the tumult of a modernizing nation and asking itself, "Is this good?"
Since the "big bang" of liberalization in 1989, as some economists call it, Vietnam's ailing economy has righted itself, investment and exports are up, and the vigor of private enterprise and rising incomes is evident from north to south.In 1990, Vietnam had 100,000 telephones; today it has 800,000. Two years ago, Hanoi had no taxis; now it has a thousand. Last year the nation went from importing rice to being the world's third-leading rice exporter.
This year the economy is expected to grow by more than 9 percent. Inflation, which had soared to 600 percent or higher, is down to around 12 percent. Nearly $18 billion in foreign investment is on the books, with the first big wave of dollars having poured into the country last year.
In one month last year, Vietnam established diplomatic relations with the United States, set up a framework for relations with the European Union and joined the formerly antagonistic regional bloc, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
At the same time, though, gaps between rich and poor and between the fast-developing cities and the lagging countryside have widened rapidly, threatening social instability. With reduced Government support, the quality of education and health care for the poor -- more than half the population -- has deteriorated. Unemployment and underemployment have emerged as problems, along with a migration of poor people to the already overcrowded cities.
But however rough the road, the Western ambassador said, the economic reforms are irreversible.
"You see heated discussions now on ideology and it looks like the leaders are heading away from the pragmatism of doi moi," he said. "But at the same time, the Ministry of Trade has begun discussions on how to reduce tariffs. If you go to the Finance Ministry they are working on a value-added tax. At the Central Bank they are working on a stock market. I think the most important signals are these structural ones relating to trade and investment."
The core issue for the party congress is control. "As Lenin taught, we are not afraid of capitalist enterprises, but of not being able to supervise and control them," the party's General Secretary, Do Muoi, said last December.
Despite the clear success of economic liberalization, the party appears to be determined to maintain a central role for state-owned enterprises. Do Duc Dinh, an analyst with the Institute on World Economy in Hanoi, said that 15 to 17 "strategic industries," including energy, transportation, steel and oil, would continue to dominate the economy under state control in the decades ahead.
"The private sector has grown very fast, but the Government still sees the state sector as the main sector," he said.
The sudden attempt to supervise and control foreign advertising earlier this year rattled the confidence of the American entrepreneurs who have staked claims here since President Clinton lifted an economic embargo two years ago. Already they had begun to complain that Vietnam, with its shaky legal structure, its corruption and its exhausting, multilevel bureaucracy was a bigger challenge than they had realized.
"There was a certain sense for a while this year that perhaps things had stalled out," said Michael J. Scown, a lawyer with the Washington-based firm Russin & Vecchi who heads the American Chamber of Commerce in Ho Chi Minh City. "People were wondering whether reforms were going to continue, or whether there would now be a backlash against foreign investment. You would hear things from the Vietnamese like, 'We've got enough representative offices already. We don't need any more.' "
Like others who monitor the situation here, Mr. Scown said that both Vietnamese and foreigners were holding their breath now, waiting for the results of the party congress.
"Nobody knows what policies will come out or who the policymakers will be," he said. "Everything is on hold. There's also something of the flavor of an American election year with a lot of rhetoric about law and order and protecting traditional Vietnamese values."
For Vietnam today these are new and genuine concerns.
"The real issue under the surface is the issue of national identity," said Mr. Babson, of the World Bank. "There is a question where the country is headed."
Last November, Ha Dang, a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, summarized the dangers that face the party as "lagging behind economically; deviation from socialist orientation; red tape and corruption; and peaceful evolution."
"Peaceful evolution" -- what the party fears from such influences as foreign advertising -- is an Asian Communist term referring to a Western conspiracy to impose capitalism by peaceful means. And it has never been better defined than by President Clinton when he announced the establishment of diplomatic relations last July.
"Increased contact between Americans and Vietnamese will advance the cause of freedom in Vietnam just as it did in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union," Mr. Clinton said.
Or as some Vietnamese commentators have suggested, the United States is still trying to win the Vietnam war, this time with consumer goods instead of B-52's.

HEADLINE: How to Turn Around a Magazine for Walkers

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Everyone loves a success story. Particularly the beleaguered magazine industry, where 7 out of 10 start-ups fail within a decade.
This story is about Jan Thaw Bruce, a woman with a tenacious belief in a foundering magazine devoted to walking. With the magazine in its death throes, Ms. Bruce, who was then its publisher, raised more than $1 million, acquired the publication from her boss and persuaded staff members to stay on without pay until the magazine could be repositioned and turned around. 
 Started as The Walking Magazine in 1986 by Raben Publishing, a small Boston-based publisher of sports and fitness magazines, it began life with a circulation of 250,000, aimed at older people who liked to walk. Newsstand and direct-mail response were strong, and circulation grew to more than 400,000 in three years.
But the magazine was not making money. In 1990, with the industry in a deepening recession, the owners put the magazine up for sale.
There were no takers, and no wonder. Walking is an improbable subject for a magazine -- neither a competitive sport nor even an athletic endeavor. It requires no special expertise, no special equipment and certainly no special clothing. Not even special shoes.
Ms. Bruce saw things differently. In 1980, as associate circulation director at Rolling Stone, she had learned a valuable lesson about the importance of positioning a magazine correctly.
Rolling Stone had been started as a music magazine but was later repositioned as the magazine for the rock-and-roll generation.
"The whole spin for the magazine came together," Ms. Bruce said of Rolling Stone. "The vision for the product was right and it spoke to a generation. It leaped ahead into a general-interest category."
With that model in mind, Ms. Bruce, who had started as circulation director and then became publisher of The Walking Magazine, presented the owners with a new marketing strategy: aim the magazine's sights a generation lower than the older readers it was then attracting.
"As the baby-boomer generation was walking into middle age, growing up, having careers and families and needed to stay fit, I saw that walking could have a tremendous role to play as an effective fitness activity," she said.
When the owners began to talk about closing the magazine, Ms. Bruce went to investors and began to raise money herself.
Within six months she assembled an investment group, raised more than $1 million, founded Walking Inc., acquired the publication and changed the title from The Walking Magazine to Walking. Staff members agreed to stay on and went without pay for two weeks before eventually being reimbursed.
A new ad sales staff was hired. Subscription prices were raised by 26 percent. And the magazine was repositioned as the authoritative publication about walking.
The gamble worked. In 1994, Cowles Magazines Inc., a unit of the Cowles Media Company, bought Walking for $9.4 million. The new owners have invested in circulation and much-needed reader research. They also called in J. C. Suares, a well-known illustrator who has redesigned many magazines. As a result, Walking is more accessible and makes greater use of graphics, short secondary articles and charts. The first two redesigned issues, June and August, saw 50 percent increases in newsstand sales, Ms. Bruce said.
The magazine's main topics are health, fitness and, of course, walking. There are articles on body strength and inner strength, weight-reduction pills, nutrition and tips about botanical-based skin care products.
Ms. Bruce, who took the title of managing director, said the magazine was now "just about profitable."
Walking's primary audience is now 25 to 54 years old, with women making up almost 70 percent of the readers.
The most recent figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations show an average circulation of 510,000 an issue for Walking, which comes out six times a year. This gives Walking a larger circulation than Runner's World, Outside or Bicycling.
In 1995, Walking had 300 ad pages, up 2 percent from 1994. Advertisers include Reebok, Nike, Nordic Track, Kraft, Lipton, Excedrin and the Better Sex Video Series.
"This magazine has an active audience and people tend to be somewhat upscale," said Mike Gross, president of Paragon Media Inc., a media-buying consultancy. "After gardening, walking is the No. 1 recreational activity. It's something that people do for exercise no matter what their age. I recommended Walking to clients for 1995 and I'm recommending it for 1996."
Walking is testing offshoots of the magazine, including a newsletter, a walking program and affiliations with more than 800 walking clubs around the country. Ms. Bruce has also tried to sell the company's walking program to health care companies for their members.
"Our success fits in with major trends," she said. "People now see that fitness is a sort of cornerstone to good health, which wasn't the case 20 years ago."
Now, her mission over and her magazine up and running, Ms. Bruce has decided to move on. She has taken a job as senior vice president and general manager of consumer sales at Individual Inc., a company based in Burlington, Mass., that supplies customized business news to companies and individuals.
"This is a fascinating time to be in publishing," she said. "A new set of rules for media is about to be created and I want to be part of that."

HEADLINE: Global Talks Covering Phones Near Deadline

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Negotiators from 51 countries are racing against the clock at the World Trade Organization in Geneva this month, hoping to meet their self-imposed deadline of April 30 for an agreement on liberalizing trade in telecommunications.
At stake is the future of the global telecommunications industry, and possibly of the World Trade Organization itself. The goal of the talks is to open domestic telecommunications markets to foreign companies, potentially saving consumers billions of dollars. But an agreement would also put many sluggish national telephone companies at risk of being trampled by more efficient foreign competitors. 
 But political battles and fears by some countries that their home-grown companies will be no match for foreign competition have put the talks in jeopardy.
Last week the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, warned that the negotiations would "soon be in serious trouble" unless other countries made more generous liberalization offers.
And the director general of the World Trade Organization, Renato Ruggiero, expressed concern "about the amount of work still to be done," saying it would be "simply unacceptable" to let the talks fail.
The United States set the pace of the Geneva negotiations in February when it offered to throw open its telecommunications market to foreign companies provided the other countries that have so far made liberalization offers agreed to improve those offers.
"We are ready to open up a $213 billion a year market -- $100 billion worth of local calls, $100 billion worth of long-distance calls and $13 billion worth of international calls -- if other countries do likewise," said a senior American trade negotiator who asked not to be identified.
In addition to better access to foreign telecommunications markets, American officials said they were seeking a binding agreement insuring even-handed regulation of competing companies. The organization would enforce such an agreement, imposing sanctions on offenders.
So far, however, American trade officials have insisted that foreign liberalization offers made in Geneva are insufficient, raising fears that the United States might again walk away from an agreement, just as it did last summer on the deal to free trade in financial services.
"Most of the offers from U.S. trading partners are simply deficient," said Kim N. Wallace, a telecommunications analyst with Lehman Brothers. "Some do not seem aimed at a successful conclusion of the talks at all."
And at a meeting of European Union foreign ministers on March 25, Sir Leon Brittan, the European Union's trade negotiator, tried to persuade member governments to improve their offers, ending all restrictions on foreign providers in 1998. But his efforts were blocked by the hostility of powerful state-owned telecommunications monopolies, in a sense, undercutting the European Union's negotiating authority.
While 38 of the 51 governments participating in the negotiations have made offers so far, the quality of the offers varies, American trade officials said. Some countries, including Venezuela, Hungary and the Czech Republic, want liberalization. But many developing countries, including India, South Africa and Malaysia, have yet to make offers, and other proposals have been deemed less than satisfactory by American negotiators.
What is at stake in the negotiations is much more than increased competition leading to lower charges and better service for telephone, fax and telex users. When the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations ended with the creation of the World Trade Organization last year, this new body was given the immediate task of negotiating three agreements: freeing trade in financial services, in telecommunications and in maritime transport.
Its record so far, however, is unimpressive. Last summer the Clinton Administration refused to sign an agreement allowing foreign banks, insurers and other financial service companies better access to the United States market because it said other countries were not offering enough access in return.
Then last month, Sir Leon warned that the talks on liberalizing sea transport -- due to end in June -- were "not going very well." He called for a "change of heart on the part of the United States," which has refused to dismantle a 76-year-old law restricting trade between American ports to American ships.
"Three failures in a row would be a bad blow for W.T.O.'s role as a forum for negotiating freer trade, leaving it as only a depository for trade complaints," said Gary C. Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. The institute calculates that a successful telecommunications agreement could save consumers $100 million a year over the next decade.
A Federal Communications Commission study published in January found that roughly half the $4.3 billion that American phone companies paid foreign monopolies in 1994 to deliver overseas calls went straight to the bottom line as profit.
The fear that the World Trade Organization might be heading for another failure, diplomats said, helped explain why Mr. Ruggiero was pressing behind the scenes for a special world trade conference next year to inject new political momentum into multilateral trade liberalization and to strengthen his organization's role.
Some of the difficulties of the talks are shown by the position of the 15-nation European Union, which negotiates as a single body. While the union is offering in principle to extend the planned liberalization of its internal telecommunications market in 1998 to the rest of the world, a number of exceptions remain.
Spain, Portugal, Greece and Ireland want to delay opening their domestic markets until the year 2000 or 2003, while Belgium plans to continue rationing the award of radio licenses. And these exceptions have been used as excuses by developing countries for not making more generous offers themselves.
Developing countries have defended their restrictive position by saying their domestic telecommunications industries would be hurt by free trade.
But the World Bank disagrees, contending in a recent study that opening these countries' telecommunications industries to outsiders would help attract the estimated $60 billion they need over the next five years to bring the industries up to the standards of the industrial world.

HEADLINE: The Young and Restless Audience: Fine Tuning -- A special report;
Computers, Cable and Videos Cut Into Children's TV-Watching Time

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Through the years in TV land, an advertiser seeking the eyes and ears of children knew pretty much where to find them. So Bucky Beaver might pitch Ipana toothpaste during "The Mickey Mouse Club," Maypo could promote porridge on "Captain Kangaroo" and Mattel could send Barbie waltzing through the commercial breaks of "Garfield and Friends."
But these days marketers seeking the pre-teen-age mass audience have a tougher time of it, because of a trend that has been quietly developing for more than a decade. 
 Simply put: Children watch less television than they used to.
Weekly television viewing hours among children ages 2 to 11 are down 18 percent from a dozen years ago, according to Nielsen Media Research.
And even when a child is perched in front of a television these days, he or she is part of an increasingly fragmented audience. Some are watching free over-the-air programs, while others gravitate toward cable channels.
One activity not captured by these Nielsen numbers is videocassette viewing. While this activity may look a lot like TV watching to many parents, it is considered something completely separate by the advertising industry, because videocassettes contain no conventional advertising.
And now that one-third of households in the United States have personal computers, a growing number of children are forsaking at least part of their TV time to gaze into the cool glow of a computer monitor.
No wonder advertisers are looking beyond conventional television in search of the more than $7.3 billion in spending money that American children have jingling in their piggy banks each year. "To reach kids, you have to be in a lot of different places," said Jack Irving, executive director of the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi, the advertising agency. "New technologies and other activities are beginning to take them away."
Make no mistake: most of the nation's 28.2 million children ages 2 to 11 still spend more time watching television than they devote to almost any other activity -- an average of 21 hours and 38 minutes a week.
But that is down more than five hours a week from the mid-1980's, according to Nielsen.
And the falloff is all the more striking because it has come in an era when television viewing in the United States has held steady over all, with some groups, like adult men, watching even more than they did a dozen years ago.
So where has the young audience wandered? There are few definitive studies.
But a recent New York Times survey found that in households with at least one child in the 2-to-12 age range, slightly more than half the homes reported that the child had watched television "some" or "a lot" during the previous day. And yet, the survey also found that in one-third of those households the child had spent time watching a videocassette.
And in perhaps the most revealing new clue to how today's children are spending their time -- and the biggest new challenge to advertisers -- the survey found that in 33 percent of the households the child had used a computer "some" or "a lot" on the previous day.
"I'd rather have the girls do almost anything else than watch TV," said Tracy Levin of Birmingham, Ala., explaining why she and her husband recently bought their daughters a Gateway 2000 PC and opened an America Online account for the family.
Like many teen-agers today, 13-year-old Shoshanna Levin was already proficient with PC's. And now her 4-year-old sister, Alison, is getting up to speed.
With children like the Levin girls in mind, advertisers are casting a wider net. McDonald's, which once might have reached most of the Happy Meal clientele with Saturday morning ads on CBS programs like "Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles," now more carefully picks its spots among broadcast programs, while also buying time on the Nickelodeon children's cable channel, taking out ads in the related Nickelodeon magazine and experimenting with an interactive McDonald's game on Nickelodeon Online, one of the leading sites for children on the America Online computer service.
Recognizing that children with PC's and on-line access tend to come from the relatively well-to-do households that consumer marketers covet, McDonald's also has its own "McFamily" site on America Online. Other marketers trying to reach children on line include the Kellogg Company, Nintendo, Pepsico, Toys "R" Us and Nabisco, a unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings.
"The dollars being committed are really viewed as research-and-development spending," said Erica Gruen, director of media services at the advertising agency Merkley Newman Harty and a former senior vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi Interactive.
"But there is a truism that advertising follows eyeballs," Ms. Gruen said. "This year we will see a lot of dollars chasing kids on line."
Jane Dukes, McDonald's manager of marketing communications, said that so far the company's on-line efforts were considered more a marketing of the McDonald's brand than they were advertisements for products. But that could change.
"We think we have to innovate, be relevant and stay contemporary," Ms. Dukes said, "because if cyberspace is where our customers are, that is where we want to be."
It is not clear, though, whether parents want marketers to be there.
The Center for Media Education, a nonprofit research and lobbying group in Washington, recently released a six-month study of World Wide Web sites and on-line services directed at children.
Among the concerns raised by the report were potential invasions of family privacy through unwitting children: at some sites, a child may be invited to play a computer game, to join a club or to enter a contest. But to do so, the child may be required to answer questions asking how old the child is, how old the family's other children are, what movie they saw last, what toys they like and what their parents do for a living.
To many parents, "computers still have this 'halo effect' as something new and wonderful, something they'd rather have kids do than sit in front of the TV," Kathryn C. Montgomery, president of the Center for Media Education and a co-author of the report, said when it was released. "But it's in no way safe from the kinds of advertising and marketing practices that can harm kids."
The report angered some of the marketers cited, including Kellogg and Nabisco, which said that the criticisms were overly broad, because no two on-line sites were alike.
"We're confident that the information provided on our home page is consistent with children's advertising guidelines," said Anthony Hebron, a spokesman for Kellogg. "Anyone providing personal information or E-mail addresses on our site is doing so on a strictly voluntary basis."
Regardless of what the social merits of on-line outreach may be, some television executives, like Geraldine B. Laybourne, who recently became president of Disney/ABC Cable Networks after serving as president of the Nickelodeon and Nick at Nite cable services, see the PC as their most threatening rival for audiences. "Computers are not as faddish as video games," Ms. Layborne said. "They are far more interesting."

The Choices
More Sources Of Programming
Computers, of course, account for only a portion of the falloff and fragmentation of the children's television viewing audience. Market studies and demographic trends point to other factors as well.
Data from Nielsen indicate that even when children are sitting in front of the television, increasingly it is to view a rented or purchased videocassette, like the Disney movie "Pocahontas."
Not only does a video mean that the parent or child -- not a broadcasting executive -- is acting as programmer, videos are also a limited-access medium for marketers and advertisers.
The beginning of the "Pocahontas" tape, for example, presents a parade of Disney promotions: for Walt Disney World; for a Disney video game; for a coming animated feature, "The Hunchback of Notre Dame," and for older Disney films that are available on video.
Cable programming for children also helps to fragment an audience that once could be counted on to watch the Saturday-morning cartoons of ABC, CBS and NBC.
Today, though only about two-thirds of the nation's households subscribe to cable, one cable programmer, Nickelodeon, has 4 of the 10 programs most watched by children ages 2 to 11. The rest are broadcast by the Fox network, whose "Goosebumps," a series of ghost stories, late on Friday afternoons, is the most popular children's show. Nickelodeon is owned by Viacom Inc., and Fox is owned by the News Corporation.
And many children spend more time than they did a decade ago in weekend and after-school sports or other activities, according to a Nickelodeon/Yankelovich study released last November. More children, too, spend at least part of their week in paid day care -- including nearly one-third of pre-schoolers today, compared with 23 percent five years ago, according to the Census Bureau.
The example of Shelia Martin and Donald Alexis of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, sheds light on day care's television impact.
Ms. Martin is director of the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit developer of affordable homes for moderate-income buyers. Her husband, Mr. Alexis, works at the Park Slope Food Co-op.
Their 5-year-old son, Stephen, a kindergartner, attends an after-school program at the YWCA of Brooklyn, where his 3-year-old sister, Darian, goes to Montessori school. Neither child watches television at the Y, and their parents strictly limit viewing at home.
"The children don't get home until 6:30 P.M.," Ms. Martin said. "They can watch one half-hour a night after school and two hours each on the weekend."

The Money
Class Division At a Young Age?
If the children's television audience is becoming more fragmented, it may be breaking along economic fault lines. One-third of the nation's households do not subscribe to cable television, and income appears to be a factor in who does. The average income of households with cable in 1995 was $43,637, compared with $38,853 for all American households, according to Media Mark Research Inc.
So far, the sheer volume of viewers that the over-the-air broadcasts like Fox's "Goosebumps" can still attract enables broadcasters to charge higher ad rates than cable programmers can. One advertising executive, insisting on anonymity, said a broadcast network might be able to charge $5.50 per thousand viewers for advertising on a popular children's program, compared with $3 per thousand on a similarly popular cable program.
But the executive said that the price gap would not necessarily continue. And certainly Nickelodeon, now in 63 million homes, is benefiting financially from its popularity: its advertising revenues soared 18 percent last year, to an estimated $277 million, from 1994, according to Paul Kagan Associates, a cable industry research and consulting firm.
Yet for advertisers, even cable is not an automatic conduit to the children with the biggest piggy banks. Various data, including the recent New York Times survey, indicate that the children in the most affluent homes may be the ones spending the least time on television of any sort. Many children's advertisers, as a result, are looking more carefully at print, said Robert Horne, executive vice president at Griffin Bacal, the advertising agency that represents Hasbro and Discovery Zone.
A number of children's publications have been created since 1989, including Sports Illustrated for Kids. And even some children's cable programmers, like Nickelodeon and Disney Adventures, have branched out into magazines.
Nickelodeon magazine, which has a circulation of 550,000, is seeing significant growth in paid advertising pages -- 220 last year, compared with 178 in 1994, according to the publisher, Lynn Lehmkuhl.
From an advertiser's perspective, Mr. Horne said, magazines "supplement what you do on television, so you create a synergy between what kids are reading and viewing."
As advertisers sift through the fragmenting children's audience, some experts on children's television wonder what the trend means for the nation's youth.
"It is the rare child who would not watch the most popular TV shows, but wealthy kids are doing more sophisticated things, too," said Joan Ganz Cooney, the founder and executive chairman of the Children's Television Workshop and the driving force behind "Sesame Street" and other educational children's television programs.
Ms. Cooney adheres to the philosophy that the best children's television programming helps give the nation's youth a common basis for understanding the world.
Whether most broadcast television programming has ever fulfilled that potential is debatable, of course. But because much of the popular children's programming is gravitating toward cable, where less affluent children may not follow, Ms. Cooney worries about their ability to share in mainstream cultural experiences. And the home PC may increase the fragmentation, she said.
"Now the differential will be widened further by computers in the home," Ms. Cooney said. "The children in more affluent homes are being prepared for the future at a very young age."

HEADLINE: Books on Tape Inc. Carves Out Quiet Niche Among Big Publishing Houses

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER 

DATELINE: COSTA MESA, Calif.

 BODY:
In 1975, when a former Olympic rower named Duvall Y. Hecht founded Books on Tape Inc., his plan to market audiocassettes containing complete spoken-word versions of printed books was considered foolhardy, even eccentric.
By the mid-1980's, when publishers like Random House, a unit of Advance Publications, and Simon & Schuster began pushing "audio books," or condensed versions of best sellers and self-help books, the most important part of Mr. Hecht's business strategy -- offering unabridged recordings of a wide variety of books -- was rejected by these publishing giants as impractical. 
 Today, while the mainstream audio-book industry has mushroomed into a fiercely competitive $1.4 billion business, Mr. Hecht, 65, maintains a genteely profitable cottage industry.
"If anything, their success has resulted in increased business for us," said the silver-haired Mr. Hecht.
Indeed, the continued health of Books on Tape reflects the fact that niche opportunities remain as the publishing industry searches for mass markets in new media.
"When people who've been buying abridgments find us, they think they've died and gone to heaven," said Mr. Hecht over lunch near his company's headquarters in this seaside community in Orange County.
Heaven, by the definition of Mr. Hecht and his customers, is the ability to cushion oneself against grueling commutes by listening to, say, 12 hours of "Economics of Crisis" by Eliot Janeway or seven hours of "Northanger Abbey" by Jane Austen on tape.
Mr. Hecht's larger rivals publish and sell a limited number of titles, typically six to eight a month, in severely edited one- or two-cassette versions. Books on Tape rents and sells an eclectic range of about 3,000 titles, which come in packages of 90 minutes, 6 hours, or 15 hours of cassettes. The company commits every word in the printed version to tape.
Books on Tape contends, without serious challenge, that it publishes the world's largest selection of unabridged audio books -- from "The Client" by John Grisham to "Down and Out in Paris and London" by George Orwell and the complete works of Winston Churchill.
The big publishers' audio books are usually sold in retail bookstores, with all the rewards for successfully appealing to a large audience, as well as the heavy penalties for misjudging public demand.
Books on Tape rents and sells its products almost exclusively through the mail. Mr. Hecht said his privately held company reported $10 million in annual revenue last year. That might be barely a blip on the publishing industry's radar screen but some 150,000 customers receive Books on Tape's 300-page catalogue.
About a third of the company's business is sales to libraries that pay an average of $60 a title. A core group of about 85,000 individuals are steady renters, Mr. Hecht said. Some spend up to $1,000 a year on tapes, which cost $9 to $20 each for 30 days.
"For the price of a two-hour freeze-dried abridgment they can get the full story told in the author's own words," Mr. Hecht said.
At the company's office in a converted sailmaker's loft, dozens of books being considered for recording line the bookshelves. "A lot of these are suggested or actually sent to us by our customers," said Mr. Hecht, who oversees a staff of 65.
On a second-floor balcony, a dozen or so tape decks are busy duplicating titles from master cassettes. More than 350,000 sets of rental tapes leave the building each year; about 99 percent eventually return.
To the mainstream audio-book industry, the idea of concentrating on a relatively small number of customers -- and the postage- and labor-intensive operation that supplies them with easily copied rental tapes -- is out of the question.
Seth Gershel, publisher of the audio division of Simon & Schuster, owned by Viacom Inc., which controls about a third of the market, said: "If we did what Books on Tape did, we would not be moving enough units, reaching enough customers. It would put us out of business."
Mr. Hecht said that Books on Tape is almost completely immune to the twin perils of the mass-market book business: press runs that are too small, frustrating potential customers, and overly optimistic sales predictions, which leave the publisher eventually swallowing thousands of unsold books.
"Except for a few big titles, for which we stock 500 or 1,000 tapes, we have no backlog to speak of," Mr. Hecht said.
Rather than hire the television and movie stars that the big publishers generally use to record audio books, Books on Tape employs experienced regional actors.
The company also economizes by recording books in the public domain and sublicensing unabridged recording rights, often on a nonexclusive basis, from big publishers issuing their own abridged editions. The authors whose works are published by Books on Tape typically receive a small advance and a royalty of 10 percent of all sales and rentals.
"They're not getting rich from us, but I haven't heard many complaints," Mr. Hecht said.
Mr. Hecht is quite satisfied with the way things have gone. After winning a gold medal in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, he entered the financial industry. The idea for Books on Tape was born in 1973, during an hourlong commute from his Orange County home to his securities firm office in Los Angeles.
Mr. Hecht and Sigrid Hecht, then his wife, invested $100,000 in the business. Another $100,000 was provided by a group of silent partners who own a third of the company stock.
 The first title issued by Books on Tapes was "Paper Lion" by George Plimpton. Within a few years the business had moved out of the Hechts' living room. It has since attracted several smaller rivals, most notably Recorded Books Inc., based in Prince Frederick, Md., which offers about half as many titles as Books on Tape.
 "That competition keeps us sharp," Mr. Hecht said. "If you believe in the free market, as I do, the important thing is for the customer to have what he wants and to have it in profusion."

HEADLINE: Jury-Duty Dodgers Tell It to the Judge;
After He Hears Their Best Whoppers, a Get-Serious Warning

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
A summons for jury duty in New York State these days arrives with a bunch of tender little carrots dangling from it. Like, say, shorter service. Expanded lists, so that everyone else will be roped in, too. A juror-complaint person. Comfortable chairs. And court employees who have had to attend niceness training seminars. So, nibble, nibble?
This is not, however, about the new carrot inducements to lure prospective jurors from their hiding places. 
 This is about what happens to those who refuse to bite.
This is about the stick.
Every Friday morning, hearings are held in a Manhattan courtroom, affording the indignant and the sheepish an opportunity to tell their best whoppers to a judge. One after another, they offer theories about why they appear to have ignored years of summonses for jury duty, why they should not now be fined $250 and why they should not start jury service immediately.
The Friday hearings are obviously perceived as a last-ditch, get-serious warning, because proportionally, people respond in far greater numbers than they do to the earlier waves of jury summonses. A morning's calendar may have 60 cases, and usually about 40 people show up. They are held weekly only in Manhattan, which has the greatest need for jurors and the greatest number of evaders.
One recent Friday morning, an Upper West Side therapist approached the bench, confident, annoyed. Years ago, he said, the city changed the address of his corner building, from the street to the avenue, and he still hasn't been getting all his mail. So the fault for his seeming juror scofflaw status lay not with him, but with the post office.
Vincent Homenick, Manhattan's earnest and indefatigable chief jury clerk, ominously rattled a computer printout and reeled off a half-dozen dates since 1989 on which notices to the therapist had been mailed.
Justice Louis I. Kaplan fixed the therapist with a deeply skeptical gaze. "You haven't gotten mail on all those dates?" asked Justice Kaplan, who always presides over the Friday hearings in State Supreme Court. "What about the most recent one? It has the right address. And why didn't any of the other letters come back to us?"
The therapist sputtered. Sized up his options. And then punted. "Well, aren't there any exemptions?"
Actually, no. On Jan. 1, professional exemptions, covering some 20 lines of work, were ended. Even so, the therapist would not have been covered because he has a master's degree, not a Ph.D.
"What about my patients?" he tried.
"Change their hours," replied Justice Kaplan, who handed him a $35 judgment and a May date to start jury duty.
Cruel? Heartless? Court officials want to know just how much groveling they have to do to attract jurors to serve. Innovations to increase juror enrollment and decrease juror misery throughout the state have just kicked into high gear, largely at the urging of Judith S. Kaye, New York State's top judge. In civil trials, judges now supervise and sometimes take over the questioning of jurors, cutting down on intrusiveness and expansiveness by lawyers. Overnight stays for deliberating juries are no longer mandatory. By 1998, jurors' daily fees will rise to $40 from the current $15.
And no longer are the same people being called over and over. Names are now drawn from five sources: lists of registered voters, the unemployed, those on public assistance, taxpayers and drivers. Podiatrists and embalmers are among the professionals who can no longer duck service. The same goes for doctors, lawyers and police officers (all three of whom were represented on a recent Manhattan murder jury). Returns are improving so much that in many counties, jurors need only serve one day if they are not selected for a trial.
In Manhattan, that required term of service has been whittled down to three days from two weeks. Norman Goodman, the County Clerk of Manhattan, said the percentage of jurors who were showing up for service had doubled from January's, to nearly 30 percent. "It's a miracle!" exclaimed the incredulous Mr. Goodman, who said this was the first real good news he'd had since taking office in 1969.
But not everyone is getting with the program. In Manhattan, which has the most jury trials of any jurisdiction in the state and which consumes jurors at a voracious rate, some 30,000 people have resisted the urge to serve, and their cases are pending.
For them, there does come a moment when the normally accommodating Mr. Homenick, who has heard every juror excuse conceivable, stops being Mr. Nice Guy.
So exactly how many times can someone ignore a summons before the system starts sending those nasty-grams? Mr. Homenick declined to specify. "We don't want your readers to know how many notices they can just chuck in the garbage," he said.
As chief clerk of the jury division, Mr. Homenick has even been sent obscene responses to his summonses ("makes you wonder what kind of jurors they'd be," he said). He vows that he does try to give breaks to people in tight situations. Although the exemptions for sole proprietors have been tanked, he will, for example, try to figure out whether there is a seasonal aspect to their work and schedule jury service during their slower months.
And he will grant temporary exemptions to a person who can show that three days of jury service will cause extreme financial hardship. "That means compromising the ability to support themselves and their families," said Mr. Homenick, during a break in the Friday hearing. "But we've had doctors come in and complain that they'd lose $10,000 in billing for three days. Do you think they're the kind of people who will have trouble feeding their families?"
The hearing resumed. Another prospective juror, a woman from Hell's Kitchen, approached Justice Kaplan. According to Mr. Homenick's records, the woman had not answered inquiries sent to her home repeatedly over the last 18 months.
"So?" Justice Kaplan said.
She took a deep breath and said evenly, "Due to my emotional problems and chemical dependencies, your honor, I don't think I'm an appropriate juror at this time."
Justice Kaplan, who has heard dozens of stories, asked for proof. She produced a letter from her doctor. "This just says you're being treated by him," the justice said gruffly. "How do I know it's not for an earache?"
The woman pointed to the letterhead. "That's a methadone clinic," she said, blushing. The justice hastily excused her.
Most pleaders do have the forethought to bring documentation and witnesses to support their case: passports, tax documents, copies of letters, even their lawyers (although a paralegal who brought a lawyer to argue that she was indispensable to their firm was fined the full $250). Once, a secretary to a building contractor brought her boss, who thundered that he would not be able to work if his assistant went on jury duty. In ringing tones, the contractor summed up: "And if she does, I'll fire her!"
For a long moment, the silence in the courtroom hung thick and threatening. Then Justice Kaplan broke it. He not only ordered the secretary to start jury duty the following Monday, but also ordered the boss to do his service immediately after hers was finished. And if the secretary wound up being fired for doing her civic duty, said the justice, he would hold the boss in criminal contempt.
In fact, it would appear that if a pleader's goal is to reduce a fine or further delay jury service, belligerence should not be the tactic of choice.
Adrienne Gorman, another therapist, stormed up to the bench, her short hair quivering. Mr. Homenick conceded that Ms. Gorman had served in 1982 and deliberated on juries in 1987 and 1991 but said that she had refused to sign the summonses mailed to her in 1992, 1993, 1994 and 1995.
"I know many people who haven't been called," Ms. Gorman snapped. "When they have served two times, I'd be very happy to serve again. But not until."
Justice Kaplan icily told her that she had to serve, starting in mid-May. "I'll be a hostile juror, then!" Ms. Gorman said.
He fined her $50.
"I'm not paying," Ms. Gorman said.
If a judgment for not complying with a jury summons goes unpaid, it is entered on one's record. That means whenever the adversely judged wants a line of credit or a mortgage, the unpaid judgment will pop up.
All morning long, the grumpy parade marched up to Justice Kaplan. Some began unctuously: They really, really believed in jury duty and would just love to serve -- except they had a problem.
Said one pleader: "I couldn't show up for jury duty that day because I was in so much pain that I had to go to the emergency room!" With a flourish, he produced his medical bill.
The justice scoured it and scowled. "But this says you were only there for a few hours!"
Another pleader tried his luck. "I'm in the export business and I travel a good deal, so I can justify all 10 of those adjournments for jury duty!" he announced.
Justice Kaplan was not bowled over. "But it's not up to you to justify them," he said. "Pay a fine of $100 and start serving in May."

HEADLINE: Cities Are Digging Deep and Wide as Congress Tightens Purse

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
When Congress began swinging its ax in earnest last fall at the Federal deficit, somebody forgot to tell Amarillo to duck.
The transportation spending bill that Republican legislators pushed to passage in November whacked $225,000 off the annual subsidy to the 13-bus transit department in the Texas panhandle city. A political impasse over poverty programs bottled up a $48,000 allotment for summer jobs for youths in Amarillo. 
 A White House veto of another Republican spending bill put housing programs on a month-to-month budget that is shaving about $100,000 a year from Federal subsidies to poor renters in the city. More reductions loom.
"Assuming the worst, we're looking at a 33 percent cut in funding" for aid to the homeless, said Vicki Covey, assistant director of community services in Amarillo, "and I'm starting to assume the worst."
What is striking after six months of Republican-inspired parsimony, though, is how seldom the worst has occurred so far. Some belts have surely tightened, as Republican leaders promised, and millions have in fact felt the pinch of Federal-spending restraints, sometimes painfully, as President Clinton has warned.
But Congress is already loosening other cinches, agreeing to restore money to programs and agencies it had vowed to slash only months ago when elections seemed less imminent. And some targets of Republican budget cuts have discovered, a bit grudgingly, that it is possible to make do with less Federal financing than they had been accustomed to.
Facing at least a 23 percent cut in Federal subsidies to employ teen-age students this summer in city parks and offices, Sacramento, Calif., and Pittsburgh are recruiting private businesses to fill the breach with hundreds of jobs of their own. Louisville dug into its own budget for $600,000 in summer-jobs money.
Memphis decided that it could renovate the historic Exchange Building into 270 apartments with a smaller dollop of Federal aid than it had counted on. Iowa's State Legislature may make up some of the money that a deeply suspicious Congress has withheld from the Legal Services Corporation, the federally financed agency that helps provide lawyers' services to the poor.
The Amarillo Transit Department, which ferries a half-million mostly working-class passengers each year, planned for a 50 percent cut in service when the Transportation Department sliced its subsidy in November. Instead, the state government dug deep and ponied up the lost $225,000, at least for this year. Which is not to say that anyone is happy about his new circumstances.
"This year, we're O.K.," said the city's transit manager, Wayne Pelton. "Now, from there on, I can't say what's going to happen."
In fact, any respite from spending cuts may be temporary, because both Congress and the White House insist that they have just begun to clamp down on domestic spending.
Republicans say spending in this fiscal year on so-called domestic discretionary programs -- most domestic spending, except for the military and entitlements like welfare and Medicare -- will be $23 billion less than was forecast when they took control in January 1995. As envisioned by the Republicans, spending in real dollars (the amount adjusted for inflation) would more or less drop steadily as the Federal budget moved toward balance in 2002.
Mr. Clinton has denounced the "extreme Republican effort to balance the budget through wrongheaded cuts and misplaced priorities," but his latest budget also proposes real cuts in domestic spending later this decade, followed by modest increases in 2001 and 2002.
It is too early to say with precision how deeply this year's budget reductions will eventually bite. Some Federal programs are financed with 1996 allotments earmarked for 1997 expenses, so that state and local governments will not feel the effects of cuts until they begin to spend it some months from now.
Federal aid to schools, which is usually parceled out in the winter to be spent when classes begin in the following autumn, is one example. This year's budget battle has stalled passage of legislation setting a budget for education spending, and schools are complaining that they cannot hire teachers and buy supplies for September's classes until it is settled.
Scores of other programs are limping by on monthly stipends, usually at or slightly below 1995 spending levels, while Republicans and Democrats continue fighting over permanent budgets for the programs. They include social programs like nutrition services for the aged and adult day care that may not be major bones of contention in Washington, but have gotten caught up in the larger legislative battles.
"It's housing, economic development, riverfront trail development -- a whole potpourri of initiatives," said Margaret McCormick Barron, director of intergovernmental relations for Pittsburgh. "To the best of my knowledge, we've not had to stop anything. But we've had to be very, very creative in our planning."
And then there are many federally financed initiatives that have been forced to make cuts, large and small, to cope with the new budget reality.
Sacramento and Pittsburgh may have found money and employers to provide jobs for thousands teen-agers this summer. But Amarillo has not. Its summer youth program, which would have put 15 young people to work in city departments, has been zeroed out for this year by the Texas state government, which acts as a conduit for Federal jobs grants.
In Fresno, Calif., unlike Iowa, nobody is making up a 30 percent cut in Federal money for legal aid to the poor. So Central California Legal Services has shrunk its office space by about half; cut its roster dealing with evictions, domestic violence complaints and similar cases by 20 percent, to 2,000, and canceled weekly seminars on common legal problems.
"Now we just give them packets," said Sherry Carey, the agency's executive secretary.
The public-housing authority in Kansas City, Mo., is already in receivership and has laid off its security police and stopped assisting disabled applicants for housing, among other things, to offset the loss of $800,000 from an annual Federal subsidy of $4.8 million.
Amarillo, which has a program that gives vouchers for Federal rent subsidies to the poor, is withholding unused vouchers for three months before giving them to other families, those whose annual average income is about $5,000.
Idling the surrendered vouchers saves the Federal Government about $100,000 a year that would have been spent on subsidies had another family been given the chance to use them immediately. For the 2,100 Amarillo families vying for the 935 vouchers, it means that two and a half years of waiting for an apartment they can afford has been extended by three months.
Indeed, services to the poor have been cut about three times as deeply as other domestic discretionary programs, according to an analysis released last month by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning research and advocacy group in Washington.
Whether that will remain so is another question. The White House has used such reductions as weapons in the emerging Presidential campaign, and Republican leaders have agreed to trim back some proposed cuts, in programs like those for education and subsidies that help pay heating bills for the poor. More such easing in reductions can be expected this summer as both sides wrap up the spending battles and move on to the fall campaign.

HEADLINE: Optometrists Clash With Eye Surgeons Over Laser Process

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 7

 BODY:
Eager to perform a new eye procedure that experts say could generate as much as $10 billion in revenues, two groups of eye-care specialists are battling each other here and in other capitals over bills that will help to determine which side will control the market.
On one side are optometrists, whose duties were once limited to eye examinations and prescribing glasses but who have been winning broader rights to diagnose diseases, treat them and prescribe drugs in 47 states. 
 On the other side are ophthalmologists, eye doctors who have attended medical school and have gradually lost their monopoly on many eye treatments but still are the only ones who can perform eye surgery. They contend that the procedure is too risky to allow people without medical degrees to conduct it.
The pot of gold shining in front of both groups is a relatively new -- and expensive -- laser procedure, known as photorefractive keratectomy, that corrects nearsightedness by slightly flattening the cornea. If it catches on as many experts predict, it could mean millions of dollars in fees going to whichever group performs the procedure, and it could hurt the market for new glasses and contact lenses.
While no one is questioning the right of ophthalmologists to perform this new procedure, optometrists are saying they should also be authorized to do it. With both sides under the same intense economic pressures that are pinching many medical specialties, the fight over who will be allowed to execute this laser procedure is shaping up as one of the nation's most bitter medical turf wars.
"It's economics," said Dr. Kenneth P. Taylor, director of the medical and ophthalmic consulting unit at Arthur D. Little Inc. "Everyone's rushing for the cash flow from a procedure that in 10 or 20 years may become as common a right of passage as getting braces."
Experts say the relatively painless procedure, which now costs from $1,800 to $2,300 per eye, should revolutionize the eye-care industry by correcting the vision of people with moderate to mild nearsightedness. Still, some ophthalmologists caution that the procedure is not all it is cracked up to be and note that there are no studies of its impact on a patient's vision beyond three years.
Dr. Taylor warned that the initial market for the procedure would be relatively small -- roughly 240,000 patients a year -- and that other laser procedures may supplant this one. Still, he added that both ophthalmologists and optometrists are looking to refractive surgery as "the holy grail" that will compensate for declining government reimbursements and the pressure from managed-care organizations to cut rates.
This has led to a nationwide movement by optometrists to gain the right to perform laser procedures, and Connecticut is at the forefront of the debate. Last month, the State Senate voted by 28 to 7 to authorize them to use lasers, as well as to treat glaucoma and prescribe oral drugs, including painkillers and steroids.
That victory was the result of an extensive lobbying campaign that has intensified in recent weeks as the Connecticut Association of Optometrists strives to win the next vote in the State House of Representatives and to overcome the suddenly mobilized ophthalmologists. The optometrists have been running full-page newspaper and radio advertisements and sending sacks of letters to lawmakers, pleading with them to allow optometrists to perform the procedure.
Both sides have hired two of the capital's most influential and costly lobbying firms, and lawmakers say it has turned into one of the most heated battles before the legislature. "I've seen legislators hollering at each other over this," said State Representative David Pudlin, a New Britain Democrat.
In the last two years, similar legislation to let optometrists use lasers has been offered in Alaska, Colorado, New Jersey, California and Virginia and, ophthalmologists and optometrists agree that new fronts will break out across the nation over the next several years. Optometrists are already performing this procedure in Idaho.
The clashes are the latest in a long-running feud that began more than 20 years ago when optometrists began seeking the right to use diagnostic drugs. Since then, they have won the right to do this in almost every state and have obtained varying powers in 34 states to use drugs for treatment of serious eye diseases, like glaucoma, a chronic disorder that can lead to blindess.
This gradual expansion in the scope of optometry represents a concerted effort to redefine the profession beyond eye exams and glasses to being the primary health care provider for eye problems. Some health experts say that this attempt to supplant ophthalmologists as the basic eye practitioner has been further encouraged by the general trend toward managed care and its emphasis on using less costly types of service.
According to figures provided by associations for the two groups, a typical optometrist earned about $80,000 in 1994, about half what an ophthalmologist earned. The ophthalmologist's education is more extensive, having gone to four years of medical school and completed four years of internship and residency, compared with the optometrist's four-year optometry program.
Indeed, a central question in the debate over laser procedures is whether optometrists' knowledge is sufficient to do them.
Dr. Alden N. Haffner, president of the State University of New York College of Optometry, told Connecticut lawmakers earlier this year that optometric education has changed sharply in the last two decades, teaching students about treating diseases and using prescriptive medications and now offering guidance with laser therapies.
"The profession has been undergoing a metamorphosis," Dr. Haffner said in an interview last week. "We are now primary eye-care practitioners, and using lasers is going to be a fundamental part of that role."
But ophthalmologists maintain that optometrists have already expanded their authority too far and that laser procedures should generally be considered surgery -- an area off limits to those without medical training. They note that despite claims by optometrists to being primary eye-care providers, a recent survey in The Review of Optometry showed that optometrists write only 2.5 percent of ophthalmic prescriptions and that many did not consider themselves well prepared for such a role.
Although optometrists contend that they can learn the new laser procedures just as most ophthalmologists will have to learn them, Dr. Patricia Caton Reardon, president of the Conecticut Society for Eye Physicians, dismissed that argument.
"You have to scrape off the outer skin and then reshape the eyeball," Dr. Reardon said. "It doesn't take a rocket scientist to see that's invasive surgery."
Still, the procedure does not involve opening the eyeball, and the Federal Government has left it up to the states to decide whether optometrists can perform photorefractive keratectomies.
The procedure has only been authorized since last October, when the Food and Drug Administration granted Summit Technology of Waltham, Mass., the right to manufacture and market an excimer laser system designed for this procedure. On March 27, another company, VISX Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., received F.D.A. approval to produce and sell its own excimer laser.
The procedure lasts about 40 minutes, though only 30 to 40 seconds involve the laser. In the first part, the epithelium, the skin covering the cornea, must be peeled off. Then, a computer-operated laser, set and positioned by the practitioner, shoots pulses of cool ultraviolet light that reshape the cornea. Finally, a soft contact lens is placed over the eye, serving as a bandage until the epithelium is healed.
In the first few days, the practitioner must watch closely to see how the cornea is growing back and to use medications to guide its formation. While the eye may hurt a bit initially, the vast majority of patients report an improvement in vision. A small number continue to need glasses and may suffer other complications.
The procedure is generally not covered by insurance.
With as many as 70 million nearsighted people in the United States, the potential market is large, easily $10 billion. Yet, it is far from clear how quickly that potential will be reached.
Dr. Taylor of Arthur D. Little said that the procedure now makes sense only for those between about 25 and 45 years old, that a large number of nearsighted people's vision is too impaired to be helped by the process and that others will not be able to afford it. Of this pool of about 10 million people, he assumed that only a small percentage would be ready in the next few years to try the new procedure.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new laser procedure for correcting nearsightedness was demonstrated at Crystal Vision Associates on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan by Dr. Robert C. Cykiert, an ophthalmologist, with Randy Kilminick, a laser technician. In the chair was Wendi Fitzpatrick, who has had the procedure and can now see without eyeglasses or contact lenses. Optometrists are battling to be allowed to perform the procedure. (Jack Manning/The New York Times) (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALLAn Early Lesson on Expectation vs. Reality

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
When the comparison was suggested to him yesterday, Dallas Green laughed and said it probably was fair: Having Zane Smith and Danny Darwin shut out the Mets for a total of 11 innings during the dry part of the weekend was like Green's pitching two successive shutouts when the manager played for the Mets in 1966.
The only problem is, Green didn't pitch a major league shutout beyond 1961, and the Mets did fail to score a run against the retreads Smith and Darwin in the space of 20 hours Friday and Saturday. 
 The Pirates' outlook with the 35-year-old Smith and the 40-year-old Darwin is not as bright as the Mets' outlook with their pair of 23-year-old pitchers, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson. But the Pirates came to Shea Stadium for the second series of the season and showed why teams play the games on the schedule rather than let the experts determine the outcome.
They play the games because expectations do not always translate into achievement on the field. Some players and teams, in fact, crumble under the weight of expectations.
Asked on opening day what his expectations were for the Mets, Green said: "I'll be disappointed if they don't play very sound defense. If they're not one of the five best defensive clubs in either league, I would be very surprised."
Five games later, the Mets were the worst defensive team in the National League, having committed nine errors, which, for just one example, happened to be nine more than the Colorado Rockies had committed.
That is not to say that Green's defensive expectations have placed some sort of unbearable burden on his players.
"We've been reading and hearing that stuff since last year," Green said, discussing the expectations others brought into this season for the Mets. "That's what I told the guys. It's part of big-league baseball. It's part of the expectations of every spring when every team thinks it can win a championship. All of us have realistic ideas of what the team can do. I don't think we're putting any more pressure on this team than already is on it. Every time Izzy and Wilson go out there, they're supposed to throw no-hitters. But they're used to that."
The Pirates entered the season lugging no one's expectations as excess baggage. But Jim Leyland, their manager, said before rain washed out the third game with the Mets: "I'd rather have high expectations than none at all. When people have pretty high expectations, that means you're normally pretty good. I'd much rather have the pressure of a team that's supposed to win than the pressure of managing a team that's not supposed to win. There's more pressure with that than there is with a team that's supposed to win. A lot of guys say it's a lot of pressure to be expected to win, but I'd rather have that kind of pressure."
Leyland and the Pirates won three consecutive division championships not long ago, then watched as economics stripped them of their best talent. Now, scrapping to get back to respectability, the Pirates make whatever moves are necessary to fill holes. Thus, the presence of Smith (8-8, with a 5.61 earned run average last year) and Darwin (3-10, 7.45 e.r.a.) in the starting rotation.
The St. Louis Cardinals, on the other hand, filled their holes with people like Tony La Russa, Ron Gant, Gary Gaetti, Dennis Eckersley, Todd Stottlemyre and Andy Benes, rapidly raising expectations for themselves.
"Sometimes the expectations come from somewhere else and it's not fair," La Russa said. "The key is the expectations the club has for itself. If the club feels it's legitimate and all the experts think you've got nothing, so what. If all the experts think you have a good club and you don't, so what, because you have to believe you have a chance."
The Mets' 1996 expectations were fueled in the last eight weeks of the 1995 season, when the team won 34 of 52 games, a .654 percentage compared with .380 (35-57) previously.
"We all talk about going to the next level, but we don't know what that next level is going to be," Green said. "We have never played .500 baseball other than the stretch of 60 days last season, so we've got to learn to do that for a length of time. We're still young. We're still going to make mistakes. But I think this team can hold together and have a good summer. Some clubs have improved themselves. I think we can play with most of them. We've proven that. It's just a case of us learning how to handle the peaks and valleys of a 162-game season together as a team."
The season is only a week old, and the Mets have tumbled into their first valley. Committing nine errors in five games and failing to score a run against Zane Smith and Danny Darwin can do that. How they climb out of this early valley will be instructive for them and those who expressed the expectations.

HEADLINE: Let's Vote on Giving Yankees a Stadium

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your April 4 news article on building a new stadium for the Yankees: Politicians and other boosters will justify spending public money on George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, for two reasons. They will contend that the city will receive an economic return from the investment, and they will profess that "civic pride" requires that the Yankees be kept in New York. 
 If the economic returns will be so bountiful, why would private capital allow the public purse to intrude on the investment? If the city places a higher value on keeping the Yankees than on police and fire protection, schools, transportation, parks, sanitation, hospitals, child welfare and other services, shouldn't New Yorkers whose money will be transferred to Mr. Steinbrenner get to vote on that curious preference? They should insist.

Yonkers, April 5, 1996

HEADLINE: The End of Broadway's Run

BYLINE: By Robert Brustein; Robert Brustein is the artistic director of the American Repertory Theatre and drama critic of The New Republic.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The playwright William Gibson once remarked that a dramatist can't make a living on Broadway, only a killing. For decades now, serious writers haven't even been able to make a killing.
The commercial theater may still be considered one of New York's primary tourist attractions, but out-of-town visitors largely patronize musical spectaculars featuring falling chandeliers and whirring helicopters. By the end of this season, only eight plays will have opened on Broadway, and only Terrence McNally's "Master Class" will recoup its initial investment. 
 The Broadway Initiatives Working Group -- a consortium of commercial producers, theater owners and unions -- is trying to restore Broadway as an incubator of serious new plays by reducing the risks to investors. This well-intentioned idea ignores an unhappy truth: There is no longer an audience for serious Broadway plays.
The group's chief suggestions are Federal, state and city tax abatements. New York City has already waived its commercial rent tax on Broadway theaters for the first year of a play's run. The group wants similar abatements on materials for sets, costumes and stage props. It has also created a trust to give grants or loans to theaters and producers.
We should welcome anything that can help the ailing Broadway economy. But some might find it curious, at a time when the cultural buzzword is "privatization," that for-profit theaters should be requesting indirect public subsidies for the sake of encouraging private investment. Is this really the best way to ignite the creative spirit? Wouldn't American theater be better served by giving direct subsidies to the playwrights and the Off-Broadway and nonprofit theaters that can more easily stage new works?
It has been three decades since Broadway was a mecca for new plays, despite intermittent efforts to recapture the past. For example, in the early 90's the Broadway Alliance, a group of producers and theater owners, lowered ticket prices after gaining concessions from unions. Yet of the nine works produced, only two returned their initial investment.
 Yes, a few serious plays have gone straight to Broadway and made money, but success has been fleeting. David Henry Hwang's "M. Butterfly" was a hit, but his next play, "Face Value," closed quickly. And while August Wilson's "Fences" and "The Piano Lesson" were modest successes, his other plays, like "Two Trains Running," lost money for investors, despite his Pulitzer Prizes.
The problem lies with demographics. The audiences that flocked to "Death of a Salesman" and "A Streetcar Named Desire" have either moved to Florida or transferred their allegiance to Off-Broadway institutions like the Manhattan Theater Club and the New York Public Theater. Fifty percent of the patrons for Broadway's new musicals come from out of town, a number that increases to 80 percent for the long-running blockbusters.
Perhaps we should acknowledge that, having lost its traditional audience, Broadway can never again be a home for new plays. Theater foundations should consider giving money directly to playwrights and to the Off-Broadway theaters that are in a better position to risk new works.
Nonprofit theaters are languishing from dwindling Federal and foundation grants. Fellowships for playwrights have declined by 60 percent over the last two decades. The era in which the theaters and writers could count on subsidies produced Arthur Kopit, Edward Albee, Sam Shepard, David Rabe, David Mamet, Adrienne Kennedy, Christopher Durang, Marsha Norman and countless others.
Few of these playwrights started out thinking about Broadway profits. But out of their creative ferment came the flowering of American theater. To risk extending a horticultural cliche, the playwright plants the seeds and the nonprofit theater nourishes the flowers while Broadway, acting as the florist, occasionally plucks the splashiest blossoms.
Everyone shares Broadway's nostalgia for its past glory. But it is getting things backward to renovate the flower shop while the seeds are rotting for want of rain.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 13, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article by Robert Brustein on April 8 about a plan to provide subsidies to Broadway theaters misattributed a quotation. It was the playwright Robert Anderson who wrote, "You can make a killing in the theater, but not a living."

HEADLINE: Help Close Technology Gap for the Disabled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As Carl R. Augusto notes in "Technology Gap" (Op-Ed, April 3), the new Telecommunications Act of 1996 provides a chance to address some problems. One provision will require manufacturers and providers to insure that their equipment and services are accessible to people with disabilities, which can help level the playing field for 49 million Americans, 60 percent of whom are unemployed. Another provision is to insure that video programming is accessible to 38 million Americans with hearing disabilities and visual impairments. 
 Other provisions on universal service and deployment of advanced services to schools and libraries hold promise as equalizers of opportunity for all Americans traditionally underserved in telecommunications, including people with disabilities. I urge everyone who cares about these issues to become involved as the F.C.C. implements this historic law.
 
REED HUNDT

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Drops in U.S. Stocks and Bonds Leave Dollar Mixed for the Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against most leading currencies following sharp selloffs in United States bond and stock markets, then gradually recovered in New York to end mixed.
"It's a very thin market and nobody was going to load up the trucks with dollars on a day that was predicted to see a selloff in stocks and bonds," said Margaret Kudaraskas, a senior foreign-exchange analyst at Technical Data in Boston. 
 In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 107.75 Japanese yen, up from 107.68 yen late Friday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4817 German marks, down from 1.4835 marks. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5290.
American bonds and stocks tumbled yesterday, following Friday's employment report that was stronger than expected for a second consecutive month. The data indicated that the economy was growing faster than previously thought and that inflation -- and higher interest rates -- could revive.
While higher interest rates would bolster the value of the dollar by making United States deposits more attractive, the selloffs in stocks and bond threatened to reduce demand for dollars among foreign investors. Expectations of higher interest rates lifted the dollar on Friday, when the stock market was closed and bonds held a shortened session.
In other trading, the dollar fell to 1.1953 Swiss francs, from 1.1960, and to 5.0521 French francs, from 5.0850. Against the Italian lira, the dollar was unchanged at 1,566 lire.
Anticipation that the United States bond and stock markets would tumble at their opening yesterday dragged the dollar down in Asian trading earlier in the day. Still, trading was thin, with financial markets in Europe and Hong Kong closed.
The dollar continued to fall in New York trading as the Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 140 points, before recovering to end down 88.51 points. As bonds and stocks came off their lows, the dollar pared its losses in late trading.
"If we can contain the losses in stocks and bonds to where we are now, I think it will firm up," Ms. Kudaraskas of Technical Data said.

HEADLINE: Utilities Seek Deal's Approval

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, April 8

 BODY:
The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company and the Potomac Electric Power Company said today that they had jointly filed applications with the Public Service Commissions of Maryland and the District of Columbia seeking approval of the $2.9 billion acquisition of Potomac Electric by Baltimore Gas.
The companies said the resulting company, the Constellation Energy Corporation, would freeze basic electric rates until 2000, provide credits to reduce customer bills if the company met financial goals and provide a package of economic development incentives totaling $10.6 million annually. 
 Baltimore Gas and the Washington-based Potomac Electric both said they expected to complete the transaction, first announced in September, by the end of the first quarter of 1997.
The transaction still requires approval by the Public Service Commissions of Maryland, Washington, Pennsylvania, Virginia and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
