HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
25 Years an Exile: An Old Black Panther Sums Up

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
More than a quarter of a century after he sought political asylum in Cuba, William Lee Brent still seems American to the core. He speaks a Spanish tinged with the Louisiana accent of his boyhood, prefers whisky to rum, and continues to focus his attention on many of the same causes he once espoused as a member of the Black Panther Party.
But Mr. Brent has cast his lot with the Cuban revolution, and even if he wanted to, he could not return to the land of his birth. He arrived here in 1969 after hijacking an airliner bound for New York from San Francisco with 76 people on board, and after all these years he remains a fugitive from American justice. 
 Now, at the age of 66, Mr. Brent has written an autobiography, "Long Time Gone: A Black Panther's True-Life Story of His Hijacking and 25 Years in Cuba" (Times Books, a subsidiary of Random House). In it, he recalls growing up poor in the South, the years he spent in San Quentin prison on an armed robbery conviction, his career as a political activist in Oakland and the ups and downs of his life in Cuba -- but expresses no remorse for the act that first brought him here.
"I considered myself a foot soldier, out there with the troops, where I could make a contribution to the black liberation movement," Mr. Brent said during an interview here. "I was at war, as strange as that may sound to some people now, with an enemy, which was the United States Government, and the skyjacking was a continuation of that struggle."
If Mr. Brent has any regrets, they stem from his isolation from his mother and sister, who have never come to visit him, and his inability to fully "feel the pulse of what's going on in the black community anymore." In retrospect, he views his association with the Black Panthers as the highlight of his life, and refers frequently to party leaders such as Eldridge Cleaver, Huey Newton and Bobby Seale both in the book and in conversation.
By his own admission, Mr. Brent squandered the first half of his life on petty crime, which rewarded him with nothing more than an intimate knowledge of the American prison system and a bitterness that corroded his soul. Joining the Black Panthers, he said, plunged him into "a vital, effervescent, crazy, wonderful period of time" that gave him direction, purpose, pride and, above all, a political education.
"The Panthers were a street gang, but one that was highly politicized and conscious," Mr. Brent said when asked about several recent revisionist books that portray the group as basically criminal in intent. "It was a street gang with a political agenda directed toward bettering the black community. Instead of dealing dope and getting rich, they did what they were supposed to do."
But when Mr. Brent first arrived here, he found to his shock that the Cuban state security apparatus regarded him with the same suspicion as the American authorities. Instead of being hailed as a hero, he was tossed into jail for 22 months, where he struggled to convince his captors "I am a revolutionary" and not a C.I.A. agent. He was then sent to "hijack house," a halfway home full of renegade Americans unhappy to learn that the Cuban revolution had no use for sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll.
Prison in the United States "is not as hard as here," Mr. Brent said when asked to compare his eight years in San Quentin and Tehachapi with his time in an isolation cell on the outskirts of Havana. "Here they don't allow you to do anything but hard time."
Since his release, Mr. Brent has done a bit of everything: cut sugar cane and raised pigs, worked in a soap factory, taught English to high-school students and been a disk jockey and announcer on Radio Havana. "I wouldn't trade those years for anything, because they taught me how to love work, instead of hating it and having to struggle to find a job," he said.
Mr. Brent now lives with his wife, Jane McManus, a fellow American radical who first visited Cuba in the 1960's, in a comfortable apartment with a view of the Almendares River and a tree-studded park. His neighbors may be Cuban, but the records in his music collection are jazz and blues. He uses a computer to stay abreast of "the movement," as he still calls it, and its crusades, attested to by a prominently displayed poster calling for freedom for Mumia Abu-Jamal, a radio journalist convicted of killing a police officer in Philadelphia in 1981 in a case that has drawn widespread protests.
"Here I have basically learned that I was an American," he said, idly petting a pair of longhaired dachshunds as they wandered by. "I had never considered myself an American before, but you can't get rid of what you are, what you grew up in, the way you were formed."
To promote his autobiography, Mr. Brent has taken part in several radio telephone call-in programs from the United States, and also recently held a book party at his residence here. That event drew a mixed crowd of American and Canadian expatriate leftists and prominent Cuban intellectuals.
"This is a remarkable book filled with authenticity and sincerity, with strong images of Bill's childhood," Victor Casaus, a Cuban writer, told the gathering. "It demonstrates the author's need to settle accounts, including with some demons from his own past."
But recent years have also been unsettling, Mr. Brent said, and a challenge to his beliefs. With the collapse of the Soviet bloc and the mounting economic privations that have followed here, he said, "the people who worked and sacrificed everything" have become disillusioned and the Government "has had to struggle to preserve some of the social gains that had been made."
"Cuban society is more and more dependent on outside forces" from the world of capitalism, Mr. Brent lamented. "People have discovered that not all Cubans are in agreement with the revolution, that they want some things the revolution taught them were bad, like Big Macs and Nikes."
Nevertheless, his own faith that socialism is the best path for humanity remains unshaken, he said. So is his conviction that he must never abandon his struggle against "the system" he still believes forced him here, even if it means he never sets foot in the United States again.
"I've been running all my life, fleeing one thing or another, looking for this, trying to find that," he said. "I've been on a flight from depression, oppression, racism, injustice, inhumanity, cruelty. That flight is not over, but I'm not just running from it. I'm fighting it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Lee Brent, a former member of the Black Panther Party, arrived in Cuba in 1969 after hijacking an airliner and since then has cast his lot with the Cuban revolution. Now he has written his autobiography. (Larry Rohter/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: Jordan Allowing U.S. to Use Its Air Base for Flights Over Iraq

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 8

 BODY:
For the first time since the Persian Gulf war, American warplanes are preparing to carry out patrols over southern Iraq from neighboring Jordan, a step that could elevate tensions between Baghdad and Amman.
Jordan sided with Iraq during the war, in 1991, and remained aligned with Iraq until eight months ago. It has since reversed its course, but its decision to permit the American aircraft to use Jordan as a base for flights over Iraq is being seen as evidence of a a wholesale transformation in its policy toward Iraq. 
 "It's an irreversible step," said a Western diplomat based in Amman, the Jordanian capital. Another well-placed envoy there described the move as Jordan's "most hostile action so far" toward Baghdad.
Since he broke with Iraq last August, King Hussein of Jordan has granted refuge to several prominent Iraqi defectors, most notably to two sons-in-law of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. The King has encouraged Iraqi opposition leaders to establish an office in Amman and has ordered stepped-up scrutiny of shipments bound for Iraq by way of Jordanian ports to insure compliance with United Nations sanctions.
Beginning this week, nearly three dozen United States Air Force F-15's and F-16's will be based for at least two months at an airfield near the Iraqi border to give tangible new form to the King's change of heart.
The aircraft, drawn from various bases in the United States, will join other American and allied warplanes in enforcing the no-flight zone in the southern third of the country, where Iraqi aircraft have been prohibited from flying since August 1992.
The zone was established by the United States, France, Britain and Russia to limit Iraq's military suppression of dissident Shiite Muslims in the region. President Hussein and most of his Government are members of Iraq's large Sunni Muslim minority.
Until now the patrols have been carried out exclusively by aircraft operating from carriers in the Persian Gulf and from bases in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Bahrain, all wartime allies. The United States and its allies carry out similar aerial patrols from bases in Turkey to help protect Kurds in northern Iraq.
Because the pro-Iraqi sentiment in Jordan, particularly among the country's large Palestinian population, that led King Hussein to oppose Western intervention during the gulf war still runs deep, some officials and diplomats in Amman consider his decision to offer his territory as a base potentially risky politically.
They say the discomfort would multiply if an American plane operating from Jordan fired on a threatening Iraqi plane or anti-aircraft emplacement, as has happened more than half a dozen times since the daily operations began.
"Jordan is leading with a glass chin," one European diplomat said of the decision, which will put Amman, which long enjoyed close political and economic ties with the Iraqi Government, in the company of countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
"Particularly in the Arab world," the diplomat said, "it's not a friendly act to station hostile airplanes near a neighbor's territory."
So sensitive is the American presence that Jordan at first denied that the warplanes would carry out patrols over Iraq, saying they were in the country only to take part in American-Jordanian military exercises. It has refused to permit reporters access to the Azraq air base near the Iraqi border, where the first of the 34 American aircraft and the 1,500 personnel that make up the Air Expeditionary Force began to arrive last week.
Marwan Muasher, Jordan's Information Minister, said last week that the American fighter jets and their crews would be used in part to help train the Jordanian Air Force, which is due to receive F-16 aircraft from the United States. American officials said that joint exercises would be conducted by the two countries beginning later this week, involving about 1,000 American soldiers, but that they would be separate from the patrol flight operation.
Iraq, which for the most part has shrugged off Jordan's recent unfriendliness, has not yet commented on its former ally's plan to play host to the American patrols. But even after five years in which its northern and southern skies have remained the exclusive domain of foreign air forces, Iraq may find the new Jordanian role difficult to ignore, diplomats say.
Under an agreement with the United Nations, whose wartime sanctions otherwise prohibit Iraq from selling its goods abroad, Jordan still relies on imported Iraqi oil to meet all of its energy needs. Even today, stretches of the 600-mile desert highway that links Baghdad and Amman were busy with fuel tankers.
But in recent months, Jordan has slashed its trade with Iraq in half, and some drivers interviewed along the bleak route said they were having trouble finding work.
Officials in Washington initially described the decision to use Jordan as a temporary base for the patrols as a way of filling a gap between the departure from the Persian Gulf of the Nimitz aircraft carrier task force and the arrival of its successor, the George Washington.
The carriers play a central role as platforms for the aerial operations, and their absence from the strategic waterway tends to leave American military officials nervous.
But the George Washington has arrived already in the gulf, closing a gap that proved shorter than expected, and an American official in Amman conceded that there was no pressing military need to bring Jordan into the picture.
American aircraft involved in the operation will not fly directly from Jordan over Iraq, a step that would be perceived as an overtly hostile act because it would involve entering airspace still controlled by Iraqi forces, American officials said.
Instead, they will fly south over Saudi Arabia, then turn west and north to enter only the airspace over southern Iraq that the United States and its allies have deemed off limits to Iraqi planes.
Among the Iraqis who have defected to Jordan since last summer, the most significant was Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel al-Majid, a son-in-law of President Hussein and the former director of Iraq's military procurement program.
He and his brother, another son-in-law of the President, and their wives returned to Baghdad in February. The brothers were reported to have been killed by family members.
But King Hussein has continued to grant asylum to other Iraqi defectors, including Lieut. Gen. Nizar al-Khazraji, a veteran of the gulf war who arrived in Amman late last month after escaping into Turkey from the Kurdish area of northern Iraq.
The former director of Iraqi military intelligence, Gen. Wafiq al-Samerai, who had lived in Syria since defecting in late 1994, has also decided to settle in Jordan, officials there said on Sunday. Both military men are thought likely to join the ranks of the the Iraqi National Accord, an American-backed Iraqi opposition group that has operated an office in Jordan since January.

HEADLINE: Debating The Language Of Signs;
New Jersey Towns Tell Asian-Owned Stores: Advertise in English, Too

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: PALISADES PARK, N.J., April 8

 BODY:
Hong Gol Kim, owner of Nadri Tour and Travel, says 95 percent of his agency's business comes from Korean customers. So why, he asks, should he have to comply with a local law that requires him to put up a promotional sign with equal-sized letters in both Korean and English?
"The American people in the neighborhood don't come to my office," he said. "If my customers are 50-50 -- English and Korean -- then I'll do a 50-50 sign." 
 For all his misgivings on the language required in commercial signs in this town not far from the Hudson River, he said he will follow the law, but only after he goes to court on May 22 to answer a summons. He said he wants the judge to explain the logic of the law to him.
Palisades Park is one of seven towns clustered near the George Washington Bridge that have responded to a growing Asian presence in their downtowns by imposing regulations on the Asian merchants. Since 1992, all seven towns have enacted laws requiring that half of any foreign-language commercial sign be in English. But the impact has been most noticeable here, where Asian-American merchants now own most of the 144 stores on the milelong commercial strip, Broad Avenue.
Longtime residents grumble that the younger Korean merchants cater only to the growing number of Asian residents despite admonitions from their elders to accept the new sign law and to try to serve everyone in town. Older residents seem wary, resentful and suspicious. Often, they flood the town's building inspector, John Candelmo, with calls complaining about perceived violations of the sign law.
"We have a lot of people in town who police the signs," he said.
The Mayor, Susan Spohn, said there was a need for more tolerance and cultural understanding. "The whole issue for many is -- this is America, and signs should be in English," she said. "For a portion of the people -- if they had their druthers -- they'd have completely English signs. But we don't have a national language."
Mr. Candelmo's trouble with the Nadri travel agency is the latest skirmish between City Hall and some of the new Korean merchants. In the last six years, they have bought or leased aging stores, revitalized them and, seemingly overnight, recast the avenue's look. Gone are the fixtures that served Italian, German, eastern European and other immigrant groups that for much of this century shaped the insular, working-class texture of this 1.3-square-mile town of nearly 15,000.
The old ethnic mix has been changed by an influx of Asians since 1980. In 1990, they made up 20 percent of Palisades Park's population, up from about 6 percent in 1980. And more Asians have moved in since the last census. Over half the newcomers are Korean.
What they are finding on Broad Avenue are new Korean-owned restaurants and specialty food stores, art galleries and beauty salons, and stores for pianos and violins, golf equipment and pet supplies, books and artwork, dresses, carpets and furniture, office supplies and electronics.
The old Chamber of Commerce has disbanded, and Broad Avenue has only a few stores left with all-English signs. Paul's Fish Market, a fixture for 68 years, is one. "I have zero Korean customers," the owner, Jerry Nolan, said. "The Korean people prefer to do business with their own, which makes it very difficult."
Visidor DeCarlo, owner of Palisades Pizza, said his shop attracts Asian-American teen-agers. But he estimated that he has lost about $50 in nightly pizza sales since a bar next door was replaced by a Korean restaurant. Mr. DeCarlo said he thought briefly about adding Korean symbols to his sign.
"But it wouldn't be authentic," he said. "It wouldn't be an Italian restaurant. I wouldn't want them to come here because I have Korean writing. I'd want them because I have good pizza."
Soon after the influx quickened in the late 1980's, the town enacted a sign law that required English lettering but did not set any size specifications. That produced signs dominated by Asian symbols. In September 1994, an amendment was passed mandating equal-sized lettering. At the same time, the town banned flashy neon tubes framing windows and doors and more than two colors on a sign, saying the lighting was too garish.
"We were starting to get the rainbow effect, with bright, bright, clashing colors -- hot pink, red orange, and orange, black and yellow," Mr. Candelmo, the inspector, said.
Older Korean merchants on Broad like Andy W. Nam, the owner of Grand Furniture, endorsed the new law. Mr. Nam came to America in 1967 and opened his furniture store in 1989 in a former A.&P. store. English dominates the big awning above his front window, and he said he has always told younger merchants that use of two languages is the best way to entice American and Asian customers.
Not all abide. In recent months, six merchants have been fined from $150 to $250 each for violations, Mr. Candelmo said. "They usually plead ignorance," he said.
Since taking office last October, Mayor Spohn said she has started work on easing tensions and cultural divisions. She goes to functions of the Korean-American Chamber of Commerce. The Town Council has appointed a new liaison to the Asian community -- Peter Suh, a real estate agent who teaches citizenship classes to Koreans and, like Mr. Nam, believes the 50-50 sign law is a key to economic success and acceptance.
There are other cross-cultural overtures. The Korea-American Chamber of Commerce now donates money from its annual golf outing to the Police and Fire Departments and the ambulance corps. And Benjamin Joo, the chamber president, who is a pharmacist, is pleased that the Democratic Party invited him and some other merchants to a victory party after last fall's elections.
But frictions persist. Recently, a Korean church donated $10,000 to the town's $2 million fund for a new library. "When I accepted the check," Mayor Spohn said, "I heard criticism that 'she's catering to them.' "
City Hall must, she said, promote better cultural understanding. Zoning laws and building regulations are alien notions in Korea, she said, and officials must take greater pains to teach newcomers to abide by them. Longtime residents who object to Korean stores staying open nights and on Sundays must understand that Koreans are hard-working and industrious, she said. And, she added, residents must also understand Koreans' love for singing and abandon suspicions that the karaoke recording studios behind the blackened windows in one building on Broad Avenue are not dens of drinking and prostitution.
On the other hand, she said, the Korean merchants have to make the old-time residents feel more welcome. Mr. Nam, the owner of Grand Furniture, denies intentional slights. "Some store owners can't speak English well and are shy -- they just step back and smile," he said.
Officials in the other six towns with sign laws say they do not have Palisades Park's enforcement problems or cultural divisions. Fort Lee, Englewood, Leonia and Cliffside have all adopted 50-50 sign laws since the early 1990's. Officials in Fort Lee say it has less friction because the population is more transient and its Asian stores are not as clustered as Palisades Park's. Englewood, Leonia and Cliffside Park have fewer Asian merchants. Two other towns, Ridgefield and Englewood Cliffs, which adopted their laws in the last few months, have the fewest Asian merchants. But officials say they want laws in place should Asians start to move in in greater numbers.
Ridgefield's law is directed only at new merchants, and several longtime Italian restaurants, among them Ristorante Focacceria Italiana, are exempted from the 50-50 rule.
The towns justify the laws on safety grounds. English lettering, officials said, helps police officers, firefighters and ambulance attendants locate the businesses in emergencies. But a similar law in Pomona, Calif., was ruled unconstitutional by a Federal judge in 1989 on the ground that it limited free speech and discriminated against merchants' national origin. Pomona's Asian-owned businesses had filed the lawsuit.
But the ruling is not legally binding outside that judge's district. Here, the older Korean merchants seem to want the 50-50 signs.
"This is the United States of America," said Mr. Suh, the new liaison. "We have to follow the rules and regulations and must include the English name in signs. If I go to Germany and put in a sign in the Korean language, do they like that? I don't think so. We've got to live in peace -- everybody together. That's what I'm trying to teach the Korean community."

HEADLINE: Cash-Poor in New York City

 BODY:
New York City ran out of cash to pay its bills 21 years ago, brushing closer to bankruptcy than at any time since the Depression. The city is nowhere near bankruptcy now, but it is certainly short of cash. Companies that do business with the city have been told to expect delays in getting paid, while monthly contributions to employee pension funds have been suspended and property owners are being offered discounts for early tax payments. All these problems are painful signs of chronic fiscal problems from Washington to Albany to City Hall.
The underlying problems are no secret. They result from a longstanding disparity between the city's stagnating economic base and the rising costs of government. Despite billions of dollars in budget cuts under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the imbalance remains. The State Financial Control Board, established in the fiscal crisis of 1975, projects deficits of $1.7 billion in the next fiscal year, growing to $4.6 billion by the end of the decade if nothing is done to further reduce costs or raise more money. 
 The gap has been compounded by labor agreements between City Hall and the municipal unions calling for wage freezes now and substantial increases in pay and benefits down the road. The budget impasse in Washington has added a further element of uncertainty.
Most states have gone ahead with budgets and not assumed any Federal windfalls in the form of reduced costs for welfare and Medicaid. But Gov. George Pataki of New York imprudently assumed such savings in his first budget proposal, and now he and the State Legislature are paralyzed over what to do if they do not materialize. Neither party in Albany has had the nerve to rethink the multibillion-dollar tax cuts enacted last year. They are looking instead at budget gimmicks to reduce the size of the deficit this year.
The refusal to face up to reality in Albany has, for the 12th year in a row, prevented enactment of a budget in time for the start of the new fiscal year on April 1. The temporizing, in turn, made it impossible for Mr. Giuliani to know how much state aid he can count on for his own budget, which is supposed to be presented later this month. More than likely, the Mayor will fill his budget with guesswork and empty projections, since he would rather assume that the state will help close his budget gap than embark on another round of tough spending cuts.
Seasonal cash shortages often occur in New York at this time of year. Tax revenues, for example, do not start pouring in until after July 1, when residents start paying their real estate taxes. Late budgets in Albany have meant delays in state aid payment for at least a dozen years. But this year, the city is hemmed in by a series of unreal and unwise budget assumptions of its own.
Two weeks ago, for example, the city got approval to raise $125 million in cash from the Municipal Assistance Corporation from a bond refinancing. The principle behind such refinancings is that you take the money now and promise to cut the budget later. The city is also trying frantically to unload assets, with mixed results. The sale of WNYC-TV has not won approval from the Federal Communications Commission. Hundreds of millions worth of mortgages on city-owned housing projects and liens on unpaid property taxes are supposed to be sold in the next few months, with many experts doubting they can be unloaded on schedule.
Because New York is the financial capital of the nation, a place of civic generosity, there is a tendency to think of the annual budget struggle as a game of no real consequence. But the numbers suggest otherwise. Like a family scrambling to make ends meet by refinancing its mortgage, selling the car and collecting old debts from deadbeat relatives, the city is facing some hard truths.
The last few years have seen cutbacks in services for the poor and middle class alike. The next few months will determine whether city and state politicians can rethink their support of tax cuts that have been enacted or proposed, wage and benefit increases that take place two years from now and costly employee work rules that have undercut the drive for savings in city government. The alternative is an endless cycle of cash shortages.

HEADLINE: The Limits of Openness in Vietnam

 BODY:
Vietnam eagerly welcomes foreign investment these days. But the American businessmen who rushed in after Washington finally normalized ties with Hanoi last year are discovering that Communist hard-liners still grip the reins. Tight ideological controls and a maze of bureaucratic regulations make Vietnam a difficult place to do business and imperil its continued economic advance.
The latest blow to foreign businessmen is a nationwide campaign that targets foreign commercial advertising as a "social evil" to be eradicated, along with prostitution, narcotics and gambling. All over Vietnam, billboards for products like Coca-Cola and Esso gasoline are being blocked out by new coats of paint. 
 While technocrats in the ministries of Trade and Finance draw up plans for modernizing taxes and tariffs and the central bank prepares for the opening of a stock exchange, hard-liners in the military and Communist Party politburo worry that foreign investment threatens to undermine Vietnamese traditions, Ho Chi Minh's Socialist legacy and continued tight political control by the Communist Party. "We are not afraid of capitalist enterprises, but of not being able to supervise and control them," the party's general secretary said last December. Indeed, the Government expects to keep the most important industries in its own hands.
A showdown between Vietnam's modernizing and hard-line factions could occur as early as this June's Communist Party Congress, when a new set of top national leaders is expected to be named.
Six years of market-oriented economic reforms have already brought impressive results. Foreign investors have thus far committed $18 billion. The economy is expanding rapidly, average incomes are rising and inflation has been tamed.
But no Communist Government anywhere, China's included, has yet established the rule of law and climate of predictability that businesses require for serious long-term investment. When Secretary of State Warren Christopher spoke in Hanoi last summer, he rightly emphasized that sustained economic development depends not just on legal protections for property but also on due process for all citizens, free exchange of information and a free press. Vietnam's hard-liners are headed in the opposite direction. They are not just cracking down on foreign advertising, they are also arresting Vietnamese intellectuals who argue that continued economic reform requires more, not less openness to outside ideas.
Capitalist development may be compatible, in its early phases, with authoritarian rule. But longer-term progress will be stunted by insistence on Leninist ideological puritanism. Further, the United States Congress will rightly resist extending most-favored-nation trading privileges to Vietnam until it commits itself more firmly to due process and human rights for all.
Sooner or later, Vietnam, like China, will have to choose between its hopes for rapid development based on international investment and its fears of foreign ideological pollution.

HEADLINE: MARKETS RETREAT AS INTEREST RATES CONTINUE TO CLIMB

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
Stock and bond prices tumbled today as long-term interest rates continued a swift, sharp ascent that is at odds with the Federal Reserve's policy of keeping rates stable and that analysts said could endanger the moderate rate of growth expected this year.
The latest rise in interest rates was set off by data on Friday that showed the economy creating jobs at a faster-than-expected clip. Although the stock market was closed for Good Friday, long-term rates jumped sharply in the bond market. Today that rise, plus a further increase in interest rates, gave the stock market a bad case of the jitters, put upward pressure on mortgage rates and further complicated the economic outlook in a Presidential election year. 
 Early this year, the economy appeared to be running out of steam. But more recently, investors seem to perceive it as rebounding strongly enough to revive fears of inflation. And that fear has set in motion an upward move in long-term rates -- including those that make home mortgages and auto loans more costly -- that may well act to restrain the economy's growth later this year without requiring any action by the Federal Reserve.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 88.51 points today, or 1.56 percent, to close at 5,594.37, after having been down as much as 140 points during the day. [Page D1.]
Interest rates on long-term Government bonds rose to 6.87 percent, up from Friday's close of 6.82 percent and well above the 6.67 percent rate on Thursday. At the beginning of the year, the benchmark 30-year bond yielded only 5.85 percent.
Investors sell bonds, driving up interest rates, when they believe that inflation may erode the value of their holdings or because they think that the Federal Reserve will raise official interest rates to stem inflation.
Unlike the Federal Reserve, which manipulates short-term rates after lengthy deliberations in an effort to keep the economy on an even keel, the bond market is driven by the self-interest of investors and their snap judgments about whether to buy or sell securities.
Those judgments often play a useful role in guiding the Federal Reserve and in helping to smooth out economic ups and downs. But in this case, many economists said, the market appears to be overreacting to economic data that may exaggerate the economy's strength, and that such a sharp rise in rates may well not be justified, especially since there are few signs of incipient inflation.
But whether its conclusions are justified or not, the market effectively sets mortgage rates and heavily influences other long-term loans. If the current surge in rates continues it could put the economy on the skids later this year, economists said.
"The market is saying that the economy cannot afford much of a re-acceleration in job growth without reigniting inflation," said Mark Vitner, an economist with the First Union Corporation, a banking company in Charlotte, N.C. "From a fundamental economic standpoint the market is overreacting. I don't think the pickup in job growth we've seen this year in any way confirms that the economy is about to re-accelerate or has already reaccelerated."
Previously worried about a faltering economy, the Federal Reserve last cut rates on Jan. 31, when it lowered its Federal funds rate by a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent, after cutting rates twice during the second half of 1995. After the January rate cut, most economists predicted further reductions this year, saying the economy was still weak.
But the Federal Reserve held rates steady at the last meeting of its policy-making committee, on March 26, and no one expects it to reduce rates when the committee next meets, on May 21. The outlook for the rest of the year is murky, economists said.
While the heavy selling in the bond market on Friday and today came in response to new data on the economy's strength, the rate increases also reflect the waning hopes of investors for a deal between the Clinton Administration and the Republican-controlled Congress to balance the budget in seven years, economists said. A balanced budget would mean less government borrowing and therefore less upward pressure on rates.
Already the rate rise has slowed the rush by homeowners to refinance mortgages and caused concern that home building would suffer just as the spring and summer selling season gets under way. Housing is one of the most important sectors of the economy.
If there is a positive side for consumers, it is that interest rates for certificates of deposit and other savings accounts are inching up.
But most of the concern among economists is over the potential damage higher rates can do to an economy that while improving still appears to be relatively sluggish. Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said that if long-term bond rates reached 7 percent by the middle of this year, economic growth in the second half would be half a percentage point less than if rates had remained where they were at the beginning of the year.
"It's going to have a meaningful effect on the economy, especially in the second half of the year, just in time for the election," Mr. Sohn said.
The Mortgage Bankers Association, which tracks how interest rates are affecting the housing industry, a major sector of the economy, said the surge in rates was already dampening consumer interest.
David Learah, the association's chief economist, said the proportion of mortgage applications representing refinancings had fallen sharply, from 53 percent in February to 29 percent at the end of last month. Refinancing is economically important because it puts more cash into the hands of homeowners.
As mortgage rates have pushed up by a full percentage point this year, to an average of about 8 percent for a 30-year mortgage, hundreds of thousands of potential buyers are priced out of the market, Mr. Learah said. For now, home sales and home construction are holding up relatively well because the economy is creating jobs, he said, but rising rates could take their toll soon.
"The refinancing boom is over -- that's the first victim," Mr. Learah said. "Right now the housing sector will contribute to economic growth, because the economy's winning the battle. But interest rates will win the war, and when the housing sector goes down, so will the economy."
Monetary policy as practiced by the Federal Reserve has always taken account of the bond markets. Increasingly, as the White House and Congress have come to appreciate the link between long-term rates and economic health, politicians have also had to take notice of the cumulative weight of investment decisions made by bondholders around the world -- a kind of electronic plebiscite on their economic policy.
Indeed, in playing a major role in monetary policy, the markets can do the Federal Reserve a favor as well as make its job more difficult. After the 1987 stock market crash, bond prices surged, bringing interest rates down and helping to keep the economy out of recession. Should the markets this year be correct in seeing a resurgence in growth and in inflationary pressures, they will have helped provide a corrective action without the Federal Reserve having to move. Most analysts agree that the Federal Reserve would prefer not to raise rates during a Presidential election year.
The interplay among policy, politics and the markets can be even more complex. Investors today were speculating that because the economy was showing signs of strength, the Federal Reserve might have to raise rates later this year. The futures market, where investors bet on where interest rates will be months down the road, already reflects a belief that the Federal Reserve will raise the Federal funds rate, one of the short-term rates it controls, by next fall.
But if the rise in long-term rates is sustained and the economy shows signs of weakness by July or August, the Federal Reserve may well conclude that the proper policy is another cut in rates.
"Right now the market is doing the tightening for them," Mr. Sohn said of the Federal Reserve. "We still cannot rule out monetary easing by the Fed starting in July because they may have to offset the effects of higher interest rates on the economy."

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble on Jobs Data, and Rates Hit 8-Month High

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
For the second straight month, the stock market fell victim to signs that the economy is growing faster than many on Wall Street had expected -- growth that bond traders fear will result in a revival of inflation and higher interest rates.
In the first trading session since Friday's report by the Labor Department that companies added a hefty number of new jobs to their payrolls in March, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 88.51 points, or more than 1.5 percent, to 5,594.37. But stock prices finished the day well above their lowest levels at midday, when the Dow was down 140 points. 
 Analysts said the partial turnaround in the afternoon came as traders reflected on the market's quick rebound last month after a similarly sharp selloff, which also followed a stronger than expected employment report.
Yesterday's decline in stock prices was matched by further losses in the bond market. After falling nearly 2 points on Friday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 17/32, to 89 1/32 for each $100 of face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.87 percent from 6.82 percent on Friday. [Page D19.]
Traders had expected the stock market to decline sharply after Friday's bond market rout, which lifted long-term interest rates to their highest levels since late August and nearly a full percentage point above the lows hit in mid-January. Looking ahead, analysts said, stock market volatility is likely to continue, but general growth in the economy portends a further lift to corporate profits and the stock market.
"These are the initial signs of a true economic recovery," said John Y. Kim, chief investment officer at Aetna Retirement Services. "This is a decent buying opportunity and certainly not a situation where you should be lowering your equity exposure."
Broader stock market indexes also declined yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 11.62 points, or 1.7 percent, to 644.24, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 12.55 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,105.66. On the New York Stock Exchange, volume totaled 421.9 million shares, up from 383.4 million shares last Thursday, and advancing stocks outpaced gainers, by more than 7 to 1.
Two historic patterns dominated the discussion among market analysts yesterday. The first compared yesterday's activity to the 171-point decline in the Dow Jones industrials on March 8, after the Labor Department's report the American companies added more than 700,000 jobs in February, twice the level expected. (That increase was revised to 624,000 on Friday.)
At that time, traders abandoned hope that the Federal Reserve would cut short-term rates further when it met at the end of March, a feeling that proved to be true. Nevertheless, in little more than a week, the Dow rebounded and hit a new high, thereafter bouncing along relatively unchanged until yesterday's drop.
Similarly, two years ago, on April 1, 1994 -- also Good Friday, with the stock market closed -- the Labor Department reported the biggest payroll gains in six years. That unexpected good economic news caused bond yields to rise sharply, to 7.26 percent from 7.08 percent.
The following Monday, April 4, 1994, the Dow industrials and the Standard & Poor's 500, which had lost about 7 percent of their value over the previous two weeks, each fell another 1 percent or so, to their lowest levels of the year.
But that Monday's trading was the end of that slide, and the stock market never looked back, rebounding 5 percent through the end of 1994, even as the Federal Reserve continued to raise short-term rates.
Yesterday's decline, like those of 1994 and last month, is likely to prove to be an overreaction, said Mr. Kim, who does not subscribe to the notion that the Fed will begin raising rates.
"I think they will stay neutral for the foreseeable future," he said. While bond and stock traders retain vivid memories of 1994, when the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by 2.5 percentage points., "I don't see that scenario repeating itself," he added.
The greatest danger to stock prices, Mr. Kim said, will come if growing employee payrolls result in upward pressure on wages, as companies raise wages to attract qualified workers. Significantly, he said, companies hired relatively few part-time workers in the first quarter, a trend that, if it continues, would mean that job growth is "more robust than we expect."
Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, a mutual fund company in Overland Park, Kan., said the volatility characteristic of the last few weeks in the stock market was likely to continue as traders reacted to new economic data that would provide little clear direction to long-term investors.
"So long as we're in a period where there is no reasonable proof of the strength of the economy, the bond market is going to be in a defensive mode," Mr. Herrmann said. He predicted that stock and bond markets would continue to roil "until sometime in May, when we have enough hard numbers to suggest whether the economy is accelerating," and if so, how quickly.
Traders, with their shorter-term focus, however, are less willing to wait for definitive data, to the frustration of mutual fund managers, said Robert Bissell, a senior vice president at Wells Fargo Investment Management. "I was surprised to see the bond market react so negatively to a sign of some strength -- but not significant strength -- in the economy," he said.
Whatever the trend in the economy, some analysts still believe that stocks are overpriced. Melissa R. Brown, director of quantitative analysis at Prudential Securities, said the spread between the current price-earnings multiple of the S.& P. 500 and a "fair value" measure based on current interest rates "is the widest it has been since 1990." She calculates "fair value" at about 15 times earnings, while the S.& P. is trading at about 17 times this year's expected earnings.
Of the 30 stocks in the Dow industrials, only three managed gains yesterday, and they were some of the economically sensitive stocks that have been the strongest in the market this year. I.B.M. rose 1 5/8, to 119 3/8; Alcoa jumped 1 1/4, to 63 1/4, and Bethlehem Steel gained 1/8, to 13 3/4. Gains among those and other cyclical companies have pushed the Dow industrials to a gain of 9.3 percent since Jan. 1, twice that of the S.& P. 500.
Bank stocks were hit hard because of perceptions that higher interest rates would damage their earnings. Citicorp fell 1 1/2, to 79 3/8; Chase Manhattan fell 2 3/4, to 70 5/8, and BankAmerica fell 2 3/4, to 76.
Brokerage firms also declined amid expectations that a stock market drop would diminish trading. For example, Dean Witter, Discover fell 3 1/4, to 55 1/4, and Merrill Lynch fell 3 1/8, to 58 1/2.
Other interest-rate and economically sensitive stocks, like those of utilities, which rely on borrowed capital for the bulk of their financing, also plunged. Con Edison closed at 30 5/8, down 1 1/8; Duke Power closed at 48, down 1 1/2, and Southern closed at 23 1/2, down 7/8.
But technology stocks generally moved against the trend. Compaq rose 2 3/8,, to 40; LSI Logic rose 2 1/4, to 30 7/8, and Intel rose 1 3/8, to 60 5/8.
Informix, a software developer whose shares were the most heavily traded on American stock markets yesterday, plummeted 7 1/8, to 18 3/8, after saying that first-quarter profits would be below Wall Street estimates. Nearly 31 million shares changed hands, more than 10 times the stock's average daily volume.

HEADLINE: ON BASKETBALL;
St. John's Expectations Exceeded Its Means

BYLINE: By Malcolm Moran 

 BODY:
They used the word "family" at St. John's yesterday, a word that fit more comfortably when the university's place in the world was more consistent. When Fran Fraschilla was welcomed to the St. John's family as the 15th men's basketball coach in the university's history yesterday afternoon, identified by Ed Manetta, the athletic director and one-man search committee, as "our top choice," the mating dance was complete.
The cutting predictions of the basketball industry, an increasingly ruthless place, were right on target this time. The consensus thinking was simple. St. John's would start high, shooting for the giants of the industry, floating some names to give its search a sense of credibility. Then the university would realize how unprepared it is to deal with the highest economic reaches of the business, deal with the reality check and settle for a comfortable candidate. 
 Fraschilla has been doing more than just waiting for this chance. He has worked for years from the mid-major conferences to the Big East and the Big Ten. He speaks the language. His up-tempo style made him a popular candidate with the players. He could do for St. John's what Tom Penders did for Rhode Island in 1988: Turn the available talent into a National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament team, get hot at the right time and appear as if he had invented the game.
But it is a different St. John's that Fraschilla goes to work for, far different than it was in December 1975, when undefeated Indiana was the big-time team and St. John's took a bold if unsuccessful shot in the Holiday Festival. The ante has been raised because the Big East now makes everything possible. Now that St. John's has the intention of building dormitories and a new arena, tolerance is no longer affordable. There is only one constant -- a perception of a place in the world that is built upon a world gone by. The expectation of performance is the equal of that at Duke or Kansas, but the resources are not.
This is what has happened to the family at St. John's. The men's basketball coach is gone. The women's basketball coach is gone. The baseball coach is gone. The athletic director is gone, with far less ceremony than Jack Kaiser deserved for a professional lifetime of service. The hiring of Brian Mahoney, announced in the same room in Alumni Hall four years ago, was characterized yesterday as Jack Kaiser's recommendation to a search committee. Longtime family members have been treated better.
Lou Carnesecca, an assistant to the Rev. Donald Harrington, the university president, was an understated presence on Fraschilla's day. He was asked if the job had changed.
"When I first started coaching, you were allowed to grow and make mistakes," Carnesecca said, looking back more than 30 years. "They took a chance on you and they helped you develop. Today, you've got to do it. If not, you're on your way. The business has changed.
"The big thing about it is years ago, after you won a ball game, there was joy. You were happy. You had a little libation. Today, after you're finished you go to the video room. And where there was joy, now it's relief. It's different."
St. John's took too long to learn what many outsiders understood for years, that for much of the last three decades it benefited from the fact that a long time ago, a kid named Carnesecca set out for college in the Bronx, became homesick, came back to Brooklyn and never looked back. Goodwill was a constant, tolerance was a given.
Now the bodies come and go, with one noticeable problem. If this program has a national profile as high as its demanding followers insist, where were the high-profile candidates? Not Pat Kennedy or Rick Majerus. What does it say that John Calipari, the coach of the University of Massachusetts, a member of the Atlantic 10 Conference and a program that was dormant less than a decade ago, had no interest in discussing the opportunity to work for the Big East's New York City franchise?
"I would say there were coaches with higher profiles than Fran with whom there were discussions," Harrington said. "Either direct discussions, or through intermediaries. And there was a significant amount of interest there. But not all the factors came together in such a way that one of those people emerged as being the best candidate. I would say there was interest from high-profile coaches."
The St. John's that expanded its family again yesterday is neither the one that Fran Fraschilla observed in the 70's nor the place it aspires to be. It is somewhere in between, a work in progress, a place dependent upon a basketball identity that has far more to do with where it is than what it is.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Tumble As Treasuries Extend Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, extending a selloff from Friday, when a stronger-than-expected employment report jolted the market.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 17/32, to 89 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.87 percent, from 6.82 percent on Friday.
It was the highest yield since Aug. 23, 1995, when the yield reached 6.91 percent. Trading volume was 58 percent heavier than on an average Monday, according to Govpx, a bond pricing service.
While the price decline was not as steep as it was on Friday, when trading halted early in observance of Good Friday, it shows how bearish the market has become.
Market participants see an economy growing faster than previously believed, increasing the chances that inflation, now moderate, will begin to accelerate. Such an outlook rules out any relief soon from the Federal Reserve through a cut in short-term interest rates.
"The latest breakdown in the credit markets has strongly confirmed the bearish bias," said Joel Marver, chief technical analyst at Technical Data in Boston. "Don't expect to see the yield floors we saw in 1995 and early 1996 again this year." Technical Data forecasts the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 7.25 to 7.40 percent in the next few months. The last time the yield was at 7 percent was May 11, 1995.
Concerns about the market's ability to absorb new supply also hurt prices yesterday as the Treasury began auctioning $30.25 billion in new two-year notes and five-year notes, in addition to $27 billion in its regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
Although the market was bracing for poor results at the Treasury's auction of two-year notes, prices sagged further than expected. The high yield at the auction was 6.144 percent.
Today, the Treasury will sell five-year notes and analysts expect dealers will have to make further concessions in price to see an improvement in demand. In when-issued trading yesterday, the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.48 percent, about 8 basis points more than it was on Friday and 36 points more than on Thursday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Still, traders said there was fairly strong demand at the regular weekly auctions for three- and six-month bills. The average rate for the three-month bill fell to 5.03 percent, down from 5.07 percent last week, and the rate of the six-month bill rose to 5.19 percent, from 5.06 percent. Analysts said that the auction was good in light of the market's bearish sentiment and that the bills likely received help from both the selloff in the long end of the market and in the stock market.
Bond prices came off their lows in the afternoon, helped by a short-covering rally by investors who had bet against the market.
But the cash market was also weighed down by a decline in the futures market, as the June bond contract fell below 108 24/32. The contract dropped as low as 108 10/32 before closing at 108 29/32.
And some analysts see concerns about inflation mounting.
For instance, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities is at its highest level since 1988. The index, which measures various commodity prices, is often looked upon as a harbinger of rising inflation.
"So far the rise in the index has not overly affected Treasury bonds, but you can be sure that the market is very much aware of the rise," said Margo Evashevski, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International of San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm. "But as wage inflation fears begin to surface, the inflationary outlook may be more concerning."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of new two-year notes and three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Man Arrested In L.I. Killings Of 5 Prostitutes

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: YAPHANK, L.I., April 8

 BODY:
A 42-year-old postal worker has confessed to killing five prostitutes, dismembering their bodies and disposing of them in garbage bins on Long Island and in Yonkers over the last five years, the police said today.
The suspect, Robert Shulman of Hicksville, hung his head and trembled as he was led from the police station this morning for arraignment on murder charges, which could result in the death penalty. 
 Asked by reporters how he felt, he said, "Horrible." Asked if he had anything to say to the families of his victims, he said softly, "I'm sorry."
At a news conference this afternoon, Detective Lieut. John Gierasch of the Suffolk County police noted several similarities between Mr. Shulman's case and that of Joel Rifkin, the unemployed Long Island landscaper who admitted in 1993 to having killed 17 prostitutes. But Lieutenant Gierasch said he knew of no connection between the two men, nor did he believe that Mr. Shulman had patterned his crimes after those of Mr. Rifkin.
"All I can say about Mr. Rifkin is, it appears coincidental at this time that Mr. Rifkin was apparently operating at the same time as Mr. Shulman and engaged in similar activity," he said. "We have no information that connects one to the other or indicates that they knew each other."
Asked if there might be more victims, Lieutenant Gierasch said the police believed Mr. Shulman had been "relatively forthright," but he added, "Obviously everything is subject to a continuing investigation and we are not yet prepared to conclude anything one way or another."
Mr. Shulman told the police that he picked up his victims on a street corner in Hollis, Queens, which he said he visited often because it was a known gathering place for prostitutes.
He said he took them to his one-bedroom apartment, where they would use drugs and have sex before he bludgeoned them to death with barbells, a hammer or a baseball bat.
He would cut off their arms so their bodies could not be identified. But Suffolk County detectives, with the help of a tattoo found on a victim who was dumped in a bin in Melville, L.I., in December, were able to identify her as Kelly Sue Bunting, 28, of Hollis, Queens, known as a prostitute.
When detectives questioned other prostitutes who worked along Jamaica Avenue near 201st Street in Hollis, they remembered Ms. Bunting and recalled that they had last seen her drive away with a man in a light blue Cadillac that often cruised there.
At least two prostitutes told the police they also had been picked up in the same car and taken by the same man to a house in Hicksville. They led the police to Mr. Shulman's apartment at 11 Glow Lane, Lieutenant Gierasch said. He said that Mr. Shulman, a letter handler at the post office in Hicksville, was arrested Saturday afternoon a short distance from his apartment. A search of his apartment turned up forensic evidence linking him to the murders, Lieutenant Gierasch said, but he declined to describe the evidence.
He said Mr. Shulman lived in an apartment on the first floor in a house shared with three other people, including Mr. Shulman's younger brother, Barry, 37, and an elderly man and woman who were not identified.
Neighbors said the Shulmans kept to themselves but often had visitors late at night.
"In all the 10 or 12 years he lived there, he never once spoke a word to us," said Henry M. Bialick, a retired weekly newspaper publisher. "We had him pegged as being a little weird, but of course nobody thought he was a killer."
Thomas Rottino, 21, said: "He really wasn't like a neighbor. He was just some weird guy. You'd wave to him and he wouldn't wave back."
Mr. Rottino's mother, Patricia, said she was shocked at Mr. Shulman's arrest. "It's pretty scary when you find out you are living next to an animal like this," she said. "It's a very trusting, middle-class area where some people don't even lock their doors. You'd never expect anything like this."
Mr. Shulman was to have been arraigned today in Suffolk County Court in West Islip, but when it was disclosed in court that he had assets totaling nearly $300,000, the hearing was delayed until Tuesday so Mr. Shulman could hire his own lawyer. Authorities argued that he was not indigent and therefore should not be assigned a court-appointed lawyer.
Detectives said that Mr. Shulman made $34,000 a year as a postal worker and said they did not know where he had obtained his large savings. The police said Mr. Shulman grew up in Long Beach and Westbury, where he graduated from high school in 1972. He also took courses at Hofstra University for two years, the police said.
Although he was initially charged with the murders of two women whose bodies were found in Suffolk, District Attorney James M. Catterson said Mr. Shulman would be tried on three counts of murder.
He said the third count would be for the slaying of an unidentified woman whose dismembered body was discovered on April 6, 1995 in a recycling plant in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. He said the body had been left in a Dumpster in Nassau County, but was not discovered until a truck that emptied the bin arrived at the recycling plant.
Mr. Catterson said he had not yet decided whether to seek the death penalty for Mr. Shulman. He said the death penalty was an option made available under the state's recently enacted capital punishment law, since the last killing took place after the law went into effect last year.
The law states that capital punishment may be sought if two or more people within the state are slain within a period of 24 months in separate but similar incidents or pursuant to a common scheme or plan.
The bodies of two victims were found in separate bins in Yonkers: The body of Lori Vasquez, 24, of no known address, was found in a garbage can in a residential area on Aug. 31, 1991; and the body of the second and unidentified victim, who had a butterfly tattoo on her back, was found June 27, 1992, in a bin at a small shopping center.
Lieutenant Gierasch said that Mr. Shulman's brother, Barry, was "still under investigaton" in connection with the case, but had "not been charged with anything."
"We do not believe, at this time, that he is involved in the murders," he said. "He may have had some complicity in the removal and discarding of the bodies. That's under investigation."
The police said that although the two brothers lived in close quarters, they had separate rooms and worked different shifts at the post office and did not necessarily know the activities of one another.
The police said the blue car driven by Robert Shulman to cruise the streets of Hollis, Queens, was registered in the name of Barry Shulman.

LENGTH: 1451 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Senate Race Attracts the Nation's Eyes

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 5

 BODY:
To reach voters in New Jersey, Richard A. Zimmer, who has already made his pitch in Texas, Florida and New York, will spend the next months seeking support in Illinois, Arizona, Minnesota and California.
Mr. Zimmer, a 51-year-old Republican Representative from Flemington, is running for an open Senate seat in a state served by two of the most expensive advertising markets in the country, and, following a well-trod path, he is looking for money wherever he can find it. 
 Although he is not as well known in his own state as the Democratic candidate, Representative Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood, Mr. Zimmer knows that political contributors nationwide are interested, for two reasons. First, this race for the seat being given up by Bill Bradley, along with 12 other open races, will play an important role in determining the makeup of the Senate. Second, voters here, among the first to revolt against high taxes and big government, offer a testing ground for national political messages.
A lawmaker who promoted fiscal restraint in nine years in Trenton and six in Washington, Mr. Zimmer wants the race to be a test of voters' willingness to approve Government spending.
"This kind of match is a matchup that will be seen as a referendum on government," Mr. Zimmer said after a campaign event this week, "and it will get national attention as a result."
A third-term member of the House, Mr. Zimmer has two primary challengers, State Senator Richard J. LaRossa and Richard A. DuHaime, a Passaic County freeholder. He has the endorsements of many New Jersey Republican leaders, including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, and a big fund-raising advantage. Mr. LaRossa has tried to make an issue of Zimmer's out-of-state trips, saying, "We do not need another U.S. Senator jet-setting around the country raising money for campaign advertisements."
Mr. Torricelli, 44, who began the race with $1 million in his campaign treasury, has had an easier time than Mr. Zimmer raising money in and out of state. During the last three months, he has taken in more than $100,000 from contributors in Florida and $100,000 from labor organizations in Washington.
With seven months to go before Election Day, both national parties have already committed $750,000 each, the full amount allowed under Federal election laws, to their nominees in the fall. The Democratic National Committee has cited New Jersey as one of five states in which it will mount major get-out-the-vote drives.
"This is a top race and will receive top attention across the board," said Gordon Hensley, spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Beyond direct financing, both parties are expected to contribute millions for such generic campaign efforts as telephone canvassing. Since New Jersey is also a swing state in the Presidential election, there will be numerous visits from President Clinton the Republican nominee, expected to be Senator Bob Dole.
By November, each of the two Senate candidates expects to have raised $6 million to $8 million, to pay for what is typically one of the more expensive races in the country, in a populous though small state. Broadcast advertising is their largest expense, because the candidates must buy time on stations in New York and Philadelphia to reach New Jersey voters. There are no major network affiliates in New Jersey.
Mr. Torricelli has moved ahead of Mr. Zimmer in raising money, according to estimates based on their Federal Election Commission filings, which will not be publicly released until mid-April. Lawrence Weitzner, Mr. Zimmer's manager, said the Zimmer campaign would report $2.2 million to $2.5 million in cash, with a small percentage from out of state. David Plouffe, campaign manager for Mr. Torricelli, said he would report $3.7 million in cash, with about 25 percent from outside the state.
The state's trend-setting position has magnified its national attention, several political analysts said. For example, the anti-tax Republican revolution that swept the country in 1994 first swept New Jersey in 1991, when control of the State Legislature switched from the Democratics to the Republicans. "New Jersey is the place that sort of seems like the harbinger of things to come," said Ross K. Baker, a political science professor at Rutgers University.
The retirement of Senator Bill Bradley created a vacuum that drew in Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Torricelli, two strong candidates who reflect the national agendas of their respective parties in a state with the landscape, population and issues that make it a virtual microcosm of America.
Economically, few states better symbolize the nation's confusion than does New Jersey: a Republican Governor, Mrs. Whitman, has remained widely popular in large part because she delivered on her promise of huge income tax cuts over the past two years, while large employers like AT&T have laid off workers by the thousands.
To win over the state's traditionally nonideological moderate voters, both Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Zimmer are trying to paint each other as an extremist. But Mr. Torricelli's liberal-to-moderate record in Congress differs from the tax-and-spend liberal that Mr. Zimmer has described, while Mr. Zimmer's conservative-to-moderate record suggests that he is not a Newt Gingrich clone, as Mr. Torricelli has said.
Both are experienced campaigners, although Mr. Torricelli seems to relish the spotlight more.He has gained widespread attention for accusing the Central Intelligence Agency of sponsoring violence in Guatemala and for his courtship of Bianca Jagger, the former wife of Mick Jagger.
Mr. Zimmer, on the other hand, seems stiff and uncomfortable in public. Even Mr. Weitzner, who is managing Mr. Zimmer's campaign, conceded that Mr. Torricelli has more of a national profile. "He's more flamboyant," Mr. Weitzner said.
"He's a family man," Mr. Weitzner said of Mr. Zimmer. "He's got two kids. I think that's the profile that more voters are looking for."
Mr. Zimmer has begun criticizing Mr. Torricelli for absences during votes in Congress and for a recent reprimand that Mr. Torricelli received from the House Ethics Committee for preparing one press release, amounting to $2.83 of fax machine time, in his Congressional office for political purposes. "This will be about character," Mr. Weitzner said. "Mr. Clean against Mr. Mean."
The difference between the two candidates was underscored vividly in events each held this week.
Thirty minutes after his news conference in Newark was scheduled to begin on Wednesday, Mr. Torricelli finally arrived, his car backing rapidly up a one-way street before screeching to a halt.
Because of high winds that morning, Mr. Torricelli's announcement that he would receive the endorsement of a fellow Democrat, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, had been moved at the last minute from the steps of the Federal courthouse to a nearby indoor location. An aide to Mr. Torricelli explained that the Congressman refuses to wear mousse, so 'the wind would have made his hair look a mess in front of the television cameras."
Mr. Torricelli was loquacious, wading through a small crowd of uniformed police officers who attended to show their support for his gun control initiatives. Arriving at the microphone, Mr. Torricelli joked about his small size, comparing himself with the retiring Senator. "Thank you for combing Essex and Union County to find the only officers short enough to make me look more like Bill Bradley," he said.
Two days later, Mr. Zimmer held a press conference to announce that he was receiving the endorsement of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Mr. Zimmer chose the steps of the Somerset County Administration Building in Somerville, a quaint central New Jersey town.
Mr. Zimmer arrived early, and although he looked as if he would rather have been at a desk balancing a budget, he mingled with the few supporters and reporters who showed up. His straightforward announcement lasted five minutes.
For now, many voters seem unaware of the early campaigning and nationwide canvassing for money. A Quinnipiac College poll released in the first week of April of 908 registered voters in New Jersey found 38 percent still undecided.
But some voters, like Charles Jones 3d, are already watching closely. Mr. Jones, a resident of Somerville since 1958, is just the kind of voter who could make the difference in November. Although he is a registered Democrat and the vice president of the local building and trade workers union, Mr. Jones attended Mr. Zimmer's event outside the county administration building. "Sometimes I vote Republican," he said. "It all depends on the candidate and the issues."

HEADLINE: U.S. Puzzling Over Motives Of North Korea in the DMZ

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
American officials, while playing down the threat posed by North Korea's sudden round of violations of the military armistice that keeps the peace between the two Koreas, said today that they were baffled by the message Pyongyang was trying to send.
They presume North Korean troop movements inside the two-and-a-half-mile-wide demilitarized zone are part of a continuing effort to undermine the 1953 Military Armistice Agreement and push the United States into bilateral peace negotiations with Pyongyang. Yet they think the timing is symbolic, possibly aimed at the parliamentary elections in South Korea this week and a brief visit there planned for next week by President Clinton. 
 But without direct contact with the secretive Pyongyang Government, relatively faceless after the death of Kim Il Sung in July 1994 and the stillborn emergence of his successor and son, Kim Jong Il, American officials do not really know. "I think they're trying to coerce the United States to sit down with them and negotiate a peace treaty without Seoul, and we have no intention of doing that," a senior Pentagon official said.
The good news, he and others said, was that after three nights of armed incursions, North Korean troops did not enter the demilitarized zone again Monday night, showing an encouraging degree of restraint and political control in a country with severe economic problems and food shortages.
"But as to why they did it to begin with," the Pentagon official said, "we probably won't know that until we ask them." And asking them is problematic, he said, since the North Koreans no longer attend meetings at the DMZ and the last face-to-face meeting between North Korean and American diplomats was late last year at an undisclosed location.
In every meeting with Pyongyang officials, the United States has rejected any idea of peace talks with the North Koreans that would cut out Seoul, American officials said, emphasizing that peace was a question primarily for the North and South Koreans to settle among themselves.
While the United States can play "a supportive role," the officials said, the original Military Armistice Agreement was signed between Pyongyang and the United Nations, not the United States. That position was repeated today by the State Department spokesman, Glyn Davies, who urged the North Koreans to abide by the armistice agreement.
Still, some officials suggest that Washington's willingness to negotiate directly with North Korea over its nuclear program in October 1994 gave some impetus to North Korea's efforts, which began that February, before Kim Il Sung's death was announced in July, to replace the 43-year-old agreement through bilateral talks between Pyongyang and Washington.
The nuclear agreement promised future bilateral relations, including the establishment of interest sections, between Pyongyang and Washington -- but only after other commitments were met, American officials emphasized, including constructive dialogue between North and South Korea, a message "repeated at every opportunity."
But in December 1994, the Americans negotiated with Pyongyang again for the return of a helicopter pilot shot down over the DMZ. In each case, the South Koreans were kept informed, the Americans say, although Seoul made no secret of its unhappiness over the nuclear negotiations.
On Feb. 22, the anniversary of Pyongyang's proposal two years ago for direct talks with Washington on a peace treaty, North Korea proposed an "interim peace agreement" to be negotiated with Washington.
"Though the interim agreement was a new wrinkle, we viewed this as a continuation of the peace talks idea" and pronounced it unacceptable, an American official said. But that latest proposal seems at the heart of these most recent events.
Last Thursday, North Korea announced that it would no longer honor the terms of the Military Armistice Agreement and North Korean troops stripped off their required armbands. On Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights they moved an increasing number of troops -- up to 300 -- into the demilitarized zone 30 miles north of Seoul, setting up offensive positions with mortars before leaving.
The movements violated the armistice, which calls for no more than 35 soldiers and 5 officers with side arms to enter the demilitarized zone.
At the same time, Pentagon officials said, there has been no North Korean military activity elsewhere that would indicate any imminent invasion or aggression. On Friday, the officials said, the first day of the incursions, there was no military ground or air movement in North Korea at all, which the Americans understood as a message not to overreact.
And in what may be a reflection of North Korea's dire economic straits, the Pentagon officials said, the normal military training period of December to March was marked by "virtually no training that we could see." They also said that some North Korean soldiers were doing civilian police duty for the first time, an indication that potential civilian unrest over the lack of food is preoccupying the military more than an imminent invasion of the South.
"They do these exercises, and then beg the international community for food," one Pentagon official said. "April is a critical month for them and they don't have much to harvest, as we understand it, and we don't know what their food stocks are like."
Those concerns were articulated by Defense Secretary William J. Perry after a speech today. He called the incursions "provocative" and added: "The second and broader concern is that the North Korea economy is in terrible shape now. It is so bad that there is really not enough food distributed to feed all the people. And this is causing, as you can imagine, tremendous tensions and conflicts within the country."
 "We have a continuing concern that the Government in North Korea might respond in some sort of an irrational way to the problem they see in trying to simply keep themselves, keep the regime in power because of these great internal tensions," he added.
 The Presidential spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said that when President Clinton meets President Kim Young Sam of South Korea in Cheju on April 16, "the current status of forces along the DMZ will no doubt be a subject."
While Mr. Clinton's visit, announced only March 29, may explain the timing of the incursions, American officials discount the idea that Pyongyang is trying to influence elections, much as China tried to do when it twice organized military exercises near Taiwan before elections there.
"Raising the specter of a military threat would be expected to help the ruling party in South Korea, and they know that," an official said. "So we assume that's not their calculation."

HEADLINE: Hung Jury Declared in Killing Of a Chinatown Tourist in 1991

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
A Manhattan jury was declared deadlocked yesterday on murder charges against a reputed Chinese gang member accused of killing a tourist in Chinatown five years ago.
But the defendant, Jin Wai, 23, who officials say is a member of the Ghost Shadows gang, was found guilty of criminal possession of a weapon, a felony that carries a sentence of 5 to 15 years. 
 The victim, Rhona Lantin, a 26-year-old economist with the United States Agriculture Department in Washington, was visiting Chinatown when she was struck down by gunfire in what the police said was a gang dispute.
The Manhattan District Attorney's office will decide by May 3 whether to seek to retry the murder case, said a spokesman, Wayne Brison.
Miss Lantin had attended a high school reunion on July 4, 1991, at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, where she and five classmates watched a fireworks display and then drove to Chinatown for a late meal.
Prosecutors said Mr. Jin, also known as Chiu Wai-Ip, was arguing with an exiled member of the Ghost Shadows, a gang that has terrorized storeowners in the neighborhood through extortion and robbery, as the car carrying Ms. Lantin stopped at Mulberry and Bayard Streets at about 11:30 P.M.
Mr. Jin pulled a gun on the gang member and fired several shots, prosecutors said, but the gang member escaped harm. One bullet, however, struck Miss Lantin in the right temple, they said.
Two jurors who spoke on the condition of anonymity, a copy editor for a travel magazine and an author of children's books, said yesterday that the first vote as deliberations began was 11 to 1 for conviction but by yesterday had dropped to 8 to 4.
The jurors said the leader of the not-guilty group said he had "a gut feeling" that Mr. Jin was innocent. No gun was recovered and, while witnesses saw Mr. Jin with a gun, none of them actually saw him shoot Miss Lantin.
Finally, Justice Felice K. Shea of State Supreme Court told the prosecutor, William Mahoney, and the defense lawyer, Lawrence Dubin, that the jury appeared "adamant" about being deadlocked and to force them to continue deliberations "would not be fruitful and would be coercive."
