HEADLINE: Proposed Multipurpose Stadium: Bucking Recent Trend

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
On the surface, the argument seems unassailable: A giant dual-purpose sports stadium on Manhattan's West Side as a future home for the Yankees would make more money for the city and for local businesses than a single-function baseball park. It would create more jobs and generate more tax revenue without significantly higher costs. Squeezing every possible use from the space, according to a consultant's report, offers the best hope of paying off the stadium's $1 billion-plus price tag.
But what looks like a cash cow might conceal, underneath, a clunky dinosaur, stadium experts said in assessing the report commissioned by New York City and the Yankees. The trend in major league baseball around the country is 180 degrees away from the switch-hitting megastadium with its artificial grass and multiple uses that is enthroned in the report as the city's most lucrative choice. 
 Most newer stadium plans are consciously aimed at recapturing the intimacy and innocence of the game as it once was, with smaller urban ball parks and real, easily trampled grass that does not lend itself to trade shows and concerts. The goal in places like Baltimore and Cleveland -- both recently cited by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for their successful downtown ball parks -- is toward cozy reconnection of fan and player, not the sprawling distances required in stadiums built for baseball and football. The Cleveland Indians, for example, went in 1994 from a 70,000-seat dual-purpose stadium, shared with the Browns football team, to a comparatively petite 42,865-seat downtown park and saw attendance soar.
"Every park that has been built for baseball in the last 10 years has been a baseball-only park," said Janet Marie Smith, a vice president for planning and development for the Atlanta Braves, who helped plan Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore as a vice president there in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Ms. Smith said that most megastadiums built in the 1970's, the height of that trend, had since been chalked up as failures.
"The Phillies, the Reds, the Pirates, the Braves -- they were all disappointed in their parks," she said. "They were designed as multipurpose, the seats weren't configured for baseball and they had little personality -- there's a spirit that's hard to capture in a domed multipurpose stadium because the orientation is toward concerts and other events."
The question, then, is whether the New York economy is different enough from the rest of the nation in that a tried-and-rejected idea identified with the 1970's might still make perfect sense here, or whether the numbers will drive the city into a corner where the only thing that can be done economically is not the right answer for baseball.
New York's Deputy Mayor for economic development, John S. Dyson, said in an interview that in a perfect world the Yankees would have their own smaller, dedicated ball park, with real grass instead of artificial turf. But he remains convinced that the pressures dictated by a limited amount of land, a tight public purse that constrains how much taxpayers should have to contribute and the vagaries of weather in the Northeast suggest the best solution may be a large, removable-roof multipurpose stadium on Manhattan's West Side.
"Is it ideal? No," Mr. Dyson said. "The ideal would be to have a sports stadium for everybody. But I believe this is the way it ought to be done -- we have to amortize the expenses over as many ways as possible to benefit the city."
He said that the aspect of the plan that gave him the most pause was the apparent impossibility of natural grass, which fans and players both prefer. "But we can't think of any other way, and neither can they," he said of the consultants working with the city. And the simple fact, he added, is that New York is different from every place else -- both in what can work and what has to be made to work because of the unique local pressures.
"When somebody says, 'This isn't how they do it in Boise,' I say with all due respect, 'This is New York,' " Mr. Dyson said.
The stadium proposal for Manhattan does conform to some national ball park trends. In cities from Denver to Baltimore, teams are moving their teams closer to the downtown urban centers. Stadium experts say part of the pressure for that is cost saving, to try to capitalize on the transportation and parking that already exist.
But again, the Yankee plan, with its huge cost, counters that trend on another level. The driving economic force for a Manhattan location is not the existence of an infrastructure that makes the plan cheaper -- there are huge obstacles to overcome, like the construction of a platform over the existing West Side rail yards -- but rather the allure of a huge market that makes its high cost feasible.
Many of the new downtown stadiums are also envisioned specifically as anchors of downtown urban renaissance. A spokesman for the Cleveland Indians, Bob DiBiasio, said that the area around the team's new park was "awful." But he said that 15 new restaurants had opened in the last two years within a five-minute walk of home plate.
In New York, the Yankees would be leaving the city's poorest borough and moving to its richest, where much of the recent economic success in the city, especially in tourism, has been concentrated.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Surge in Market Rates Worrisome to Policy Makers
Stock and bond prices tumbled as long-term interest rates continued a swift, sharp ascent that is at odds with the Federal Reserve's policy of keeping rates stable. Analysts said the rate surge could endanger the moderate rate of growth expected this year.
The latest rise in interest rates was set off by data released Friday that showed the economy creating jobs at a faster-than-expected clip. The markets' response put upward pressure on mortgage rates and further complicated the economic outlook in a Presidential election year. [Page A1.]
 
The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond rose to 6.87 percent, from 6.82 percent. [D19.]
 
$1 Billion Bid for Cajun Power
Zeigler Coal Holding and a unit of Northern States Power said they had offered $1 billion in cash for the non-nuclear assets of the bankrupt Cajun Electric Power Cooperative, beating out 11 other bidders. [D2.]
 
Web Guides Attract Investors
Nynex and the Tribune Company each announced investments in companies that provide electronic guides to the Internet's World Wide Web. Tribune paid $7 million for an 8 percent stake in Excite of Mountain View, Calif., which produces search software, and Nynex plans to buy 5 percent of privately held Infoseek. [D4.]
 
Raytheon to Buy Chrysler Units
Raytheon agreed to buy most of Chrysler's Texas-based military electronics and aircraft-upgrading business in a deal valued at about $475 million. Raytheon will add the units to E-Systems, which it acquired last year for $2.3 billion. [D2.]
 
Moody's Recalls Retired President
Moody's Investors Service said that William O. Dwyer, its former president who retired from its corporate parent, Dun & Bradstreet, in 1993, would again become its president. Mr. Dwyer, who is 63, replaces John Bohn, 58, who resigned suddenly on April 1. [D4.]
 
Big Board Would Ease Curbs
The New York Stock Exchange is seeking to loosen its two most extreme curbs on sharp market swings. The so-called circuit breakers were designed by the Big Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission after the October 1987 stock market crash. [D4.]
 
Ann Taylor to Salvage Supplier
Ann Taylor Stores, seeking to salvage its principal supplier and better manage its merchandising, said it would buy 100 percent of a venture it shares with Cygne Design, and another company unit. [D4.]
 
Microsoft in Deal for Aha!
Microsoft agreed to acquire Aha! Software, which makes pen-based programs for portable computers, notably the Inkwriter program. Terms were not disclosed. [D2.]
 
State Farm Ordered to Pay Rebates
California ordered State Farm Insurance to pay at least $172 million in rebates, rejecting an administrative law judge's ruling that the company has no obligation. [D4.]
 
Rockwell to Pay Environmental Fine
Rockwell International agreed to pay a $6.5 million fine in connection with an explosion in 1994 at a California field laboratory that killed two men at its rocket engine subsidiary. Federal prosecutors said the fine was the maximum allowed. [D2.]
 
A Living Wage For the Poor
In Baltimore the pay of 4,000 low-wage workers has nearly doubled to between $6 and $10 an hour since the enactment nine months ago of the nation's first ordinance forcing an employer who does business with a city to pay its workers a "living wage." Now more than 30 other cities are also seeking similar ways to raise the pay of the working poor. [A1.]
 
Interpublic Buying Another Agency
Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, a privately held New York shop known for stylish, witty creative work for clients like Saab, agreed to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Some Cities Flexing Fiscal Muscle To Make Employers Raise Wages

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, April 3

 BODY:
The pay of 4,000 low-wage workers here office clerks, janitors, ticket takers -- has risen sharply since the city forced companies with city contracts to pay their workers well above the minimum wage. Now more than 30 other cities are also seeking ways to use taxpayer money as a lever to raise the pay of the working poor.
The goal of what its advocates call the living-wage movement is legislation that will require any company that benefits from tax dollars -- like tax rebates, supplier contracts, cash grants or the use of city-owned land -- to pay employees at least $6 an hour, and gradually more. The national minimum wage is $4.25 an hour. 
 So far, only Baltimore, Milwaukee and Santa Clara County in California have enacted such ordinances. Each goes only part of the way toward meeting the goal, with Baltimore's the most ambitious. It raised the minimum to $6.10 an hour last July for companies with city contracts, with an increase to $6.60 set for July 1 of this year.
Other city governments, including those in New York, New Orleans, Denver, Chicago and Los Angeles, are considering similar measures. So are a few states. Minnesota is the closest to enacting one, although the Governor there says he will veto it.
"I would rather fight this battle in Congress as an increase in the minimum wage," Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore said in an interview. "But I became convinced that if I did not agree to the living wage, we would end up paying out more in food stamps and welfare, and so far the ordinance is not that costly."
The living-wage movement is in part an effort to fill the void left by Congress's failure to keep the minimum wage moving in step with the cost of living. Even the current effort by the Clinton Administration to raise the minimum to $5.15 would not make up the ground lost since the 1970's. But the movement is also a response to the growing concentration of low-wage jobs in cities, many of them spun off by the hotels, restaurants, convention centers and sports stadiums that have sprung up as a result of publicly subsidized downtown revival projects like Baltimore's Inner Harbor.
The two city ordinances enacted so far cover only companies that do business with the local governments as suppliers. Neither has been broadened to apply to companies that have benefited from public subsidies like tax rebates or the use of public land for hotels or office towers. Santa Clara County requires a $10-an-hour minimum wage for the employees of any company granted a county tax abatement but says nothing about suppliers.
The limited coverage in Baltimore has softened its impact. The Schmoke administration estimates that once the rate rises to $7.70 in 1998, the cost to the city -- in higher prices for goods and services the city buys -- will still be only $3.5 million, or less than 1 percent of the city's current revenues.
But the narrow scope of the Baltimore measure sticks in the throats of officials at the Industrial Areas Foundation, a network of community organizers with roots in the labor movement that is promoting the living-wage issue. With so few people covered, they say, the Baltimore ordinance is hard to enforce, particularly in a city with 9 percent unemployment. "Unless you establish a much broader base, one that reflects all the public spending, then the wage floor will stay at $4.25 an hour," said Jonathan Lange, an organizer with the foundation.
Downtown redevelopment projects have resurrected many cities as centers of commerce and tourism. At the Inner Harbor in Baltimore, the shopping pavilions, restaurants, office towers and hotels bustle with people. An aquarium, convention center and baseball stadium also bring people downtown -- greatly increasing the resolve of Baltimore's major corporations, like T. Rowe Price, the mutual fund operator, to stay in their office towers nearby.
But such commercial centers are sustained through huge public subsidies. Maryland's state government, for example, is spending $200 million to build a football stadium, and the city government must raise $50 million to help pay for a convention center expansion.
The justification for these subsidies has always been the promise of good jobs for the minorities that now populate many American cities. Sixty percent of Baltimore's population is black. And the jobs have indeed come, by the tens of thousands, but they are for maintenance workers, cleaning people, janitors, gardeners, store clerks, restaurant and hotel workers, and ticket takers and hawkers at Orioles games -- all low-wage jobs. That raises the question of whether more downtown redevelopment, so important to American cities over the past 25 years, can be justified.
Another question is whether Baltimore's government, or any city government, should continue to shrink, laying off workers and cutting services so that scarce tax revenue can be channeled in part into subsidies for downtown redevelopment. Indeed, the Baltimore ordinance is aimed in part at helping workers who once earned $8 an hour or more as municipal employees -- serving food in school cafeterias, cleaning municipal buildings or driving city vans -- but who do the same work for half that pay today, as employees of the private contractors that now supply these services to the city.
Mayor Schmoke says such privatization and cutbacks must continue, in part to pay for downtown redevelopment. His administration has eliminated 4,000 jobs since 1987. Baltimore's business community insists that if wages rise by very much, rents and hotel rates will as well, and that businesses will go elsewhere.
"I have a serious doubt," said M. J. Brodie, president of the City of Baltimore Corporation, which oversees redevelopment, "based not on empirical evidence but on talking to business people, that we can make the leap to what is called a living wage and still remain competitive."
The Rev. Vernon B. Dobson, minister of the Union Baptist Church in rundown East Baltimore, heartily disagrees. As the dean of Baltimore's black ministers, he has played a major role in bringing nearly 50 black churches into the new battle over jobs and wages.
"Only as I have gotten older," said Mr. Dobson, a 73-year-old civil rights veteran, "have I realized that an impoverished community lacks the means to lift itself."
Working with the Industrial Areas Foundation, the churches campaigned for the wage ordinance finally enacted in late 1994, with its requirement that companies holding contracts with the city pay employees at least $6.10 an hour. When the wage goes to $7.70 in 1998, it will be what a full-time worker would have to earn to support a family of four at the Labor Department's current poverty line, $15,600 a year.
A similar coalition in New York, also put together by the foundation and involving 350 churches, more than half of them black or Hispanic, is backing a bill before the City Council that would set the pay floor at $7.50 an hour. Its chances of being enacted are uncertain.
The Milwaukee measure, like Baltimore's, sets an eventual minimum wage of $7.70 an hour, but that affects only the companies selling to the schools. For other municipal work, the level is $6.05 an hour. Milwaukee's ordinance covers even fewer workers than Baltimore's.
For Mr. Dobson, championing the living-wage movement is something of a reversal. In 1978, responding to appeals from Baltimore's business community to back the Inner Harbor, he mobilized enough black voters in a referendum to allow the first Inner Harbor buildings to rise on city-owned land.
"Who had thought that so much activity would not produce good jobs," Mr. Dobson said, rubbing his eyes and remembering the optimism.
The optimism faded slowly in Baltimore. This was home until the late 1980's to thousands of high-wage, blue-collar jobs, most of them now gone. The biggest employer was Bethlehem Steel, with its Sparrow Point works, but dozens of small manufacturers also went away. And people like Rene Brown, who once earned $8.50 an hour as a supervisor at a meatpacking plant, found themselves moving down the pay ladder.
For three years, Ms. Brown has been cleaning the 17th floor of the World Trade Center, an office tower in Baltimore's revived downtown. Her pay is $4.25 an hour. Never a raise, no benefits, no overtime. All 36 rooms must be cleaned in four evening hours. But ask her why she does not hunt for a higher-paying job, and she bristles.
"I like where I am," she said. "I like the tenants. They know me and trust me. They leave their belongings around and know they are safe. Tell me why I have to move. Just give me a raise."
Coming to work one day last year, Ms. Brown met Kerry Miciotto, who was serving coffee on a street corner. Ms. Miciotto, 38, is an organizer for Baltimoreans United in Leadership Development, the operating arm of the coalition formed by the black churches and the Industrial Areas Foundation. A friendship developed, and soon Ms. Brown was signing up other cleaning people for the coalition's Solidarity Sponsoring Committee, an experimental effort at organizing a new kind of union for the working poor, particularly people who often change employers. The recruiting lure was the call for a living wage.
So far, only Baltimore has so elaborate a structure for this movement, and the Solidarity Committee, with 350 members, exists only because a traditional union, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, is financing the experiment, having already paid out $600,000.
The experiment has worked for Ms. Brown, who is in her 40's. While the World Trade Center's offices are rented to private companies, the building is owned by the state, which subcontracts cleaning services to the company that employs Ms. Brown. She and Ms. Miciotto joined a delegation last month that met with Gov. Parris N. Glendening and appealed to him, in effect, for a raise. Although the state is not bound by the city ordinance, the Governor, in a letter to the two women, said the state would put the contract for cleaning services up for bids again, specifying a $6.60-an-hour minimum wage.
"I felt totally honored to be sitting there with him," Ms. Brown said. "But I am waiting to see it really happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kerry Miciotto, third from left, is one of the organizers urging Baltimore workers to seek a higher minimum wage. The city's government is leading the way in what its advocates call the living-wage movement. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
When Pettitte Takes Mound, There Is No Room for Jitters

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
Andy Pettitte pondered the question for a few seconds and could not supply an immediate answer. Asked to remember the last time he was nervous, Pettitte was stumped. He remained silent until someone mentioned his wife giving birth to a son in 1994. Pettitte nodded and called it nerve-racking.
But what about in baseball? Moments later, Pettitte recalled a sunny afternoon two spring trainings ago when he opposed Jimmy Key and the Yankees in an intrasquad game. He was an untested left-hander supposedly destined for Class AAA and he was frightened. 
 "As far as baseball, I've never been scared," Pettitte said. "When I faced our lineup then, I was definitely nervous. I remember shaking out there on the mound."
Do not expect Pettitte to be nervous today when he is scheduled to oppose the Kansas City Royals in the home opener before a sellout crowd of more than 57,000 at Yankee Stadium, that is, if the weather that has already wreaked havoc by forcing the postponement of three games is agreeable.
Maybe Pettitte should be tense. After winning their first two games in Cleveland, the Yankees lost three straight games in Texas while scoring only five runs. Pettitte will be the first starter from a renowned rotation to stroll to the mound in the Bronx in a season filled with sizable expectations and his responsibility is to halt the losing streak.
"I'm excited," said the 23-year-old Pettitte, who will be the youngest Yankee to start a home opener since Jim (Hippo) Vaughn did so at 22 in 1910, when the team was called the Highlanders and home was Hilltop Park on 168th Street and Broadway. "I really didn't realize it was that big a deal."
Everything about the home opener is a big deal. George Steinbrenner, who was noticeably absent from a road trip that started neatly in Cleveland and turned nasty in Texas, will be in the owner's box and Joe DiMaggio will throw out the ceremonial first pitch.
Too bad the DiMaggio of old couldn't join an underachieving lineup that is missing Tony Fernandez more than the team imagined, misses Tim Raines, the leadoff man who still hasn't made his Yankee debut, and misses Pat Kelly, whose replacement, Mariano Duncan, is no defensive stalwart at second and is better suited to being a utility man.
Fernandez (fractured right elbow) might be lost for the season and Kelly (right shoulder tendinitis) cannot even throw a ball, so General Manager Bob Watson said he would meet with Steinbrenner soon to discuss possibly pursuing a starting second baseman.
The switch-hitting Raines (chip fracture of the left thumb) can only swing left-handed, so Dion James, unemployed a week ago, has started the last three games, including two in left field.
"We're a little short right now," is the polite way that David Cone phrased it after he pitched seven superb innings and emerged with a no-decision in a 4-1 loss to Texas during a doubleheader loss Sunday.
Despite the dreary situation, Watson refused to sound an alarm. "I don't see us being that desperate right now," Watson said.
But the G.M. is obviously not thrilled with Duncan at second, the rookie Andy Fox as the utilityman and a spotty bench.
"I'm not going to say I'm happy," Watson said. "Sure, we'd like to improve. But I'm not going to mortgage the future."
Kelly received another cortisone shot yesterday and could either be throwing by the weekend or pondering new treatment and perhaps more surgery. If Steinbrenner gives approval to obtaining a second baseman, Watson said he would ignore the reserve players who have been casually mentioned as possibilities.
"If I'm going to do something, I want to go front line," Watson said. "It's not going to be for a backup. I'd like to talk front line with somebody. But that's going to be tough. Everyone's only played five or six games."
New York's sixth game will feature Pettitte, who was 8-2 with a 2.61 earned run average at the Stadium last year. When Manager Joe Torre told Pettitte that he was starting the home opener after the soggy weather spoiled plans and prevented Key from being available, the never nervous left-hander said, "Oh, O.K."
Even after Pettitte's 12-9 rookie season and snazzy spring, Torre was amazed by his effort in 35-degree weather last Wednesday against the Indians. Holding the defending American League champions to one run in six and two-thirds innings, he guided the Yankees to a 7-2 victory, despite not having a useful change-up. Of course, Pettitte was not uptight.
"He was remarkable," Torre said.
So the legend of Pettitte will continue today, against Chris Haney and the Royals. It will be a big day. It is always a big day, even bigger when the Yankees have lost three in a row.
But for Pettitte, it will not be nerve-racking. "I'm not scared of going out there and messing up," he said. "I know I'm going to give it the best I can. If it doesn't work out, it doesn't work out."

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Taiwan's Lobbying in U.S.: Mixing Friendship and Hardball

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
Last spring, a representative of Taiwan got himself invited to a reunion in Dallas of the Flying Tigers, American pilots who fought as volunteers for the Chinese Nationalists, and pledged that his Government would erect a monument to Americans killed in China in World War II.
In February, Taiwan donated $100,000 to an environmental group in Connecticut, Friends of Animals, to help curtail poaching of elephants and the rare black rhinoceros and to offset its image as a major trafficker in contraband rhino horn. 
 But when a China scholar at the University of Michigan recently co-signed a dissent at the end of a report commissioned by the Council on Foreign Relations on how to strengthen American ties to Taiwan -- saying that relations with Beijing must take priority -- the retaliation was swift and harsh.
Taiwan accused the scholar, Kenneth Lieberthal, of failing to "promote our national cause" and announced that as a result, a three-year $450,000 grant to the university would not be renewed in the fall for another three years.
When it comes to Taiwan's campaign to win friends, influence people and get its way in the United States, no gesture is too small to make, no potential supporter too insignificant to pursue. Indeed, Taiwan has lobbied hard in this country since 1949, after the Nationalists lost China's civil war to the Communists and retreated to the island of Taiwan.
But rarely has the power of Taiwan's lobby been so strongly felt as last month, when China staged ambitious war games in the Taiwan Strait and the United States sent warships to nearby waters. Taiwan's representatives, lobbyists and friends in Congress went on the offensive in a different way --successfully pressing both houses of Congress to pass unanimous resolutions condemning China's belligerence.
Although the United States and Taiwan officially agree with Beijing that there is only one China, Taiwan's campaign has helped convince many Americans that Taiwan, not the officially recognized People's Republic of China, is the China that should be known and loved.
The campaign seems to ignore two crucial moments in Chinese-American relations: the 1972 Shanghai Communique, in which the Nixon Administration acknowledged Beijing's position that there is but one China and that Taiwan is part of China, and the decision by President Jimmy Carter in December 1978 to establish diplomatic relations with Beijing, and to cut off official ties with Taipei in early 1979.
The tools Taiwan has used in its remarkably successful all-out wooing of America: money, charm, pressure and creativity.
Taiwan has cultivated friendships in places high and low by welcoming hundreds of lawmakers and their staffs, governors and state legislators, even veterans groups and Rotary Club members on first-class junkets to Taipei.
It has gained access to the White House, Congress, Wall Street and editorial pages by spending millions of dollars on some two dozen lobbyists and political consultants.
It has disarmed the heartland with its community spirit, sponsoring cultural events infused with political meaning, like a recent production in Houston of a version of "King Lear" set during the ancient Zhou dynasty -- complete with silk brocade costumes. In exchange, it has urged local governments to fly Taiwan's flag in international displays and to issue diplomatic license plates to the cars of its officials.
And when Taiwan has had to, it has played hardball, punishing institutions when they objected to its rules. "The Taiwanese keep asking for things, they keep knocking on doors," said Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan who has served as both a paid and unpaid adviser to Taiwan. "They're either tied with or second only to the Israelis in their effectiveness."
To the chagrin of Beijing, Taiwan has never had a more powerful message to sell. Its leaders have transformed their tiny island of 21 million people into America's sixth-largest trading partner, with a full-fledged democracy and higher foreign-currency reserves than any other country except Japan. Taiwan's international stature skyrocketed last month when it held direct presidential elections for the first time, and dozens of American lawmakers are expected to attend President Lee Teng-hui's coming inauguration.
By contrast, China remains an authoritarian Communist state whose relationship with Washington is strained over such issues as the pirating of American movies and music by China, its poor performance on human rights, its weapons-related sales to Pakistan and Iran, and its recent war games near Taiwan. American exports to Taiwan last year were $19.3 billion, as against $11.7 billion to China, even though its population is 60 times bigger than Taiwan's.
"If you want to sell soap, it has to smell good," said James Lilley, a former Ambassador to China who is avidly pro-Taiwan. "And Taiwan has a hell of a good product to sell."
Mr. Lilley, now a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, which has received money from Taiwan in the past, has himself been a beneficiary of Taiwan's generosity.
"They bring me over and pay my way," he said. "They put me up in a hotel. They send over flowers and fruit -- but no women -- to my room. I see the people I want to see."
Taiwan officially operates in Washington from a five-story de facto embassy known as the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, which employs about 300 people and loosely administers 13 regional offices around the country.
Because the United States does not recognize Taiwan as a sovereign state, Taiwan's "diplomats" may be warmly welcomed in Congress but are forbidden to enter the White House or State Department. That means they must think creatively when they want to meet senior officials.
Benjamin Lu, Taiwan's "ambassador" here, has had several private meetings with President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, through the intercession of Peter Rosenblatt, a lawyer and former Johnson Administration official with close ties to the Democrats.
"I do what they ask me to do," said Mr. Rosenblatt, who is on an $8,500-a-month retainer to Taiwan.
But the economic and cultural office has nowhere near the budget of the Taiwan Research Institute, an organization associated with President Lee's Nationalist Party. The institute now pays the lobbying company of Cassidy & Associates $125,000 a month, according to the company's disclosure statements filed with the Justice Department, as required by law.
For that fee, Cassidy employees meet with lawmakers and Administration officials, brief journalists and put pressure on state capitols to adopt pro-Taiwan resolutions "to promote understanding and awareness of the progress made by the democracy movement in Taiwan," the statements say.
Cassidy has claimed credit for helping to persuade Congress last year to vote overwhelmingly to give Mr. Lee a visa so that he could receive an honorary degree from Cornell University, his alma mater, which received a $2.5 million grant from "Friends of Lee Teng-hui" in 1994. The vote prompted the Clinton Administration to overturn 16 years of policy and allow the visit.
Taiwan also made a dramatic offer last year to pay $1 billion to the United Nations in exchange for membership. The offer was turned down; China, a permanent member of the Security Council, would have automatically vetoed such a move.
Undaunted, Taiwan has begun a major effort this year in Congress and in state legislatures to gain support. In recent years, 23 state legislatures have passed pro-Taiwan resolutions, some of them calling for membership in the United Nations.
But Taiwan sometimes is carried away with its desire to get its way, and the experience of the University of Michigan is only the most recent instance of an institution's learning the hard way that money often comes with strings attached.
A few years ago, Taiwan's Government refused to renew a three-year, $440,000-a-year grant to Columbia University because it felt that Taiwan's political opposition had received too much prominence at an academic conference.
And two years ago, the Fairbanks Center for East Asian Research at Harvard University had to return $40,000 to Taiwan's Government after it objected to the choice of Gordon Wu, a Hong Kong business magnate, as the speaker for a major public lecture.
But Taiwan has many other ways to spread its good will.
In one week in February, three separate delegations of lawmakers toured Taiwan, including Representative Matt Salmon, a freshman Republican from Arizona.
Mr. Salmon said he could not recall who paid for his trip, but his office said the visit had been financed by Taiwan's equivalent of the Chamber of Commerce. He said that he has been pro-Taiwan since he was a Mormon missionary there in the 1970's and that the visit had nothing to do with his vote last month in favor of a nonbinding resolution for the United States to defend Taiwan if China attacked.
"They were cordial in every way," Mr. Salmon said. "They were very thoughtful, very nice. The rooms were very nice, I mean very nice. We weren't driven around in limousines. I think they were Buicks."
Taiwan's courtship of the powerful, the not-so-powerful and the potentially powerful has paid off in unexpected ways.
Eleven years ago, on Taiwan's National Day rally and parade through Presidential Square in Taipei, there were two American Governors in the audience: Charles S. Robb of Virginia and Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
"Bill Clinton, Governor of Arkansas, U.S.A., said it was apparent to see from the parade that Chinese people here and abroad support the Government," Taiwan's news service reported that day.
Mr. Clinton understands firsthand the problems of Taiwan: the trip was one of four he made to the island in his years as Governor.
He never stepped foot in China as Governor, and considering the deterioration in relations, he may never visit as President. 
 The article also misspelled the name of a research center at Harvard that had to return $40,000 to Taiwan's Government after Taiwan objected to the choice of a Hong Kong businessman as a lecture speaker. It is the Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, not Fairbanks.

HEADLINE: Nynex and Tribune Company Buy Stakes in Internet Ventures

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Nynex Corporation and the Tribune Company each announced separate investments yesterday in companies that provide electronic guides to the Internet's World Wide Web, offering the latest evidence of growing investor interest in such services.
The Tribune Company said it had paid $7 million for an 8 percent stake in Excite Inc., a Mountain View, Calif., company that produces search software and operates a site on the World Wide Web that allows people to use its program to locate other sites. 
 Nynex announced that it had spent several million dollars to acquire 5 percent of the privately held Infoseek, which operates a competing Internet search and navigation company based in Santa Clara, Calif. Nynex did not give a specific dollar amount for its investment.
As the number of sites on the World Wide Web has soared over the last year, the need for tools to help people find what they are looking for has become increasingly important. Search sites such as the ones operated by Excite and Infoseek have become gateways to the Internet for many users, making the sites attractive to advertisers.
In a recent study of selected sites by the research firm Simba Information Inc., Infoseek generated the most advertising revenue in January and February.
"The Web has 200,000 sites and no one can find anything," said Gary Arlen, president of Arlen Communications, a research firm in Bethesda, Md. "It's getting worse, not better."
That has fueled investor interest in the companies. Last week, after Excite and Lycos Inc., another web guide company, held their initial public offerings, their stock prices soared. Yahoo! Inc., which is probably the best-known Internet search company, is scheduled to go public this week.
"There is still no clear winner yet," Mr. Arlen said.
But yesterday's announcement by the Tribune Company, which made its investment in Excite before last week's initial public offering, appeared to dampen some of the enthusiasm. At about $8.70 a share, the price that the Tribune paid for its stake was much less than the offering price of $17 a share Excite was sold at last week. Shares of Excite plunged on news of the Tribune Company deal, closing yesterday at $15.375, down $4.625 in Nasdaq trading. Lycos shares closed at $17.75 yesterday, down 25 cents.
For the Tribune Company, which owns newspapers and television and radio stations, Excite is the latest in a series of minority investments in new media companies. Tribune also has stakes in the on-line service America Online, the electronic payment company Checkfree and Starsight Telecast, which produces an electronic television program guide.
Before yesterday's announcement, Nynex had chosen Infoseek's search software as the backbone for Big Yellow, an electronic yellow pages on the World Wide Web that Nynex said would include every business in the country. In addition to the investment, which was made by Nynex Information Technologies, Infoseek said Mathew J. Stover, president of Nynex Information Resources, had been elected to Infoseek's board. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 12, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Tribune Company's $7 million investment in Excite! Inc., an Internet company, misstated the stock market's reaction to the disclosure, around midday Tuesday. Excite!'s stock price showed little change when the Tribune investment was disclosed, although it had fallen sharply earlier in the day; the disclosure did not depress Excite!'s stock price.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A No-Nonsense Teacher Braving the Wilderness

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

A SCHOOLTEACHER
IN OLD ALASKA
The Story of Hannah Breece
Edited by Jane Jacobs
Illustrated. 302 pages. Random House. $24.
 This book, which is in the most-unforgettable-character tradition of the old Reader's Digest, arrives like a manuscript in a bottle. It is the publication, after a delay of more than 50 years, of the story of Hannah Breece, who spent the years between 1904 and 1918 teaching school in various parts of Alaska. Miss Breece's grand-niece, Jane Jacobs, a writer whose books on urban life and architecture have been influential for more than three decades, edited the manuscript, which was written in the 1930's but rejected for publication then. Luckily Miss Breece's story is finally seeing the light, for she is an unforgettable character indeed. We should all have had a great-aunt like Ms. Jacobs's.
Miss Breece, a rugged educational pioneer from Pennsylvania, had taught Indian children in the Western States and was already 45 when she arrived at her first Alaskan post in a village called Afognak in the Kodiak archipelago. An unmarried woman of exceptional energy, fortitude and dedication, she wanted to bring the benefits of civilization to what she commonly called "these primitive people," by which she meant a large number of the 60,000 or so inhabitants who lived in the vastness of Alaska early in this century. 
 Miss Breece traveled by steamer and skin-covered canoe, by dog sled, on horseback and on foot through freezing winter passes. She taught in the most educationally needy and remote places in Alaska that she could persuade her employer, the Department of the Interior, to send her to. She was a benign, prudish autocrat who knew what was right, whether it was forbidding children to come to school until their mothers had cleaned their kitchens, or dumping barrels of "hooch" so village women would not be tempted by demon drink.
"I have always been careful when working among inferior races to convey to them that I have their interests at heart and love and respect them as people," Miss Breece writes in one passage, revealing the mixture of condescension and high expectations that she held toward those among whom she worked, "but that I do not come among them to sink to their level but to uplift them."
Ms. Jacobs, a person of a more relativistic sensibility, is embarrassed by remarks like those. Indeed, we learn in her informative and affectionate editor's preface that the "white man's burden stuff" in her great-aunt's memoir is what first dissuaded her from helping get the book into shape when Miss Breece, retired and living with relatives in Pennsylvania, first wrote it. Ms. Jacobs writes also that Miss Breece's original text was "maddeningly unassembled" and full of gaps, so that "reading it was like contemplating a box of jigsaw puzzle pieces."
Ms. Jacobs did her editor's work very well. Miss Breece, who died in 1940 at the age of 80, is not a literary giant, but she is a good storyteller with an eye for detail, a keen appreciation of Alaska's natural beauty and, despite the white man's burden stuff, an unalloyed admiration for many of the people she encounters. Her descriptions of the hardships of Alaskan life -- and her willingness to share some of them -- make for arresting passages in a book that never fails to hold the reader's interest.
There is, for example, the story of 14-year-old Ephram Derenoff who, because of his age, had no time to lose as far as his schooling was concerned. But Ephram "lived on a small off-shore island by himself, to make hay and tend the family's cattle," Miss Breece writes. "He fed them when it was too stormy or the snow too deep, hunted game for himself and lived in a shack." The Derenoff family's spare economic situation made this necessary. Still, in order to feed the cows and enable the boy to go to school, Miss Breece continues, his mother "left their home in the Russian village to live all winter by herself in the desolate shack." She adds, "Could any mother and father make greater sacrifices to educate a child?"
The Katharine Hepburn character in "The African Queen" has nothing on Hannah Breece, who matter-of-factly tells stories that would bring out a more "wasn't it amazing" quality in somebody less self-controlled. She slept in unheated cabins on Arctic nights, outran a forest fire, hid from foraging bears, fell off a bridge into an icy flume, was grounded on a shifting sandbar on a ramshackle boat in a river coursing between Iliamna Lake and the Bering Sea. She must have been lonely. Occasionally, especially during the sunless Alaskan winter, she admits to melancholy, but she never complains and she certainly never feels sorry for herself, not even when she breaks a leg in a fall in the panhandle city of Douglas.
Even her assumption of cultural superiority only slightly diminishes the admiration one has for this teacher, both intrepid and proper in her long skirts and petticoat. Her smugness was cultural rather than racial, and in this sense she might even have been ahead of her time. "I want to draw a line between 'whitizing' and civilizing them," Miss Breece assures us of the villagers to whom she was bringing the benefits of their still recently acquired Americanness.
She could note that "a white man who married an uneducated native woman did not bring his wife up to his standards but instead almost invariably descended into native ways himself." But in her role as a teacher, she treated everyone alike: the Russians left over from the Czarist possession of Alaska, the Eskimos, the Aleuts, the Athabaskans, the Scots, the Swedes. She believed in education as the route to a better life, and in this she was not wrong. The dignity, intelligence and skills of the indigenous people and the innumerable acts of kindness shown to her by "natives" do not escape her attention.
Ms. Jacobs has done us all a service by bringing out this memoir in unexpurgated form. It is the story of a remarkable woman who lived a heroic life.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jane Jacobs (Toronto Star Syndicate/Random House)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
At God's Elbow

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the spring of 1982 I was working in the Business Day section of The New York Times and was befriended by a young editor there named Nathaniel Nash. Nathaniel was a gentle soul and a deeply religious Christian. He liked to come by and talk to me about Israel. In April 1982 The Times assigned me to cover the Lebanese civil war, and at my goodbye party Nathaniel whispered to me: "I'm going to pray for your safety." I always considered his prayers my good luck charm, and when I walked out of Beirut in one piece a few years later, one of the first things I did was thank Nathaniel for keeping watch over me. He liked that a lot.
I only wish I could have returned the protection. Nathaniel Nash, age 44, was the one reporter on Commerce Secretary Ron Brown's airplane when it crashed into a Croatian hillside last week. Newspapers are rightly shy about highlighting their own losses in such a tragedy. In news stories, Nathaniel was listed with 34 others in the paragraph beginning, "Also killed in the crash of Secretary Brown's plane . . ." But Nathaniel deserves to be remembered for more than that, for his life and his death say so much about what the craft of journalism is, or should be, about. 
 Nathaniel was The Times's Frankfurt bureau chief, specializing in economic news. He previously served in Latin America as the Times bureau chief in Buenos Aires. Nathaniel was a species that's being lost in this era of 500 cable channels -- the professional reporter and proud of it.
With today's cacophony of magazine shows, Oprah-style interview sessions and talking-head news commentaries, many people have lost sight of what real journalists do. Journalists do not appear on the McLaughlin show and scream at each other. Journalists don't interview mothers and daughters on daytime confession hours. Journalists don't have their own shock-jock radio shows. Unfortunately, though, these are the people many Americans see most often in quasi-journalist roles and these are the people they think of as journalists today. Journalists are reporters like Nathaniel Nash, who go off to uncomfortable and often dangerous places like Croatia and get on a military plane to chase after a visiting dignitary without giving it a second thought -- all to get a few fresh quotes, maybe a scoop, or even just a paragraph of color that no one else has, for a story about the reconstruction of Bosnia.
Nathaniel also was a living reminder that to be successful, journalists don't have to be cynics. The book on Nathaniel as a reporter was that he was too nice. His colleagues always doubted that anyone that nice could ever succeed in journalism, but somehow he triumphed over this handicap and went from one successful assignment to another. It was because Nathaniel intuitively understood that there was a difference between skepticism and cynicism. This is a lesson a lot of us have forgotten. Skepticism is about asking questions, being dubious, being wary, not being gullible. Cynicism is about already having the answers -- or thinking you do -- about a person or an event. The skeptic says, "I don't think that's true; I'm going to check it out." The cynic says: "I know that's not true. It couldn't be. I'm going to slam him." There is a fine line between the two, but it's a line Nathaniel always respected.
Finally, Nathaniel could always remind his fellow journalists how lucky they were to have the front-row seat to history that comes with being a foreign correspondent. Whether he was covering Europe or Latin America -- which he loved -- Nathaniel always had this endearing "I-can't-believe-they're-actually-paying-me-to-do-this" quality about him. He always conveyed a sense that being a foreign correspondent was a privilege to be cherished.
Nathaniel left us too soon. Journalism needs people like him so badly. But our loss is nothing compared with that of his wife, Elizabeth, their twin 5-year-old daughters and 8-year-old son. While nothing can compensate for the loss of a father, one only hopes that those children will one day know that their daddy represented the very best qualities of his profession.
When I first heard the news about Nathaniel I whispered a prayer for him, but it quickly struck me that that wasn't necessary. For he was such a good soul I know that right now he is sitting at God's elbow -- and probably taking notes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Buzzless Buzzword

BYLINE: By Bill McKibben; Bill McKibben, an environmental writer, is author of "Hope, Human and Wild."

DATELINE: JOHNSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
The fight against bad English is not frivolous," George Orwell wrote in 1946 -- a conviction that has grown ever truer in the intervening half century. Today, a muddled thought or phrase can send the whole globe marching down a cul de sac. This is why Earth Day, April 22, should be spent with dictionaries and thesauruses.
For nearly a decade, environmentalists have tried to introduce a catchword into the planetary vocabulary. "Sustainability" made its debut in the mid-1980's in United Nations documents, and today it is standard jargon in certain circles. Think tanks and policy analysts use it constantly; just last month, President Clinton's Council on Sustainable Development issued its report, "Sustainable America." 
 But the phrase has never made the leap to lingo -- and never will. It's time to figure out why, and then figure out something else.
"Sustainability" was born partly in an effort to obfuscate, to paper over the tension between the fact that societies are overexploiting the planet's physical resources and the fact that everyone seems reluctant to stop this rapaciousness. Hence, phrases like "sustainable development" and "sustainable growth" are used when the real intent is to put off the day of reckoning for a few more decades.
The President's Council, whose report is powerful in many ways, could not even bring itself to call for less use of energy, only for less use of energy "per unit of industrial output" (say, one less barrel of oil in making each widget while producing ever more widgets).
It's no wonder we want to avoid choosing between economic growth -- between an expanding, interdependent world economy -- and a healthy environment. Helping economies in poor countries grow might reduce some of the environmental damage that comes of desperation; it allows rich countries to alleviate certain kinds of pollution with advanced technology.
But the largest environmental problems -- global warming, destruction of habitat -- are essentially caused by economic and population growth, not by faulty technology.
To deal with such troubles in the next few decades, the world will need not only bicycles and energy-efficient mass transport, it will need a new way of thinking. Our societies will have to voluntarily stabilize, if not reduce, the size of their economies and populations.
 "Sustainability," which Orwell would have disdained, is no help in this situation. In competition with "growth," "sustainability" is doomed, because it does not refer to anything familiar. We understand "growth," because everything that lives grows.
But we do something else, too, if we are lucky. We mature. We stop growing physically, and we start concentrating on moral, spiritual and cultural development. And so "maturity" just might be the right new buzzword. People can imagine mature societies, civilizations, perhaps even economies, even though we may not know yet how to achieve them.
The transition to a world of tighter limits -- by choice now, or necessity later -- would be wrenching. But at least the term fits our frame of reference.
Maturing means restraining oneself -- precisely what environmentalists contend our species must do. Maturity means, at bottom, recognizing that you are not the center of the world but part of something larger. And that is just the point that the ailing planet wants everyone to grasp.

HEADLINE: If Refrigerators Could Speak, The Stories They'd Tell

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
CAROLYN VERWEYST used to think she knew everything about people and their refrigerators: what they crammed into crispers and shoved onto shelves, how long they foraged for midnight snacks, why they preferred doors that opened to the right instead of to the left.
Then she went to the videotapes, and found out there was a lot she didn't know. 
 Yes, the videotapes: hours and hours of people opening their refrigerators, staring at the shelves, taking food out, putting food in. "We mounted video cameras in peoples' houses," said Ms. Verweyst (pronounced VUR-wist), a marketing executive with the Whirlpool Corporation in Benton Harbor, Mich. "Every time they opened their refrigerator, they turned on a video camera."
Whirlpool's videotapes are not exactly material for "Candid Camera." The 75 refrigerator owners in Atlanta, Chicago and Los Angeles knew they were being watched.
Nor were Mrs. Verweyst's tapes anything like "9 1/2 Weeks," the sexually explicit 1986 film that starred Mickey Rourke and Kim Basinger. Ms. Verweyst likes the scene where Mr. Rourke spreads food over Ms. Basinger's body as she lies in front of -- what else? -- a refrigerator.
"That didn't happen in any of our videos," Ms. Verweyst said. "We got excited when we saw people stuffing 12 loaves of bread in the refrigerator."
Supermodels like Elle Macpherson have been known to keep film and champagne in their refrigerators, while some college professors use them as safe-deposit boxes, stowing chapter after chapter of their latest work in the one place in the house they consider fireproof. But the videotapes yielded new answers to the basic question: what do refrigerators contain these days?
The surprise answer is: more beverages and a lot less food.
In fact, based on the videotapes, Ms. Verweyst has concluded that refrigerators in the 1990's are more like beverage coolers. Consumers on the videotapes stored much less meat and fewer raw ingredients than Whirlpool executives had expected 75 typical consumers would. (Whirlpool, which promised the 75 consumers confidentiality, said it did not tabulate the precise breakdown of how much space they gave over to meat, food and beverages.)
Of course, time-pressed Americans have been cooking less and bringing home more packaged and processed foods for years now. But the videotapes also showed Whirlpool that it was time to start building next-generation refrigerators around the packaging people bring home. That means bigger storage spaces.
It may also mean more refrigerators in the kitchen -- but not necessarily more of the standard white boxes.
Sub-Zero of Madison, Wis., introduced a line of small freestanding refrigerators last year. Paul Leuthe, the company's manager of marketing services, said the idea was to put specially designed, limited-capacity appliances in "decentralized, functional places." "If you have a large concentration of vegetables, you can keep the vegetables near a sink," he said. "If you have a lot of pre-packaged foods, you can put one next to a microwave."
Or even, say, in a mud room. "If you have kids coming in and going out, you can put a small base refrigerator by the back door," Mr. Leuthe said. "They're in and back out again."
He concedes that modular refrigerators have been a slow sell. They have been marketed to consumers who are remodeling their kitchens and architects who are planning brand new ones.
Ten years ago, Ms. Verweyst thought that baby boomers would downsize -- trade in their refrigerators for ones with fewer cubic feet -- as they became empty nesters. "The reality finally hit us," she said. "Even if you're an empty nester, you want a refrigerator that's as big or bigger than the one you had when you were raising kids. People say, 'I can't believe we raised four kids and only had a 16-cubic-foot refrigerator,' and go out and buy a 25-footer." Apparently, people think bigger is better.
In the 1980's, the average new refrigerator was an 18-cubic-foot model. Now, it is closer to 22 cubic feet, and models that are 30 cubic feet are not unusual.
Mr. Leuthe said the typical Sub-Zero was a 20-cubic-foot unit, but the company's new modular refrigerators may scatter even more storage space around the kitchen: an under-the-counter unit can hold five cubic feet, and some kitchens are designed to have two or three of them in addition to a larger unit.
Refrigerator manufacturers are also confronting another design issue: with baby boomers moving into an older age bracket, hard-to-reach shelves may have to be moved into more convenient locations.
"You want to be considerate of things that are awkward for older people, like bending and stooping," said Martha Reek, Whirlpool's senior home economist. She has been looking into making shelves more easily adjustable, "so you don't have to bend over if your knees hurt," she added.
Another discomfort-reducing possibility: adding tiny wheels to help crisper drawers slide out without a lot of effort.
Perhaps only in America would such a commonplace appliance be studied in such detail -- there are a total of 99.8 million refrigerators in the United States, the Government says. There are 75 million frost-free models and 24.8million that have to be defrosted manually. Refrigerators are the nation's second-most-common consumer product, after televisions. There are 119 million televisions.
The refrigerator may be the 20th-century's quintessential invention, revolutionizing eating habits and making possible long-distance shipments of foods. The appliance finally did what everyone from Alexander the Great (whose fondness for ice cream is well documented) to Thomas Jefferson (who designed an ice house for Monticello) to Thomas Moore, a 19th-century farmer from Brookeville, Md., had dreamed of.
Moore, after all, invented the first refrigerator, and also the word to describe it. It was no frost-free model, but it had one advantage that latter-day refrigerators do not: it was portable. Moore's device was essentially a wooden box. Inside, he placed a jug loaded with cream, milk or butter that was nestled in ice. Moore headed off to his local market, where customers were so delighted by the freshness of his dairy products that he commanded twice the price of his competitors.
Hungry, thirsty consumers had to wait until fairly late in the Industrial Revolution before manufacturers began turning out mechanical ice boxes. And eventually, marketing executives like Ms. Verweyst began peering inside.
Above all, what the videotapes make clear is that consumers do not see the insides of their refrigerators the way the engineers who designed them do.
Ms. Reek recalled a recent consumer test session in which she gave people a container with removable half-moon indentations to put eggs in but didn't tell them its intended purpose. One woman wanted to take the egg-holders out and use the box for ice cubes.
"It's fine with me if that's what she did with it," Ms. Reek said, "but the person who designed it never considered it for ice cubes, which means from a science point of view we need to test it in freezing conditions."
 
Questionable Contents
 
IF you are what's in your refrigerator, what's in there, anyway?
"Unidentified things wrapped in foil," said G. David Newman of Morris Plains, N.J., who discovered and discarded them when he bought a new refrigerator.
"Very, very primeval oozes of cilantro and watercress," said Nina Shippen, a health-care marketing executive from Newton, Mass. "And chicken wings. They have little white spots on them, but they're only six or seven weeks old."
At least those items were edible originally. In a Whirlpool Corporation survey of 500 consumers last year, answers included a shoe, a cordless telephone, a copy of TV Guide and a remote control.
As for food, 80 percent of the respondents said they had milk in their refrigerators, 37 percent said eggs, 36 percent said juice and soda, 26 percent said butter and 11 percent said cheese. Leftovers were also on the list: 22 percent said they had pasta, 17 percent pizza, 10 percent chicken and 8 percent meatloaf.
Whirlpool conducted the survey by telephone, and said the margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Chefs do not necessarily keep food in their refrigerators. Christopher Gross, the chef and owner of Christopher's in Phoenix, said he stored two essentials there: caviar and batteries. Jean Joho, the chef at Everest in Chicago, keeps his cigars next to the mustard.
Whirlpool is so committed to well-scrubbed shelves that it promotes "Clean Out Your Refrigerator Day" to induce consumers to throw away outdated items.
"Most of the time, the stories that are told are very logical," said Martha Reek, the senior home economist at Whirlpool.
Which is how she explains another item reported in the survey, car keys in the freezer. "You come home from the grocery and throw things in the freezer so they won't thaw," she said, "and you throw your keys in there."
Whirlpool's survey also found a frozen rat, worms for fish bait and a toaster.
"One lady told me her favorite pet bird had died," Ms. Reek said. "Her spouse was out of town. She froze it, and pulled it out later. I think they were going to take it outside and bury it in a special place."
Clearly a one-time event.
How often do most people clean their refrigerators? The answers in Whirlpool's survey ranged from once a month (42 percent) to once a week (30 percent) to once a year (5 percent).
Ms. Shippen said her refrigerator had been cleaned twice in the two years she has had it: once by a friend who was appalled by what was inside and once -- last Friday, in fact -- by Ms. Shippen herself. JAMES BARRON

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Helped by Economy, Rises Against Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a 26-month high against the Japanese yen yesterday as traders displayed renewed optimism about the American economy and concern over tensions on the Korean peninsula.
The dollar also rallied to its highest point against the German mark in more than six months and its highest New York finish in more than a year on signs that German interest rates may come down soon. It also rose broadly against other major currencies. 
 The big story for the dollar was a renewed sense of American economic strength. On Friday, the Government reported that 140,000 jobs were created in March, following a gain of more than 500,000 jobs the month before, suggesting that the economy is more buoyant than many had believed.
That data caused a selloff in the Treasury bond market Friday and Monday, but improvement yesterday heartened currency investors who carefully follow bonds as an indication of interest-rate direction.
"Good news on the U.S. economy is in fact good news," said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group.
In late New York trading, the dollar was worth 108.30 yen, up from 107.75 late Monday and its highest late New York rate since February 1994.
The dollar was also quoted at 1.4982 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.4817 on Monday. This was the dollar's best finish against the mark since February 1995, although it was quoted higher in intraday trading in mid-September.
Contributing to the dollar's gains against the mark were comments by the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, that suggested the German central bank was expecting interest rates in European markets to come down.
The dollar also rose against the British pound, which fell to $1.5205 from $1.5290.
The dollar had been making little headway for some time and analysts called the strong gains overdue. Indications of economic strength are seen as positive for a currency as surging profits and prosperous consumers tend to attract investment.
A second factor helping the dollar was a state of heightened tensions between North Korea and South Korea. In times of uncertainty, investors tend to buy dollars, which have been afforded a safe-haven status because of the currency's stability. The Korean troubles particularly helped the dollar against the yen.
"The Asian market is always much more sensitive to instability on their side of the world," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at Bank Leumi Trust Company.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
In Virginia, Good Sign For Offices

BYLINE: By JAMES R. HARDCASTLE 

DATELINE: HERNDON, Va.

 BODY:
Two office projects are under construction in Fairfax County, Va., the leading suburban office market in the Washington area, providing the first evidence of a return to speculative office development in the county since the real estate recession of 1989.
At one project, along the Dulles Toll Road two miles east of Dulles International Airport, the steel is already in place for a four-story building of 103,000 square feet in which Airbus Industrie of North America has signed a lease for just under half the space. The rest is being built with no tenant commitments and is being marketed for occupancy this fall. The project is called Presidents Plaza II. 
 Speculative space is also part of another project, in Tysons Corner, the largest commercial center in Fairfax County. KPMG Peat Marwick will be the major tenant. The international accounting and consulting firm has entered into an agreement with Westmark Realty Advisers of Los Angeles, a development arm of the CB Commercial Real Estate Group, to build a 278,000-square-foot structure called the 1616 International Drive Building. KPMG Peat Marwick will occupy 178,000 square feet and the rest will be leased out. Occupancy will start in the spring of 1998.
Despite the speculative space, real estate brokers categorize both these buildings as ones essentially built to specifications by large tenants willing to commit to leases of 10 to 15 years for big portions of the buildings.
Construction is under way on at least three other large office buildings in the county. But all of those buildings were designed to be occupied by a single tenant who agreed to lease all the space within them.
Fairfax County wraps around the the southern boundary of Washington and three close-in northern Virginia regions. Last year, organizations moving to or expanding in the county accounted for 57 percent of the net office space absorbed in the Washington metropolitan area, or 2.45 million square feet out of 4.24 million square feet, according to the Washington office of Faison Associates, a commercial real estate service company based in Charlotte, N.C. Net absorption is the difference between the amount of space leased and the amount given up through move-outs or shrinkage.
Presidents Plaza II is being developed on a seven-acre site by Schroder Real Estate Associates of New York as an investment for a TRW Inc. pension fund. It will be the twin of an existing occupied building. Schroder bought the 100,000-square-foot Presidents Plaza I, with land for the twin building, from a General Electric Investment Corporation fund last year for $13 million. The corporation is an adviser to General Electric pension funds. Airbus Industrie, a consortium of European aircraft manufacturers, is moving from a nearby building in Herndon.
Brokers say the market for office space is drum tight. The office vacancy rate in northern Virginia has declined from a high of 22 percent at the end of 1990 to less than 6 percent, CB Commercial said in a spring regional market review. "As a result, office building owners are looking forward to 1996 with more enthusiasm than they have had in 15 years," the report said.
Stephen H. Spencer, a CB Commercial broker who negotiated the 15-year KPMG Peat Marwick deal, said that class A, or prime, space in the Tysons Corner area was currently leasing for $20 to $23 a square foot a year, with relatively minimal concessions for preparation of existing space, and to $20 to $22 a foot in Reston, the other major office center in the county.
"The landlords are in a situation where they control the space and demand is growing," Mr. Spencer said. As a result, he predicted, "We'll see rents in class A buildings in the high $20's in the next two years."
Helping demand is strong growth in the information, telecommunications and military-related industries that last year helped generate a net increase of 23,000 jobs in northern Virginia.

HEADLINE: Preventing Portable Nukes

BYLINE: By Jessica Stern; Jessica Stern, who is writing a book on terrorism, is a fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution.

DATELINE: ALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
What if the bomb that killed 168 people and blasted the Federal building in Oklahoma City a year ago this month had been nuclear?
It's not a far-fetched scenario. Nuclear materials -- once extremely difficult to find outside of controlled, government facilities -- are increasingly making their way to the international black market. 
 Theoretically, it is possible to make a well-designed nuclear bomb from a lump of plutonium the size of a soda can. A crude nuclear bomb -- which requires less expertise but more fissile material -- would be deliverable by van.
Even a crude one-kiloton atomic explosion -- tiny by nuclear standards -- would be hundreds of times more powerful than the Oklahoma blast. (In America, it might also permanently alter the balance between security and civil liberties: There would be much more support for widespread domestic F.B.I. and C.I.A. surveillance and for chips that monitor electronic conversations.)
Next week in Moscow, President Clinton and the heads of the other Group of Seven industrial nations will meet with President Boris Yeltsin at a nuclear summit meeting to discuss such worries.
The chaotic breakup of the Soviet Union has increased the risk of nuclear terrorism. Cash-strapped Russian Army troops are selling their weapons abroad, often through Russian mafia middlemen. Hardware from missiles designed to carry nuclear warheads has made its way from the former Soviet Union to Iraq. And in November, Chechen terrorists placed a container of radioactive material in a Moscow park. (Officials removed it after the perpetrators told reporters where it was.)
Despite these problems, the Russian Government has found 80 percent of its nuclear facilities to have no "portal monitors" -- exit doors with built-in radiation detectors -- to prevent insider theft.
Russian officials have repeatedly denied that any nuclear smuggling has involved weapons-grade material. But terrorists and would-be nuclear nations aren't that picky. They would probably be satisfied with lower-grade uranium or the kind of plutonium found in spent nuclear reactor fuel rods.
Seven confirmed cases of theft from the former Soviet Union involve such "weapons-usable" materials -- ingredients that could make a nuclear device capable of killing hundreds of thousands.
Since 1991 -- under legislation proposed by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana -- Congress has appropriated a total of $1.5 billion to help former Soviet states protect and dismantle nuclear warheads and create safe storage for weapons-grade nuclear materials.
But the program applies only to Russia, Belarus, Ukraine and Kazakhstan -- even though other former Soviet republics also possess nuclear materials and expertise.
And the $1.5 billion total -- an appropriation that barely squeaked through Congress -- isn't much. (Compare it to the $346 billion America spends annually on other forms of national defense.)
To protect ourselves, we should urge President Clinton and Congress to take the following action:
* Expand Nunn-Lugar to embrace all former Soviet states.
* Regularize meetings with the Group of Seven nations and Russia on nuclear smuggling.
 * Intensify intelligence efforts in all former Soviet countries, especially in Central Asia and the Caucasus, which are likely export routes for illicit nuclear components.
 * Expand training in the former Soviet Union in law enforcement, customs and forensics.
These steps carry a low cost. And anything less is irresponsible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
